item.title: Interpersonal Oppression
item.description: The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group. Interpersonal racism is what white people do to people of color up close--the racist jokes, the stereotypes, the beatings and harassment, the threats, etc. Similarly, interpersonal sexism is what men do to women - the sexual abuse and harassment, the violence directed at women, the belittling or ignoring of women's thinking, the sexist jokes, etc. Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Interpersonal Oppression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Intersex
item.description: Describes variation in sex characteristics, such as chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones or genitals. "Intersex," like "Female," and "Male," is a socially constructed category that humans have created to label bodies that they view as different from those they would classify as distinctly 'female' or 'male.'
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Intersex.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Privilege
item.description: Likewise, people who benefit the most from these systems internalize privilege. Privileged people involuntarily accept stereotypes and false assumptions about oppressed groups made by dominant culture. Internalized privilege includes acceptance of a belief in the inherent inferiority of the oppressed group as well as the inherent superiority or normalcy of one‚Äôs own privileged group. Internalized privilege creates an unearned sense of entitlement in members of the privileged group, and can be expressed as a denial of the existence of oppression and as paternalism.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Internalized Privilege.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Oppression
item.description: The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad. Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value. On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Internalized Oppression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Homonegativity
item.description: The degree to which to which one rejects their sexual identity.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Internalized Homonegativity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Institutional Oppression
item.description: The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society - the laws, the legal system and police practice, the education system and schools, hiring policies, public policies, housing development, media images, political power, etc. When a woman makes two thirds of what a man makes in the same job, it is institutionalized sexism. When one out of every four African-American young men is currently in jail, on parole, or on probation, it is institutionalized racism. When psychiatric institutions and associations 'diagnose' transgender people as having a mental disorder, it is institutionalized gender oppression and transphobia. Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional. For example, if a policy unintentionally reinforces and creates new inequalities between privileged and non-privileged groups.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Institutional Oppression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internal Locus of Control
item.description: Believe that the outcomes of their actions are results of their own abilities.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Internal Locus of Control.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ideological Oppression
item.description: Any oppressive system has at its core the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. This idea gets elaborated in many ways - more intelligent, harder working, stronger, more capable, more noble, more deserving, more advanced, chosen, normal, superior, and so on. The dominant group holds this idea about itself. And, of course, the opposite qualities are attributed to the other group - stupid, lazy, weak, incompetent, worthless, less deserving, backward, abnormal, inferior, and so on.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Ideological Oppression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Uncertainty
item.description: How uncertain one is concerning their sexual identity.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Identity Uncertainty.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Superiority
item.description: How favorable one views sexual minorities compared to heterosexual people
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Identity Superiority.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Politics
item.description: A tendency for people of a particular religion, race, social background, etc., to form exclusive political alliances, moving away from traditional broad-based party politics. Rather than organizing solely around belief systems, programmatic manifestos, or party affiliation, identity political formations typically aim to secure the political freedom of a specific constituency marginalized within its larger context. Members of that constituency assert or reclaim ways of understanding their distinctiveness that challenge dominant oppressive characterizations, with the goal of greater self-determination. Identity politics shifts out moral and political attention from individual wrongful acts against individuals - perhaps motivated by prejudiced attitudes or bigotry - to structural and systematic injustice against social groups. This process of recognizing as social and systematic that was formerly perceived as isolated and individual has also characterized the identity politics of marginalized groups (i.e., racial ethnic minorities and LGBTQ persons) For all these groups, identity-based politics has been a source of strength, community, and intellectual development.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Identity Politics.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Centrality
item.description: How central one's sexual identity is to one's overall identity
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Identity Centrality.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Identity Affirmation
item.description: The association of positive thoughts with one's sexual identity
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Identity Affirmation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Historical Trauma
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Historical Trauma.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: High-Context (HC) Communication
item.description: Anchored in the physical context (situation) or internalized in the person. HC communication relies heavily on non-verbals, and the group identification/understanding shared by those communicating.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/High-Context (HC) Communication.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Hegemony
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Hegemony.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender-Expansive
item.description: Conveys a wider, more flexible range of gender identity and/or expression than typically associated with the binary gender system.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender-Expansive.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Non-Conforming
item.description: A broad term referring to people who do not behave in a way that conforms to the traditional expectations of their gender, or whose gender expression does not fit neatly into a category.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender Non-Conforming.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Identity
item.description: One's innermost concept of self as male, female, a blend of both or neither - how individuals perceive themselves and what they call themselves. One's gender identity can be the same or different from their sex assigned at birth.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender Identity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Fluid
item.description: A person who does not identify with a single fixed gender; of or relating to a person having or experiencing a fluid or unfixed gender identity.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender Fluid.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender Expression
item.description: External appearance of one's gender identity, usually expressed through behavior, clothing, haircut or voice, and which may or may not conform to socially defined behaviors and characteristics typically associated with being either masculine or feminine.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender Expression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Gender
item.description: The result of socially constructed ideas about the behavior, actions, and roles a. particular sex performs. Term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Gender.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: External Locus of Control
item.description: Attribute success or failure to luck or chance, a higher power, or the influence of another person.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/External Locus of Control.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Experiential Intersectionality
item.description: The experience of being a member of more than one social group that cannot be decomposed into the experience of being a member of each. Example: The experience of being a Black woman is not just the experience of being Black and the experience of being a woman. The experience of being a Black woman is a proper compound of the two.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Experiential Intersectionality.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ethnocentric Monoculturalism
item.description:
Refers to a belief in the superiority of one's group's cultural heritage over another, and the implications of those standards upon the less powerful group. Cultural Encapsulation: Cultural Encapsulation Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
Cultural Racism: Cultural Racism Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations. Belief in the Superiority of the Dominant Group Belief in the Inferiority of Others Power to Impose Standards Manifestation in Institutions The Invisible Veil
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Ethnocentric Monoculturalism.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equity
item.description: Giving everyone what they need to be successful (may appear unfair)
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Equity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Equality
item.description: Treating everyone the same (aims to promote fairness)
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Equality.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Difficult Process
item.description: How difficult one's sexual identity development was.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Difficult Process.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Responsiveness
item.description: An approach that takes into consideration and responds to the cultural values, lifestyles, strengths and assets of the client as they interact with the wider society.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Responsiveness.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Racism
item.description: Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Racism.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Paradigm
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Paradigm.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Oppression
item.description: When members of the dominant culture impose their standards upon culturally diverse populations without regard for differences.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Oppression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Humility
item.description: The ability to maintain an interpersonal stance that is other-oriented (or open to other) in relation to aspects of cultural identity that are most important for the client. Culturally humble therapists rarely assume competence. Requires the therapist to engage in self-reflection and self-critique. A complementary component to cultural competence associated with an open attitudinal stance or a multiculturally open orientation to work with diverse clients.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Humility.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Formulation Interview
item.description: Provides a framework to assist clinicians in assessing the cultural identity of the affected individual, perceptions of the distress (including how the cultural group of the client would view the problem), psychosocial stressors and 'cultural features of vulnerability and resilience,' and cultural aspects of both the client and the clinician that might impact treatment. Viewing culture therapeutically includes a perceptual expansion of cultural groups to include age, gender, sexual orientation, religion, language, occupation, military service, social networks, substance use, migration status, geographical region, relationship status (i.e., married or divorced), and not simply race and ethnicity.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Formulation Interview.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cultural Encapsulation
item.description: Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cultural Encapsulation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Critical Race Theory
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Critical Race Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Concealment Motivation
item.description: Being concerned with protecting one's sexual identity
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Concealment Motivation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cognitive Biases Codex
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Cognitive Biases Codex.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Biological Sex
item.description: The physical sex characteristics you are born with and develop including genitalia, chromosomes, hormones, etc. Generally assigned at birth and often categorized as male, female, or Intersex.
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Biological Sex.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Accepting Concerns
item.description: Worry relating to potential rejection of one's sexual identity
item.guid: Glossary/Diversity/Accepting Concerns.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Temperament
item.description:
An individual's early innate expression of biological, behavioral, and emotional responses to the environment. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
Most temperaments are inherited, and family members are also likely to have similar temperaments. Parents are likely to model and reinforce their child's tendency toward BI or emotionality. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
item.guid: Glossary/Diagnosis/Key Terms and Concepts/Temperament.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.description: the percentage of individuals who meet criteria for a disorder during a specific period of time. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 128)

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Lifetime Prevalence
item.description: The percentage of individuals who meet criteria for a disorder at any point during their lifetimes. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 128)
item.guid: Glossary/Diagnosis/Key Terms and Concepts/Lifetime Prevalence.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Emotionality
item.description: The tendency to become emotionally aroused. (@russoDSM5FamilySystems2024, pg. 129)
item.guid: Glossary/Diagnosis/Key Terms and Concepts/Emotionality.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)
item.description: The handbook used by health care professionals in the US and much of the world as the authoritative guide to the diagnosis of mental disorders DSM contains descriptions, symptoms, and other criteria for diagnosing mental disorders. It also provides a common language for researchers to study the criteria for potential future revisions and to aid in the development of medications and other interventions. Used universally with Guidelines for disorders Not a 'perfect mirror of nature' Imperfect because there is more to understand through research. Right now, it is a culmination of mental disorders, a dictionary used to communicate with administrators, clients, and clinicians. Provide a shared language among professionals and clients. Most up to date information to provide help and assistance Clinical judgement, DSM is a 'part' of diagnosis. It must be used with clinical judgement. (What does 'clinical judgement' mean?) We should not be using the DSM too rigidly, but providing the help our clients need. Problem: People who should take it least seriously is scientists. Cannot make the psychiatric progress clients need. 1840: Category 'insanity' first attempt to quantify and name psychiatric diagnoses 1844: APA published a predecessor of the DSM: A classification of institutionalized mental patients Early 1900's First description of schizophrenia by Emil Kraeplin 1917: Statistical Manual for the Use of Institutions for the insane, including 22 diagnoses. 1952: First DSM, 130 pages long, 106 disorders 1994: DSM-IV, 886 pages long, 297 disorders 2000: DSM-IV-TR, 943 pages long, 365 disorders 2013: DSM-5, 991 pages long, 157 disorders 2022: DSM-5-TR, 1050 pages long Standardizes billing and coding Standardizes diagnoses and treatment Guides research Guides treatment Oversimplifies human behavior Increases risk of misdiagnosis or over-diagnosis Provides labels, which can be stigmatizing Growing scientific evidence favors dimensional diagnosis of mental disorders Takes into account individual subjective report of symptom experience and clinician interpretation Integrates both objective and subjective data to enhance the accuracy Categorical: A categorical approach to assessment relied on diagnostic criteria to determine the presence or absence of disruptive or other abnormal behaviors, whereas a dimensional approach places such behaviors on a continuum of frequency and/or severity. Presence or absence Yes or no Dimensional: Frequency: None of the time to all of the time Hourly, daily, weekly, monthly Intensity/Severity: Absent 0, mild 1, moderate 2, severe 3 Duration: How long does it last? First (Categorical): Yes / no Second (Frequency): How often? Third (Intensity/Severity): Rating (Mild, moderate, severe) Fourth (Duration): How long does it last? Growing scientific evidence favors dimensional diagnosis of mental disorders. Takes into account individual subjective report of symptom experience and clinician interpretation. Integrates both objective and subjective data to enhance the accuracy of the diagnostic process. Integrates measures administered at initial interview and over time to track symptom status and response to treatment. Disorder-specific and correspond closely to the diagnostic criteria. Some are self-completed by the individual, couple, or family. Interpreted by the clinician Shared back with the individual, couple, or family Others require a clinician to complete. A generic assessment instrument for health and disability. Used across all diseases, including mental, neurological, and addictive disorders. Short, simple and easy to administer (5 to 20 minutes) Applicable in both clinical and general population settings. A tool to produce standardized disability levels and profiles. Applicable across cultures, in all adult populations. Directly linked at the level of concepts to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) The reason for the assessment, including the member's: Perception of the condition Description of symptoms (including reason for referral) History of mental health treatment (including review of member's records) Important developmental incidents Maltreatment, trauma or abuse issues History of alcohol and drug usage and treatment Health history and family health history, including physical, chemical and mental health history Cultural influences and their impact on the member An assessment of the member's needs based on: Baseline measurements Symptoms Behavior Skills Abilities Resources Vulnerabilities Safety Assessment methods and use of standardized assessment tools Clinical summary, including recommendations and prioritization of needed mental health or other services Involvement of the member and member's family in the assessment and his or her preferences or referrals to services. Sufficient data to support findings on all axes of the current Diagnostic and Statistic Manual (DSM), and any differential diagnosis. We don't truly have systemic diagnoses in the US context The medical model warrants an INDIVIDUAL (identified patient/client) Diagnoses are listed by INDIVIDUAL Diagnostic criteria for relational problems are needed. M The relationship comes first Making a diagnosis is a team effort Open-ended and check-list questions Use screeners/questions to hone in on the diagnosis Pay attention to clinical significance Risk/benefit analysis of diagnosis Understand comorbidity Be cautious about 'other' categories Document your thinking Remember the stakes are high
item.guid: Glossary/Diagnosis/Key Terms and Concepts/Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mixed-Agenda Couples
item.description: These are couples in which one spouse is seriously considering divorce and is reluctant to try couples therapy (but does show up for the first session) while the other spouse wants to preserve the marriage and is eager to start couples therapy. We refer to the first spouse as leaning-out and the second as leaning in. Discernment Counseling creates a holding environment for the couple to develop clarity and confidence in deciding on the next step for their relationship, whether it is divorce or a shared commitment to couples therapy to repair the relationship.
item.guid: Glossary/Couples/Key Terms and Concepts/Mixed-Agenda Couples.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: EPOR
item.guid: Glossary/Couples/Key Terms and Concepts/EPOR.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Discernment Counseling
item.description: Discernment counseling is a short-term process (one to five sessions) with the goal of greater clarity and confidence in the decision about a direction for the marriage, based on a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage and each partner's contribution to the problems. It is not intended for cases in which one partner has made a final decision to divorce and simply wants a venue to convince their spouse to accept the decision. The immediate decision is whether to carve out a 6-month period of all-out effort in couples therapy to restore the marriage to health, with divorce off the table during that time. At the end of 6 months, they can reopen the decision about divorce on the basis of what they have learned about the prospect of successfully rebuilding their marriage. Therapy aims for improvement in the relationship (e.g., increased intimacy, decreased toxic conflict), whereas discernment counseling aims for clarity and confidence about a next step. The goal of discernment counseling is not to solve marriage problems but to see whether they can be solved. There is no relationship homework for couples in discernment counseling, no teaching of skills during sessions, and no enactments of deeper ways to connect. If clients ask for ways to manage their problems during discernment counseling, we use a 'restraint from change' approach by reminding them that relationship change should not be expected during discernment counseling. Path 1: The marraige as it has been: the status quo, neither divorce nor working in therapy to improve the relationship. Path 2: Separation or divorce Path 3: A 6-month commitment to couples therapy (and sometimes other forms of help, such as substance abuse counseling, parenting classes, or individual therapy) with divorce off the table and with the possibility of putting divorce back on the table at the end of the 6 months. The idea behind path 3 is to move beyond amibalence about working on change and see whether it is possible to put the marriage into a place that would be good for both partners. Path 3, as we emphasize repeatedly, involves each partner developing a personal agenda for change on the basis of a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage and their role in the problems. An advantage of framing the immediate outcomes as paths is that it moves clients past the dichotomous choice between staying together or breaking-up. The therapist too can support the idea that something has to change - the marriage cannot continue as it has been. So sometimes the discernment process begins with agreements instead of disagreement - something has to change; the old ways of being married is no longer viable. Implicitly we are saying that divorce is not a failure in this process; it is simply one of the options to be explored in a serious way, even thought only one spouse is actively considering it. Sometimes it has taken years to build up the courage to put divorce on the table in a chronically distressed marriage. Path 3 avoids the 'in or out' conundrum by offering a provisional commitment to work hard on the relationship for a period, with divorce not an option for this period but something that can be revisited later if things do not change enough. Most of the work occurs in separate conversations with each spouse, with carefully orchestrated sharing of take-home messages from the individual conversations. The flow of the sessions goes this way: Time with the couple together Meeting with one spouse alone (the other goes to the waiting room) The other spouse returns and the first spouse summarizes key learning from the individual conversation Meeting with the second spouse alone The second spouse shares learning from that conversation A check out with both spouses during which time the therapist shares reflections on the process thus far. The majority of the time is with each partner alone. Times when both parties are together in the room are carfully orchestrated to minimize demoralizing exchanges and to maximize the focus on what each is learning about themselves in the process, rather than what each wants the other to change. The individual conversations have both similar and different areas of focus for the leaning-in and leaning-out partners. Similar themes are helping each better understand the dynamics of the relationship (their relational dance), their individual contributions to the problems, and how these relational and personal issues could be addressed in couples therapy (and sometimes with other helping resources). In terms of different themes, the therapist helps the leaning-out spouse figure out which path to take on the basis of an exploration of the sources of the person‚Äôs pain and discouragement about the prospect of change. The focus is on making a decision that has integrity for one‚Äôs self and others on the basis of a deeper understanding of self and the marriage and how the problems could be addressed in couples therapy if that is the chosen direction. The limit of five sessions, although not immutable, creates an expectation of intense work within a limited time frame. Going on much longer also makes it difficult for the couple not to expect relationship change and for the therapist to not lapse into doing couple interventions. We say one to five sessions and not five sessions because clients are asked each time about whether they want to do an additional session up to five. Some people are emotionally flat when their spouse is in the room and then liven up when our one-to-one time begins. A big part of this approach is helping clients see the difference between traditional marital therapy and discernment counseling and allowing them to indicate their willingness to engage in the process. We are interested in knowing exactly what the couple knows about discernment counseling. The clients must leave the conversation with an understanding that the goal for discernment counseling is to help them gain greater clarity and confidence in their decision making about the future of their marriage. We pay specific attention to whether they are currently living together and the status of any legal proceedings associated with divorce. After collecting some basic information over the phone, we typically ask something such as, "Can you tell me a bit about your current situation and how do you think it might be helpful to your situation?" It is important that leaning-out partners feel heard and that they understand how this process is different from anything they have tried as a couple before. It is important to assess whether leaning-out partners have made a decision to divorce or are open to the work of discernment. The following questions can be helpful in determining this: "Would you say that you've made your decision about the future of your marriage or are you still seeking some level of clarity in this process?" If they report that they have made a decision, you can ask about their level of confidence in the decision: "How confident are you that you're making the right decision?" For leaning-out partners who indicate they know they want a divorce and would like to use the session to 'break the news' to their partner, or for those who say they do not know how to tell their partner, you can inform them that this is not consistent with the goals of discernment counseling. You might respond in the following manner: "It may be that discernment counseling is not exactly a good fit for what you want to do. The goals of discernment counseling are to help people get a greater sense of clarity and confidence in their decision making about a direction for the future of their marriage based on a better understanding of what happened to the marriage to get it to the brink of divorce and each person's role in that. If you're hoping for a different outcome, like helping your spouse understand why you want a divorce, discernment counseling is not appropriate for your situation." Usually, the leaning-in partner makes it clear that they want to preserve the marriage, but if not, ask that question directly. If the leaning-in partner feels desperate to do anything to save their marriage, suggest that they purchase and begin reading Michele Weiner-Davis's (2002) book The Divorce Remedy. (They learn that they must first look at themselves and their own behavior before the marriage can get to a healthier place) "Her book is written specifically for people who have recently found out that their spouse is considering divorce. She gives some practical advice on how you can act toward your partner at this stage of the process. There are probably things you can be working on that will make the situation somewhat better without making your partner feel as though he or she is committing to working on the relationship. This approach may be your best option at the moment." We cannot emphasize enough the value of respecting client autonomy during this process. Never assume that both parties are equally interested in attending discernment counseling. Discernment counseling is a way of meeting both parties where they are and not privileging one person's agenda over the other. "It is really important that your spouse feel as though they have a choice in whether to come to discernment counseling. If he or she feels forced into it, it won't go well and will likely contribute to more estrangement from you on their part. " Never assume that because one spouse has told you about something that has been happening in the relationship, the other spouse knows about it. The intake conversation must be conducted one on one, without the person's partner or anyone else in the room. The person on the intake phone call has to be able to speak freely about their perspective on the problems they are having and the struggles they are experiencing making a decision regarding the future of their marriage. "Are you in a place that you can speak freely without interruptions?" If there is noise or other distractions, you may want to suggest a different time or place for the call. You also should ascertain whether the client has told their spouse about discernment counseling. "Have you discussed discernment counseling with your spouse? What do you think is his or her level of interest in participating? Does your spouse know that you and I are speaking today?" Avoid the temptation to speak to one partner right after the other for the sake of convenience. It is probably worth taking the time at the phone intake to ensure that no one is feeling forced into having this conversation. There is also benefit to suggesting that the first partner you speak with explain to their partner that they have spoken with a discernment counselor and that if the spouse is interested, they can e-mail or phone the counselor to set up an interview. In no case should you cold call the other partner, who may not be aware of the initial contact from the spouse. Consider using the following script as a guide to the initiator of the phone call: "It sounds like discernment counseling is appropriate for your situation according to what you've told me. The next step is for your partner and me to chat about their take on the situation and whether they are interested in discernment counseling. What might be a good idea for you is to tell your partner that we talked today, and point her to the website that describes discernment counseling. Further, you can tell them that if they are interested in doing this work, they can contact me directly and we can have a similar conversation to the one you and I just had. What is important here is that no one feels coerced to be part of this process. By putting the ball squarely in their court, they can demonstrate their willingness to do discernment counseling by initiating the call. " Respect the autonomy of each person to engage in this process at their own pace. The phone intake is to describe, in sufficient detail, the purpose, goals, and process of discernment counseling. "The goal of discernment is to help couples arrive at greater clarity and confidence in their decision making about the future of their marriage based on a deeper understanding of the problems in the marriage and each person's contributions to them. " "Discernment counseling is typically a brief counseling modality and could last anywhere between one and five sessions. There is no need to commit to all five sessions because each of you would only commit to attending one session at a time. " "The format of the sessions consists of meeting as a couple with the counselor as well as having some time dedicated to one-on-one work with the counselor. After each one-on-one portion of the session, each partner will summarize what he or she is 'taking with them' from the time with the counselor and share it with the partner who was waiting outside the room. The first session is 2 hours, and subsequent sessions are an hour and a half each. " "In discernment counseling, we discuss the paths that are before every couple on the brink of divorce. Path 1 we call the status quo path and represents your relationship continuing the way it current is. Path 2 represents the separation or divorce path. Path 3 is the possible reconciliation path, in which the couple agrees to take divorce off the table for a 6-month period of couples therapy, and each one commits to work on the relationship to see whether they can get the relationship to a healthier place. These three paths frame the discussions we have in discernment counseling." "Discernment counseling is different from typical marriage counseling. The goal is not to solve your problems but to help you decide whether to try to solve your problems or choose a different path. It's not about immediate change in your relationship but seeing what changes each of you might need to make in the future if you decide to work on yourselves and your marriage." Finally, you can end this portion of the phone intake by asking how this process sounds to them and whether they are still interested on the basis of what you have discussed: "Does this sound like a process that might hold some value for you in your current situation?" We are mostly concerned with is whether one of the partners is feeling coerced to participate and whether participating in discernment counseling will put one of the partners at risk of IPV. - "We want to make sure everyone who participates in discernment counseling does so voluntarily and that no one is put at risk. So I have a few questions that we ask everyone who contacts us for an appointment. - Are you feeling pressured by your spouse to participate in this project? Yes / No. - If yes, does the pressure seem coercive (for example, is it accompanied by threats with personal or legal ramifications)? Yes / No - Have you or your spouse ever had an order of protection from a court? Yes / No - If yes, who? - My last questions are about what happens when you and your partner get into arguments or fights. Again, our goal is to make sure everyone is safe. - Has your partner ever done something to you out of anger that has caused you physical pain, bruises, or bodily injury? Yes / No (If yes, get specifics) - Do you ever feel afraid of your spouse? Yes / No - If yes, are you in danger now? Yes / No - If yes to either, I can help you talk to someone at an agency that can help you. Would you like me to give you that information? In an emergency, urge the person to call 911. Ask if you can call back to check on the person. ‚ÄúLeaning In or Out Measure.png‚Äù could not be found. We strongly recommend a 2-hour block of time because of the amount of ground to be covered in the session. After both partners' perspectives are heard in response to a series of questions, the discernment counselor meets one-on-one with both members of the couple, and each briefly shares what he or she learned in the individual conversations. The session ends with the couple in the room together for a summary of the work that was done that day and any impressions the discernment counselor has to share. If both spouses agree, the second discernment counseling session is then scheduled. In this first meeting together, each person is asked to share their own and listen to the other‚Äôs views on how the relationship got to the point where divorce is a possibility, how they have tried to fix the problems they have identified, and how their children (if any) play a role in their decision making. They are also asked to provide a brief account of a time when things were going well in the relationship.
item.guid: Glossary/Couples/Key Terms and Concepts/Discernment Counseling.md

item.title: Trepanning
item.description: "A technique used in antiquity where holes were drilled into the skull to allow demonic spirits to escape. The popular view in ancient cultures is that madness was caused by evil spirits who had invaded the body." (Cummings, 2023, pg. 2) "There are sources that date back roughly 7,000 years ago that show evidence of trepanning." (Cummings, 2023, pg. 2)
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Trepanning.md

item.title: The Cycle of Change
item.description: Adapted from work by Prochaska and DiClemente (1983) - Precontemplation: - A logical starting point for the model, where there is no intention of changing behavior; the person may be unaware that a problem exists - Contemplation: - The person becomes aware that there is a problem, but has made no commitment to change. - Preparation: - The person is intent on taking action to correct the problem; usually required buy-in from the client (i.e., the client is convinced that the change is good) and increased self-efficacy (i.e., the client believes they can make a change) - Action: - The person is in active modification of behavior. - Maintenance: - Sustained change occurs and new behavior(s) replaces old ones. Per this model, this stage is also transitional. - Relapse: - The person falls back into old patterns of behavior. - Upward Spiral: - Each time a person goes through the cycle, they learn from each relapse and (hopefully) grow stronger so that relapse is shorter or less devastating
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/The Cycle of Change.md

item.title: Stages of Therapist Development
item.description: @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018 Therapists trained in individual therapy generally go through three stages of development when learning to do family therapy. In the first stage, they focus on acquiring the skills necessary to work with families. In the second stage, they learn to apply systemic theory to their clinical work, and in the third, ‚Äúself of the therapist‚Äù stage, they focus on more personal issues in relationship to their clinical work The initial skills stage is characterized by the therapist trying to figure out what to do with clients. This focus then shifts in the theory stage to how to think. In the final stage, the therapist focuses on the use of self in being with a family. Beginning therapists report feeling overwhelmed by the experience. Many report going home after seeing clients and crying, while others report that the stress results in headaches, difficulty sleeping, stomachaches, or changes in appetite. Learning to relax and be present in the therapy room with clients is a good place to start. A solid assessment and effective treatment hinge on the therapist‚Äôs ability to listen and attend to the client‚Äôs story, and to show the client that he or she is understood. Beginners can learn to replace their anxiety about ‚Äúdoing something‚Äù with relaxed curiosity and empathy. This approach leads to useful questions and inquiries, which is where therapy begins. The therapeutic relationship is a necessary but not always sufficient ingredient for change. To be effective, interventions must be rooted in a clear understanding of family dynamics. ‚ÄúI know I should be focusing on the process, but I feel like I‚Äôm stuck in the content.‚Äù Beginning therapists are able to develop good insights and hypotheses, but will have difficulty connecting these pieces together into a coherent picture or treatment plan Many therapists find it helpful to adopt a particular theoretical orientation for conceptualizing cases Explore how the therapist-as-self is both an asset and a liability in therapy. Many of our personal experiences can become catalysts for new ideas and understanding in therapeutic work Therapists‚Äô unresolved issues or ‚Äúgrowth areas‚Äù can become impediments in therapy. The growth and insight derived from working on these issues can provide the perspective necessary to make constructive use of life experiences in therapy. Thinking (or even obsessing) about clients is something that tends to subside with time and experience. One reason for this change is that the therapist gradually gains a greater sense of clinical mastery by virtue of experience. Therapists learn to balance objectivity and emotional involvement with clients. Therapists learn how to construct an emotional boundary The potential for burnout among beginning therapists exists because of several factors. Learning to do therapy can be demanding. Therapists have other stressors outside of their clinical work The courses or clinical work may raise personal issues for you as you learn to do therapy. To avoid burnout, practicing good self-care is essential Taking time for yourself seems counterintuitive when faced with an overwhelming number of tasks to accomplish, but the time lost is often made up by being able to work with renewed energy and efficiency. (many therapists are willing to give this advice to their clients but have difficulty following it themselves.) Be willing to set limits. As therapists gain experience, they often will become more willing to set some limits on their availability, giving them some protected time for themselves. You also need a strong social support network Being with family and friends outside the field will allow you to temporarily escape the demands of being a beginning therapist. Connecting and obtaining support from your peers within your program is invaluable Keep the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù in mind and recall the benefits of being a therapist. Keep the following ‚Äòreminders‚Äô at hand:** Becoming a therapist takes time. This is an opportunity for you to be a learner; you are not expected to be an expert. Becoming an effective therapist takes several years of training. Make sure you take care of yourself. Use constructive means for stress reduction. Develop resources for support from other students, peers, and colleagues. Self-doubts are normal. Be patient with yourself, focus on the positive, and pay attention to the developmental tasks of becoming a therapist. Use the skills that brought you to the field. While you are learning lots of new theory and material, continue to pay attention to your intuition, your desire to work with others, and your natural abilities.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Stages of Therapist Development.md

item.title: Secrets in CFT
item.description: Responsible handing of secrets is necessary to avoid ethical, legal, and therapeutic problems. Secrets indirectly influence the couple system due to the consequences and symptoms of secrets. Literature on the disclosure of secrets in therapy is scarce. It is unethical for therapists to collude in keeping secrets. Through voluntary facilitated disclosure or referral therapists should avoid a double-bind while doing therapy with non-disclosed secrets. @butlerFacilitatedDisclosureClinical2009

item.title: Risk Assessment
item.description: Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others. Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium or low risk. Examples of risk areas include: Suicidal Ideation Homicidal Ideation Child Abuse/Neglect Intimate Partner Violence Physical Health Issues or Crises Inability to care for self or others Animal Abuse Substance Use

item.title: Program Integrity
item.description:
The extent to which an intervention is implemented as intended. (pg. 1720) Provides insight into why programs work or do not work. (pg. 1720) There is a major caveat in previous effectiveness research with the absence of information on program integrity. It is often unknown to what extent programs are actually implemented as originally intended (i.e., program integrity). (pg. 1720) The absence of significant intervention effects can be explained either as a lack of effectiveness of the intervention itself, or as a failure to implement the intervention as originally intended. (pg. 1720) Based on the limited information on program integrity provided, there are differences with program implementation and integrity across studies. (pg. 1721) Without documentation of program integrity it is impossible to determine whether significant, non-significant or ambiguous findings can be attributed to the theoretical model underly- ing the program, or to the implementation of the program. (pg. 1721) Program Drift: The aims and objectives of treatment change over time.
Program Reversal: The goals of treatment are undermined or threatened. Program Non-Compliance: The content of the program is altered, or goals are changed or abandoned without reference to theoretical or empirical evidence.
Exposure: Describes the length and frequency of the sessions implemented by the facility Adherence:
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Program Integrity.md

item.title: Multidirected Partiality
item.description: A balanced therapeutic alliance is crucial for the success of couple therapy; the therapist does not accept the role of judge. If there is egregious or abusive behavior, the therapist takes a stand; violence is out of bounds and the principle of safety first is bedrock in any therapy. Nevertheless, even setting limits and identifying problematic behavior is done from a place of concern and compassion. The therapist maintains a stance of ‚Äúmultidirected partiality‚Äù partial to each partner, on each one‚Äôs side. When clients feel understood and affirmed, the therapist can challenge them. Multidirected partiality is not neutrality; the therapist cares about both partners, is partial to each. But the partiality is balanced. The couple therapy office must be a ‚Äúshame-free, blame-free zone,‚Äù a safe environment for clients to explore their vulnerabilities and relational disappointments. It is crucial that clinicians be aware of their own vulnerabilities and survival strategies, and note when they get caught up in a vulnerability cycle with clients. Therapists need to address unfinished business with their own family of origin.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Multidirected Partiality.md

item.title: Mental Disorder
item.description: A mental disorder syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotional regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning. Mental disorders are usually associated with significant distress or disability in social, occupational, or other important activities. An expectable or culturally approved response to a common stressor or loss, such as death of a loved one, is not a mental disorder. Socially deviant behavior (i.e., political, religious, or sexual) and conflicts that are primarily between the individual and society are not mental disorders unless the deviance or conflict results from a dysfunction in the individual, as described above.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Mental Disorder.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.description: David Levy (1943) Levy believed maternal overprotectiveness stems from mothers who were deprived of love, and it developed into either domineering or overindulgent behaviors. Believed it was the cause of child's problems.

item.title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA)
item.description: Makes health information portable so that individuals can maintain health insurance between jobs. Ensure that health care plans and providers are held accountable with regard to keeping health information private Provides federal privacy protections for physical and mental health information known as protected health information (PHI). Compliance: If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE). If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE. If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care. State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc. When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can‚Äôt be.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH)
item.description: Increases patient rights over their PHI Increases restrictions over disclosure of PHI Increased fines for HIPAA violations Funding for compliance audits Compliance: If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE). If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE. If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care. State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc. When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can‚Äôt be.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH).md

item.description: Solution-Focused Therapy Solution-Focused therapists routinely ask clients at the end of the first session to think about what they do not want to change as a result of therapy. This focuses them on strengths in their lives and begins the solution-generating process.

item.title: First-Generation Students
item.description: First generation students may find it more difficult to ask for help. They may worry they are seen as difficult or demanding. They deserve success just as much as their privileged counterparts. They find that graduate school feels like getting locked out when everyone else has the key. They face criticism from family and friends about the demands of graduate school or the type of person they have become.

item.title: Equipping Youth to Help One Another (EQUIP)
item.description:
Effective in neutralizing decreases in social skills and moral value evaluations. (pg. 1720) Earlier studies yield contrasting results on the effectiveness of EQUIP. (pg. 1720) Not effective in reducing cognitive distortions and improving moral judgement. (pg. 1720) Aims to teach antisocial youth to think and act responsibly. (pg. 1720) EQUIP is implemented in all juvenile correctional facilities as part of a nationwide methodology. (pg. 1720) EQUIP is designed to teach antisocial youth to think and act responsibly by combining a peer helping and skills-streaming approach. The peer helping approach of the EQUIP program is based on the Positive Peer Culture (PPC) This is a positive culture in which individuals feel responsible for each other and actually help one another. (pg. 1721) A peer helping approach alone is not sufficient to counter negative peer pressure, since antisocial youth often lack the skills necessary to adequately help each other. (pg. 1721) The EQUIP program therefore also targets three specific 'limitations' of antisocial youth:
Cognitive Distortions: Described as 'inaccurate or rationalizing attitudes, thoughts, or beliefs concerning own or other's behavior.' Social Skill Deficiencies: Described as 'imbalanced and unconstructive behavior in difficult interpersonal situation.' Moral Developmental Delays: Described as "the persistence beyond early childhood of an immature moral judgement and a pronounced 'me-centeredness' or 'egocentric bias.'"
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Equipping Youth to Help One Another (EQUIP).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Essentialist Approach
item.description: @holleyExploringBasisGender2010 Popular stereotypical conceptions of Martian men and Venetian women (e.g., Gray, 1993) Suggest the differences between men and women stem from innate biological or psychological attributes. Previous studies have suggested men are less able to tolerate sustained levels of physiological arousal than women. This also suggest men and women grow up in differing social worlds. (Holley et al., (2010)) (Smith et al., (2010)) Stable differences between men and women explain why wife-demand/husband-withdraw (WDHW) occurs more than husband-demand/wife-withdraw (HDWW) (Eldridge & Christensen, 2002). Some scholars have proposed that women are socialized to be more oriented towards relationships than are men (Napier, 1978)
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Essentialist Approach.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Disclosure
item.description: Disclosure with peers and supervisors helps to accept struggles. Influenced by trust in the therapist and believing self-disclosure would be beneficial. Promotes healing and attachment, but decision should be left to offending spouse. Disclosure is the best course of action to resolve potential conflicts and improve working alliance.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Disclosure.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Demand-Withdraw (Pursuer-Distancer)
item.description: A 'female-demand/male-withdraw' pattern or a 'female-pursuer/male-distancer' pattern is dysfunctional. This one is true. Andy Christensen has pioneered the research in this area of couple relationships.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Demand-Withdraw (Pursuer-Distancer).md

item.title: Construal Humility
item.description: Partners in a couple, seeing the same moment in different ways, may engage in ‚Äúdueling realities.‚Äù Making room for multiple narratives and differences of perspective and opinion, and recognizing the right of each to their own experience, are key aspects of relational ethics. Mentalization is the awareness that others have their own ways of thinking and experiencing. The therapist offers ‚Äúconstrual humility‚Äù as a model, noting that we all construe or make sense of our world, but there are multiple ways to look at most interactions. Making room for dual narratives rather than dueling narratives is a key skill of relational ethics in both couple and intergenerational relationships.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Construal Humility.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Closed System
item.description: A functionally related group of elements regarded as forming a collective entity that does not interact with the surrounding environment.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Closed System.md

item.title: Client Variables
item.description: Attributes of clients that are thought to contribute to successful outcomes, such as proactivity and motivation.

item.title: Blended Families
item.description: Separate families united by marriage; stepfamilies.

item.title: Black Box Concept
item.description: The idea that because the mind is so complex, it's better to study people's input and output (behavior, communication) then to speculate about what goes on in their minds.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Black Box Concept.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Beneficence
item.description: Two general rules reflect this principle: Do no harm. Maximize possible benefits and minimize possible harms.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Beneficence.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Belmont Report
item.description:
The ethical principles are respect for persons, beneficence, and justice. Respect for Persons:Respect for Persons This principle includes two requirements: Acknowledge and treat individuals as autonomous. Protect those with limited autonomy.
Beneficence:Beneficence Two general rules reflect this principle: Do no harm. Maximize possible benefits and minimize possible harms.
Justice:Justice This principle requires researchers to: Treat people fairly. Design research to share burdens and benefits equitably. Balancing the Three Principles:
According to the Belmont Report, "These principles cannot always be applied so as to resolve beyond dispute particular ethical problems. The objective is to provide an analytical framework that will guide the resolution of ethical problems arising from research involving human subjects." In some cases, the principle present competing claims for resolving ethical problems. (i.e., informing subjects about some aspects of the research would invalidate the research, the principle of respect for persons may be compromised in order to provide benefit) Federal Regulations for Protecting Research Subjects:
The 'Federal Policy for Protection of Human Subjects' (the Common Rule) includes a list of criteria for the review of research. These criteria reflect the ethical principles outlines in the Belmont Report: respect for persons, beneficence, and justice. Review Criteria for Expedited and Full Review: IRB members conducting an expedited review, or a convened IRB conducting a full review, must determine the following: Risks to subjects are minimized: By using procedures that are consistent with sound research design and that do not unnecessarily expose subjects to risk. Whenever appropriate, by using procedures already being performed on the subjects for diagnostic or treatment purposes. Risks to subjects are reasonable in relation to anticipated benefits, if any, to subjects, and the importance of the knowledge that may be reasonably be expected to result. In evaluating risks and benefits, the IRB should consider only those risks and benefits that may result from the research (as distinguished from risks and benefits of therapies subjects would receive even if not participating in the research). The IRB should not consider possible long-range effects of applying knowledge gained in the research (e.g., the possible range effects of the research on public policy) as among those research risks that fall within the purview of its responsibility. Selection of subjects is equitable. In making this assessment the IRB should take into account the purposes of the research and the setting in which the research will be conducted. The IRB should be particularly cognizant of the special problems of research that involves a category of subjects who are vulnerable to coercion or undue influence (such as, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, or economically or educationally disadvantaged persons). Informed consent will be sought from each prospective subject or the subject's legally authorized representative. Informed consent will be appropriately documented, or appropriately waived. When appropriate, the research plan makes adequate provision for monitoring the data collected to ensure the safety of subjects. When appropriate, there are adequate provisions to protect the privacy of subjects and to maintain the confidentiality of data. For purposes of conducting the limited IRB review, the IRB shall make the following determinations: Broad consent for storage, maintenance, and secondary research use of identifiable private information or identifiable biospecimens is obtained. Broad consent is appropriately documented or waiver of documentation is appropriate. If there is a change made for research purposes in the way the identifiable private information or identifiable biospecimens are stored or maintained, there are adequate provisions to protect the privacy of subjects and to maintain the confidentiality of data. When some or all of the subjects are likely to be vulnerable to coercion or under influence (such as, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, or economically or educationally disadvantaged persons), additional safeguards must be included in the study to protect the rights and welfare of these subjects.
Federal regulations provide a list of criteria that the IRB must determine are satisfied in order to approve research. The criteria reflect the ethical principles identified in the Belmont Report.

item.title: Attachment
item.description: The innate tendency to seek out closeness to caretakers in the face of stress.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Attachment.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Assimilation
item.description: The process of becoming integrated into the surrounding context.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Assimilation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Antisocial Behavior
item.description: Defined as behavior that is harmful to others by breaking important social or moral norms. (pg. 1720) Antisocial behavior is very costly to society. (pg. 1720) Many interventions have been designed to reduce antisocial behavior, and especially Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) programs have shown to be relatively effective. (pg. 1720)
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Antisocial Behavior.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Antecedent
item.description: Noun: A thing or event that existed before or logically precedes another. Adjective: Preceding in time or order; previous or preexisting.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Antecedent.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Allegiance Bias
item.description: The tendency for researchers to design studies in such a way that favors their preferred method of therapy.
item.guid: Glossary/CFT Keywords/Allegiance Bias.md
