item.title: Untitled Kanban
item.description: Adolescent7You aced a difficult exam, but you studied with a friend you parents don't approve of.You went to a party, and there was underage drinking. You did not participate, but you are unsure how your parents will react.You've started dating someone from a different cultural background, and you are unsure how your parents will react.You are feeling insecure about your appearance and have been considering extreme dieting.You are being bullied at school, but you don't want your parents to worry.You are questioning the religious beliefs that your parents taught you and exploring other spiritual paths.You have developed strong political views that differ significantly from your parents', and you are concerned about causing conflict.+ Add a cardParent4This parents values emotional connection and understanding. They prioritize open communication and want their child to feel safe sharing anything with them.(Controlling & Intrusive) This parent emphasizes rules and monitoring. They believe it is their responsibility to know everything about their child's life to keep them safe. This parent's psychological control may inhibit the child's disclosure for fear of a harmful reaction.(Anxious & Overprotective) This parents focused on safety and potential risks. They tend to worry excessively and may overreact to perceived threats.(Disengaged & Distant) This parent shows little interest in the adolescent's life. They may be preoccupied with their own problems or struggle to connect emotionally with their child.+ Add a cardExternal Influence5(Peer Pressure) Your friends encourage you to keep this a secret, saying your parents wouldn't understand and would just make things worse.(Cultural Norms) In your culture, this topic is considered taboo to discuss with parents, as it's seen as disrespectful or inappropriate.(Past Experiences) Last time you shared something similar, your parent overreacted, leading to a huge argument and a loss of trust.(Media Influence) A TV show you watched portrayed parents as being completely out of touch with teenagers' lives, making you think your parent might not understand.(Discrimination) An adolescent may not share a story of discrimination with their parents, fearing negative parental reactions.+ Add a card

item.title: 7. Family Influences
item.description: I. OverviewThis document summarizes findings from five research articles focusing on various aspects of adolescent development, with an emphasis on the role of family dynamics, cultural factors, and individual experiences in shaping adolescent well-being. The themes covered include: The impact of adolescent secrecy and disclosure on adjustment. Parental strategies for gaining knowledge about their adolescents' lives and the influence of these strategies on adolescent outcomes. The interplay of cultural and general stressors on Latinx adolescents' mental health and the protective role of familismo. The importance of family acceptance for the mental and physical health of LGBT adolescents. II. Key Themes and FindingsA. Secrecy vs. Disclosure in Adolescent-Parent Relationships (Frijns et al., 2010) Core Argument: The traditional measure of adolescent disclosure to parents conflates two distinct constructs: disclosure (what adolescents freely share) and secrecy (what adolescents actively conceal). Secrecy has a stronger impact on adolescent adjustment than previously recognized. Key Findings:Factor analysis confirmed that disclosure and secrecy are separate constructs. "Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..." Secrecy and delinquency were reciprocally related over time. Increased secrecy is linked to "stress-related psychological problems, prevent full processing of the secret information, and cause mental rumination and obsessive preoccupation with the secret." Implications: Researchers should distinguish between disclosure and secrecy when studying adolescent-parent relationships. Interventions should address the underlying reasons for adolescent secrecy. B. Parental Knowledge and Strategies (Liu et al., 2020) Core Argument: Parental knowledge of adolescent activities is influenced by both parent-driven strategies (e.g., solicitation, control, warmth) and child-driven strategies (e.g., disclosure). Key Findings:Children's disclosure is the strongest predictor of parental knowledge compared to parental solicitation, behavioral control, and psychological control. The meta-analysis showed a significant correlation between children's disclosure and parental knowledge (œÅ = 0.523, p < 0.001). Psychological control is negatively associated with parental knowledge. Parental warmth and behavioral control indirectly contribute to parental knowledge by promoting children's disclosure. "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure." Cultural differences exist: The association between behavioral control and parental knowledge was stronger in Eastern cultures compared to Western cultures. Implications: Parents should focus on fostering warm, supportive relationships with their children to encourage open communication and voluntary disclosure. C. Stress and Familismo in Latinx Adolescents (Montoro & Ceballo, 2021) Core Argument: Both cultural and general stressors impact Latinx adolescents' psychological well-being, but familismo (a strong emphasis on family unity, support, and obligation) can serve as a protective factor. Key Findings:Family-based cultural stressors were associated with increased depressive symptoms whereas familismo was associated with fewer depressive symptoms Greater material need was associated with increased depressive symptoms and a less positive future orientation. "Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship." Racial discrimination is positively associated with anxiety Implications: Interventions should leverage the strength of familismo to help Latinx adolescents cope with stress and promote positive mental health outcomes. D. Family Acceptance and LGBT Adolescent Health (Ryan et al., 2010) Core Argument: Family acceptance is a critical protective factor for LGBT adolescents, significantly impacting their mental and physical health in young adulthood. Key Findings:"Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors." LGBT adolescents with low family acceptance were more than three times as likely to report suicidal ideation and suicide attempts compared to those with high family acceptance. Latino, immigrant, religious, and low-socioeconomic status families appear to be less accepting, on average, of LGBT adolescents Implications: Promote interventions that educate and support families in accepting their LGBT children to reduce health disparities and improve well-being. III. Quotes Frijns et al. (2010): "Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..." Liu et al. (2020): "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure." Montoro & Ceballo (2021): "Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship." Ryan et al. (2010): "Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors." IV. Overall ImplicationsThese studies collectively highlight the crucial role of family relationships in adolescent development. They emphasize the importance of open communication, parental warmth and support, cultural understanding, and acceptance in promoting adolescent well-being. The findings suggest that interventions should focus on strengthening family bonds, addressing both cultural and economic stressors, and promoting positive family dynamics to support healthy adolescent development.

item.title: @atkinQualitativeExaminationFamilial2022
item.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: A qualitative examination of familial racial-ethnic socialization experiences among multiracial American emerging adults., Author: Atkin, Annabelle L.; Jackson, Kelly F.; White, Rebecca M. B.; Tran, Alisia G. T. T.; Journal: Journal of Family Psychology, Volume: 36, Issue: 2 Pages: 179-190 Year: 2022 DOI: 10.1037/fam0000918 ISSN: 1939-1293, 0893-3200 This qualitative interview study investigated the types of parental racial-ethnic socialization messages received by Multiracial American youth over the course of their development. The Multiracial population in America is the largest demographic group among individuals under the age of 18 (Saulny, 2011), but there is a dearth of research about the development of this rapidly growing population. Multiracial youth are members of multiple racial-ethnic groups. Thus, racial-ethnic socialization is particularly complex for Multiracial families because parents typically have different racial backgrounds and experiences compared to their children. Interviews were conducted with 20 Multiracial emerging adult college students (Mage = 20.55; 10 male, 10 female) of diverse racial backgrounds to identify the types of parental racial-ethnic socialization messages they received growing up. Using thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), nine themes of racial-ethnic socialization content emerged: Cultural socialization, racial identity socialization, preparation for bias socialization, colorblind socialization, race-conscious socialization, diversity appreciation socialization, negative socialization, exposure to diversity socialization, and silent socialization. This research advances the literature by (a) identifying domains of racial-ethnic socialization messages for Multiracial American families, (b) examining a diverse sample of male and female Multiracial youth, (c) differentiating monoracial versus Multiracial socialization messages, and (d) distinguishing the unique connotations of egalitarian socialization messages (e.g., colorblind, raceconscious, diversity appreciation). The Ô¨Åndings have important implications for understanding the development of Multiracial American individuals and families. Keywords: #Multiracial #Biracial #Qualitative It was not until 1967 that interracial marriages became legal across the US with the Loving v. Virginia case. The Multiracial population in America is the largest demographic group among individuals under the age of 18. There is a dearth of research about the development of this rapidly growing population. There is a lack of research that examines how Multiracial American families navifate racial issues and prepare their children for living in a society dominated by monocentrism, which assumes every individual is associated with only one racial group and pathologizes and excludes those who do not fit this norm. More research is needed that examines racial-ethnic socialization or the transmission of messages from caregivers to children about the meaning of their racial-ethnic group membership, in Multiracial families. Socialization from caregivers plays an important role in reducing the negative effects of racial inequities by helping children of color understand race, develop a strong sense of identity, and build resilience to racial conflict.
Critical Multiracial Theory (MultiCrit)
Ecological Model of Biethnic Identity Formation Theorizes how race-related factors work together to inform development. This model posits that the messages that caregivers give about their child's racial-ethnic heritage and culture might shape how the Multiracial child understands their racial-ethnic identity and prepare them for responding to racial discrimination. Little is know about how this process of racial-ethnic socialization plays out in Multiracial families. Parents may not know how to provide useful messages or may even convey discriminatory messages to their child. The model posits that social climate affects Multiracial youths' experiences of racial-ethnic socialization and identity development. Previous qualitative studies examining racial-ethnic socialization in Multiracial families have found that monoracial parents typically do not talk explicitly about race and ethnicity with children, utilizing colorblind messages that deemphasize the significance of structural racism instead. One recent study with transracially adopted Korean American adults raising Multiracial children found that parents did engage in socialization promoting monoracial identities (i.e., Asian American or White), but did not specifically promote Multiracial identity. MultiCrit highlights that on top of racism and colorism, Multiracial youth experience monoracism, or discrimination based on one's Multiracial status. Multiracial youth report being exoticized, tokenized, objectified, placed into monoracial boxes, rejected, and forced to pick a monoracial identity to appease monoracial peers. Seven domains of racial-ethnic socialization experienced by Multiracial American youth: Cultural Socialization Encompasses messages about cultural traditions and values and exposure to people, foods, and other aspects associated with one's racial-ethnic heritage. Racial Identity Socialization Involves messages about how the child belongs to and should be proud of their membership in various racial-ethnic groups, as well as labels they can use to racially identify themselves. Preparation for Bias Messages Teaches children about racial stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination they may face based on their race and create space for dialog about experiences of racism within the family. Egalitarian Socialization Prioritizes messages about everyone being the same Negative Socialization Encompasses implicitly or explicitly conveyed prejudicial Exposure to Diversity Messages Exposure to diversity through schools and communities was another way parents influenced their children's racial-ethnic socialization. No Racial-Ethnic Socialization Some parents were silent on the topic of race or actively avoided or ignored the topic. Nine themes representing the content of racial-ethnic socialization messages emerged from the analysis of the interviews Racial Identity Socialization Preparation for Bias Socialization Colorblind Socialization Diversity Appreciation Socialization Race-Conscious Socialization Exposure to Diversity Socialization Negative Socialization Silent Socialization Involves exposure to the customs and traditions of youths' heritage cultures. Participants reported learning about and experiencing many different cultural aspects from their parents including language, food, clothing, traditional dance, media, and holidays, which helped them feel more connected to their cultures. Participants also learned about their culture through stories about their family history and the history of the parent's origin country, visiting their parent's country of origin, and participating in cultural events such as local festivals or community parties with family friends from a specific ethnic background. Food was the most prominent connection Multiracial youth had to their culture. Food was a cultural aspect that crossed over from one parent to the other, in that moms would learn from their mother-in-law how to cook dishes specific to their husband's culture. Food was an important way that family celebrated their multiple cultures. Language Socialization There were parents who knew their partners, making it another aspect of shared family culture for Multiracial families. Racial identity socialization involved messages from parents to Multiracial youth explaining their racial-ethnic background(s) and sometimes also telling them which labels they could or should use to identify with their racial background. Some racial identity socialization messages acknowledged the Multiracial nature of youths' identities, while others encouraged identification with only one racial-ethnic group. Certain messages from parents emphasized the monoracial aspects of youths' identity. In certain situations, parents also encouraged youth to identify with the racial background that would be most advantageous to them in achieving a goal. Youth were taught to focus on only one of their heritages if it would help them in applying to jobs or schools. There were also messages from parents that highlighted youths' multiple heritages or Multiracial identity. Participants reported that their parents taught them that they were members of all of their groups, though the term 'Multiracial' was rarely ever mentioned. "You are both things, you are biracial... Definitely identify as such." Even second-generation Multiracial youth were reminded to acknowledge all of their backgrounds. Preparation for bias socialization involved both making Multiracial youth aware of racial biases that others might have due to their racial-ethnic heritage and teaching them how to respond to or cope with experiences of others racially discriminating against them. Preparation for bias also occurred through parents sharing the experiences they had with discrimination played. Moreover, youth learned from their parents by witnessing them experiencing discrimination and seeing how they responded. Messages that prepared youth for bias in ways that were applicable to discrimination targeted at both their monoracial and Multiracial groups were labelled General Preparation for Bias Messages. One way parents suggested that Multiracial youth handle racial bias was by ignoring people who discriminated against them and letting things go.

item.title: @crocettiIdentityFormationAdolescence2017
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Identity Formation in Adolescence: The Dynamic of Forming and Consolidating Identity Commitments, Author: Crocetti, Elisabetta; Journal: Child Development Perspectives, Volume: 11, Issue: 2 Pages: 145-150 Year: 2017 DOI: 10.1111/cdep.12226 ISSN: 1750-8592, 1750-8606 The biological, cognitive, and social changes that occur in adolescence stimulate young people to think about themselves, reÔ¨Çect on the kind of people they want to become, and Ô¨Ånd their place in society. Traditionally, these changes have been explained by Erikson‚Äôs theory and Marcia‚Äôs identity status model, but process-oriented models of identity provide new insights. In particular, dual-cycle models, such as the three-factor identity model, focus on the dynamic process by which young people iteratively form and maintain their identity over time. This iterative process is captured by the interplay of commitment, in-depth exploration, and reconsideration of commitment, as well as by distinct identity statuses. Furthermore, the extent to which adolescents Ô¨Ånd a stable identity is intertwined strongly with their psychosocial functioning and well-being. Keywords: Need to Read
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Adolescent and Emerging Adulthood/5. Racial and Ethnic Identity Development/@crocettiIdentityFormationAdolescence2017.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: @loydRacialEthnicSocialization2018
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Racial/ethnic socialization for White youth: What we know and future directions, Author: Loyd, Aerika Brittian; Gaither, Sarah E.; Journal: Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, Volume: 59, Pages: 54-64 Year: 2018 DOI: 10.1016/j.appdev.2018.05.004 ISSN: 01933973 Teaching and talking about race and ethnicity with children and adults is especially important in racially diverse societies. This process has been coined racial/ethnic socialization (RES). Despite the importance of RES, we still know very little about how this process unfolds in the lives of White youth. Thus, from a social, cognitive, and developmental perspective, the authors summarize Ô¨Åndings from empirical research and theory on RES for White youth across stages of development‚Äîearly childhood through young adulthood. Since RES is linked with cross-group attitudes (e.g., less bias, prejudice, stereotyping) and behaviors (e.g., inclusion), we highlight future directions for research and discuss applications for existing Ô¨Åndings for an increasingly diverse society. Keywords: Need to Read

item.title: @umana-taylorEthnicRacialSocialization2020
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Ethnic‚ÄìRacial Socialization in the Family: A Decade's Advance on Precursors and Outcomes, Author: Uma√±a‚ÄêTaylor, Adriana J.; Hill, Nancy E.; Journal: Journal of Marriage and Family, Volume: 82, Issue: 1 Pages: 244-271 Year: 2020 DOI: 10.1111/jomf.12622 ISSN: 0022-2445, 1741-3737 Abstract In the current decade, the U.S. population reached historically high levels of ethnic‚Äìracial diversity and reelected the nation's first Black‚ÄìWhite biracial President. Simultaneously, scholars also documented significant ethnic‚Äìracial inequities in education, increased xenophobia, and a racial climate that revealed deep‚Äêseated ethnic‚Äìracial tensions. Given this backdrop and acknowledging the significant role that families play in youths' abilities to navigate their social contexts, the current review focused on the literature on families' ethnic‚Äìracial socialization efforts with youth from the 2010 decade. Our review of 259 empirical articles revealed that there has been an exponential increase in research on family ethnic‚Äìracial socialization in this decade. Furthermore, although it is clear that family ethnic‚Äìracial socialization is a robust predictor of youths' adjustment, the associations between socialization and adjustment must be considered with attention to specific socialization strategies, the confluence of strategies used, and the unique contexts within which families' lives are embedded. Keywords: Need to Read
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Adolescent and Emerging Adulthood/5. Racial and Ethnic Identity Development/@umana-taylorEthnicRacialSocialization2020.md

item.title: @sladekItsAllMix2022
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: ‚ÄúSo, like, it‚Äôs all a mix of one‚Äù: Intersecting contexts of adolescents‚Äô ethnic‚Äêracial socialization, Author: Sladek, Michael R.; Uma√±a‚ÄêTaylor, Adriana J.; Hardesty, Jennifer L.; Aguilar, Gladys; Bates, David; Bayless, Sara Douglass; Gomez, Elisa; Hur, Connie K.; Ison, Ashley; Jones, Shandra; Luo, Hua; Satterthwaite‚ÄêFreiman, Megan; V√°zquez, Michael A.; Journal: Child Development, Volume: 93, Issue: 5 Pages: 1284-1303 Year: 2022 DOI: 10.1111/cdev.13756 ISSN: 0009-3920, 1467-8624 Cultural-¬≠ecological theories posit that ethnic-r¬≠ acial identity (ERI) development is shaped by transactions between contexts of ethnic-¬≠racial socialization, yet research considering intersections among multiple contexts is limited. In this study, Black, Latino, White, and Asian American adolescents (N = 98; Mage = 16.26, SD = 1.09; 55.1% female identifying) participated in surveys and focus group discussions (2013‚Äì¬≠2014) to share insights into ERI development in context. Using consensual qualitative research, results indicated: (a) family ethnic-¬≠racial socialization intersects with community-¬≠based, peer, media, and school socialization; (b) ethnic-¬≠ racial socialization occurs outside family through intersections between peer, school, community-¬≠based, and media settings; and (c) ethnic-r¬≠ acial socialization is embedded within systems of racial oppression across contexts. Discussion includes implications for future research and interventions supporting youth ERI. Keywords: Need to Read

item.title: @caseySimpleModelsSelfControl2015
item.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Beyond Simple Models of Self-Control to Circuit-Based Accounts of Adolescent Behavior, Author: Casey, B. J.; Journal: Annual Review of Psychology, Volume: 66, Issue: 1 Pages: 295-319 Year: 2015 DOI: 10.1146/annurev-psych-010814-015156 ISSN: 0066-4308, 1545-2085 Adolescence is the transition from childhood to adulthood that begins around the onset of puberty and ends with relative independence from the parent. This developmental period is one when an individual is probably stronger, of higher reasoning capacity, and more resistant to disease than ever before, yet when mortality rates increase by 200%. These untimely deaths are not due to disease but to preventable deaths associated with adolescents putting themselves in harm‚Äôs way (e.g., accidental fatalities). We present evidence that these alarming health statistics are in part due to diminished self-control‚Äîthe ability to inhibit inappropriate desires, emotions, and actions in favor of appropriate ones. Findings of adolescent-speciÔ¨Åc changes in self-control and underlying brain circuitry are considered in terms of how evolutionarily based biological constraints and experiences shape the brain to adapt to the unique intellectual, physical, sexual, and social challenges of adolescence. Keywords: #Cognition #Development #Emotion #Motivation #Peers #Prefrontal-Cortex
The dual-system based largely on Metcalf & Mischel's (1999) two-system model of willpower. According to the model, self-control results from a balance between a 'cool' and a 'hot' system. The cool system is an emotionally neutral, strategic, and flexible cognitive system. The hot system is emotionally driven by fears, desires, and reflexes. The balance between these two system varies as a function of the individual, development, and stress. The dual-system model was used to heuristically explain brain systems underlying behavior involving immediate versus delayed rewards. Portions of the limbic system

item.title: 4. Cognitive & Neurological Development
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Adolescent and Emerging Adulthood/4. Cognitive & Neurological Development/4. Cognitive & Neurological Development.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.description: Developmental Systems Perspective Adolescent development is best understood as a dynamic interplay between the individual and their changing context. Long-term impact of adolescence While acknowledging the influence of early childhood experiences, both sources highlight the unique and lasting impact of adolescent experiences on adult outcomes. Authors criticize traditional theories that separate individual and context, arguing that they fail to capture the relational nature of development. Developmental Systems Model This model considers the dynamic interplay of multiple levels of organization, from biological to cultural. This model emphasizes Change and Relative Plasticity Individuals and contexts are constantly changing, and this plasticity allows for potential interventions to promote positive development Relationism and Integration Variables from different levels of organization are interconnected and influence each other. Historical Embeddedness and Temporality Development is embedded within historical time, leading to both continuity and discontinuity within and between individuals. Limits of Generalizability, Diversity, and Individual Differences The dynamic nature of development limits generalizability and highlights the importance of considering individual and contextual diversity. Implications for Research and Application This model calls for multilevel, longitudinal research to understand individual-context relations and design intervention that alter those relations in positive directions. 'Shot Out of a Cannon' models emphasize early childhood experiences determining life trajectory. 'Contact Sport' models acknowledge the continuous interaction between individual and context throughout life. Research shows that interventions targeting early childhood influence long-term outcomes by impacting specific adolescent factors like substance use onset, teen births, and educational attainment. The authors advocate for longitudinal studies explicitly designed to test the unique contribution of adolescence to long-term outcomes. The authors hypothesize that childhood and adolescence likely have both cumulative and domain-specific effects on adult outcomes. Both sources agree that adolescence is a critical developmental period with lasting impacts on adult outcomes. They advocate for a developmental systems approach that recognizes the dynamic interplay between individual and context throughout the lifespan. Future research should prioritize longitudinal studies explicitly designed to pinpoint the specific characteristics and experiences during adolescence that contribute most significantly to diverse long-term outcomes. This knowledge will inform effective policies and interventions to maximize the positive potential of adolescence for individuals and society as a whole.

item.title: GLM 2
item.description:
Multiple Linear RegressionSimple Linear Regression Include Model Fit, R-squared change, Descriptives, Part and Partial Correlations, and Collinearity Diagnostics Confidence intervals are not necessary but can be helpful. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR)
Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box
Drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive.
The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line)
We use SLR to investigate how one variable (x or the Independent Variable) explains the variability (Variance) in the other variable (y or the Dependent Variable). If x is indeed a significant Predictor of y, we can use x to predict y.
We only have one Predictor (Independent Variable) in the model. In SLR, Multiple R = |rxy|
R-squared is the proportion of the variance in the Dependent Variable (y) that can be explained (accounted for) by the Independent Variable s / Predictor s in the model (x's) In SLR, R-squared equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y (r-squared). 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ¬± .2 (weak) r = ¬± .4 (moderate) r = ¬± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ¬± .1 (weak) r = ¬± .3 (moderate) r = ¬± .5 (strong) R-squared = .448 in the example above. 44.8% of the variation in kid's scores on the cognitive test is accounted for by their mother's IQ. Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: - What we can explain by the model (regression) - What we still cannot explain (error)
Mediation Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually Œ±=. 05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: Œ≤1 = 0 H1: Œ≤1 ‚â† 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: œÅ = 0 (œÅ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: œÅ > 0 H0: œÅ2 = 0 H1: œÅ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < Œ± For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.
For the example, the Omnibus test results in the ANOVA table show that the model significantly predicts the Dependent Variable, (F(1,432) = 108.643, p < .001) Pasted image 20250129080138.pngPasted image 20250129081552.png
MLR is used when you want to understand the relationship between one Dependent Variable and two or more Independent Variable. It is commonly applied in scenarios such as: Predicting Outcomes For example, predicting house prices based on square footage, number of bedrooms, and location. Understanding Relationships For example, analyzing how factors like advertising spend, produce price, and customer satisfaction influence sales. Controlling for Confounding Variables For example, studying the effect of education level on income while controlling for age and work experience. Utilize Cook's Distance under the 'Residuals Statistics' Table
If the maximum Cook's distance is below 1.0, then the assumption is met. Other tests may give a different cutoff point, but for our purposes we will use 1.0. Testing for Extreme Outliers
Observations are independent of each other (no Autocorrelation) How to Check Use the Durbin-Watson test. If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 - 2.5, the assumption is met. Examples
For this example, we'll say 1.482 is close enough to 1.5 and the assumption is met. Ensure house prices are not influenced by neighboring houses. Solutions
Use Time-Series Design if data is Autocorrelation. Testing the Independence of Error
In Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable. How to Check
Calculate the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF). Values above 5-10 indicate multicollinearity. Example Check if square footage and number of bedrooms are highly correlated. Solution Remove or combine correlated variables.
Autocorrelation Multicollinearity
Dependent Y variable Block Use next and previous buttons for blocks of variables Independent (s) x-variables Method Allows you to use stepwise, never use this Always use paste to send the analysis to the syntax editor and save your work. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Move Dependent Variable to Dependent. Move Independent Variable (s) to the Independent (s). In Statistics, select Estimates (Under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (Under Residuals). Click Continue. In Plots, select Histogram and Normal Probability Plot (Under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. In Save, select Cook's (Under Distances). Click Continue. Click OK.
You can save residuals as their own variables to detect multivariate outliers. Predicted values tell you what SPSS thinks the y value should be based on the x-values of the case. Residual values are how far off SPSS was Mahalanobis distance tells you how far away a case is from the 'cloud' of other values.
The residuals (errors) have constant Variance across all levels of Independent Variable s. How to Check Plot residuals vs. Predicted values Look for a random scatter. In SPSS: request Linear Regression Plots. Y > ZPred X > Z Resid If the scatterplot shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met.
Example Check if the spread of residuals is consistent across predicted house prices. Solution Apply transformations or use weighted least squares. Testing Homoscedasticity An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing. SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also. Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore
Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.
The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed. If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met. If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.
If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met. The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped. The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2. The Explore command on its own cannot separate the dependent variable into groups based on not one but two or more independent variables. However, we can perform this feat by using the Split File command. Click Data -> Split File Click Organize Output by Groups. Transfer the independent variables you wish to categorize the dependent variable on into the Groups Based On box. Proceed as above. Testing for Normality
The relationship between the Dependent Variable and each Independent Variable is linear. How to Check Use scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your Dependent Variable (Outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your Independent Variable (Predictor) to the X-Axis If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.
Example Plot house price against square footage to see if the relationship linear. Solution If not linear, apply transformations (e.g., log, square root) Testing Linearity

item.title: Assignment 4
item.description: This classwork/homework assignment is a multiple imputation activity. You will continue to use data from the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten 2011 Cohort. The classwork/homework write-up is due by Tuesday at 11:59PM (3/18). The data you need come from two sources. The first is the data file you have been working on for class activities the last several week. The second is located in this week's folder. A researcher wants to know whether maternal depressive symptoms are associated with children‚Äôs early learning and development. But before the researcher can address this question, you are asked to think about and address missing data. The researcher has provided you with several variables in addition to the variables you have worked with thus far: You are asked to include an overall composite of depressive symptoms. The research provides you with 12 items that you are asked to composite (P2BOTHER P2APPETI P2BLUE P2KPMIND P2DEPRES P2EFFORT P2FEARFL P2RESTLS P2TALKLS P2LONELY P2SAD P2NOTGO). You will also include three child variables: a) a variable capturing children‚Äôs academic achievement, b) a variable capturing children‚Äôs socioemotional skills, and c) a variable capturing children‚Äôs executive functioning. For the academic achievement measure, you will need to create a new composite variable that is composed of reading, math, and science (X2RSCALK4 X2MSCALK4 X2SSCALK4). For socioemotional skills, you will need to create a new variable that is the average of teacher reports of self-control, interpersonal skills, externalizing behavior, and internalizing behavior (i.e., X2TCHINT X2TCHEXT X2TCHCON X2TCHPER). Children‚Äôs executive functioning skills are captured with a single item: X2DCCSTOT. The researcher also wants you to include covariates/indicators for race/ethnicity (X_RACETH_R), child sex (X_CHSEX_R), income (X2INCCAT_I), parents‚Äô marital status (P1CURMAR), parents physical health (P2HEALTH), household members under 18 (X1LESS18), and household members over 18 (X1OVER18) . With that in mind...Step 1: You need to merge the new data into the dataset you have been working with. This requires a 1 to 1 merge using CHILDID. This step will be graded via your do/log files (.25 points)Step 2: Once the data are merged, examine your data. Orient yourself to the old and new variables (e.g., are they continuous, categorical etc etc) and recode any new variables as appropriate. Recall how Stata recognizes missing data. Please also create the appropriate composites prior to imputation. The composites will be what you will use in your imputation. If you recode other variables, please provide a justification. This step will be graded via your do/log files and your justification in your word document. (.25 points) Step 3: Once you have cleaned your data, run some descriptives for all of your variables (including your covariates) and determine the degree of missing values for each variable. Please also estimate a correlation matrix for your focal independent and dependent variables (do not include the list of covariates for your correlation matrix). What  patterns you notice from the descriptive statistics? How much missing data are there for the variables? What patterns do you notice from the correlation matrix? (1.00 point) Step 4: Determine whether data are MCAR. Examine and discuss the missing data patterns. Are there common patterns of missing data? Are there uncommon patterns of missing data? Anything you notice worth discussing? If data are not MCAR, discuss whether the data may meet assumptions of MAR or MNAR. Why or why not? If you have any concerns proceeding to imputation, discuss it here. (1.25 points) Step 5: Run an imputation model with 10 datasets. Make sure you specify each variable correctly. And remember to upload your do and log files (for the entire assignment). This step will be graded via your do file (1.00 point) Step 6: After you have run your imputation, estimate descriptives within the 10 imputed datasets. You do not have to do this for every variable. Run these descriptives for the focal variables of interest (depressive symptoms, children's academic achievement, social skills, and executive functioning). Use the mi xeq command (e.g., mi xeq: sum XYZ). Discuss what you notice about the means/SDs across the imputations. (1.00 point)Step 7. Estimate correlations (use mi xeq: corr) among your focal variables from step 1, but this time within your 10 datasets. Are there any similarities between the imputed and non-imputed data? Are there any other differences you notice? (.75 points) Step 8. Upload your word document, log file, and do file. Please upload stata versions of your log/do files (not copied/pasted into word).

item.title: Mediation
item.description:
Single Mediation
Moderation Mediation examines how the effect of an independent variable (IV) on a dependent variable (DV) is transmitted through a third variable, called the mediator (M). In simple mediation, there is one mediator. To determine if the IV influences the DV directly and/or indirectly via the mediator. The model splits the total effect into The portion of the effect of IV on DV that is not explained by the mediator. The portion of the effect that is transmitted from IV to DV through the mediator. Relationships among IV, mediator, and DV are linear. Scatterplots: Go to Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot and plot DV vs. IV and DV vs. M. Look for a straight-line pattern. Residuals vs. Predicted Plot: Run Analyze > Regression > Linear‚Ä¶; click Plots‚Ä¶ to assign standardized predicted values (X-axis) and standardized residuals (Y-axis). Criteria: No systematic pattern (i.e., randomness, with any curve test yielding p > .05). Residuals have constant variance across all levels of predictors. Examine the same residuals vs. predicted plot for an even spread (no funnel shape). Residuals are approximately normally distributed. Create histograms and Q‚ÄìQ plots using Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram or Q‚ÄìQ plot options. Criteria: Skewness values less than |2.0| and kurtosis values less than |7.0|; Q‚ÄìQ plot points should lie near the diagonal line. Observations are independent. Confirm via your study design. Review the Durbin‚ÄìWatson statistic from your regression output (values between 1.5 and 2.5 are acceptable). There are no unmeasured variables that confound the relationship between the mediator and DV. This is primarily a design issue; however, consider including control variables if needed. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX by Andrew Hayes Choose Model 4 (designed for simple mediation). Set the DV, IV, and mediator in the appropriate boxes. Enable bootstrapping (commonly set to 5,000 samples) to obtain robust confidence intervals (CIs) for the indirect effect. Click OK. Direct Path (IV ‚Üí M): Example: a = 0.40, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path from Mediator to DV (M ‚Üí DV, controlling for IV): Example: b = 0.50, SE = 0.12, p = .002 Indirect Effect (a √ó b): Example: 0.40 √ó 0.50 = 0.200.40 \times 0.50 = 0.20 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.08, 0.35] (does not include zero ‚Üí significant mediation). Direct Effect (IV ‚Üí DV controlling for M): Example: c‚Ä≤ = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005 Total Effect (IV ‚Üí DV without mediator): Example: c = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001 A mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to examine whether [Mediator] mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The total effect of [IV] on [DV] was significant (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001). When [Mediator] was entered into the model, the direct effect decreased (b = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005). The indirect effect was significant (b = 0.20, SE = 0.07, 95% CI [0.08, 0.35]), indicating that [Mediator] partially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. Parallel mediation involves multiple mediators that operate simultaneously. Each mediator is theorized to transmit the effect of the IV on the DV independently. To examine whether different processes (mediators) independently contribute to the effect of the IV on the DV. This model allows you to assess which mediator(s) play a significant role and to what extent. IV ‚Üí Mediator 1 ‚Üí DV IV ‚Üí Mediator 2 ‚Üí DV (Mediators do not influence one another) Generate scatterplots for DV vs. each mediator. Run separate regression analyses for each mediator (DV as outcome, mediator as predictor) and inspect residuals vs. predicted plots. Criteria: Residuals should show no systematic pattern. Create histograms and Q‚ÄìQ plots for the residuals of each regression. Criteria: Skewness < |2.0| and kurtosis < |7.0|. Run a correlation matrix (Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate) among the mediators. Criteria: Inter-mediator correlations should be moderate (ideally, r < 0.80) to avoid redundancy. As with simple mediation, verify study design and check the Durbin‚ÄìWatson statistic (1.5‚Äì2.5). Navigate to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Use Model 4; PROCESS allows entering multiple mediators simultaneously. Enter the IV, DV, and list all mediators. Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals for each indirect effect. Click OK. Example: a1 = 0.30, b1 = 0.40 ‚Üí Indirect effect = 0.30 √ó 0.40 = 0.12 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.03, 0.22] (significant if CI does not include zero, p = .012). Example: a2 = 0.25, b2 = 0.35 ‚Üí Indirect effect = 0.25 √ó 0.35 = 0.0875 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.18] (significant, p = .025). Sum of individual indirect effects (if both are significant). Example: c‚Ä≤ = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001 A parallel mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to evaluate whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] independently mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The indirect effect through [Mediator 1] was significant (b = 0.12, SE = 0.06, 95% CI [0.03, 0.22], p = .012), as was the indirect effect through [Mediator 2] (b = 0.09, SE = 0.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.18], p = .025). The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001), suggesting that both mediators contributed uniquely to the overall relationship.‚Äù Serial mediation (also called chain mediation) involves two or more mediators arranged in a specific sequential order. The IV affects the first mediator, which in turn affects the second mediator, and so on, eventually influencing the DV. To investigate the process by which the IV impacts the DV through a chain of mediators, highlighting the step-by-step mechanism and temporal ordering of effects. Generate scatterplots and residual vs. predicted plots for each link: IV ‚Üí M1, M1 ‚Üí M2, and M2 ‚Üí DV. Use histograms and Q‚ÄìQ plots for residuals in each regression. Criteria: As before, look for random dispersion, skewness < |2.0|, kurtosis < |7.0|, and Durbin‚ÄìWatson between 1.5 and 2.5. There must be theoretical or empirical support for the hypothesized order (e.g., M1 influences M2). Run intermediate regressions (e.g., regress M2 on M1) and ensure that coefficients are significant (p < .05) in line with your theory. Consider and control for variables that may confound the relationships between mediators if necessary. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Choose Model 6 (designed for serial mediation). Enter the IV, DV, and mediators in the specific sequential order. Click Options: Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals. Click OK. Path IV ‚Üí Mediator 1: Example: a1 = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001 Path Mediator 1 ‚Üí Mediator 2: Example: d = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path Mediator 2 ‚Üí DV (controlling for IV and M1): Example: b2 = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002 Sequential Indirect Effect (IV ‚Üí M1 ‚Üí M2 ‚Üí DV): Calculation: a1 √ó d √ó b2 = 0.35 √ó 0.45 √ó 0.30 = 0.0473 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.10] (if CI does not include zero, the effect is significant, e.g., p = .018). Direct Effect (IV ‚Üí DV controlling for mediators): Example: c‚Ä≤ = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001 A serial mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 6) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to test whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] sequentially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The analysis indicated that [IV] significantly predicted [Mediator 1] (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001), and [Mediator 1] significantly predicted [Mediator 2] (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001). Furthermore, [Mediator 2] significantly predicted [DV] (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002). The sequential indirect effect was significant (b = 0.047, SE = 0.02, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10], p = .018), indicating that the effect of [IV] on [DV] was transmitted via [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] in sequence. The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001), suggesting partial mediation. Check Assumptions in SPSS: Generate scatterplots, residual vs. predicted plots, histograms, and Q‚ÄìQ plots. Verify diagnostic values: skewness (< |2.0|), kurtosis (< |7.0|), Durbin‚ÄìWatson (1.5‚Äì2.5), and inter-mediator correlations (r < 0.80 for parallel mediation). For serial mediation, confirm intermediate regression steps are significant (p < .05). Conduct Mediation Analysis with PROCESS: Use the appropriate model: Model 4 for simple and parallel mediation; Model 6 for serial mediation. Enter variables as specified and enable bootstrapping (commonly 5,000 samples) to generate 95% confidence intervals. Interpret Output: Evaluate p-values for each path (significant if p < .05). For indirect effects, confirm that bootstrapped confidence intervals do not include zero.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/GLM 2/Mediation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Sampling & Complex Designs
item.description:
Why should we strive for population representative sampling? Important for policy or practice. We do not want to recommend changes that are not based on research that is representative of the full population those changes would impact. How? Narrow our populations of interest (e.g., Columbus instead of the US) Work on large teams Use secondary data Normally used to compensate for over- and under-sampling of individuals Example It is common to over-sample minority groups... If we doubled the size of our minority sample, then each minority case would get a design weight of 1/2 or .5. We use the design weight when we want the statistics to be representative of the population. Used to compensate for the fact that persons with certain characteristics are not as likely to respond to the survey. Example Most population surveys have substantially more female than male respondents; because surveys over-represents females and under-represents males in the population, a weight is used to compensate for this bias. There are many responsent characteristics that are likely to be related to the propensity to respond such as age, education, race/ethnicity, place of residence. Dataset with cases Simple mean (4 + 2 + 1 + 5 + 2) / 5 = 2.8 Weighted mean {(4 1) + (2 2) + (1 4) + (5 1) + (2 * 2)} / 10 = 2.1 With unweighted data, each case is counted equally With weighted data, each case is counted relative to its representation in the population Unweighted data represent only those in the sample who provide data Weights allow analyses that represent the target population Most STATA commands can deal with weighted data, where the weight is a variable in the dataset. You need to specify the type of weight and the weight variable, using brackets at the end of your command, as in: summarize x [weight=weightvarname] tab x [weight=weightvarname] regress y x [weight=weightvarname] There are 4 types of weights in STATA, but for most data analyses you will use one of the following: Probability pweights, for observations sampled with unequal probability of selection. Use this for inferential analyses. Analytic aweights, for data containing averages where the average is weighted by the # obs used in calculating the average‚Ä¶. Use this for your descriptive statistics.
Different studies create different types of weights... Some data create weights depending on: Level of analysis (child, teacher, or school) Type of analysis (cross-sectional vs. Longitudinal) Source of data (child assessment, parent interview, teacher questionnaires, etc.) For example, the ECLS-K has ~ 105 different options Many suggest you use combination weights when estimating longitudinal analyses because they assume that these users will not adjust for attrition on their own. I suggest avoiding the use of attrition weights. Instead, use modern missing data procedures for attrition bias, and use the appropriate sample weight to adjust for sampling bias I make this recommendation because attrition weights have two key disadvantages Attrition weights often reduce the analytical sample size, and thereby, statistical power. If many non-model variables related to missing data are incorporated, missing data techniques adjust for attrition bias more effectively than attrition weights Use weights whenever possible, but some methods do not allow weights Steps to follow to avoid vias in unweighted analyses
Include as Independent Variable that might account for the sample design or non-response
If a weight is available, it can also be included as an IV If the weight is associated with the outcom ein a model including the design variables, then the weight is likely to have been constructed in a way related to your outcome; bias is possile. E.g., some multilevel models, some structural equation programs, etc. National samples are first divided into primary sampling units... What these units are depends on the study. - E.g., in many data of the US the PSUs are geographic areas consisting of counties or groups of counties
After identifying PSUs, then PSUs are stratified into groups. These groups are formed to keep similar units together... How many and what types of strata are determined by study goals.
Then within each strata, and within PSUs, you sample Software can make the adjustment... A few different approaches with the easiest being the Taylor Series approach Use primary sampling unit (PSU) and strata variables in the data file. The strata and PSU identifiers are often associated with a specific sampling weight variable. For example, in the ECLS-K the weight C1CW0 has the following strata and PSU: C1TVWSTR and C1TCWPSU svyset PSU [pweight = WEIGHT], strata(STRATA) Then use svy: before your subsequent commands (e.g., svy: tab or svy: mean or svy: regress) svy: will NOT work with all commands svy: mean and mean [weight = weight] yield the same mean estimates‚Ä¶ it is the SEs that are different)

Weights should be used when analyzing data from national samples; otherwise, you cannot make claims about representativeness The appropriate weight should be selected based on: Level of analysis Round (s) of data Source (s) of data There may not be a 'perfect' weight for many analyses All statistical tests should be based on standard errors that account for complex sample design
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/7. Sampling & Complex Designs.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 6. Variable Selection & Data Relationships
item.description:
Big data allows for complex analyses and many (undocumented) decisions are made during the research project, including what IV, DV, and covariates to include.


https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/p-hacking/ What are covariates and why do we include them? Conditioning on such risk factors is necessary to remove bias. Do NOT use p-values to determine covariate inclusion. Use a priori theory! Achieving statistical significance with covariates and without transparency
As you are making decisions regarding your variables, consider the following questions: How will constructs be operationalized? What items will be used and which measures are critical to the tests? If multiple measures are available, what will be done? These issues often require quite a bit of conceptual considerations and defending in the peer-review process. In big datasets, measures are often abbreviated. Measurement problems arise when The concept to be measured are vague or poorly defined Indicators are imperfect measures of the underlying construct Individual responses are inaccurate (e.g., distraction, illness, poor comprehension) Errors lead to erroneous values Accuracy The closeness of the measurement to the true value Bias A systematic variation of measurements from the quality being measured Precision The closeness of repeated measurements to one another

Inaccurate and unreliable measurement results in serious concerns regarding the Validity and Reliability of the hypotheses tested using given measures.
The vast majority of constructs require more than one item, Why? Low content validity (sensitivity and reliability) The primary objective of creating a series of composite scales is to avoid the exclusive use of, or dependence on, single item constructs where possible. The use of several variables as indicators provides an opportunity to represent differing facets of a given concept, with the aim of yielding a more well-rounded perspective and, arguably, a better measure. X1 = I often feel alone X2 = I am often sad X3 = I often feel like crying X4 = I cannot shake off the bluesalpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std item alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std gen (depress) alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std (depress) min(3)

Cronbach's Alpha (One metric of reliability) - 0.90 or greater = great - 0.80 - 0.89 = good - 0.70 - 0.79 = acceptable - 0.60 - 0.69 = marginal - 0.59 or less = not acceptable sem (Depress-> X1, ) (Depress-> X2, ) (Depress-> X3, ) (Depress-> X4, ) standardized latent(Depress ) nocapslatent (CFA code) factor x1 x2 x3 x4 (EFA code) Alpha approach takes the average, whereas factor approach allows different weighting of items.

Bwt_tm 5 - bag_tmx 5, as well as column wjpvwcx 5 - wjpcwcx 5 Convergent Validity
(wjpvwcx 5, bag_tmx 5) Discriminant Validity Within indicator correlations should exceed 0.50. Always look at your data Data collection issues: recording errors ~60 different ways of spelling Philadelphia in one dataset browse (stata syntax)
sum (Continuous variables)
tab (Categorical Variable)

http://guessthecorrelation.com/‚Äã Guess that correlation is a game with a purpose. It is entertaining, but data on our guesses are collected and used to analyze how we perceive correlations in scatterplots. So, the more people that play, the more data generated. Always plot your data.
Outliers are anomalous objects or values Data that have characteristics different from most others Values of an attribute that are unusual This is not just noise! An outlier is an event that is suspected of not being generated by the same mechanisms as the rest of the data.
Deviates significantly from the rest of the dataset Deviates significantly with respect to a specific context of the object The individual data objects may not be outliers, but the object as a whole deviate significantly from the entire dataset.
Departures from normality are usually not serious in large samples, but there may be some bias in standard errors and test statistics. One solution is to transform the non-normal data (e.g., log, square root, etc.) Other methods are potentially more rigorous
Estimates of standard errors are robust against non-normality because assumptions of Normality are relaxed. Several different ways to get robust standard errors. Huber-White sandwich method, use the option vce (robust)

Why do we test for reliability in subpopulations? Establish the psychometric properties of a new or existing measure/assessment tool Means for determining generalizeability Are we measuring the same construct in the same way across groups or across time? Increase confidence that observed differences between groups reflect true differences and not those ties to measurement. Reliability within subgroups is often assumed but rarely tested and is a big issue for many datasets that do not use previously validated meaures. Why use existing composites? Data availability: you often may not have all necessary data to create the composite Reproducibility: everyone uses the same construct Convenience: time and effort spent on identifying possible composites and determining best source of information to creating them But first, always read the user's guide and when item level data are available, check yourself!

item.title: 5. STATA Basics and Data Management
item.description:
Great for data management Very powerful and flexible, for most models. STATA can Handle Continuous, Categorical, and count variables Evaluate group differences via multiple group analysis Evaluate complex survey data and make necessary adjustments (e.g., clustering, weights) Handle missing data through full information maximum likelihood or multiple imputations
Run more basic (Regression, EFA, CFA) and more complex analyses (MLM, LGCM, GMM)
The big window Results of all STATA commands appear here (except graphs) Records all STATA commands that have been entered. A previous command can be repeated by double-clicking the command in the Review window Shows a record of all variables in the dataset Across the top of the screen
Click the (editor) button. All data are visible here. Note that no commands can be executed when the data editor is open. There are two ways to operate STATA Commands can be types directly into the Command window and executed by pressing Enter. Commands can be written in a separate file (called a do-file) and executed together in one step. List of all the commands you need for your project No need to repeat work; recreate your dataset by running the do-file Easy to correct mistakes you find later To create / edit do-file: Starting a new do-file: doedit Editing an existing do-file: doedit DOFILENAME.do Type in commands Save do-file (control + s) To use Do DOFILENAME.Do Try to be organized Use headings For all test in do-flies that are not commands, begin the line with * Log records all commands and output during the session To use: Open new log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CLOGNAME.log Write over an existing log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, replace Add to an existing log Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, append To close log Log close / cmdlog close To read a file using the command window Use "C:...\sample.dta", clear use sample.dta, clear To save a file Save "C:...\sample.dta" [, replace] Type 'browse' in the command window Column holds the variable Row holds the observation Cell of a particular variable for a particular observation is a value Allows you to edit the data The number of observations in the dataset Number of variables in the dataset The amount of memory the dataset is using and how much memory you still have to work with Basic information about the variables in our dataset
Variable name, label and type Some basic descriptive statistics for variable
The general syntax for all STATA commands is: [prefix:] cmdname [varlist] [=exp] [if exp] [in exp] [weight] [using filename] [, options] Elements in square brackets are optional for some commands Sometimes cmdname is all that is required, for example, codebook or describe STATA is case sensitive
New variables can be created using generate Gen racev2 = race New variable can contain functions or combinations of existing variables Gen income = inc1 + inc2 + inc3 You can use *, +, -, /, ^ Replace may be used to change the contents of an existing variable Replace oldvar = exp1 [if exp2] Always recommend that you do not save over original values. 'If' is used to restrict the command to a desired subset of observations: Replace race =. If race == 999 The double == sign is used to test for equality, while the single sign is used for assignment Operators can be used after if: & denotes 'and' | denotes 'or' ~ or ! Denote 'not' Rename may be used to rename variables Rename oldvarname newvarname To drop a variable or variables, type Drop varlist Alternatively, keep varlist eliminates everything but varlist To drop certain observations, use Drop if exp For example, drop if unemplrate== Dataset in memory is called 'master dataset' Dataset filename is called 'using dataset' Variables with same name will be combined Variables in only one dataset will have missing values for observations from the other dataset. To join corresponding observations from a STATA dataset with those in the dataset in memory, type: Merge 1:1 varlist using filename
If more than one observations has the same value of varlist in the master dataset, use: Merge m: 1 varlist using filename To add another STATA dataset below the end of the dataset in memory, type: Append using filename

For Mean, Standard Deviation (SD) use sum: Sum bex_tm54 For stats by subgroup, add bysort: in option section Bysort csex_m01: sum bex_tm54
For Categorical Variable s use tab: Tab csex_m01 Syntax using correlate Correlate bex_tm54 bex_tm1s bex_tmg3
pwcorr provides significance levels
Syntax using ttest ttest bex_tm54, by (csex_m01) Results using regress: Regress bex_tm 54 meducm 01 inc_6_54 csex_m01
Coef. = Beta Coefficient Std. Err. = Standard error T = Ratio of beta to standard error P>|t| = significance level [95% conf. Interval] = Confidence Interval Critial Ratio The most basic form of a statistical test of significance 1.96 for p < .05 2.58 for p < .01 3.24 for p < .001 If you know the name of a command, enter Help cmdname If you don't know it, enter Findit word 1 [word2] ... This queries a database and some of the official internet sources (such as STATA FAQs, STATA articles) Google Email or call STATA Technical services Statalist archives / forums
Check the cheat sheets (statacheatsheets.pdf)

item.title: Serial Mediation
item.description: Serial mediation (also called chain mediation) involves two or more mediators arranged in a specific sequential order. The IV affects the first mediator, which in turn affects the second mediator, and so on, eventually influencing the DV. To investigate the process by which the IV impacts the DV through a chain of mediators, highlighting the step-by-step mechanism and temporal ordering of effects. Generate scatterplots and residual vs. Predicted plots for each link: IV ‚Üí M 1, M 1 ‚Üí M 2, and M 2 ‚Üí DV. Use histograms and Q‚ÄìQ plots for residuals in each regression. Criteria: As before, look for random dispersion, skewness < |2.0|, kurtosis < |7.0|, and Durbin‚ÄìWatson between 1.5 and 2.5. There must be theoretical or empirical support for the hypothesized order (e.g., M 1 influences M 2). Run intermediate regressions (e.g., regress M 2 on M 1) and ensure that coefficients are significant (p < .05) in line with your theory. Consider and control for variables that may confound the relationships between mediators if necessary. Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Choose Model 6 (designed for serial mediation). Enter the IV, DV, and mediators in the specific sequential order. Click Options: Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals. Click OK. Path IV ‚Üí Mediator 1: Example: a 1 = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001 Path Mediator 1 ‚Üí Mediator 2: Example: d = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001 Path Mediator 2 ‚Üí DV (controlling for IV and M 1): Example: b2 = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002 Sequential Indirect Effect (IV ‚Üí M 1 ‚Üí M 2 ‚Üí DV): Calculation: a 1 √ó d √ó b 2 = 0.35 √ó 0.45 √ó 0.30 = 0.0473 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.10] (if CI does not include zero, the effect is significant, e.g., p = .018). Direct Effect (IV ‚Üí DV controlling for mediators): Example: c‚Ä≤ = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001 A serial mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 6) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to test whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] sequentially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The analysis indicated that [IV] significantly predicted [Mediator 1] (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001), and [Mediator 1] significantly predicted [Mediator 2] (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001). Furthermore, [Mediator 2] significantly predicted [DV] (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002). The sequential indirect effect was significant (b = 0.047, SE = 0.02, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10], p = .018), indicating that the effect of [IV] on [DV] was transmitted via [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] in sequence. The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001), suggesting partial mediation.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/GLM 2/Serial Mediation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Parallel Mediation
item.description: Parallel mediation involves multiple mediators that operate simultaneously. Each mediator is theorized to transmit the effect of the IV on the DV independently. To examine whether different processes (mediators) independently contribute to the effect of the IV on the DV. This model allows you to assess which mediator (s) play a significant role and to what extent. IV ‚Üí Mediator 1 ‚Üí DV IV ‚Üí Mediator 2 ‚Üí DV (Mediators do not influence one another) Generate scatterplots for DV vs. Each mediator. Run separate regression analyses for each mediator (DV as outcome, mediator as predictor) and inspect residuals vs. Predicted plots. Criteria: Residuals should show no systematic pattern. Create histograms and Q‚ÄìQ plots for the residuals of each regression. Criteria: Skewness < |2.0| and kurtosis < |7.0|. Run a correlation matrix (Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate) among the mediators. Criteria: Inter-mediator correlations should be moderate (ideally, r < 0.80) to avoid redundancy. As with simple mediation, verify study design and check the Durbin‚ÄìWatson statistic (1.5‚Äì2.5). Navigate to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX. Use Model 4; PROCESS allows entering multiple mediators simultaneously. Enter the IV, DV, and list all mediators. Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals for each indirect effect. Click OK. Example: a 1 = 0.30, b 1 = 0.40 ‚Üí Indirect effect = 0.30 √ó 0.40 = 0.12 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.03, 0.22] (significant if CI does not include zero, p = .012). Example: a 2 = 0.25, b 2 = 0.35 ‚Üí Indirect effect = 0.25 √ó 0.35 = 0.0875 Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.18] (significant, p = .025). Sum of individual indirect effects (if both are significant). Example: c‚Ä≤ = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001 A parallel mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to evaluate whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] independently mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The indirect effect through [Mediator 1] was significant (b = 0.12, SE = 0.06, 95% CI [0.03, 0.22], p = .012), as was the indirect effect through [Mediator 2] (b = 0.09, SE = 0.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.18], p = .025). The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001), suggesting that both mediators contributed uniquely to the overall relationship.‚Äù
item.guid: University Resources/Current/GLM 2/Parallel Mediation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie
