item.title: HW 3
item.description: A moderator is a variable that affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an independent variable (x) and a dependent variable (y). A mediator is a variable that explains the mechanisms or process through which an independent variable (x) affects a dependent variable (y). The purpose of the ‚Äòseed‚Äô option in a line of PROCESS syntax is to lock the random number generator. This ensures that the findings remain consistent across multiple runs of the analysis. Without specifying a ‚Äòseed‚Äô value, the random number generator would draw different values each time, leading to slightly different results. When a covariable absorbs variable from both the predictor and the error term, it can lead to: Sphericity is an assumption in repeated measures ANOVA that states the variance of the differences between all pairs of within-subject conditions (levels of the independent variable) should be equal. This means that if we have three time points (A, B, C), then the variance of (A ‚Äì B) ‚âà variance of (A ‚Äì C) ‚âà variance of (B ‚Äì C). Sphericity is a special case of homogeneity of variance assumption and is specific to repeated measures designs. Potential Consequences of Violating Sphericity Inflated Type I Errors Rate (False Positives) Standard F-tests assume sphericity, so violating it increases the risk of finding a significant effect when none actually exists. The p-values become too small, leading to incorrect conclusions. Reduced Statistical Power (False Negative) If sphericity is violated and not corrected, the test might be too conservative, making it harder to detect real effects (Type II Error: Failing to detect a true effect). Distorted F-ratios The denominator degrees of freedom in the F-test get inflated which makes the ANOVA test statistics biased. This impacts the accuracy of hypothesis testing. Long-Format Data
item.guid: University Resources/Current/GLM 2/HW/HW 3.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Repeated Measures Designs
item.description:
Repeated measures designs are an extension of the dependent group (paired samples) t-test. Paired samples t-tests are used to compare means between paired, dependent, or matched groups. Collection of data on the same persons over time means responses are related to each other, across time. They are Dependent Observations Differences from pre to post (e.g., time 1 to time 2) Often the same respondents, repeatedly measured (not always, but not our focus) In comparison, independent-groups designs look at: Differences in means across groups (often manipulated in experimental designs) Mean differences across existing groups Gender, school level, generation status (e.g., quasi-experimental designs) With repeated measures designs, the structure of the data becomes relevant. Data types Long Respondents have multiple rows of data corresponding to multiple measurement occasions Wide Respondents have one row of data Multiple variables are used to represent multiple measurement occasions GLM for repeated measures (aka repeated measures ANOVA/MANOVA) Combination of both between-and within-subjects factors are referred to as 'mixed designs' Different people are assigned to different levels of the factor Each case (person) is exposed/included to only one condition or level The same person tests all conditions (i.e., is exposed to all levels of the factor) Repeated-measures designs are 'within-subjects' designs, where each subject forms a 'group' or factor Repeated measures ANOVA SST = SS (Explained) + SS (unexplained) We are trying to explain differences in teh repeated measures due to time (or whatever the within factor is) We are removing/controlling variability due specifically to subjects. We need to characterize unexplained/residual variability carefully for repeated measures designs (i.e., through the subject x time interaction) One-Way Repeated Measures ANOVA One-Way Repeated measures ANOVA with A treatments/times and B persons includes three 'sum of squares' terms.
‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-1.png‚Äù could not be found.
Independence of Observations (e.g., people)
Normality (minimal effect if balanced design)
Homogeneity of Variance
Sphericity / Circularity Events measured closer in time tend to be more highly correlated than events measured farther apart in time. A form of compount symmetry, but less restrictive. Correlations include Greenhouse-Geisser, Huynh-Feldt
Lack of Sphericity leads to increased Type I Errors (finding false significance)
Homogeneity of Variance for the difference score, meaning variances across conditions/time are equal. Relatedly, homogeneity of covariance is equal variances and covariacnes across time. Sphericity is a tough assumption to meet, as we don't expect correlations between times 1, 3, and 5 to be necessarily the same. Mauchly's sphericity test in SPSS tests this assumption. We do NOT want this to be statistically significant. The distribution of the data will not be in line with an F-distribution Loss of statistical power Post-hoc tests become uninterpretable If violated, what should we do? Use a more conservative f-test. SPSS gives you three options increasing in conservatism Consider using MANOVA Consider using multilevel modeling Based on estimates of sphericity (Epsilon; Œµ) Ranges from 0 - 1 with higher scores meaning greater homogeneity Huynh-Feldt Correction (least conservative) Œµ > .75 Greenhouse-Geisser (more conservative) Œµ < .75 Lower-bound (most conservative) Œµ <. 75 If the results change depending on which correction used, it's a safer bet to use Greenhouse-Geisser regardless of Epsilon value (e.g., the cutoff somehow made a difference) or report both and acknowledge the difference.
Instead of time as treatment effect (univariate), MANOVA treats time as separate Dependent Variable s (multivariate) Repeated measures analyses automatically include both, but if sphericity is violated, it might be better to just use MANOVA. Repeated Measures ANOVA Univariate DV More rigid assumptions of sphericity When sphericity holds, use RM ANOVA You can look at contrasts and other post-hoc tests MANOVA Multivariate DVs Less rigid assumptions of sphericity A large violation of sphericity (Œµ < .70) and sample sizes of 10 people larger than the number of groups (j + 1), use MANOVA. The power of MANOVA varies as a function of the correlation between the DVs.
Multilevel modeling approach (aka Hierarchical Linear Models; General Linear Mixed-Effects Models) Growth curve models Predicts individual differences in change over time Time is nested within each subject Very flexible Allows for random effects and variability in measurement occasion. If the overall F for differences among treatments is statistically significant, further analysis is needed to evaluate where the significant differences are. The SPSS procedure contrasts that can be used to evaluate differences. If the repeated measure has k levels, a set of contrasts include (k - 1) comparisons Options Polynomial contrasts (the default in SPSS, but rarely used in social sciences) Repeated contrasts Simple contrasts For a study that features a control group and one or more comparison groups, the usual question is whether each of the comparison groups has a mean that differs significantly from the control group mean. For repeated measures, the control group is Time 1 (baseline). So, comparisons are made based on differences between Time 1 and all other time points. Time 1 > Time 2, Time 1 > Time 3 This set of contrasts does not provide information about all possible comparisons, as the baseline must be included in all of them.
Very similar to dummy coding in Multiple Regression, where we only know differences between the reference category and all other categories (not each other) Compare the mean of each level (except the last) with the mean of the subsequent level Time 1 > Time 2, Time 2 > Time 3 Useful if the responses are in a meaningful order (like time) Equivalence (or justifiable inequivalence) of measurement is crucial Makes more sense when the levels of the repeated-measures factor correspond to different amounts of treatment (rather than different types) If there are k levels for the repeated-measures factor, then (k - 1) polynomials will be tested. Example - Patients' responses to an anxiety drug administered over time ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-2.png‚Äù could not be found. SPSS makes it easy to restructure your data, albeit if certain parameters are in place first There must be an ID variable for every participant There must be an index variable that indicates timepoint for data There must NOT be duplication of a case within a timepoint Preferable if all cases have equal timepoints of data (makes things easier to see and is required by most analyses, though not necessarily for data restructure) Data > Restructure > Restructure Data Wizard! Ignore the words SPSS uses (they are hard to understand) and instead look at the pictures. Wide to stacked is first, and stacked to wide is second. Ignore the third one (trust me). ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-3.png‚Äù could not be found. Select your ID variable and put it as the identifier variable and select your timepoint variable and put it as your index variable. Leave everything else as default on all other pages! ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-4.png‚Äù could not be found. You need to tell SPSS how many variables you want to create. So, if the global satisfaction scale has seven items that we want combined across time, we need to say seven variables. ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-5.png‚Äù could not be found. Select your ID variable and put it as the case group identification. You could also 'use case number' and have the ID variable be a fixed variable, but I find that more troublesome. You then have to include all items to be stacked in separate blocks based on what the variable will be. You must do this for every variable to be stacked. The dataset has 129 such variables, so you can see that this will take a long time. Most of the time, stacked data comes stacked so you don't need to do this. ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-6.png‚Äù could not be found. Repeated measure design in which two (and only two) paired variables are compared to each other. Typically, Time 1 and Time 2 are compared. Dependent samples t-test assesses differences, not changes. Change/growth requires three timepoints and often longitudinal modeling is used. Analyze > Compare Means and Proportions > Paired Samples t-test Always put the second timepoint first in the list so that you are getting authentic difference score. ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-7.png‚Äù could not be found. Analyze > General Linear Model > Repeated Measures Indicate number of levels and the name of the measure being analyzed over time. Note that two levels could be assessed with dependent samples t-tests, but not if a covariate gets entered! ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-8.png‚Äù could not be found. Fill in the levels of the predictor variable with the appropriate timepoint variable. Contrasts are selected based on desired output or needs of the study. ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-9.png‚Äù could not be found. A child psychologist assessed 8 children on their fear of snakes, on a scale of 1 - 10. The children were then treated for their fear and retested at four more time points, one month apart. What is our factor? Number of levels? Number of subjects? H0: ¬µtreat 1 = ¬µtreat 2 = ¬µtreat 3 = ¬µtreat 4 There is no significant difference in the mean fear of snakes between times of treatment. H1: at least one of the ¬µ is different (not all the ¬µ are equal) There is a significant difference in mean fear of snakes between times of treatment. GLM Variables Used Go Here
/WSFACTOR=FactorName #Levels Polynomial /MEASURE=NameofMeasurement /METHOD=SSTYPE(3) /PLOT=PROFILE(FactorName) TYPE=LINE ERRORBAR=NO MEANREFERENCE=NO YAXIS=AUTO /EMMEANS=TABLES(FactorName) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /PRINT=DESCRIPTIVE ETASQ OPOWER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA=ALPHA(.05) /WSDESIGN=FactorName.GLM Baseline Treatment1 Treatment2 Treatment3 Treatment4 /WSFACTOR= TreatmentTimes 5 POLYNOMIAL /MEASURE = FearofSnakes /METHOD = SSTYPE(3) /PLOT=PROFILE(TreatmentTimes) TYPE=LINE ERRORBAR=NO   MEANREFERENCE=NO YAXIS=AUTO /EMMEANS=TABLES(TreatmentTimes) COMPARE ADJ(LSD) /Print = DESCRIPTIVE ETASQ OPOWER HOMOGENEITY /CRITERIA = ALPHA(.05) /WSDESIGN = TreatmentTimes.‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-12.png‚Äù could not be found. ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-13.png‚Äù could not be found. Assumption of Sphericity was met. Use top line ‚Äì ‚ÄúUsual‚Äù F
We reject our Null Hypothesis, F (4,28) = 9.435, p < .001. There is significant difference in the mean fear of snakes during the different treatment times. Partial Œ∑2 = .574, indicating 57.4% of the variation in the scores is accounted for by the differences in the scores. When constructing our table, we have the Between Groups Line (the line for the test that we use for our final result). We also have the Within Groups (error) line (the associated error line for whichever test we use). But what about the between persons results and the total line? Below is the Test of Between Subjects Effects We use the error line here to construct the Between Persons line ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-14.png‚Äù could not be found. As for your Total Line, we just add Extension to the dependent t-test Same individuals measured two or more times Sometimes called a Within-Subjects Design In a one-way repeated measures model, each subject responds to each level of the factor In a balanced design Each subject responds to all J levels of the factor Each of the n subjects has J scores do N = n x J Unequal cells can only happen when subjects miss the administration of one or more levels of factor A A researcher tested whether 1-hour, biweekly yoga classes increased the fitness level of eight undergraduate studnets over a 4-month period (4 levels of within-subjects factors). Students were measured at the end of each month using a 10-point fitness measure (10 being most fit). ‚Äú7. Repeated Measures Designs-10.png‚Äù could not be found. Mean: 2.625; 4.75; 5.875; 8.125
Independence
Homogeneity of Variances
Testing for Normality
Testing the Independence of Error
Sphericity This assumes that the variance of the difference scores for each pair of factor levels is the same Example: 20 children were tested at 3 rd grade, 5 th grade, and 8 th grade. The test scores were compared over time. Thus, we have 3 levels in the within-subjects factor (Time). For each pair of levels, we can obtain a st of difference scores. The sphericity assumption states that these three sets of difference scores have equal variance. If the variance of the difference scores are statistically equal then the sphericity assumption has been met. The violation of sphericity is serious for the repeated measures ANOVA The violation of sphericity is serious for the repeated measures ANOVA.
The violation causes the 'Usual' F-test to become too liberal (i.e., an increase in the Type I Errors rate). Therefore, determining whether sphericity has been violated is very important.
Luckily, if violations of sphericity do occur, corrections have been developed to produce a more valid critical F-value (i.e., reduce the increase in Type I Errors rate) Like in Levene's HOV test, the null hypothesis is the variances of difference scores are equal. Test NOT Significant (p > .05) > Assumption MET! Variances are the same. Test Significant (p < .05) > Assumption NOT met! Variances are different. Measure: Score - Tests the null hypothesis that the error covariance matrix of the orthonormalized transformed dependent variables is proportional to an identity matrix: a Design: Intercept. Within Subjects Design: CAP. Mauchly's Test of Sphericity indicates that the assumption of sphericity had been violated, , œá2 (2) = 7.916, p = .019.

Time 1 > Time 2, Time 1 > Time 3 This set of contrasts does not provide information about all possible comparisons, as the baseline must be included in all of them. Very similar to dummy coding in Multiple Regression, where we only know differences between the reference category and all other categories (not each other)

item.title: 1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis
item.description:
In the broadest sense, Secondary Data are collected by someone else
If the data were collected by the researcher for the specific purpose or analysis under consideration, it is Primary Data Traditionally, our field has downplayed the importance and value of secondary data, but times are changing. The use of secondary data has a long and rich tradition in the sociology, economies, etc. Large government-funded datasets State-wide or district-level school records Journal supplements Author websites Quantitative and Qualitative Restricted and public-use Direct (e.g., biomarker data) and indirect observations (e.g., self-report) Economics Study design and data collection already completed - saves time and money Access To international and cross-historical data would otherwise take years and millions of dollars to collect Quality Data collection process is informed by expertise and professionalism that may not be available to smaller research projects External Validity Studies funded by the government generally involve larger samples that are more representative of the target population. Statistical Power Over sampling of low prevalence groups allows for increased power and precision Breadth Datasets often contain many variables Using it is the hardest part Study design and data collection already completed Data may lack depth. The greater the breadth the harder it is to measure a construct in depth. Constructs may be defined by a single item or a subset of items that have reliability/validity concerns Posthoc measurement models maybe unsuccessful Certain fields or departments may place less value on secondary data analysis May require knowledge of survey statistics/methods which is not generally provided by basic graduate statistics courses. The temptation of a statistical fishing trip Great research is driven by a good research question that is shaped by theory Data analysis is done to refine our understanding of a topic and to develop theories by testing empirical hypotheses
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis/1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 2. Research Questions and Research Ethics
item.description:
Read @schwartzImportanceStupidityScientific2008
Read @pengArtDataScience2018
Read @davis-keanAnsweringDevelopmentalQuestions2015 Before you put pen to paper (or analyze data), formulate a research question. A research question is a statement that identifies the phenomenon to be studied. For example, "Does preschool influence children's language skills?" Why are good research questions important and what makes them 'good?' Purpose Relevance Feasibility To produce a research question, you need to know the literature first. Find out what has been done and how you can contribute to the existing literature. I have a research question. If you do not have a research question, narrow down your topic. Review the literature Is the question viable, original. feasible? You have a research question! Narrow down on an area of interest Within that area, try to answer a question that: Has either not been addressed before Has been addressed before but that you could extend (i.e., new data-set, different approach, etc.) Has been addressed but requires replication Starts a new research area (NOT recommended) Read as much as you can on the topic Read recent studies first, then read backwards Read all relevant papers (or at least the influential ones) Ideas on the research topic often come from reading The more you read, the easier it will be to come up with research questions Reviewing the literature will allow you to understand whether your question has been answered/is valid. By reading previous studies, you might get ideas on how to tweak your original research question into a new one. Whether you have or do not have a research question, it is crucial that you review the literature in the area first. Many leave the review as the last step, but this is dangerous. Not original Not feasible Time constraint (e.g., not enough time) Resources (e.g., lack of data) Knowledge (e.g., do I know method X?) Too broadly defined research question Not well justified Not motivated by literature Start searching for a topic as early as possible Once you narrow down a topic/area, look at the relevant literature (i.e., a literature review) Once you have done the literature review (has it already been done? No, why not? Is it interesting/relevant?), then ask yourself: Is the question specific (not too broad)? Is it feasible in the allotted time? Do I have enough resources (data) to answer this question? How about knowledge (methods)? Is the research question falling within my area of research? If the answer is yes to all the previous question, congratulations, you have a research question. Your time is your most important resource. Do not take a project that you will lead if it only leads to one paper (except for in very rare circumstances) Try to commit to doing 3 papers on a topic/data set More efficient time use (e.g., read similar lit) Looks good when others are evaluating your CV A good research question will Allow outsiders to see your intentions Help you develop hypotheses (not always) Contributes to existing knowledge Contribution does not have to be huge Replication is a contribution Filling a gap is not enough justification, why does this gap matter? Guide the design of your methods Allow the target population to be identified Identify the outcome variables and key predictors of those variables Determine what type of study is needed (e.g., descriptive, correlational, experimental) Identify background characteristics that might influence predictors and outcomes Raise questions about how to best collect data Influence the number of participants in the study Writing a good question is an iterative process What do you want to learn about? Draft and redraft with increasing specificity using the guidelines listed above. Ask for feedback from colleagues (science is a collective effort). Build on the work of others by conducting a systematic literature review. This is a key writing skill that you will need to do for every paper you write. Hook the reader in. Practice! Explain the larger context that this study will inform. Start big and then work down to the end of the paragraph to set up something more specific that is important to know. Flows directly from the earlier points in paragraph 1. If studying X is important, then here is what I am doing. State the basic aims, hypotheses, questions, and give the briefest overview of the data and methods (focusing on strengths) Explain the potential impact of the specific things you lay out in the prior paragraph - could be theoretically, in terms of policy, filling holes, etc. Can be combined with paragraph 2 in some cases. "The scientific literature is our institutional memory. It is important that this literature accurately reflect what happened, who did it, and to what extend one observation is independent of another." - Dennis McInerney
Double Publication involves publishing the same data more than once.
Piecemeal Publication involves dividing the report of a research project into multiple articles. The articles cannot be integrated into one Each article has a distinct purpose Duplicate and piecemeal publications are misleading and distort the scientific literature.
Publication ethics disallow duplicate publication (Publication Ethics: Plagiarism, Self-Plagiarism, Duplicate Publication, and Piecemeal Publication - Julia Muennich Cowell, 2017) A researcher was interested in changes in marital quality and recruited a sample of newlywed couples and annually collected data from them over five years. The main question of interest was the extent to which personality traits at the time of marriage predict marital satisfaction and marital commitment post marriage. The researcher wrote two papers. One focused on the prediction of marital satisfaction, and the other focused on the prediction of marital commitment. The design of the study was he same in each paper, with the exception of the change in outcomes. Piecemeal A researcher recruited newlyweds and planned annual assessments over a five years. Some measures were assessments over a five years. Some measures were common to each annual assessment, whereas others common to each annual assessment, whereas others were not. After the first wave of data collection, she wrote were not. After the first wave of data collection, she wrote an article regarding the relation between divorce history an article regarding the relation between divorce history and marital satisfaction. After three waves of data and marital satisfaction. After three waves of data collection, she wrote an article on how couples who made collection, she wrote an article on how couples who made the transition to parenthood differed in changes in marital the transition to parenthood differed in changes in marital satisfaction from those who did not experience the satisfaction from those who did not experience the transition. After five waves of data collection, she wrote a transition. After five waves of data collection, she wrote a third article on the predictors of marital dissolution. The third article on the predictors of marital dissolution. The researcher decided to publish these as three separate researcher decided to publish these as three separate articles. Not Piecemeal Researcher B was interested in the relation between family process and adolescent adjustment. She conducted and published a study in which the main conducted and published a study in which the main objective was to identify specific family processes that objective was to identify specific family processes that mediated the relation between family structure and mediated the relation between family structure and adjustment. Later, she read a new study that proposed that two of the family processes that she studied had an interactive effect on adjustment. Although such an interactive effect was not of interest in the original study, interactive effect was not of interest in the original study, in additional analyses she found that such an effect did occur in her sample, although in a slightly different than in the newly published article. She wrote a second article to address this issue. Not Piecemeal A researcher was interested in the extent to which support for marriage from family and friends affects rating of relationship quality. He collected data from a large convenience sample. Although not planned, the sample contained about 60% of persons in their first marriages and 40% of persons in remarriages. The researcher prepared two papers that examined the question of interest. In the first paper, he used data from the first-marriage subjects, whereas in the second paper he used data from the remarried subjects. The variables assessed and reported in the two papers were the same. Piecemeal A researcher was interested in the links between family structure and child adjustment. The researcher administered a survey to high school students. She discovered that there were large numbers in two-biological parent, single divorced mother, and stepfather families, but very few students were in the single divorced father and stepmother families as part of the survey, students in stepfamilies answered survey items regarding the parenting behaviors of their stepparents as well as of their parents. She wrote two papers. The first examined differences in adjustment in children from two-biological parent, single divorced mother, and stepfather families (the groups with the largest sample sizes). To facilitate the interpretation of family structure effects, she decided to exclude the rather small number of students in the second paper, she explored whether children's adjustment was related to how they rated the parenting behaviors of their parents and stepparents. Not Piecemeal A researcher was interested in rates of divorce in first-marriages and remarriages in different countries. She obtained data from an international organization that contained information on a number of different countries and wrote two papers. The first addressed the divorce rates in these two kinds of couples in Canada, and the second dealt with the same issue in England. The same theoretical rationale and measures were used in both papers, although the results led to different conclusions. Piecemeal Focus on quality and not quantity of publications Replicate the study with a different sample, setting, or methodology. Do this if most of the past research you have read examines one type of sample, setting, or method. Examine the topic using a different design. If the study was a quasi- or non-experimental, conduct an experiment. Do this if causation has not been consistently established by past research, or it has not been consistently established with the population you are interested in. Examine how another variable might impact results Do this if you have research evidence to suggest that results may depend on another variable. Conduct a similar study with a different outcome or dependent variable. Do this if you find research evidence supporting the new associations you plan to examine. Being first is not always a sign of being a good scientist Many discoveries are wrong or over claimed. You do not show you are a great scientist by being the first to claim something. A large part of getting over being scooped is getting over yourself and realizing that science is bigger than any one of us. It also means you are doing something other people care about. If you are scooped, do not be discouraged. It is unlikely that any two researchers would address a question in the exact same way.

item.title: @schwartzImportanceStupidityScientific2008
item.description: Bibliography: Schwartz, M. A. (2008). The importance of stupidity in scientific research. Journal of Cell Science, 121(11), 1771‚Äì1771. https://doi.org/10.1242/jcs.033340 Type: Journal Article Title: The importance of stupidity in scientific research, Author: Schwartz, Martin A.; Journal: Journal of Cell Science, Volume: 121, Issue: 11 Pages: 1771-1771 Year: 2008 DOI: 10.1242/jcs.033340 ISSN: 1477-9137, 0021-9533 Keywords: Read Science makes me feel stupid too. It's just that I've gotten used to it. So used to it, in fact, that I actively seek out new opportunities to feel stupid. I wouldn't know what to do without that feeling. I even think it's supposed to be this way. Henry Taube (who won the Novel Prize two years later) told me he didn't know how to solve the problem I was having in his area. I was a third-year graduate student and I figured that Taube knew about 1000 times more than I did (conservative estimate). If he didn't have the answer, nobody did. That's when it hit me: nobody did. That's why it was a research problem. And being my research problem, it was up to me to solve. The crucial lesson was that the scope of things I did not know was, for all practical purposes, infinite. That realization, instead of being discouraging, was liberating. If our ignorance is infinite, the only possible course of action is to muddle through as best we can. We just don't know what we're doing. We can't be sure whether we're asking the right answer or doing the right experiment until we get the answer or the result. Doing significant research is intrinsically hard and changing departmental, institutional or national policies will not succeed in lessening its intrinsic difficulty. We don't do a good enough job of teaching our students how to be productively stupid - that is, if we don't feel stupid it means we're not really trying. Science involves confronting our 'absolute stupidity.' that kind of stupidity is an existential fact, inherent in our efforts to push our way into the unknown. Preliminary and thesis exams have the right idea when the faculty committee pushes until the student starts getting the answers wrong or gives up and says, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know‚Äô. The point of the exam isn‚Äôt to see if the student gets all the answers right. If they do, it‚Äôs the faculty who failed the exam. The point is to identify the student‚Äôs weaknesses, partly to see where they need to invest some effort and partly to see whether the student‚Äôs knowledge fails at a sufficiently high level that they are ready to take on a research project. Productive stupidity means being ignorant by choice. The more comfortable we become with being stupid, the deeper we will wade into the unknown and the more likely we are to make big discoveries.

item.title: @pengArtDataScience2018
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: The Art of Data Science, Author: Peng, Roger D; Matsui, Elizabeth; Year: 2018 Keywords: In Progress The thinking begins before you even look at a dataset, and it's well worth devoting careful thought to your question. This point cannot be over-emphasized as many of the 'fatal' pitfalls of data analysis can be avoided by expending the mental energy to get your question right. There are six basic types of questions. Descriptive Exploratory Inferential Predictive Causal Mechanistic Understanding the type of question you are asking may be the most fundamental step you can take to ensure that, in the end, your interpretation of the results is correct. The type of question you are asking directly informs how you interpret your results. A descriptive question is one that seeks to summarize a characteristic of a set of data. There is no interpretation of the result itself as the result is a fact, an attribute of the set of data that you are working with. An exploratory question is one in which you analyze the data to see if there are patterns, trends, or relationships between variables. These types of analyses are also called 'hypothesis-generating' analyses because rather than testing a hypothesis as would be done with an inferential, causal, or mechanistic question, you are looking for patterns that would support proposing a hypothesis. An inferential question would be a restatement of this proposed hypothesis as a question and would be answered by analyzing a different set of data. A predictive question would be one where you ask what types of people will eat a diet high in fresh fruits and vegetables during the next year. In this type of question you are less interested in what causes someone to eat a certain diet, just what predicts whether someone will eat this certain diet. A causal question asks about whether changing one factor will change another factor, on average, in a population. Sometimes the underlying design of the data collection, by default, allows for the question that you ask to be causal. In other instances, even if your data are not from a randomized trial, you can take an analytic approach designed to answer a causal question. A question that asks how a diet high in fresh fruits and vegetables leads to a reduction in the number of viral illnesses would be a mechanistic question. By necessity, many data analyses answer multiple types of questions. If a data analysis aims to answer an inferential question, descriptive and exploratory questions must also be answered during the process of answering the inferential question. The type of question you ask is determined in part by the data available to you (unless you plan to conduct a study and collect the data needed to do the analysis). If this type of data set does not exist, then the best you may be able to do is either apply causal analysis methods to observational data or instead answer an inferential question about diet and viral illness. Establish your expectations about the question Gathering information about your question Determining if your expectations match the information you gathered, and then refining your question (or expectations) if your expectations did not match the information you gathered. There are five key characteristics of a good question for a data analysis, which range from the very basic characteristic that the question should not have already been answered to the more abstract characteristic that each of the possible answers to the question should have a single interpretation and be meaningful. The question should be of interest to your audience, the identity of which will depend on the context and environment in which you are working with data. You should also check that the question has not already been answered. With the recent explosion of data, the growing amount of publicly available data, and the seemingly endless scientific literature and other resources, it is not uncommon to discover that your question of interest has been answered already. The question should also stem from a plausible framework. If you ask a question whose framework is not plausible, you are likely to end up with an answer that's difficult to interpret or have confidence in. Many questions are raised about the result itself: is it really correct?, why are these things correlated- is there another explanation?, and others. You can ensure that your question is grounded in a plausible framework by using your own knowledge of the subject area and doing a little research, which together can go a long way in terms of helping you sort out whether your question is grounded in a plausible framework. The question, should also, of course, be answerable. Specificity is also an important characteristic of a good question. Working towards specificity will refine your question and directly inform what steps to take when you start looking at data. With this degree of specificity, your plan of attack is much clearer and the answer you will get at the end of the data analysis will be more interpretable as you will either recommend or not recommend the specific action. Another aspect to consider when you‚Äôre developing your question is what will happen when you translate it into a data problem. Every question must be operationalized as a data analysis that leads to a result. Pausing to think through what the results of the data analysis would look like and how they might be interpreted is important as it can prevent you from wasting a lot of time embarking on an analysis whose result is not interpretable. The typical type of question that does not meet this criterion is a question that uses inappropriate data. The problem with this question is that for a single possible answer, there are multiple interpretations. This scenario of multiple interpretations arises when at least one of the variables you use is not a good measure of the concept you are truly after. To head off this problem, you will want to make sure that the data available to answer your question provide reasonably specific measures of the factors required to answer your question. A related problem that intergeres with interpretation of results is confounding. Confounding is a potential problem when your question asks about the relationship between factors. A brief description of the concept of confounding is that it is present when a factor that you were not necessarily considering in your question is related to both your exposure of interest and your outcome of interest. As you refine your question, spend time identifying the potential confounders and thinking about whether your dataset includes information about these potential confounders. Another type of problem that can occur when inappropriate data are used is that the result is not interpretable because the underlying way in which the data were collected lead to a biased result. The other major bias to understand and consider when refining your question is selection bias, which occurs when the data your are analyzing were collected in such a way to inflate the proportion of people who have both characteristics above what exists in the general population. A good rule of thumb is that if you are examining relationships between two factors, bias may be a problem if you are more (or less) likely to observe individuals with both factors because of how the population was selected, or how a person might recall the past when responding to a survey. The best time to consider its effects on your data analysis is when you are identifying the question you will answer and thinking about how you are going to answer the question with the data available to you.

item.title: @davis-keanAnsweringDevelopmentalQuestions2015
item.description:
Bibliography: Davis‚ÄêKean, P. E., Jager, J., & Maslowsky, J. (2015). Answering Developmental Questions Using Secondary Data. Child Development Perspectives, 9(4), 256‚Äì261. https://doi.org/10.1111/cdep.12151 Type: Journal Article Title: Answering Developmental Questions Using Secondary Data, Author: Davis‚ÄêKean, Pamela E.; Jager, Justin; Maslowsky, Julie; Journal: Child Development Perspectives, Volume: 9, Issue: 4 Pages: 256-261 Year: 2015 DOI: 10.1111/cdep.12151 ISSN: 1750-8592, 1750-8606 Secondary data analysis of large longitudinal and national data sets is a standard method used in many social sciences to answer complex questions regarding behavior. In this article, we detail the advantages of using these data sets to study developmental questions across the life span. First, we provide an overview of how using secondary data can increase studies‚Äô scientiÔ¨Åc integrity. Then, we detail where and how data sets can be obtained that answer speciÔ¨Åc questions. Finally, we discuss methodological issues related to using longitudinal, population data sets. These data sets can enhance science and test theories by increasing the rigor and generalizability of research to the general population, making secondary data analysis an important method to consider. Keywords: Need to Read Primary data are collected by an individual or a team of researchers and are often based on the theory or models of the researcher or research team. These data are also generally proprietary and not shared with the larger research community. In contrast, secondary data analysis uses data collected by other researchers or organizations, and the users are generally not part of the design of the study. These data sets (e.g., most national studies) have been collected for the use of the research community or have been made available for other researchers to use (e.g., in data archives). These data sets were collected based on the research theories and models of the primary researchers and include extensive measurements on the areas of interest to the research team. Although some data sets remain proprietary to the original researcher or research team, new regulations on data sharing from the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation are increasing the amount of data available for secondary data analysis. Many secondary data sets contain similarities in measurement that allow many data sets to be combined using techniques such as integrative data analysis, a technique that is especially useful for data sets that represent highly selective groups (e.g., children of alcoholics) that would be difficult to find in a general population sample. Combining the data sets increases the sample size and thus the power to examine these groups. Using secondary data sets, especially those collected at the population level, increases statistical power and external validity as a result of a larger sample size and greater diversity of respondents (with regard to race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status). This advantage, combined with reducing the time and money it takes to collect one's own longitudinal data, makes secondary data analysis a good option. These data resources are easy to obtain. In the US, the two largest social science data archives are the Interuniversity Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) and the Murray Research Archive.
ICPSR requires affiliation with a member institution. Some data sets are available for immediate download while others require an application explaining the scientific purpose for data use. Data are generally free though fees may apply for digitization of not-yet digital materials or other labor-intensive data-preparation tasks. Archives are easily searchable, including the ability to search by study topic or variable name. Searching by study topic is helpful when the researcher is looking for studies focused on a specific subject. Searching by variable name is helpful when the researcher is looking for studies focused on a specific subject. Searching for variable name is helpful when the researcher is interested in a particular variable, such as rates of endorsement or forms of measurement of a variable across studies. Most archives allow researchers to perform basic descriptive analyses online before downloading a data set, including frequency counts for each variable and tabular analysis. Scientists can determine whether a variable of interest has a large enough sample size, enough variance in responses, or not too much missing data for the new study. Such online analyses are also useful for testing a new hypothesis before collecting new data on the topic or performing preliminary analyses for grant applications. The most important step is to read all the data documentation - text documents posted in the data archive alongside the data. Understanding and properly accounting for the sampling frame and necessary weights are crucial in producing accurate results, and the study documentation contains the necessary information. Secondary data rarely have all the measures to answer investigators' questions. Using data that have been collected by others typically means that measures for some of the constructs germane to the research question will be missing. Because population data sets typically measure a broad set of constructs with limited measurement on any given construct, they often are not ideal for answering nuanced questions that require in-depth measurement. Once a researcher has addressed the issue of obtaining the data set or sets to address his or her research questions and whether they adequately answer the relevant research questions, additional statistical issues must be considered in analyzing this data. Because oversampling of one or more subpopulations is common in population-based studies, researchers often must apply a same weight if they want their findings to generalize to the target population. Subpopulations that are underrepresented in the sample relative to the target population have sample weights larger than 1.0, while the opposite holds for subpopulations overrepresented in the sample relative to the target population. When no sample weights are applied, it is as if a sample weight of 1.0 is uniformly applied to all subpopulations. In effect, this assumes all subpopulations are represented accurately within the sample, leading to biased estimates when this assumption does not hold. Typically, the appropriate set of sample weights and its corresponding variable name are identified clearly within a data set's documentation files.
In contrast to sample weights, which adjust for Sampling Bias, attrition weights correct for bias introduced by attrition. The objective of attrition weights is to render the Wave 2 sample comparable to the full Wave 1 sample. Mathematically, attrition weights are the inverse of the likelihood of being lost to attrition or dropping out: P (Wave 1) / (Wave 2) Combination weights (also called longitudinal weights) adjust for both sampling bias and attrition bias. Mathematically, combination weights are the inverse of the likelihood of being sampled (i.e., the sample weight) multiplied by the inverse of the likelihood of being lost to attrition (i.e., the attrition weight): [P (target population) / P (sample)] x [P (Wave 1) / P (Wave 2)]. We suggest avoiding the use of attrition weights (either alone or as a part of combination weights) and instead of using full information maximum likelihood (FIML), or multiple imputation (MI) to adjust for attrition bias and then use the appropriate sample weight to adjust for sampling bias. We make this recommendation because relative to FIML and MI, attrition weights (including combination weights) have two disadvantages: Unlike FIML and MI, attrition weights often sharply reduce the analytical sample size and, thereby, statistical power. Typically, only those participants with data at every wave are assigned an attrition weight and used in subsequent analyses. This problem is compounded as a study's number of waves (and therefore attrition) increases. Second, if many auxiliary variables (i.e., non-model variables related to missing data) are incorporated, FIML and MI may adjust for attrition bias more effectively than attrition weights. Most statistical packages can use FIML, including STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS, and AMOS, and many use MI (e.g., STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS). Most large-scale data sets were collected using complex sample designs that entail a clustered sampling design (e.g., schools are randomly sampled and then all students within the selected schools are sampled).
Because a clustered sampling design reduces variance (e.g., 100 students from the same school are likely more similar to one another demographically than are 100 students from 100 different schools), it also reduces standard errors and thereby inflates the change for Type I Errors. To adjust for these design effects, a primary sampling unit variable (e.g., schools) and potentially a stratification variable are incorporated into analyses. Most statistical packages (e.g., STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS) can adjust for a complex sampling design and typically the appropriate primary sampling unit and, if necessary, stratification variables are clearly identified within a data set's documentation files.

item.title: Midterm
item.description: The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The family's holistic quality represents the unique entity created by the combination of individual members. The parts of a system work together to create something new and distinct. (Think of a cake. When the individual ingredients are combined, they create something totally new. Each ingredient plays a unique part in the quality of the cake as they interact). In family systems, these new systems-level properties or behaviors emerge as a result of the transactions of the parts and are known as emergent properties rather than purely summative qualities Family systems are comprised of interdependent parts. When one part of the system changes, all parts will be affected. Reverberations can be felt throughout the system. Family systems are self-reflexive and self-regulating. Systems are cybernetic and utilize feedback to maintain themselves and to achieve goals. While early family systems theorists focused on families' inclinations toward homeostasis or change resistance, contemporary theorists also note adaptive changes made possible as a result of family self-regulation. Communication in human systems facilitated the family's ability to create meaning, monitor behavior and attain goals, and modify plans and future goal-directed activities based on feedback. Individual and family behavior must be understood in context. Family systems have boundaries that demarcate families from their environments, indicating who is in and out of the family system. A family receives input or 'energy, matter, and information' from its environment returns output to the environment. This interchange of inputs and outputs generates change for both the family and the environment in which it is nested. One central means through which Americans seek to fulfill their needs is through their marriage, especially as their access to nonspousal significant others has declined. Since the nation's founding, the extend to which Americans look to their marriage to help them fulfill their lower needs has decreased, whereas the extent to which they look to their marriage to help them fulfill their higher needs has increased. Just as the pursuit of higher needs frequently requires substantial insight into the self, looking to the marriage to help individuals fulfill their higher needs frequently requires that each spouse have substantial insight into the partner, and the development of such insight typically requires considerable communication and responsiveness over a sustained period. Even as Americans increasingly look to their marriage to help them fulfill their higher needs, they have, on average, reduced their investment of time and psychological resources in their marriage. In conjunction, the resource imbalance resulting from the trends described in tenets 2, 3 and 4 - insufficient investment to meet the emphasis on higher needs - has undermined spouses' marital quality and personal well-being (although those spouses who manage to invest sufficient resources experience especially strong marital quality and personal well-being). Spouses experiencing the adverse effects described in Tenet 5 have 3 general options for ameliorating or reversing these consequences: optimizing their usage of the resources that are available, increasing their investment of time and psychological resources in their marriage, and asking less of the marriage in terms of facilitating their higher needs. Suffocation model applying to more than just romantic relationshipsFamily System TheorySuffocation of Marriage ModelCompare and contrast two theoretical or conceptual perspectives that we have discussed in class to study a research topic or question of your choice in family science. How do the theoretical assumptions, methods used, and interpretation differ for these two different approaches? Which approach seems to you to be best supported by current data? What new directions do you recommend for future research in this area?You will need to support your arguments with additional citations beyond the article we have discussed in class. The additional reading section for each week in the syllabus will provide some relevant citations, but you will also need to identify your own citations as well. The paper should be: 5-7 double-spaced pages, excluding references 12-pt font and 1-inch margins Follow APA 7 format. Abraham Maslow, a psychologist, developed a 'Hierarchy of Needs' framework to show human potential (1943). He argues that a human being cannot achieve 'self-actualization' at the top of the hierarchy without having first met his needs at the lower levels. Bennet & Shangreaux (2005) 'Physiological' Needs These needs that are the most dominant of all needs. The human being who is missing everything in life in an extreme fashion is most likely motivated to meet his physiological needs first, before turning his energy and attention to others needs. Safety Needs A human being requires a sense of safety in society wherein he feels protected. Love Needs Love, affection, and sense of belongingness in order to feel complete. A human being requires a family, friends, and sense of belonging in order to feel complete. Esteem Needs Human beings have a need or desire for self-respect and self-esteem, or a high evaluation of themselves. Human beings are motivated by the need to avhieve and the desire for freedom, independence, strength, mastery, and confidence in the face of the world. Human kind is also motivated by the need to be respected by other people, by a desire for reputation or prestige, recognition, attention, importance, and appreciation. Satisfying the self-esteem need leads to feelings of self-confidence and self-worth, while thwarting these needs produces feelings of inferiority and helplessness. Self-Actualization Need Self-actualization is a desire for self-fulfillment, a desire to be all that a person can potentially be.
