item.title: 2. Strategic Family Therapy
item.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on Schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute (MRI). The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of Milton Erikson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated. Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem' He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results. Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of the symptoms his clients presented. In therapy: Accepted and emphasized positive Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal continuous actions. The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson (As a consultant)
Virginia Satir
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin Strategic Therapy is any type of therapy where the therapist initiates what happens during therapy and designs a particular approach for each problem. Strategic therapy isn't a particular approach or theory, but a name for the types of therapy where the therapist takes responsibility for directly influencing people. Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions. Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change. The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships. Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse. People are always communicating. All behavior is communicative. One cannot not communicate. All messages have report and command functions Report = Content = information = (What is said) Command = Process = underlying relationship = How it is said If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem. Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others. The approach is non-normative and complaint-based. Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse. The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship. The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as how, they view the problem, themselves, and each other. Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint. The model is called 'Strategic' because the therapist intervenes to interrupt ironic processes deliberately, on the basis of a case-specific plan that sometimes includes counter-intuitive suggestions Go slow Engage in behavior they want to eliminate What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse. The problems clients bring to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family. If problem-maintaining behavior is appropriately changed or eliminated, the problem will be resolved or vanish, regardless of its nature, origin, or duration. How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated. The persistence of the problem depends mainly on social interaction. The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others. How a family goes about trying to solve a problem usually plays a crucial role in perpetuating it.
Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (Positive Feedback loops) that maintain an impasse.
Families are stuck in a spiraling Positive Feedback loop. They make common-sense but ineffective attempts to change responses. For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums.
Family Rules: The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability.
Homeostasis:
The conservative aspect of family systems (similar to Cybernetics concept of Negative Feedback)
Circular Causality
Feedback Loops
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change
Hierarchical Structure
Prescribing Ordeals Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior When tules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes (First-Order Change)
When the rules of the system change (Second-Order Change) Rules are changed through reframes. Centerpiece of the model Families encounter many difficulties over the course of their lives, whether a difficulty becomes a problem depends on how fmaily members respond to it. Families often make misguided attempts to solve their difficulties and, on finding that the problem persists, apply more of the same attempted solutions. This produces an escalation of the problem, which provokes more of the same, in a vicious cycle. What often needs to happen? Reverse the solution!
Paradoxical Injunction:
A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
Reframing: Changing the interpretation.
Identify Feedback Loop s that maintain problems. Determine the rules that support those interactions. Find a way to change the rules in order to interrupt problem-maintaining behavior. Do not regard any particular way of functioning, relating, or living as a problem if the client is not expressing content with it. How problems develop: Cybernetic:
Difficulties turn into chronic problems by misguided solutions, forming Positive Feedback escalations. Structural: Problems are the result of incongruous hierarchies. Functional: Problems result when people try to protect or control one another covertly, so that their symptoms serve a function for the system. Once the presenting problem is resolved, therapy is concluded. If a family didn't ask for help with other issues, they aren't targeted. The job is simply to get the family moving again. Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful. In pushing family members to set concrete goals, they are forced to clarify vague dissatisfactions. The primary goal is behavior change. Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems.
Mental Research Institute (MRI): The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them.
Jay Haley: Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around) Milan: Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently. Define a resolvable complaint. Obtain a very specific behavioral picture of the complaint. Who sees it as a problem? Why is it a problem now? "What is the problem that brings you here today?" is too vague. Inquire about exactly what these complaints mean. Identify attempted solutions that maintain the complaint. Once the problem had been defined, the therapist tries to determine who has tried to solve it and how. The solution is part of the problem. Prescribe some alternative behavior! The key is to stop the performance of the problem-maintaining solution. MRI Approach: Introduction to the treatment setup Inquiry and definition of the problem Estimation of the behavior maintaining the problem Setting goals for treatment Selecting and making behavioral interventions Termination Attempted solutions: The solution is deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. For instance, parents do nothing necessary despite the growing evidence that their teenage son is using drugs. The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it shouldn't be. For example, parents punish a child for masturbating. The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes a solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. For instance, a husband buys gifts for his wife when what she wants is affection. Solutions that perpetuate problems fall into three categories: When clients deny that a problem exists (example: anorexia) ACT When clients try to solve something that really isn't a problem (example: punishing a child for masturbating) STOP ACTING When clients try to solve a problem within a framework that make a solution impossible (example: husband buys gifts for his wife, rather than giving her the affection she desires) DIFFERENT ACTIONS Understand the clients' unique language for describing the problem. To interrupt problem-maintaining sequences, therapists may try to do something that runs counter to common sense. Paradoxical interventions: The therapist directs the family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain. If they rebel, they give up their symptom(s). Most common symptom prescriptions where the family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Hope is that the family will comply and then be forced to reverse their attempted solution. May also hope the client rebels against the therapist's advice. Restraining technique: Warning clients against changing to fast and relapse; reinforced the therapist's one-down position. The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive. As soon as a family member is overwhelmed, they are instructed to make a list of all the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive. Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably. Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur. Perhaps you should continue to wake Ricky up for school, after all, you don't want to push him to be too responsible too soon. The main thing is to discover what families are doing to perpetuate the problem and then get them to do something different. Co-founded the Family Therapy Institute of Washington D.C. (1974) Hayley learned from:
Milton Erikson
Gregory Bateson
Salvador Minuchin
He adopted and modified Milton Erikson 's individual emphasis to work with families. Concerned with the function a symptom served.
Examined rules and structure of a family (influenced by Salvador Minuchin). Hayley was particularly concerned with power struggles, and often prescribed the symptom such that the cost of keeping it up outweighed the gains. Madanes was concerned with incongruence hierarchies, where a child uses symptoms to change the behavior of the parent. Family Life: Over and covert rules families use to govern themselves
Family Homeostasis: Tendency of the family to remain in its same pattern of functioning unless challenged to do otherwise.
Quid Pro Quo: The responsiveness of family members to treating others in the way they are treated.
Redundancy Principle: Fact that a family interacts within a limited range of repetitive behavioral sequences.
Punctuation: Idea that people in a transaction believe what they say is caused by what others say.
Symmetrical Relationship s: Relationships within a family are both among equals (symmetrical) and unequals (complementary).
Circular Causality: Idea that one event does not 'cause' another but that events are interconnected and there are multiple factors behind a behavior. To resolve, remove, or ameliorate the problem the family agreed to work on. Behavioral, concerned with the immediate problem, and anti-insight. Structural re-organization of the family, like the structural therapies, but with sub-goals to deal with the presenting problem. Process, not content-focused. Emphasize short term treatment (10 sessions) Define a problem clearly Investigating all solutions that have previously been tried Defining a clear and concrete change to be achieved Formulating and implementing a strategy for change Therapists must be innovative Therapy must be customizable to families (technique driven) If families are going to change, alterations in ways their members act must precede new perceptions or feelings Focus on interpersonal payoff of psychiatric symptoms Social Stage: Introduction and setup Help everyone relax, greet each family member, make sure everyone is comfortable. Problem Stage: Definition of the problem in clear behavioral terms Ask each individual for their perspective, speak to the less involved parent/partner first to get their involvement, listen carefully to the way each family member describes the problem, make sure no one interrupts until each has a turn, make observations. Emphasize the use of directives. If therapy is to end well, it must begin proper. Interaction Stage: Estimation of the behaviors maintaining the problem Encourage family members to discuss their points of view among themselves, observe rather than just hearing about the interchanges that surround the problem, look for coalitions between family members against others, how functional is the hierarchy and do family members work together as a team or undercut one another? Goal Setting Stage Providing directives Give the family a task, directives Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior. "The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." For instance, a child's misbehavior can be reframed as his way of asking for attention, not an indication of disrespect. Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions: "Who makes you depressed?" "What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?" Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change. Where a symptom is often seen as a metaphor for an underlying problem. Example: A school problem in a child may mirror a work problem in a parent. Mandanes talked about how one relationship may metaphorically replicate another and power struggles in couples (money, education, control of children, etc.) Negotiation (pg. 90)
Quid Pro Quo (pg. 91) Pretend techniques (pg. 91) Ordeals (pg. 91) Hayley believed that telling people what they're doing wrong only mobilizes resistance. Changes in behavior alter perceptions. Milan group was interested in getting families to see things differently through (reframe) positive connotation. Which then gets family members to behave differently. Shift from behavior to cognition set stage for constructivist/narrative movements. Families should have clear generational boundaries. Therapists should be 'neutral' and not have expectations for families. Therapy helps the family by simply examining the family, asking questions to help them examine their own family structure, and exposing games after which they can redesign their family into a better structure on their own.
Mara Selvini Palazzoli
Gianfranco Cecchin Presession: Generate initial hypothesis of presenting problem. Session: Validate, modify, and change the hypothesis. Intersession: Team discussion of hypothesis and arrival at an intervention. Intervention: Delivery of the intervention to the family. Postsession: Team discussion to analyze the family's reactions and to plan for next session. Highly scripted. Families treated by co-therapists and observed by other members of the team.
Positive Connotations Must include the entire family system and confirm the behavior of all family members as maintaining the stability and cohesion of the group.
Rituals: Engage families in a series of actions that ran counter to or exaggerated rigid family rules. Define the complaint in specific behavioral terms. Set minimum goals for change. Investigate solutions to the complaints. Concentrate on the 'less of the same.' Understand clients' preferred views. Use these views to suggest 'less of the same' Nurture and solidify initial change. Frequency of sessions intended to maximize the likelihood that change will be durable. Typically patter of brief (e.g., weekly, tapering off) Therapy ends when the treatment goals have been attained (and change seems reasonably stably?) Co-therapists work as a team (e.g., observing behind the mirror, leaving the room to consult) Late in session, the therapist may leave so the team can help the therapist plan a homework assignment or framing intervention. The essential role of the therapist is to persuade the family to 'do less of the same' solution that keeps the complaint going. Treatment is likely to go awry if the therapist is not in control of it. Good strategic therapists rarely exert control directly in the sense of offering authoritative prescriptions or assuming the role of an expert. Taking a 'one down position' and a stance of empathetic curiosity. I'm a little slow on the uptake here, so could you help me understand again what it is you do when he raises his voice that way? I don't know if doing this when he walks through the door will make much of a difference, but if you could try it once or twice this week, at least we'll have an idea what we're up against. Emapthetic restraint (e.g., go slow) is used to neutralize apprehension and resistance to change. When clients fail to follow a suggestion, a common response is for the therapist to take the blame (e.g., I think I suggested that prematurely) and seek alternative routes to the same strategic objective. While the model does not emphasize the importance of the therapeutic relationship, this does not mean that strategic therapists come across as cold, manipulative, or uncaring. On the contrary, many receive high ratings on rapport and alliance. Define a resolvable complaint. Identify solution patterns (problem-solution loops) that maintain the complaint. Understand clients' unique language and preferred views of the problem, themselves and each other. The first two goals provide a template for where to intervene and the third goal is relevant to how to intervene. Gather a specific behavioral picture of the complaint Who is doing what? If I had a video of this, what would I see? Assess who sees the complaint as a problem and why it is a problem now? Determine a minimum change goal What would you be doing, or the two/three/four of you be doing differently that will let you know this problem is taking a turn for the better. Inquire into behaviors that are closely related to the problem: What has the family is done to handle, prevent, or resolve the complaint? What happens after these attempted solutions? Develop a picture of what 'less of the same' will look like: What behavior, by whom, in what situation, will suffice to reverse the problem-maintaining solution? The key element to stopping the performance of the attempted solution, so as not to perpetuate 'more of the same' problem-maintaining solution. The final assessment goal is grasping the clients' unique views. This is crucial to the later task of framing suggestions: How do they see themselves and want to be seen by others? What do they hold near and dear? When are they at their best, and what do others notice about those times? What is their best guess about why a particular problem is happening - and why they handle it the way they do? Whose idea was it to come? Why now? Who is most optimistic that therapy will help? How will you know the situation is improving? What kinds of change will you settle for? What will need to happen (or not to happen) to let you know that, even if you are not out of the woods entirely, you're at least on the right path? What will each of you settle for? Therapeutic restraint: Telling clients to 'go slow' Cautioning them about the dangers of improvement Giving insturctions about how to make the problem worse Go slow is used to prepare clients for change, to convey acceptance of reluctance to change, and to solidify change once it begins to occur. Asking the family to collaborate in performing the problem patterns (e.g., an argument) deliberately. Identify problem-solution feedback loops: Demand-Refuse Discuss-Acoid Criticize-Defend Accuse-Deny Encourage the family to do less of the same: When members felt the need to talk about their relationship, they would first go bowling.
Reframing: For a small set of family complaints, the goal is to help families reevaluate their problem as 'no problem,' or as a problem they can live with. Acknowledging (Reinforcing): When a small change occurs, the therapist acknowledges and emphasizes the clients' part in making it happen, but avoids encouraging further change directly. Predicting or Prescribing: Exploring the dangers of movement. Therapeutic restraint / going slow Prescribing the symptom / performing the problem / predicting Jamming / experiment Reframing Less of the same Acknowledge / reinforce Critics sometimes regard strategic therapy as 'manipulative' because the therapist does not usually make the rationale for particular interventions explicit to clients. The therapist may say things that they do not truly believe to achieve an effective framing. Proponents counter that responsible therapy is inherently manipulative and that therapeutic candor can be disrespectful. Good therapy shows profound respect for clients' subjective experiences. Critics suggest strategic therapists may ignore problems such as intimate-partner violence or substance abuse, if clients do not perceive or present them as overt complaints in session. The model does not attempt at helping families with personal growth or solving underlying emotional issues. The central curative factor is interruption of 'ironic processes' which depends on: Accurate identification of the particular solution efforts that maintain or exacerbate the problem. Specifying what less of those same solution behaviors might look like. Designing one intervention that will persuade at least one of the people involved to do less or the opposite of what they have been doing. Applicable to any family that presents with a clear complaint. Particularly relevant for families that seem resistance to change. Most qualitative research (case reports) and follow-up quantitative data. Historically, most of the research on the effectiveness of Strategic Therapy wasn't very rigorous. Mostly case report format. Anecdotal support for its efficacy, although people tend not to write about their failed cases.
Case reports with Anorexia Nervosa, Schizophrenia, and delinquency (pg. 96) Brief Strategic Family Therapy for adolescent substance abuse and behavior problems Treatment engagement, family functioning Focuses on the process of communication rather than its content. Clever, prescriptive, expedient Critiqued as manipulative Therapist is responsible for the outcome of therapy. Families are stuck in well-intentioned but ineffective attempts to solve problems.
Paradoxical Injunction: To shake the status quo of the system Circular questioning and team supervision from the Milan group. Team approaches to therapy As a treatment for families, strategic differs from most other approaches in that the therapist is willing, and sometimes prefers, to see family members (particularly partners) individually.

item.title: 4. Measurement and Capturing the World Accurately
item.description:
What are the biggest challenges social scientists face when trying capture meaning in the real world? What strategies are helpful to overcoming these strategies? What is one construct that you are interested in capturing in your research? Thoroughly describe 3 different ways you could capture it in a study (Be creative!!!). How will you determine if your measurement strategy is 1) valid and 2) appropriate for the population you are studying? Why do researchers HARK and/or use their flexibility in their publications? Significant findings get published Desire to tell a good story Hindsight bias Need for speed How do we as a field reduce HARKing and problematic use of flexible decisions? Demand transparency Change incentive structures Use of pre-registration to: Force less flexibility after the data is collected Allow reviewers to see a priori decisions Encourage replication Encourage/mandate data sharing Ensuring appropriate use of your findings How can researchers ensure that there is appropriate use of their findings? Discussion sections Engaging with media Not overstating relevance of findings to practice and policy - especially if exploratory work (e.g., not pre-registered, no replications) Our desire to advocate can cause ethical challenges. Harm to particpants (e.g., zone of privacy) Ways that we present findings and interpret findings Something to always be aware of and thinking about when making decisions. Discuss early and often Follow professional guidelines (and journal guidelines) OSU Authorship Guidelines
ICMJE Authorship Guidelines
Authorship and contributorship | COPE: Committee on Publication Ethics Goal of understanding the world accurately (truth-seeking etc.) Want valid results Validity is how we think through likely accuracy of our research Measurement validity=closeness to the truth; are we capturing the concepts we seek to capture? How do you decide what measures to capture in a study? Start with your research question. Conceptualization: What are the concepts we are interested in? How do we define them? How do we define them in ways that are measurable? Specific Able to be captured Need to do for both objective (e.g., income) and abstract (e.g. happiness) Operationalization: The process of developing valid measurement of the variables in a study E.g., choosing measures for survey developing observation protocols, developing experimental manipulations Independent Variable Predictor Dependent Variable Outcome Control Variable (Covariate) We think they matter for both the predictor and outcome. We want to make sure the associations we are looking at are not just Moderating Variable (Changes the association you are looking at) Mediating Variable (Process) Need to conceptualize and operationalize all of these variables in advance. Goal is to use measures that are reliable and valid Look to theory for help with conceptualization Look to prior empirical research for help with measure selection When possible, choose measures for which reliability and validity has already been established. However, you will still need to demonstrate this within the sample you collect/use. Measures cannot be valid if they are not reliable. Reliability: Degree to which a measure produces a consistent answer when the phenomenon being studied is not changing Test-Retest Internal Consistency Interrater Reliability You should be prepared to report on internal consistency and interrater reliability within your own research. Reliability lets you know if you are capturing something meaningful, but not if it is what you are intending to capture. Are we capturing what we want to be capturing?
Glossary/Face Validity
Content Validity
Criterion Validity
Discriminant Validity Capturing psychological constructs is really hard. Harder than a lot of constructs in physical sciences. How can we capture constructs better? Use multiple measures (Kagan) Natural Observations Self-Reports Physiological Other Reporters Lab Tasks Challenges of multiple measures Lack of correlation Multiple reasons: Role of context Individual perceptions Brings complications, but can brings us closer to truth Lorenz and the multitrait model Think about Venn dyagrams and where shared and unique variance comes from Just because a measure works for one group of people does not mean it will work for another. Huge problem in our field. Choose measures that have been shown to be valid in populations you are studying. Use measurement invariance testing to make sure the measures are working for subgroups in your population.

item.title: 5. Generalizability, Sampling, and Power
item.description: Ground Rules for Social Research (pgs. 181-196) Chambliss et al. (2003) Henrich et al. (2010) Duncan (2008) Roy et al. (243-260) Measures cannot be valid if they are not reliable Reliability Degree to which a measure produces a consistent answer when the phenomenon being studied is not changing Test-Retest Internal Consistency Interrater Reliability You should be prepared to report on internal consistency and interrater reliability within your own research. Reliability lets you know if you are capturing something meaningful, but not if it is what you are intending to capture. Face Validity Does a test measure what it's supposed to measure? Content Validity Assess whether a test is representative of all aspects of the construct Criterion Validity Evaluates how accurately a test measures the outcome it was designed to measure Discriminant Validity Measures whether constructs that theoretically should not be related to each other are, in fact, unrelated. The measures we choose will eventually become the variables in our statistical analyses Continuous Variable can assume an infinite number of real values within a given interval (e.g., income) Count Individual piece of count data (e.g., number of kids) Ordinal Categorical variables with ordered possible values; ratings about opinions or perceptions, or demographic factors that are categorized into levels or brackets Categorical Dichotomous - only 2 categories (e.g., employed or not) Characteristic that can't be quantifiable Always measure things with as much precision as possible If possible, measure things continuously You can always collapse things into categories later. (e.g., age [use birthday and day of assessment], hours worked per week [can make part-time/full-time later]) Descriptive Statistics Want to understand your data Check for variability Check for normality Check for unusual data (e.g., bots) Check for outliers Have plan ready in advance Look at reliability statistics Look at associations among independent variables Is a latent variable warranted? (unmeasured variables that is believes to influence responses to a number of survey items) Do not look at associations (even correlations) among independent variables and dependent variables (HARKing) Qualitative research also needs to demonstrate rigor. Looks very different Validity is about ensuring appropriate conclusions are drawn - based on what informants provide and theoretical lens being used Rigor occurs throughout the research process, not just at the beginning or the end (also true for quantitative work) Role of verification Role of verification Iterative process between the data and the literature Responsiveness Requires knowing your data, knowing how to listen, and knowing how to synthesize Flexible in way of processing data Sampling Saturation Seeking negative cases Audit trails Member checks You need to demonstrate how your data or data collection plan is valid. Quantitative studies: reliability and validity; prior studies; how does this measure capture the constructs you are talking about in your literature review and research questions? Qualitative studies: What steps are you taking to ensure rigor? The literature review/introduction will direction follow your opening 2-3 paragraphs. Goal is to explain the rationale for the work you are doing. Not to comprehensively summarize every related study ever Show your work builds off of prior theory and empirical work Highlight the unique contributions of your work Although you may not review every related study, you need to do a thorough literature review to understand how your study relates to others and how your study fits. Focus on peer-reviewed journal articles Try to get a sense of paper by looking at abstract and skimming before committing to fully reading To do this more effectively, you should plan out the sections of your literature review in advance Based on your questions Provide an organization/headings for your literature review Your questions may be a series of questions (each will become a header in your literature review/introduction) Or your questions may build upon each other Your sequential logic becomes the headers for your introduction And it ensures that you know the 'argument' for each section (because you have the arrows drawn and connections made already) Note: your argument does not mean you ignore findings that don't support your hypothesis - you use them as arguments as to why your research is needed. Ultimately, should match your first 2/3 paragraphs, methods, results, and discussion. Keep your headings general and big picture Consider ending with a, 'The present study...' section May have to include a conceptual or theoretical paragraph somewhere Often easier to discuss theory within your aims-based headings Try not to use jargon, simple words instead Do not repeat yourself even if it is written in a different way (e.g., put another way) Do not provide laundry list of extant literature; instead, synthesize What is it? Is it attainable? Think about research you have read recently? Do you think they have adequately discussed generalizability? Big takeaways: Being as thoughtful as possible about our sampling plan before collecting data is going to help us create higher quality research. Be transparent about the ways in which your research is or is not generalizable. Getting good samples is really hard. Your research doesn't have to be perfect (remember no study is). Sample Generalizability: Can findings based on a sample be applied to the larger population from which the sample was drawn? Need for 'thick description' Cross-Population Generalizability Can findings from a study of one population be applied ot other populations? Usually infers in universality (although doesn't have to) Sampling is unnecessary if all the units in the population are identical (e.g., blood) But what about people? Are fundamental psychological processes the same across all people (universal)? When random sampling is not possible Availability (Convenience) Sampling: Take who you can get Exploratory or qualitative research Intro to psych! It is okay to use convenience sampling but you need to be aware of and acknowledging your limitations. Quota Sampling: Make sure sample represents certain characteristics in the population (but can't know all characteristics, and not random) This is not as good as random/probability sampling but is still a much improved strategy over convenience sampling. Purposive Sampling: Studying a subset of limited group Studying 'key informants' High on internal validity Population: The entire set of individuals or other entities (e.g., families, schools) to which study findings are to be generalized Census = study the whole population Sampling Frame A list of all the elements in a population Sample A subset of a population used to study the population as a whole Two factors that make it easier to get a representative sample: Larger samples are more likely to be representative Sample size does matter in quantitative research Both for generalizability and power However, unthoughtful sampling doesn't improve much with larger samples. It is easier to derive a representative sample from a homogenous population (i.e., can have a smaller sample) Allows us to know in advance how likely it is that any element of a population will be selected.

item.title: @bellMetatheorizingFamilyTheory2022
item.description: Bibliography: Bell, D. C. (2022). Metatheorizing in Family Theory. In K. Adamsons, A. L. Few-Demo, C. Proulx, & K. Roy (Eds.), Sourcebook of Family Theories and Methodologies (pp. 21‚Äì40). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-92002-9_2 Type: Book Section Title: Metatheorizing in Family Theory, Author: Bell, David C.; Editor: Adamsons, Kari; Few-Demo, April L.; Proulx, Christine; Roy, Kevin; Publisher: Springer International Publishing, Location: Cham, Pages: 21-40 Year: 2022 ISBN: 978-3-030-92001-2 978-3-030-92002-9 A key purpose of theorizing in family science is to develop explanations of family phenomena. There are other purposes for which theory might be constructed (Klein & White, 1996; Schneider, 2006; Swedberg, 2014), but in this chapter, I will discuss theory for the purpose of explanation (Bengtson et  al., 2005a; Fine & Fincham, 2013a). Theories are created by theorizing, and theorizing is thus any process by which a researcher develops explanations. While theorizing is about understanding the world, metatheorizing is about understanding theorizing. One may distinguish three different kinds of metatheorizing (Ritzer, 1988): ‚Ä¢ Metatheorizing to summarize, interpret, and/or critique (the contents of) prior theory. ‚Ä¢ Metatheorizing to propose rules for effective theorizing. This includes textbooks on theorizing (D. C. Bell, 2009; Chafetz, 1978; Hage, 1972; Swedberg, 2014). ‚Ä¢ Metatheorizing to describe and evaluate methods of theorizing, largely conducted by philosophers (e.g., Godfrey-Smith, 2003; Hempel, 1965; Popper, 1965; Staley, 2014). This chapter will emphasize the third type of metatheorizing, a discussion which will naturally touch to some extent on metatheorizing of the second type. Keywords: In Progress

item.title: Cluster Sampling
item.description: Sampling in which elements are selected in two or more stages, with the first stage being the random selection of naturally occurring clusters and the last stage being the random selection of elements within clusters. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 129) There are 'naturally occurring' groups in population, usually geographical or organizational. Randomly selected clusters. Then sample all units within each cluster, or random sample with each chosen cluster. Error is smaller if the clusters are similar to each other.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Cluster Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Stratified Random Sampling
item.description: A method of sampling in which sample elements are selected separately from population strata that the researcher identifies in advance. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 130) Use if one or more characteristics are focal research interest. The goal is to compare groupds (strata). The purpose is to make sure each group is represented in the sample. First divide population into groups (strata). Then a random sample is taken from each group.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Stratified Random Sampling.md

item.title: 12. Ecological Theories and Family Stress Theories
item.description:
Social Causation Social and economic conditions influence individual functioning and development.
Social Selection Attributes of individuals influence the quality of their social and economic environments.
Interactionist Individual attributes influence a person's social and economic environments.
Hardship conditions are expected to affect family functioning and individual adjustment primarily through the economic pressures they generate. The Family Stress Model proposes that economic pressures include (a) unmet material needs involving necessities such as adequate food and clothing, (b) the inability to pay bills or make ends meet, and (c) having to cut back on even necessary expenses (e.g., health insurance and medical care). When economic pressures is high, parents are at an increased risk for emotional distress (e.g., depression, anxiety, anger, and alienation) and for behavioral problems (e.g., substance use and antisocial behavior). According to the model, these emotional or behavioral problems predict increased marital conflict and reduced marital warmth, and this process diminishes nurturing and involved parenting.
Family Stress Model Links

item.title: @congerInteractionistPerspectiveSocioeconomic2007
item.description: Bibliography: Conger, R. D., & Donnellan, M. B. (2007). An Interactionist Perspective on the Socioeconomic Context of Human Development. Annual Review of Psychology, 58(1), 175‚Äì199. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.psych.58.110405.085551 Type: Journal Article Title: An Interactionist Perspective on the Socioeconomic Context of Human Development, Author: Conger, Rand D.; Donnellan, M. Brent; Journal: Annual Review of Psychology, Volume: 58, Issue: 1 Pages: 175-199 Year: 2007 DOI: 10.1146/annurev.psych.58.110405.085551 ISSN: 0066-4308, 1545-2085 This article addresses the relationship between socioeconomic status (SES), family processes, and human development. The topic is framed as part of the general issue of health disparities, which involves the oft-observed positive relationship between SES and the cognitive, social, emotional, and physical well-being of adults and children. A review of recent research and theory identiÔ¨Åes three general theoretical approaches that provide possible explanations for the association between SES and individual development: the social causation, social selection, and interactionist perspectives. Empirical evidence demonstrates support for the social causation view that SES affects families and the development of children in terms of both family stress processes (the family stress model) and family investments in children (the family investment model). However, there also is empirical support for the social selection argument that individual characteristics lead to differences in SES. Especially important, recent research is consistent with an interactionist approach, which proposes a dynamic relationship between SES and developmental change over time. Drawing on the combined set of research Ô¨Åndings, the article concludes with the description of an interactionist model that serves as a heuristic for future studies of the links among SES, parenting behaviors, and child development. Keywords: In Progress

item.title: @millerAdvancedMethodsFamily2014
item.description:
Bibliography: Type: Book Title: Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research: A Focus on Validity and Change, Editor: Miller, Richard B.; Johnson, Lee N.; Publisher: Routledge, Location: New York, Year: 2014 ISBN: 978-0-203-08452-6 Research is vital in moving the field of family therapy forward, but the myriad of possibilities inherent in working with systems and individuals can overwhelm even the most seasoned researcher. Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research is the best resource to address the day-to-day questions that researchers have as they investigate couples and families, and the best source for learning long-term theory and methodology. The contributors of this volume share their wisdom on a wide variety of topics including validity concerns, measuring interpersonal process and relational change, dyadic data analysis (demonstrated through a sample research study), mixed methods studies, and recruitment and retention. The volume contains one of the most detailed descriptions of data collections and covers interviewing, using questionnaires, and observing brain activity.  Also addressed are suggestions to meaningfully reduce cultural bias, to conduct ethical research, and, in the Health Services Research chapter, to examine interventions for clients in various income brackets. A separate, ground-breaking chapter also addresses psychophysiological research in a couple and family therapeutic context. As an added benefit, readers will learn how to become informed consumers of journal articles and studies, how to produce quality, publishable research, and how to write fundable grant proposals. Each chapter provides a clear and detailed guide for students, researchers, and professionals, and as a whole Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research advances the field by teaching readers how to provide evidence that marriage and family therapy not only relieves symptoms, but also effects behavioral change in all family members. Few studies have included information about how other members of the system change in relation to a single individual. The more traditional forms of statstical methods do not allow for multiple members of the same system to be included in the same analysis. item.title: @kazanRomanticLoveConceptualized1987
item.description: Bibliography: Kazan, C., & Shaver, P. (1987). Romantic Love Conceptualized as an Attachment Process. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 52(3), 511‚Äì524. Type: Journal Article Title: Romantic Love Conceptualized as an Attachment Process, Author: Kazan, Cindy; Shaver, Phillip; This article explores the possibility that romantic love is an attachment process‚Äîa biosocial process by which affectional bonds are formed between adult lovers, just as affectional bonds are formed earlier in life between human infants and their parents. Key components of attachment theory, developed by Bowlby, Ainsworth, and others to explain the development of affectional bonds in infancy, were translated into terms appropriate to adult romantic love. The translation centered on the three major styles of attachment in infancy‚Äîsecure, avoidant, and anxious/ambivalent‚Äîand on the notion that continuity of relationship style is due in part to mental models (Bowlby's "inner working models") of self and social life. These models, and hence a person's attachment style, are seen as determined in part by childhood relationships with parents. Two questionnaire studies indicated that (a) relative prevalence of the three attachment styles is roughly the same in adulthood as in infancy, (b) the three kinds of adults differ predictably in the way they experience romantic love, and (c) attachment style is related in theoretically meaningful ways to mental models of self and social relationships and to relationship experiences with parents. Implications for theories of romantic love are discussed, as are measurement problems and other issues related to future tests of the attachment perspective. Keywords: Bowlby's major purpose was to describe how infants become emotionally attached to their primary caregivers and emotionally distressed when separated from them, although he also contended that 'attachment behavior [characterizes] human beings from the cradle to the grave.' The purpose of this article is to explore the possibility that Attachment Theory, designed primarily with infants in mind, offers a valuable perspective on adult romantic love. For our purpose, which is to create a coherent framework for understanding love, loneliness, and grief at different points in the life cycle. Love appears to take multiple forms. They have not said how the healthy and unhealthy forms git together in a single conceptual framework. Attachment Theory not only provides such a framework, but it also explains how both healthy and unhealthy forms of love originate as reasonable adaptations to specific social circumstances. Attachment theory deals with separation and loss and helps explain how loneliness and love are related. Attachment theory links adult love with socioemotional processes evident in children and nonhuman primates; it places love within an evolutionary context. When a human or primate infant is separated from its mother, the infant goes through a predictable series of emotional reactions. The first is protest, which involves crying, active searching, and resistance to others' soothing efforts. The second is despair, which is a state of passivity and obvious sadness. The third, discussed only with reference to humans, is detachment, an active, seemingly defensive disregard for and avoidance of the mother if she returns. The attachment system, as Bowlby called the complex constellation of attachment feelings and behaviors seems have evolved to protect infants from danger by keeping them close to the mother. When very young, a human infant can do little more than cry, make eye context, smile, and snuggle in to encourage its mother to keep it near. Once mobile, however, it can actively pursue its mother and vocalize to her. When an infant is healthy, alert, unafraid, and in the presence of its mother, it seems interested in exploring and mastering the environment and in establishing affiliative contact with other family and community members. Researchers call this using the mother as a secure base. Attachment theory can be summarized in three propositions: The first [proposition] is that when an individual is confident that an attachment figure will be available to him whenever he desires it, that person will be much less prone to either intense or chronic fear than will an individual who for any reason has no such confidence in the availability of attachment figures, or lack of it, is built up slowly during the years of immaturity - infancy, childhood, and adolescence - and that whatever expectations are developed during those years tend to persist relatively unchanged throughout the rest of life. The third proposition concerns the role of actual experience. It postulates that the varied expectations of the accessibility and responsiveness of attachment figures that individuals develop during the years of immaturity are tolerably accurate reflections of the experiences those individuals have actually had. (Bowlby, 1973, p. 235) Ainsworth's research suggested a mother's sensitivity and responsiveness to her infant's signals and needs during the first year of life are important prerequisites. Mothers who are slow or inconsistent in responding to their infant's cries or who regularly intrude on or interfere with their infant's desired activities (sometimes to force affection on the infant at a particular moment) produce infants who cry more than usual, explore less than usual (even in the mother's presence), mingle attachment behaviors with overt expressions of anger, and seem generally anxious. If, instead, the mother consistently rebuffs or rejects the infant's attempts to establish physical contact, the infant may learn to avoid her. Delineated three styles or types of attachment, often called secure, anxious/ambivalent, and avoidant. Infants in the anxious/ambivalent category frequently exhibit the behaviors Bowlby called protest, and the avoidant infants frequently exhibit the behaviors he called detachment. According to Bowlby, working models (which we will also call mental models) and the behavior patterns influenced by them are central components of personality. The claim of cross-situational and cross-age continuity is still controversial but is supported by a growing list of longitudinal studies from infancy through the early elementary school years. Continuity, according to Bowlby (1973), is due primarily to the persistence of interrelated mental models of self and social life in the context of a fairly stable family setting: "Confidence that an attachment figure is, apart from being accessible, likely to be responsive can be seen to turn on at least two variables: Whether or not the attachment figure is judged to be the sort of person who in general responds to calls for support and protection Whether or not the self is judged to be the sort of person towards whom anyone, and the attachment figure in particular, is likely to respond in a helpful way. Logically these variables are independent. In practice they are apt to be confounded. As a result, the model of the attachment figure and the model of the self are likely to develop so as to be complementary and mutually confirming." (Bowlby, 1973, p. 238) No one has attempted to conceptualized the entire range of romantic love experiences in a way that parallels the typology developed by Ainsworth and her colleagues. Nor has anyone with an interest in romantic relationships pursued Bowlby's idea that continuity in relationship style is a matter of mental models of self and social life. Finally, no one has explored the possibility that the specific characteristics of parent-child relationships identified by Ainsworth et al., as the probable causes of differences in infant attachment styles are also among the determinants of adults' romantic attachment styles. We expected roughly 60% of adults to classify themselves as secure and the remainder to split fairly evenly between the two insecure types, with perhaps a few more in the avoidant than in the anxious/ambivalent category. In a summary of American studies of three types of infants Campos et al., (1983) concluded that 62% are secure, 23% avoidant, and 15% are anxious/ambivalent. We predicted that the most important love experience of a secure adult would be characterized by trust, friendship, and positive emotions. For avoidant adults, love was expected to be marked by fear of closeness and lack of trust. Anxious/ambivalent adults were expected to experience love as a preoccupying, almost painfully exciting struggle to merge with another person. This last style is similar to what Hindy and Schwarz (1984) called anxious romantic attachment and Tennov (1979) called limerence. Respondents' working models of self and relationships were also expected to differ according to attachment style. Secure types should believe in enduring love, generally find others trustworthy, and have confidence that the self is likable. Avoidant types should be more doubtful of the existence or durability of romantic love and believe that they do not need a love partner in order to be happy. Anxious/ambivalent types should fall in love frequently and easily but have difficulty finding true love. They should also have more serf-doubts than the other two types because, unlike avoidant respondents, they do not repress or attempt to hide feelings of insecurity. We expected respondents of the three types to report different attachment histories. According to the theory, Secure respondents should remember their mothers as dependably responsive and caring Avoidant respondents should report that their mothers were generally cold and rejecting Anxious/ ambivalent respondents should remember a mixture of positive and negative experiences with their mothers. Because the attachment needs of insecure respondents are unlikely to be fully met, avoidant

item.title: @daniello20YearReview2020
item.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: A 20‚ÄêYear Review of Common Factors Research in Marriage and Family Therapy: A Mixed Methods Content Analysis, Author: D'Aniello, Carissa; Fife, Stephen T.; Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, Volume: 46, Issue: 4 Pages: 701-718 Year: 2020 DOI: 10.1111/jmft.12427 ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606 Introduced by Sprenkle, Blow & Dickey (1999), common factors in marriage and family therapy (MFT) have been discussed over the past two decades. Although the MFT common factors literature has grown, there are misconceptions and disagreements about their role in theory, practice, research, and training. This content analysis examined the contributions of the common factors paradigm to MFT theory, practice, research, and training over the past 20 years. We identified 37 scholarly works including peer‚Äêreviewed journal articles, books, and chapters. Using mixed methods content analysis, we analyze and synthesize the contributions of this literature in terms of theoretical development about therapeutic effectiveness in MFT, MFT training, research, and practice. We provide commentary on the substantive contributions that the common factors paradigm has made to these areas, and we discuss the implications and limitations of the common factors literature, and provide recommendations for moving common factors research forward. Keywords: Need to Read Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), long considered the gold standard for testing the effectiveness of treatment approaches and interventions, rest on the assumption that models and interventions are responsible for change. Common Factors are defined as the general mechanisms of change that cut across models, rather than aspects of treatment that are unique to a particular model. Common factors, rather than model-specific factors, are largely responsible for effective therapy. Despite increased theoretical and empirical support for common factors, there has been continued debate about their usefulness in the MFT field. The purpose of this content analysis is to critically analyze, synthesize, and clarify the contributions of the common factors paradigm to MFT theory, research, training, and practice.
Common Factors are an umbrella term for the general mechanisms or variables associated with therapeutic change that are common across therapy models. Common factors, also called general factors or mechanisms of change, are factors that contribute to change in psychotherapy. They are not the province of a specific model but instead are found in all therapies. Common factors are further defined as broad and narrow. Broad common factors include general aspects of treatment such as client and therapist factors, extra-therapeutic variables (e.g., foruitous events, social support), therapist-client relationship factors, and the client's expectancy of the success of therapy. Empirical support for common factors is grounded in outcome studies and meta-analyses of therapeutic effectiveness. Narrow common factors refer to aspects of treatment found in several models that go by different names.
Different models of therapy share common processes or goals, otherwise defined as Model-Dependent Common Factors. These include shifting each partner's cognition, affect, or behavior; reattribution; reinforcement; desensitization; and psychoeducation and skills training. What are some examples of common factors in your own work with the various theories? How often do they overlap? The MFT field has traditionally conceptualized and explained therapeutic effectiveness through the lens of models. Therapy is effective because of the unique and particular philosophy or intervention of each therapeutic model. However, several meta-analyses of psychotherapy demonstrate this is not the care, finding no model of couple and family therapy consistently yielding better results than others. It is important to critically examine the impact, strengths, and limitations of this paradigm as applied to MFT theory and practice. What are the primary characteristics of common factors literature in the MFT field? What common factors are identified in the MFT literature? How do common factors researchers draw distinctions between change mechanisms, change process, and common factors? How do common factors contribute to the discussion about the therapeutic effectiveness of MFT? How do MFT scholars explain the relationship between common factors and models? How do common factors inform and enhance MFT practice, research, and training? How does the MFT common factors literature answer fundamental questions about therapeutic effectiveness and the process of change in therapy? We used the following criteria to determine whether to include works in our sample: Common factors are the primary focus of the work The authors discuss common factors as applied to the practice of MFT The work was published in a peer-reviewed journal or academic outlet between 1999 and early 2019. The authors have written about common factors extensively. Throughout the data analysis and discussion of the results, we met to discuss our position in relationship to common factors. We engaged in this process to acknowledge our position of support for common factors and our belief in their role as important aspects of therapeutic change; we also recognize there are significant limitations to the existing literature. Our aim was to provide a rigorous, honest, and critical commentary of the common factors literature in MFT, and we continually reminded ourselves of this aim throughout the analysis.

item.title: 3. Family Systems Theory and Parent-Child Relationships
item.description:
CNM people in same-gender relationships COVID social distancing impacts Reinforcing relationship hierarchy Isolate those living alone More time with cohabitating partners -> relationship breakdown Most childcare responsibilities for single parents Less time with parents Non-coparents parenting more Expose Of Polycule to public To COVID (for large networks) Yet, following these best practices has the potential to create or reinforce a relationship hierarchy among cohabiting and non-cohabiting partners or further isolate individuals living alone, according to Sheff (2020 b). In addition, more time among cohabiting partners and disagreements about social distancing practices could lead to tensions and relationship breakdown (Sheff, 2020 a). Single parents or parents working at home in particular may need to take on additional childcare responsibilities (Goldberg et al., 2021), potentially leading to less time with partners or non-coparent partners spending more time with children. Queer Theory Include members who are not biologically or legally connected, and the queer sexuality when they form relationships with more than one person: disentangle romantic, sexual, and coparenting relationships; and include same-gender partners. May openly challenge heteronormative assumptions Not all relationship styles do this May prioritize safety Methods No discussion of the gender composition of the relationships Include members who are not biologically or legally connected, and they queer sexuality when they form relationships with more than one person; disentangle romantic, sexual, and coparenting relationships; and include same-gender partners. However, CNM relationships differ in their degree of compliance with and challenges to heteronormativity. For example, some polyamorous parents try to ‚Äúpass‚Äù as monogamous, whereas others come out and actively compel institutions or other people to recognize their families (Pallotta-Chiarolli, 2010). Decreased contact Connection across distance Distance from children Parents with less time with parents tended to not be cisgender women: only one of these seven parents was a cisgender woman or only a biological parent; rather, three were trans or nonbinary, two were cisgender men, and most were a  combination of stepparents, nonbiological parents, biological parents, and adoptive parents. Pandemic may have more of an impact on parent‚Äìchild relationships when one or more characteristics of parents deviates from the dominant heteronorm of the primary parent (i.e., female, biological). The children lived with other parents prior to the pandemic, and in others, parents made the decision for children to live with different caregivers such as grandparents or coparents during the pandemic due to risk of exposure (e.g., parent was a frontline worker) or socialization considerations (e.g., the desire to give the child more time with other family members). "A relationship, shared,  a family, we decided it would be good for my kid to spend some time with my ex. Once that happened I have been able to visit my boyfriend twice (after 3 months apart). Both the kid and my ex is happier for the kid being up there.‚Äù Hsin-Yi‚Äôs account illustrates one way of resolving the desire to see their boyfriend and limit networks of risk exposure while also allowing their child to spend more time with other coparents. Changing dynamics and configurations at home More time at home ‚Ä¢This practice of incorporating multiple partners into a living unit could be beneÔ¨Åcial in having a ‚Äúlarge, robust household‚Äù to combat isolation, but also introduced challenges related to sharing space and dividing time among partners. Isabella, a bisexual white polyamorous stepmother to a toddler, elaborated: Fortunately, even those who discussed the stress of living in close quarters commented on the skills and strengths that they possessed as people who engaged in CNM, which enabled them to effectively communicate about their needs and boundaries. But one thing polys are pretty good at is sort of working through issues as they arise.‚Äù‚ÄúSeveral parents spoke to the strengths of their communication and conflict resolution skills. Another approach to spend more time with partners while avoiding some of the complications of moving everyone into the same house was creating multi-household quarantine pods, which sometimes further challenged heteronormative notions of family through the intentional and collaborative construction of small communities. Increased parenting responsibility Significant stress and desire for greater social support. Support for parents was generally appreciated both by children and co-parents. Negotiating risk For some, this involved a process of pausing and unpausing CNM relationships as participants made decisions about safety and relative risk. Newly exploring CNM, the pandemic seemed to at least temporarily foreclose the possibility of opening the relationship. For other participants with established relationships, the labor and thought that went into seeing existing partners appeared to take priority over the work of trying to safely meet new partners. Others noted their reluctance to meet with new individuals given the politicization of responses to COVID-19. Perhaps because those in CNM relationships often have significant experience communicating needs and boundaries to partners (including negotiating expectations around safer sex behaviors), many participants mentioned the conversations they have with partners about COVID risk without characterizing them as challenging or conflictual. Differences in protective measured ended some relationships.
In what ways are boundaries, as discussed by Family Systems Theory, may be limiting to our understanding of CNM relationships? Is this concept limiting to our understanding of this population? Or is this concept purely expansive in our understanding of this relationship type? During the pandemic, parents had less contact with partners outside of the home and focused more on the children and the biological mother or father of the children. Did the pandemic change the family processes?
Complexity (Effects of the Family Processes via Explanatory Pathways) (Mediation) Conflict affected child behavior problems through parent-to-child hostility in all family configurations except mother-child hostility in unrelated pairs (stepparents?) Genes (relatedness, low serotonin) Anger mediated association between parenting hostility and child health only for those with low serotonin. Inclusion of Siblings Child trauma symptoms is higher when siblings are treated more harshly and more parenting stress; consistent parenting for siblings; older sibling influence of delinquency (bidirectional)
Inclusion of dyadic and triadic processes (e.g., Triangulation) Family-level constructs (e.g., boundary disturbances associated with emotional dysregulation)
Specificity (Identification of moderating factors that suggested for whom or under what conditions associations are salient) ( Moderation) Moderation (e.g., meta-analyses; associations between chronic health condition and sibling well-being - stronger for older siblings and when illness was life-threatening) Advanced the literature by examining moderators that provided important information regarding participant characteristics, sample features, and research methods. The positive association between parents' marital hostility and young adolescents' internalizing problems was significant only when parents' marital cooperation was low (Zhou & Buehler, 2019) Latent class analyses (e.g., association between child effects and harsh parenting strong for those behaving poorly)
Conceptual distinctions (e.g., everyday conflict vs. Acculturation -based conflict) Multiple markers (e.g., adjustment and positive outcomes) Importance of time in the study of family processes and child and adolescent well-being. Future Directions Examination of emotion, cognitive, physiological, and behavioral regulation within and between diverse families Continue research that considers dyadic, triadic, and family-level regulation Focus on studying and enhancing family strengths and reducing risks
Consider both risks and strengths as Predictor s, Mediation (Mediator), and Moderation (Moderator) Continue investigations of gender as a moderator Increased attention to family processes Family Diversity More diverse families (e.g., more inclusive definitions of 'family' - same-sex, between-group comparisons, rural AA families, low-income families) Cultural Adaptations (e.g., FSM)
Revisioning of these theories (Family Systems Theory to include historical time and choice with racial socialization) Importance of time in the study of family processes and child and adolescent well-being Diary Diary Studies (e.g., self-blame associated with you feeling more anger on days with higher conflict) Longitudinal Studies (i.e., growth curves, cross-lagged models) Identifying developmental periods (e.g., violence during toddler and early childhood associated with IPV at age 23) Intergenerational association (e.g., accumulation of family conflict across generations) Changes in family processes (e.g., increased marital conflict associated with children's later disruptive behavior and family conflict in adolescence associated with later youth depressive symptoms) Reciprocal associations (e.g., child anxiety associated with parental hostility but reverse not true when considering other behaviors; reciprocal association between maternal sensitivity and child emotional regulation) Strengths in family functioning Strengths: Reflected in processes that have the potential to be associated with greater child and youth positive development or fewer (or less severe) developmental difficulties or adjustment problems.
Resiliency The capacities of families as functional systems to withstand and rebound from stressful challenges and demands.
Family Cohesion Closeness, support, shared fun Future directions Main takeaways Move beyond markers of child adjustment problems and focus more of positive aspects of well-being (e.g., emotion regulation, healthy sleep, positive affect, positive racial-ethnic identity) Development and reformulation of conceptual models that account for diversity in families The importance of studying everyday lives of families was highlighted and research methods like audio recording and daily diaries were crucial in furthering this area Cross-lagged designs and growth curves were used often There is a lot of variability both within and between families that needs to be studied.
