item.title: Micro-Aggressions, Micro-Resistance, and Ally Development in the Academy
item.description: Micro-resistances: incremental daily efforts that help targeted people cope with microaggressions. offensive and defensive. Examples that help increase personal and psychic strength: Reminding oneself about what you value Practicing self-care Caring for myself is not self-indulgence, it is self-preservation, and that is an act of political warefare. Taking power poses, especially before potentiallys tressful situations Thinking about the 'bigger fish you have to fry' Examples that increase your social resources: Participating in mentoring programs Building your network of mentors practicing gratitude Speak up! Use OTFD (Open the Front Door to Communication What can allies do? Become more informed and empathetic Give micro-affirmations Tiny acts of opening doors to opportunity, gestures of inclusion and caring, and graceful acts of listening.  Support colleagues Open the Front Door to Communication (OTFD): Observe: Concrete, objective, factual observations Both be able to agree on observations stated Think: Thoughts based on observations DO NOT put other person on defense Feel: Actual feelings/emotions you have as a result of the conflict/observation Desire: A statement of desired outcome

item.title: 8. Experiential Family Therapy
item.description:
Myth of Fusion: Human's must come to grips with 'aloneness.' Once we accept our aloneness then we have to make meaning for our lives. "We believe people who love us should 'just know' what we need." We have to accept we are a self. Once we accept our aloneness, we must make meaning of our lives. Freedom and Responsibility Humanistic Psychology: Humans are good and move toward growth if unhindered. Whitaker and others claim to be a-theoretical. However, Whitaker was a systems theorist and used ideas from humanistic psychology and psychoanalytic theory to guide his therapy. Jay Haley thought he could change a family behind a mirror by telling a therapist what to do. Experiential therapists did not believe this is true. They want the family to be open to their emotional experience and thoughts they are having. Anti-Technician: Rather than a-theoretical, Whitaker and other experiential therapists are anti-technician. Manipulation does not encourage open experiencing. Through feeling expression, families are able to balance separateness and connectedness. Always 'becoming' or moving forward, toward growth. Emotions/affect are validated and nurtured. Rules create balance: respect for affect and getting along. Permeable boundaries which encourage expression of intimacy needs, differentiation, bonding, conflict expression/resolution, problem solving, and playfulness. Symptoms develop when affect is blocked, impulses are denied and feelings are suppressed. Boundaries and processes are rigid: holding themselves together is more important than experiencing life. Superficial experience of emotion, self-denial, lack of empathy, lack of commitment, inability to handle conflict Little awareness, little sense of choice, flow of behavior is blocked because of unexpressed emotion.
Carl Whitaker suggested that there were 3 contexts to our symptoms: 'Driven Crazy' in an interpersonal context in which person is belittled or disqualified. 'Going Crazy' a state of temporary disorganization. 'Acting Crazy' an adaptation to the context. Increased personal integrity, greater freedom of choice, less dependence, expanded experiencing. Strengthening the family as a system by increasing connectedness within the nuclear family and across generations. Enhance ability to support the completion of developmental tasks. Battle for Structure Battle for Initiative Working Phase Termination Use of non-rational, symbol, and metaphor. Use of self is paramount: any technique comes from the therapist's creativity. Create a new therapeutic environment to alter the family's interaction in hopes of producing a different affective experience. Interrupt rigid, repetitive cycles Activate and allow for constructive anxiety or confusion. Expand the presenting problem Encourage and support any new decision (freedom to choose). Create trans-generational boundaries. Create a therapeutic supra-system in which the therapist and family are aligned, and the therapist still has the ability to differentiate (get in and get out). Self-Worth: How people learn to be people Communication: The ways people use to work out meaning with one another (Placating, Blaming, Computing, Distracting, Leveling/Congruence) Placating (peacekeeper) Blamer (im not happy its your fault) Computing (have to have a rational explanation, ultra rationale) Distracting (acts out when there is stress, someone who uses humor) Leveling/Congruence Rules: The rules people use for how they should feel and act, which eventually develop into the family system. Freedom to comment: What can you say To whom can you say it How do you go about it if you disagree or disapprove of someone or something How do you question when you do not understand Taboo subjects Taboo feelings Expressing affection Secrets Overarching goal may be to loosen up the system so there is freedom to comment. Maybe you say it yourself, maybe use family sculpting, Link to Society: How the family interacts with the outside world When communication patterns are rigid (other than congruence) and continual, and you can't comment on that. Symptoms are symptoms of the system Symptoms are created through the process of interaction Low self-worth Communication is indirect, vague, not honest Rules are rigid and non-negotiable Link to society is fearful, placating, and blaming Congruence (you the therapist must be congruent) (as a therapist, when you have a sense of what is going on in the room, you say it ‚ÄúRecording 20240412103404.webm‚Äù could not be found. ) - Only with congruence can we know each other fully and we can use our differences creatively. Focus of intervention Helping people change and grow in: Communication Beliefs about being able to grow Restoring the use of all the senses Therapist use of self is key (as with all experiential models) To alleviate symptoms you have to intervene in the process in a way that won't replicate their process. Conditions for Chage Trust Development of awareness Development of understanding Development of awareness of options Practice Universal goal for all families Development of self-worth Freedom to comment Techniques should emerge from the therapist/client interaction. Techniques are only useful in a context of trust.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/8. Experiential Family Therapy/8. Experiential Family Therapy.md

item.title: 6. Contextual Family Therapy
item.description:
Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy Biological and historical context variables (i.e., sex at birth, national origin, race/ethnicity, etc.) Also, events that you had no control over (parents divorce, illnesses) Anything that would impact how families function. Cognitions, affect, perceptions, experience, individual coping mechanisms. Could include attachment styles here or other psychodynamic constructs Patterns of interaction between family members.
Concepts of family systems theory (Boundaries, Family Rules, Triangles, Differentiation of Self, etc.) could be included here. This is the cornerstone construct for Nagy's work. Trust Loyalty (split, invisible) Entitlement (destructive) All of these influence justice and fairness in relationships and are transmitted through generations. Ontic: 'I-Thou' relationship, or dialogue Revolving Slate, justice and fairness All humans have worth and should be provided with 'due care.' When we don't get the care we deserve we develop symptoms We develop destructive entitlement which continues the cycle. Multidirected partiality Acknowledgement/accountability/crediting Exoneration Therapist use of self: you need to believe/live the theory and examine your own entitlements. Family Transaction & Power Relational Fairness/Ethical Dimension Ontic Facts Psychology Dimension II: Strong emotional reactions (anger, shame) Behaviors (control-seeking or chaotic/risky) Nay point to a destructive entitlement. As humans, we are born with value and are entitled to do care. When we do not get that, we develop a destructive entitlement. We seek others to meet our needs. We treat our partner as an object rather than a person in a relationship. Dimension III (Transactions): Rigid or chaotic structures Power struggles High conflicts Conflicts over 'nothing' Violation of trust Destructive entitlement Parentification Parent using the child to get the parents do care needs met. Overgiving Over functioning, one of the partners decides what is wrong and how to fix it. They decide what is wrong with the other person and how they need to fix it. Getting into someone else's lane. Not making 'claims' People not claiming self. People not holding themselves accountable. Loyalty conflicts or its 'invisibility' Restoring trust and balance of fairness in relationships Opening relational resources Opening a dialogue about fairness Direct address Presenting options Enhancing an individual's capacity to consider the needs of others and acknowledgement of their acts Enhancing an individual's capacity to stand up for his/her own needs and to do self-validation through acts Earned merit and due consideration = balance Not neutral Multidirected Partiality Not being neutral, being multidirectedly partial that you acknowledge each person's perspective and saying 'I get it. I understand why you may think that way.' You want the couples to learn how to validate someone else's perspective. Not agreeing with it, but just expanding the ability for a person to have compassion for others. Getting couples to ask for what You have been with me long enough you should know. Opening up of relational issues. People cannot be in a relationship and give nothing. Keep looking for their contribution. Want couples to validate each other and themselves. As people acknowledge that other people make contributions (due consideration), we feel that we are getting the due consideration. For couples therapy - considering Transitional Nonjudgmental Facilitating - 'sowing seeds and opening doors' and giving moratorium But - therapy still can be 'short-term' Avoids becoming parentified Therapists' own relational histories may resonate with those of their clients 'Self-of-the-therapist' issues may prevent clinicians from keeping a balanced stance towards members of the family Therapist does not need to be liked by their clients. Why is it so important that your clients like you? Should your clients get better for you to be a good therapist? Child maltreatment Blended families Adoption and foster care Couple relationships Anger issues Depression Self-esteem Self-destrucitve behaviors and substance abuse Multirectional Partiality Acknowledgement Crediting Anticipatory Listening Direct Address of Fairness Issues Suggestions Summary/Interpretations Making Accountable Exoneration Beginning Safety and trust Middle Dialogue and relational ethics End Integration/solidifying constructive entitlement Establish safety and trust Alliance building Assess on 4 dimensions Facts, individual psychology, family transactions, relational ethics Acknowledge past - identify transgenerational revolving slates Screen for risk factors and ethical/legal issues Emphasize strengths rather than pathology Relational Ethics and Dialogue Behavioral changes Mutual listening and validation skills Develop effective dialogue skills Make explicit relational ethics, i.e., power imbalances, broken trust Make explicit issues involving family-of-origin Destructive entitlement Split loyalties Deparentification Exoneration Integration: Solidify constructive entitlement Reinforce in calm environent Balance give and take Enhanced trust Continue work with exoneration Highlight new strengths and resources plan for the future De-escalation and soothing Acknowledgement of the other: Of reality, points of view Deeds Good starting point: "Do you see any truth in her/his words" Acknowledgement of the self (instead of 'why') Claiming considerations Repairing past unfairness Exploring family of origin model of fairness Creating a couple's new fairness: Repair and negotiation How did your childhood experiences shape your model of what you owe and deserve and your beliefs about love and fairness? Does love in your family permit you to question what's unfair? (p. 108) How does your unfinished business play out in your expectations of yourself and your partner? (pg. 112) What did your parents appreciate about you? (pg. 127) What happened when you protested unfairness (pg. 133) Parental accountability and responsibility Restoration of fairness between generations of adults (parents and grandparents) benefits children Assessing and addressing: Loyalty issues Fairness Parentification Checking and restoring age-appropriate balance of 'give and take' It is desireable to restore relationships with parents even who abused their children because it is a way to self-freedom Who was there for you? When you needed someone, who did you turn to? Who did your parent (s) turn to during times of need? Who did your parent (s) confide in most? Whom were you able to rely on in times of need? Whom were your parents able to rely on in times of need? Whom could you trust in your family to see your best interests? Whom could your parents trust in the family/their parents to seek their best interests? Have you ever felt betrayed by any of your family members? Have you heard from your parents or other family members that they felt betrayed or unsupported by the family?

item.title: @cordovaAcceptanceChangeInterventions1998
item.description:
Bibliography: Cordova, J. V., Jacobson, N. S., & Christensen, A. (1998). Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples‚Äô In-Session Communications. Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, 24(4), 437‚Äì455. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x Type: Journal Article Title: Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples' In-Session Communications, Author: Cordova, James V.; Jacobson, Neil S.; Christensen, Andrew; Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, Volume: 24, Issue: 4 Pages: 437-455 Year: 1998 DOI: 10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606 Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy (TBCT) by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCTs emphasis on behavioral change. This study examined changes in couples' communication over the course of IBCT and TBCT. Early, middle, and late sessions were coded to measure couples' communication of acceptance. Results showed that IBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time. Results support the hypothesis that structural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.
Keywords: #Research Purpose: The purpose of the current pilot study was to investigate whether these two different approaches to couple therapy lead to theoretically predictable differences in couples‚Äô in-session communication processes.
‚ÄúIntegrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCT emphasis on behavioral change.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
‚ÄúIBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
‚ÄúStructural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
‚ÄúIntegrative Behavioral Couple Therapy, developed by Andrew Christensen and Neil S. Jacobson‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
‚Äúan emphasis on promoting acceptance into the traditional emphasis on overt behavioral change.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1-2)
‚ÄúIBCT suggests that fostering acceptance is an essential step toward improving couples‚Äô relationships.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
‚ÄúTBCT suggests that effective skill building is not only necessary but sufficient for ameliorating distress.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
‚ÄúTBCT is primarily a skill-building approach to treatment. It is designed to quickly and effectively teach distressed couples the skills thought to be necessary for improving the relationship and maintaining those improvements over time.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
‚ÄúBehavior exchange focuses on teaching partners to identify those things they do that are pleasing to each other and instructs couples in the utilization of those behaviors as a means of improving the quality of the relationship. Communication and problem-solving training focus on teaching partners specific techniques useful in facilitating effective communication and problem definition and resolution. Communication training teaches partners the effective use of I messages and active listening as well as the clear distinction between the speaker‚Äôs role and the listener‚Äôs role. Problem-solving training teaches specific steps to be followed in the process of solving a problem, including problem definition, brainstorming solutions, selecting workable solutions, solution contracting, and solution testing.‚Äù (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: @byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995
item.description: "We may feel secure enough to explore if we can predict that support will be readily available if and when it is needed, especially if new ventures run into trouble or if potentially dangerous situations arise. Difficulties that lead to consultations with a family therapist often arise out of conflict within the family's own relationships." "The family script can provide routines for family life which can be followed almost automatically." "Repetition becomes the background against which change is the foreground, that which is new becomes the focus of attention. In contrast, chaos obscures potentially significant change, unless the new behavior facilitates consistency, in which case that new patter becomes the foreground, thus becoming the new center of attention." "Rewriting family scripts follows the sequence of a scripted pattern giving way to some improvisation followed by the establishment of a new pattern." "Family scripts can be defined as the family's shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts." The term 'expectations' implies anticipation of what is to be said and done within family relationships, as well as family pressures to perform the roles as expected. If one member fails to perform in the prescribed way, another member of the family may be recruited to take up that role instead. The plot is 'scripted' while the cast can change. Family scripts are revealed when repeating patterns of family interaction are either observed or described. Family Scenario: An encounter of which it can be said that something significant happens within family relationships. Basic elements of family scenario: Context Families engaging with each other around a particular task or situation Plot Family members 'motives' become clear as the scenario unfolds Outcome The consequences of the encounter are revealed The expected scenarios for each particular family situation thread together to create an overall script for how all family relationships are expected to be conducted in general. "Problem Scenarios": Instead called 'Attempted Solution Scenarios' This helps us to focus attention on how each person tries to solve the problem. The behavior that is experienced now as problematic may have started out as an attempted solution to an earlier problem. The co-constructed story may then become part of the family beliefs about what to expect of itself. Improvising implies abandoning the set script and extemporizing instead. This may happen when the old script does not fit the current situation, or when those involved are in sear of something different. The therapist can help to create a new co-constructed scenario by suggesting a goal which the family then achieves in their own way. Suggest a scenario in which it becomes necessary for the family to improvise. (in two parent families, the parents should devise a strategy together) Try to block each move that has not worked in the past. Unraveling some of the origins of the scripted scenarios frees families to explore new pathways. Work on the present and the past can reinforce each other. Replicated Scripts Parents with their own individual scenarios from childhood that are repeated Corrective Scripts Choice of the opposite style of parenting Improvised scripts Corrective scripts repeated over time The therapist's background also plays a part in shaping scenarios in therapy. Positive Labeling Can be given to replicative scrips by labeling them as being loyal to the family of origin. Corrective scripts can be given a positive frame by pointing out to parents that they are struggling to provide a better experience for their children than their parents were able to provide for them. Improvised scripts (unlike the historical replicative and corrective scripts) are written in response to current situations. They are improvised either out of necessity or driven by curiosity and a wish to explore new ways of relating. A stimulus for improvisation is a degree of uncertainty about what to do next so that interaction must be played off the cuff. Positive comments can be made about how much the family is exploring unknown territory. Attachment behavior The behavior of a person seeking proximity to his or her attachment figure in a potentially dangerous situation. (This is a mechanism that protects children - or adults - when vulnerable) The child uses the parent as a safe base from which to explore, and parent and child stay in contact to ensure that they can get together in the presence of any potential danger. In terms of script theory a potentially threatening situation evokes tightly scripted behavior in which parent and child predictably got together. Exploration allows for more improvisation. The therapist can become a temporary attachment figure to the family. The therapist must be aware of the factors that threaten the family's relationship. Any new behavior of uncertain origin emerging in a relationship (e.g., unexplained impatience) might be seen as either strange and treated as potentially dangerous, or novel and will arouse curiosity. If it is perceived as strange, attempts may be made to avoid reprovoking the impatience, returning to old familiar ways instead. If the impatience arouses curiosity, then it will probably lead to trying to discover what it is all about, and to improvise ways of dealing with it. If it becomes clear that the impatience poses a problem and something has to be done about it, new solutions may be improvised out of the necessity to sort things out. There are two main forms of improvisation in family relationships: Improvisation that comes out of necessity (Something has to be done when old solutions are not working) Improvisation out of curiosity when it feels safe to try something new, even if it is uncertain where it will lead. A therapist who is trusted by the family can make the risks involved in improvisation feel less frightening, even when family relationships are insecure.

item.title: 3. Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Linear thinking: Behavior is based on previous consequences. Major Tenet: Behavior is determined by its consequences more than its antecedents. Types of conditioning: Classical Conditioning
Operant Conditioning Big Picture: Behavioral Family Therapists are less likely to talk about how families develop and/or operate. They are concerned about the present, and how the problem is being reinforced. Symptoms: Although they are reluctant to do so, Behavioral Therapists have delineated what distinguishes a 'healthy family' and a 'dysfunctional family' (pg. 69-74 and 97-104 in FT Handbook chapters) Mutually shared goals and expectations. Support for the stresses associated with the expected transitional life stages, and other stressful life events. Mutual influence, that is positive more than negative.
Boundaries (more implicit by separating family into dyads) Tolerance for Deviance Skills in conflict resolution Adaptability Flexibility The ability to change when necessary The goal of treatment is to change the problem behavior by changing the consequences of it, or the contingencies of it. Techniques Use of Self
Parent Training: Intervention begins with an assessment of the target child's behavior. The goal of the assessment is to get a baseline of the behavior so that you can quantify change. Functional Analysis of Behavior: Once the problem behavior is identified, then the antecedents and consequences surrounding the behavior are explored. (stimuli, organismic variables, target behavior/response, consequences, contingencies). Report the assessment to the family. Intervene in the pattern. Step 1: Induction (teach the lingo) Step 2: Demonstration (show them how it works) Step 3: Implementation (contingency contracts, time-out, star charts, marble game, etc.) Generalization: The goal is that this training will be generalized to other behaviors, but booster sessions are also helpful. Alexander and Parsons (1982) created for troubled adolescents and their families. Incorporates cognitive aspects and takes a more systemic approach, while the goal is behavioral change. Integrates three perspectives: Ecological Learning Theory Cognitive Two Phases of Treatment Therapy: Designed to modify attitudes, assumptions, expectations, labels and emotions of the family. The major focus is to relabel (reframe) the problem behavior into something positive. Education: Help family behave differently in conjunction with reattributions. Resistance to treatment is considered an impediment to change. It is a natural consequence of the inappropriate application of technology and failure of the clinician to understand the meaning of the behavior. Functional Family Therapy relabels behaviors to reduce resistance and to motivate change by providing reattributions for the causes of family members' behaviors. Change in meaning is a necessary precursor to behavior change. The relabeling (reframe, positive connotation, etc.) operates at three levels: Interactional Level: Benign description of the interpersonal impact of the behavior (distance regulation) Motivational Level: Recasts the motive for the behavior in a benign light. Systemic Level: Emphasizes the similarities between people, a family theme. If the reframe works it interrupts automatic processing, interrupts the behaviors that follow from this processing, and thus, changes the contingencies around the problem behavior. Functional Family Therapy emphasizes paying attention to the interpersonal functions of behaviors: Functions: A person's pattern of behaviors, feelings, and thoughts mediate amounts of psychological relatedness in a relationship with another person (distance regulation) The expression of the function can be labeled good, bad, or neutral, the function itself is not judged. These functions are properties of relationships not traits. Linear Thinking: Cognitive processes need to be incorporated, although some would argue that they were never eliminated in the first place (i.e. cognition is a behavior). Meanings of behaviors, attribution processes, belief sets, automatic thinking can get in the way of contingency change. Unit of analysis tends to be the dyad: Behavior therapists have moved toward more contextual assessments, but each move out focuses on the one to one relationship rather than the system as a whole. Dependency on the therapist? Therapist teaches the model. Based on postivism Not postmodern, it is modern. Politics of behavioral couple therapy, acceptance.
Same process as parent training. Assessment is always first. Social Exchange Theory viewpoint. Could include couple discussing an issue in the room, with therapist observing communication patterns. Also includes evaluating the relationship itself (pg. 106-107). Strengths Major complaints Sex life (affection) Future goals Alternatives to the relationship Individual functioning of each spouse Intervention: Once assessment is complete you set goals with the clients, focusing on one problem (well defined) at a time, this comes in the form of a contract. Major Goals: Increase positive control while decreasing aversive control. Improve communication, which should facilitate future problem solving. Interventions: Active listening with behavioral descriptions of the problem Teach new behavior exchanges Encourage couple to establish clear and effective means of sharing power and decision making. Teach strategies for future problem solving Techniques: Caring Days Make a list of what your partner could do to make you feel cared for. The partner does not need to do anything in return. Do not include sex as it can be seen as coercion. Quid Pro Quo Contracts Not very common because we get into the standstill of 'they have to do it first' Good Faith Contracts Both partners engage in those behaviors whether their partner does or does not. Politics and Power Politics of Behavioral Couple Therapy (i.e. Jacobson) Jacobson saw the issue with classic BMT as a problem with power, who gets to say what needs to change? IBCT was developed from these concerns, the focus shifted to acceptance and forgiveness. IBCT Deep Analysis: D Key differences between partners in personality, interests, goals, etc. E Emotional sensitivities or vulnerabilities that each partner brings to the relationship (create a vicious cycle) E External circumstances (i.e., stressful circumstances which could exacerbate the problems created by differences and vulnerabilities) P Patterns of interaction that couples get into as they try to navigate what comes from DEE above. Intervention based on the idea that all relationship problems result from the combination of a triggering action or inaction and a sensitive reaction. They suggest that relationship problems can be resolved by altering the triggering action and the vulnerable response (emotional acceptance). Empirical support for the model in both clinical trials and efficacy research.

item.title: 4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy
item.description: Most psychoanalytic models are based on Freud's idea around the identity, ego and super ego, or the development of self. For Freud the drives were sexual (in terms of possession and control), for newer psychoanalytic ideas the drives are more around connection and validation of the self (good or bad). Object Relations Theory in some ways provides a bridge between psychodynamic theory and systems theory. We relate to people in the present based on expectations formed by early experience. Normal Development (?) Early development is based on attachment theory/separation-individuation constructs. Infant is born ready to be in a reciprocal relationship. This is activated by relating to a parent, by being loved and loving. Stages of development based on object relations: internal object (mental image of self and other, and self in relation to other). Objectless (primary narcissism/autistic) there is no other, only self. The following stages focus on the development of self through relations with internal and external objects: first the actual interactions and then the unconscious residue of the interactions. As humans, we exist in the context of relationships not as single units: There is no self without an object, there is no object without a self. Infants develop in a context of concentric 'holding environments.' As infants internalize the guarding, protecting, soothing and nurture of this 'holding environment' they begin to form a self (even if the environment is inadequate). These early experiences then form our 'unconscious' drives for connection or separation. 'Real' others are 'used' to satisfy those drives, and we find others to validate our sense of self (good or bad). Health: achieving and preserving psychic wholeness through good object relations, integrating our 'unconscious' with our consciousness. Self and its relationships with others rest on and are expressed by the degree to which relations between the self and object are gratifying (but some theorists would suggest that since we are so narcissistic in the beginning, the relationships with others are never gratifying enough. Is it possible to be healthy?) Fairbairn suggest that as we internalize objects we are inevitably disappointed by them, in order to defend against this pain, we do the follow: We split off those aspects that are too painful to be tolerated. Repress these intolerable aspects. This modifies the ego. Pathology occurs when some aspects of the repressed self-object system are excessively repressed, leaving the central self depleted with an impoverished relationship to the 'ideal object.' Other forms of pathology occur when the central self system is taken over by one of the usual repressed systems, such as those whose relations are characterized by continual patterns of distance and rage with the apparent disappearance of reality. Fear-dictated flight from early object relations is also considered the deepest root of psychological problems. Skynner (1981) Diffuse boundaries Unclear identities Satisfaction from fantasy as opposed to reality Difficulty coping with separation and loss Attempts to preserve past states of relationships Attempts to manipulate others into rigidly held views of them The major goal of Object Relations Theory is to free family members of unconscious restrictions so that they will be able to interact with one another as whole, healthy persons on the basis of current realities rather than unconscious images. The encounter between the therapist and client is the intervention. The relationship is the crucible for change and growth. The therapeutic process is the same as 'normal development' during infancy. The therapist provides the holding environment, contains/introjects the clients' emotions, resolves them, understands them, somehow makes them acceptable, and then the client introjects the resolution of the emotions. Therapist projects back a 'corrective experience.' Self of therapist is key: Transference and counter-transference are the keystones of any psychoanalytic therapy, meaning the therapist must constantly be aware of who they are' for the client, and who the client is for them. Change occurs through insight and working through. Techniques: Listening Empathy Interpretation and maintaining neutrality with respect to what or how things change Big Picture (how families operate/develop): He uses attachment theory as a base. Early attachment relationships create 'working models' of how relationships are supposed to be, they create 'scripts.' as people interact with each other to become a family, they create their own 'family script' based on these early 'working models.' families have attachment patterns that are full of meanings about abandonment, engulfment, intrusion, etc. (i.e., distance regulation) These scripts provide routines for family life which can be followed automatically. They are shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts. These scripts may be carried out from generation to generation in one form or another. Some use replicative scripts (repeat what has happened in the past), while others use corrective scripts (trying not to repeat scripts from the family of origin). There is a constant tension between these two. Healthy vs. Dysfunctional families Healthy families have scripts that provide a set of roles with which each member can identify and which provides room for improvisation when facing new situations. These scripts promote interactional awareness: Consequences of interaction Self-awareness (why you are acting in a particular way) Empathic awareness (why others are acting in particular ways) Understanding the meaning of the interaction Shared coherent perception of what is happening Symptoms occur when there is difficulty updating scripts. They may occur because the script necessary remains someone or something too painful to relive. Intolerable information is blocked or edited both intraphysically and interpersonally (secrets)\ Symptoms may also occur when a family script is used to prevent what members may fear to be an even worse disaster. Even though the current script is painful, it is rigidly clung to (the solution has become to problem) Major goal is improvisation (flexibility). In order to create an environment safe enough to explore options however, the therapist must provide a secure base from which to explore. Paradoxically, scripts, although repetitive, provide the background against which change can occur. Attachment notions Secure Curious Improvisation Uncertainty Insecure Avoid strangeness Stick with the familiar Instead of conflict in the family arising out of one person's pathology which extends to influence another's behavior, family scripts are encoded in all family members' minds, but each family member plays a particular role. Therefore, each member of the family can be taught to see how their role contributes to the problem, rather than asking the 'sick one' to reown the bad object and working through these issues. Reduce strategies that undermine problem-solving abilities (i.e., triangulating, scapegoating, etc.) Reduce strategies that undermine security (threats about leaving, control, etc.) Move toward collaboration rather than coercion and blame. Re-edit scripts so the roles are fillable by the individuals in the family. Move closer to an ideal script in which a wide scope of improvising is possible. Develop a hopeful script. Promote ownership of family's success, attributable to them not you as the therapist. This is still important for the therapist to attend to. The therapist needs to contain the family's emotions in a way so as not to become another player in their script. Therapists own scripts can also be replayed, thus it is essential that the therapist understand their own family script. Byng-Hall outlines methods for staying out of the script and for containing emotional impact: Staying out: Use teams, get supervision, have a clear plan, use circular questioning Containing: Reflecting on the process, seeing emotions as valuable information, differentiating your script from the family's, share your emotional experience with the family. Absolves people of responsibility for their behavior (it is my mother's fault) Lack of empirical testing Tautological thinking: Make an interpretation, it is rejected, patient is resistant, you must be onto something. Perspective is individualist or dyadic without revision. Deterministic, linear thinking (it is my mother's fault) Blaming the victim (you put yourself in this situation, because of what your mother did) Mother blaming Long process

item.title: 1. Philosophy of Change Framework
item.description:
Parts in interaction such that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System (i.e. human systems) exchange matter/energy with the environment (for Family Systems and our purposes this in information)
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System s have to have monitoring functions that allow them to pay attention to what is important in their environments (i.e. feedback) If they have monitoring functions then there needs to be increasing complexity of rules about how to handle the feedback, and when to change in order to continue to grow and adapt to both internal and external sources of information (Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc.) All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate. Systems are goal directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback.
System Complexity: An increase in the autonomy of the component parts and an increase in the extent to which the system or its parts determines system behavior (parts of not simply reactive to input from the environment).
Requisite Variety: A wide range and quantity of varied information, experience and input into the system that is somehow stored for future use.
Morphostasis: As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Morphogenesis: As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to change in order to accommodate to the new information. These processes are simultaneous and constant as the system adapts and also maintains its integrity. When continuity and the need to accommodate to change become integrated in the system then the system is flexible and stable at the same time. When that is happening we would say the system is 'effectively' functioning and capable of growth and change. Behaviors and interaction patterns will not be repeated unless they serve the system in some way. If a pattern of interaction is repeated it is serving the system in some way (symptoms serve a function). How do families operate? How do families develop? Symptoms: What is different about families that are 'healthy' and families that develop symptoms? How do symptoms develop? They would not be repeated if it was not supported by the system. How can we intervene to change the way the family operates given the theory? What is the focus of the intervention? Is it having them act in a certain way? What is the focus? We don't teach them about theory specifically, we are wanting to change behavior

item.description:
Parts in interaction such that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Open system (i.e., human systems) exchange matter/energy with the environment (for Family Systems and our purposes this in information) Open systems have to have monitoring functions that allow them to pay attention to what is important in their environment (i.e., feedback) If they have monitoring functions then there needs to be increasing complexity of rules about how to handle the feedback, and when to change in order to continue to grow and adapt to both internal and external sources of information. (Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc) All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate. Systems are goal-directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback. System Complexity: System Complexity An increase in the autonomy of the component parts and an increase in the extent to which the system or its parts determines system behavior (parts of not simply reactive to input from the environment)

Morphostasis: Morphostasis As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).

item.title: 6. Narrative Family Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/6. Narrative Family Therapy.md

item.title: 1. Introduction
item.description:
In many contexts, the term 'couple' has replaced 'marriage' because of its emphasis on the bond between family members/individuals. This shift in language is important - taking a non-judgmental approach. There is a social value implied by the more traditional terms (which privileges marriage). Use the most inclusive term possible (e.g., family) With respect to all types of relationships, use the term 'couple' as it broadly encompasses those within a committed relationship (regardless of marital status). With respect to persons of various gender identities and sexual orientations, use the term 'partner' rather than gendered language (whenever possible). While the terms such as spouse, wife, husband, boyfriend, girlfriend may be preferred by clients - intentionally using the term 'partner' may be more inclusive. With respect to those we serve, we will refer to them as clients as opposed to patients (whenever possible). Psychiatrists are physicians whoo specializes in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mental health and emotional problems. (M.D. needed) Psychologist study the human mind and behavior. (Masters needed) Social Workers help people function the best way they can in their environment, deal with their relationships, and solve problems. (Bachelors degree needed, unless clinical social work which needs a masters level degree) Counselors assist people with personal, family, educational, mental health, and career decisions and problems. (Masters needed) All: Diagnose Individual/relational intervention Psychiatry Diagnose Prescribe Psychology Assessment Intra Marriage and family Therapy Family intervention Inter Social Work Case management A family's patterns of behaviors influences the individual and therefore may need to be a part of the treatment plan. In CFT, the unit of treatment isn't just the person - even if only one person is 'the client'; it is the set of relationships in which the person is embedded. Brief Solution-focused Specific with attained therapeutic goals Designed with attainable therapeutic goals Designed with the 'end in mind' MFTs treat a wide range of serious clinical problems including: Depression Relationship issues Anxiety Biopsychosocial-rooted problems Research has shown that CFT is as effective or more effective than standard individual treatments for many mental health problems including: Schizophrenia Affective Mood Disorder Substance (Ab)use Child Conduct Disorder Anorexia Autism Chronic Illness Couple/Partner Distress Psychiatry raised concern about scope of practice Wanted to keep MFTs from diagnosis Psychology sought amendments to the scope to place restrictions on psychological testing, and some oppose licensure in general. Social Work concerned with title restriction Wanted to call its members MFTs Counselors (ACA) historically most active opponents Opposed MFT licensure all together Labeled the discipline as a subspecialty of counseling Professionals from many different disciplines may at times utilize family-based interventions, or work from theories or models that are core to the CFT discipline. Does that mean they are CFTs? Profession vs. Practice AAMFT's response 'It's not our intent to define the standards or the scope of practice of any other discipline - social work or psychology, for example, by saying what services they can perform or what training is need to perform those series. "We assume those professions will be diligent in ensuring that their practitioners will only deliver services for which they have had training, and are competent to perform, and that the regulatory boards for those professions will police those who go beyond their competence." Classic Schools Bowen Strategic Family Therapy
Jay Haley Depathologize problems by viewing them as normative life-cycle complications. Consider possible adaptive functions for the family. Acknowledge the helpful, alberit misguided, intentions of individuals within a family to help one another. In such reformulations, new solutions can more readily become apparent.
Structural Family Therapy
Salvador Minuchin No family style is inherently normal or abnormal. Whether organizational patterns are functional or dysfunctional depends largely on their fit with the family's developmental and social demands. The strength of the system requires clear yet flexible boundaries and subsystems for the ability to shift organizational patterns to accommodate needed change.
Experiential Family Therapy
Virginia Satir
Carl Whitaker
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) Developments
Contextual Therapy
Solution-Focused Therapy Focus on solutions (i.e., what works), future-oriented. Focusing on exceptions (i.e., those times when the problem was not present). Direct toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms.
Narrative Therapy
Michael White
David Epston Families have good intentions and neither want nor need problems. Families can develop empowering stories when separated form their problems and constraining cultural beliefs. Redirect focus from causal assumptions of dysfunction to appreciate the toxic effects of many dominant discourses in the social world. Others
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy Evidenced-based treatments Couples
Emotionally Focused Couples Therapy
Gottman Therapy Relationship Education there Marital Preparation Multi-group Couples Therapy Does family therapy work? Therapeutic processes (e.g., how it works) Therapeutic outcomes (e.g., what results) How large are the effects of family therapy in terms of their impact on families? Are these effects sometimes negative? What are the efficacy and effectiveness of different models of family therapy? What therapist and family factors predict responsiveness to treatment? Is family therapy helping in treatment individual problems? What interactional patterns or characteristics of the family? How healthy and satisfied is the family? How did the relational patterns develop? How are they maintained? Risk factors for family functioning? How do cultural and contextual factors (e.g., age, gender, identity, class, race, etc.) play into the family's functioning? How has the family adapted to transitions, change, and crises? Frequency, setting, and duration of symptoms? Who besides the family is included in the problem? Are psychotropic medications being used? Are individual sessions held? And under what conditions? Co-therapists? Is therapy time limited? How long does it last? How often are sessions? What is the therapist's role? Consultant? Teacher? Healer? What is the role of the therapist-couple alliance? How is a working alliance fostered? To what degree does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist handle escalations? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Does the therapist use self-disclosure? What are the limits? Does the therapist's role change during the course of therapy? What are the treatment goals? How are the goals determined or prioritized? Who determines the goals of therapy? How are 'mixed agendas' handled? How structured are therapy sessions? Pacing or rhythm? What techniques are used to join with the family? Is psychoeducation included? Is homework included? If secrets are revealed individually, how are secrets handled? What are the common errors that a therapist can make? How is termination determines and handled? Why is family therapy important? Why might clients choose family therapy over other approaches (i.e., individual, couple, group therapy)? When might family therapy be preferred to other treatment modalities? Under what circumstances or presenting problems might family therapy be most appropriate? What is your assessment of the problem? What is the presenting problem? Who is defining it? How is it defined? Who is the identified client? How does each member of the family view the problem? Do they share the defition? What solutions have been attempted? What are the family's beliefs, values, and cultural strengths for dealing with the problem? Reaction to psychoanalytic traditions Research on schizophrenia Acknowledge of family and contextual factors in mental illness Adoption of systems theories 1920s Group Therapy Movement 1940-1950
The Child Guidance Movement (1940s-1950s) 1950s Communication and role theories 1970s Brief therapy theories Therapists first encountered families as adversaries. Therapists begin to notice that often when a client got better, someone else in the family got worse, almost as though the family needed a symptomatic member. Clients improved in the hospital only to get worse when they went home. Parents sometimes use their children as a buffer to protect themselves from intimacy/ I.e., You're scratching your eyes for your mother so she'll have something to worry about. You're a good boy. Good children sacrifice themselves for their parents. I.e., Minuchin: As a father of a child in danger, what you're doing isn't enough. Father: What should I do? Minuchin: I don't know. Ask your son. Groups dynamics are applicable to family therapy because group life is a complex blend of individual personalities and properties of the group. The process/context distinction in group dynamics had a major impact on family therapy. Attend to how family members talk as much as to what they say. Family members have a long history and a future together. Continuity, commitment, and shared distortions all make family therapy different from group therapy. Concluded that the real problem wasn't a child's symptoms, but rather the tensions in the family that were the source of those symptoms. Tendency to blame the parents, especially mothers (this was an evolutionary misdirection that haunts the field). We need to understand the family in order to diagnose problems. Many do not distinguish between couple and family therapy. Couples therapy is just family therapy applied to a particular subsystem. However, there is a case to be made that couples therapy is a distinct enterprise (see Gurman texts) For many years, therapists resisted the idea of seeing clients' families in order to safeguard the privacy of the therapeutic relationship. Converging developments in the 1950s led to a new view that the family was an organic whole. What they observed was that the behavior of schizophrenia fit with their families; what they concluded was that the family was the cause of schizophrenia. Champions of family therapy challenged the assumption that schizophrenia was a biological disease. Psychological healers everywhere cheered. Unfortunately, we were wrong. The observation that schizophrenic behavior seems to fit in some families doesn't mean that families caused schizophrenia. Families of schizophrenic members suffered for years from the assumption that they were to blame for their child's psychoses. Modern Model Events and Timeline 1942: Founding of the American Association of Marriage Counselors 1945:
Ludwig von Bertalanffy presents General Systems Theory 1950s: Intergenerational
Family Systems Theory
Contextual Therapy
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Experiential Family Therapy
Brief Strategic (Mental Research Institute (MRI)) 1960s:
Structural Family Therapy
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) 1970s: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Counselors Strategic (Milan)
Strategic (Jay Haley) 1978: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy Post-Modern Model Events and Timeline 1980s
Emotionally Focused Couples Therapy Feminist Models Collaborative Language Systems Solution-Focused Therapy 1990s Integrative Couples Therapy
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy
Narrative Therapy Solution-Oriented Therapy Multiculturalism 2000s Managed care/ empirically validated treatments To understand this better, consider the example of a mobile. When you move any one piece of a mobile, all the other pieces move too. They do not exist in isolation from one another, and movement in any one part of the system will affect all the rest of the parts of the system. The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems.
Feedback Loop: The process by which a system gets the information necessary to maintain a steady course. If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior. Feedback loops can be negative or positive.
Negative Feedback: Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track.
Positive Feedback Reinforces the direction a system is taking. What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship. Family therapists use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning) At the core, the theory is about: Structure Functioning The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Mapping sequences of interaction (which reveal how a system works)
Homeostasis: The self-regulation that keeps the system stable Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve. A system is, 'Any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.' A system can be composed of smaller subsystems. Every system is a subsystem of larger systems. Open vs. Closed systems Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances.
Social Constructionism: Seeing the world through a pair of glasses.
Reframing: Relabeling behavior to shift how family members respond to it. The goal of therapy shifted from interrupting problematic patterns of interaction to helping clients find new perspective on their lives. When they said reality was constructed, they meant socially constructed. Interpretations are shaped by our context. Interpretation of our experience mediates behavior. Social constructionists place more emphasis on the intersubjective influence of language and culture. Therapy becomes a process of deconstruction, freeing clients from the tyranny of entrenched beliefs. Inherent in most forms of therapy is the idea that before you can solve a problem, you must figure out what is wrong. But solution-focused turns this assumption on its head. The best way to solve problems is to discover what people do when they are not having the problem. Exceptions to a complaint. Therapists create a shift in their clients' experience by helping them reexamine how they look at things.
Externalization: Redefining problems not as properties of the individuals who suffer them, but as alien oppressors. The focus of therapy has expanded toward the wider context. This process started when therapists looked beyond individuals to their families. Suddenly unexplained behavior made sense. Early on, family therapists focused on behavioral interactions surrounding problems. Next, they recognize that those interactions were manifestations of a family's underlying structure. Structure became the target of change. Later, family structure was seen as the product of multigenerational processes that were governed by belief systems. Then, therapists aimed their interventions at those underlying beliefs. More recently, it dawned on therapists that those belief systems do not arise in a vacuum Behavior is shaped by transactions we don't always see. Systems concepts help make complex interactions predictable.
Family Structure: Defines the organization within which interactions take place. Interactions shape structure, but once established structure shapes interactions.
Subsystems
Boundaries
Family Life Cycle Context: People are products of their context. Behavior is powerfully influenced by interactions with other family members.
Circular Causality: Problems are sustained by an ongoing series of actions and reactions.
Triangles Process/Content Focus on the process of communication (how people talk), rather than the context (what they talk about) The goal is to get an overview of the presenting problem and arrange to meet. Listen to the description of the problem and identify all members of the family, household, and others who might be involved. Establish connection and engagement. Ask how the problem is affecting other members of the family. You'd like to hear from everyone, at least initially, in order to get as much information as possible. Reminder calls help increase likelihood of attendance. Build alliance with the family. Develop hypothesis about what is maintaining the presenting problem. Establish rapport. Gather information. Introduce yourself. Orient the family to the therapy room (physical or virtual) and the format of sessions. Invite family members to speak one at a time. Give everyone a chance to be heard. Establish a bond of understanding with each member of the family.
Process: How did you feel about coming in? What were your reactions to coming in? Take a family history. Conduct the genogram to diagram the family network. Listen for family life cycle transitions. Search for strengths and resilience. Remain curious and respectful. Explore the process of family interaction by asking questions about how family members relate to one another and inviting them to discuss their problems with one another in session. What is keeping the family stuck? Share recommendations for treatment. What is maintaining the problem? Maintain therapeutic alliance. Listen to and acknowledge family members' points of view. Through empathic understanding, family members feel respected and become open to being challenged. When one person is presented as the problem, challenge linearity by asking how others are involved or affected? What role do others play in creating or maintaining the problem? How have they responded to it? Challenge unhelpful interactions by pointing out patterns that seem to be keeping the family stuck. The more you do X, the more they do Y - and the more you do Y, the more they do X. Listen to people's feelings. Listening is a silent activity, rare in our time, even among therapists. Family members are not likely to reconsider their assumptions until they've been heard and understood. Help family members deal with one another more effectively in session. Take a less active role and encourage family members to interact more with one another. Step back and observe. When family members address their conflicts directly, they tend to become reactive; anxiety is the enemy of listening - help them listen and manage anxiety. Stay calm: You are not responsible for solving the family's problems. Just look for the constraints that are keeping them stuck. Be curious. Display empathy and respect. Review the therapeutic relationship. Say goodbye. Reinforce progress. Review what the family has accomplished. Anticipate and plan for upcoming challenges. How will you know when things are heading backwards? And what will you do? How will you know if it is time to come back to therapy? Check-in with the family following treatment, if possible. The presenting problem Understanding the referral route Identifying the systemic context Stage of family life cycle Family structure Communication Substance use/abuse Domestic violence and sexual abuse Affairs/infidelity Cultural context (race, ethnicity, culture, gender identity, sexual orientation, class, disability, etc.) Explore the presenting problem. Explore attempts to deal with the problem. What have they tried? What has been helpful? What hasn't been helpful? Has anyone who is not present been trying to help or hinder? Who referred the clients and why? What are their expectations? What expectations have they communicated to the family? Is participation voluntary or mandated? Who recognized the need for treatment? What other agencies are or will be involved with the case? Obtain a clear understanding of the interpersonal context of the problem. Who is in the family? Are there other important figures in the life of the problem who aren't present? Family of origin, immediate family, extended family, family of choice, etc. Are there other agencies involved? What is their input? Does the family see them as helpful? Remember that family therapy is an approach to people in context. Family problems become entrenched because they are embedded in powerful but unseen structure. What is the family's structure? What are the subsystems?
What is the nature of Boundaries between the subsystems?
What Triangles are present? Assess for substance use, IPV, and affairs. Consider assessment tools if needed. Be aware of mandated reporting. General Practitioner What is your scope of practice? Specialist Do you specialize in particular populations? Or problems? Most family therapists assume their approach can be applied to any problem. Of course their may be exceptions. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Systems can be viewed in terms of hierarchy, organization, and subsystems. Systems strive toward self-preservation and therefore its members work in service of the system, as well as themselves. All behavior makes sense in context. No one family member is responsible for the family's distress. Family therapists work to see the big picture. Even when a client presents with an individual issue (e.g., depression, anxiety), family therapists view it within the larger relational context. Share the following assumptions: A person's lived reality is relationally constructed. Personal identity and individual symptomology are related to the social systems in which they are embedded. Changing one's language and description of the problem alters how it is experienced. Truth can be determined only within relational contexts. Systems theory Systems metaphor A family is a system, a group of individuals who coordinate meaning and their understanding of the world. Social constructionist Textual metaphor People narrate their lives to create meaning using the social discourses available to them. Skeptical of objective reality. Reality is constructed. Reality is constructed through language. Reality is negotiated through relationships. Shared meanings coordinate social action. Founded upon the logical-positivist assumptions of an external, knowable truth. Therapist assumes expert role. Therapist is an expert who assumes the primary responsibility for identifying problems and goals, often assumes the role of a teacher or mentor. Theory and research are the primary sources of information for identifying problems and diagnosis. Therapist uses theory and research to select treatment approaches. Humans are essentially good. All people naturally tend toward growth and strive for self-actualization. Focus on treatment is the subjective, internal world of clients. Therapeutic interventions target emotions with the goal of promoting catharsis (release of repressed emotions). A supportive, nurturing environment promoted therapeutic change.
Examples such as Carl Whitaker and Virginia Satir One cannot communicate; all behavior is a form of communication. An individual's behavior and symptoms always make sense in context.
All behaviors and symptoms serve a purpose within the system, allowing the system to maintain Homeostasis. No one individual controls behavior in a system and therefore no one individual can be blamed for problems in the family. Problematic behavior emerges from the interactions between members of the system. Therapeutic change involves altering the interaction patterns within the system. Objective truth can never be fully known because it must always pass through subjective and intersubjective filters. The human mind does not have access to an outside reality independent of human interpretation. Knowledge and truth are culturally, historically, and relationally bound. Personal reality and truth are shaped by language and relationships. Language affects how identity is shaped and experienced. The identification of the problem is a social process that occurs through language. Therapy is a process of co-constructing new realities. As therapists become more aware of theories, they learn to skillfully integrate ideas from other approaches in a way that is philosophically congruent with their own approach. However, therapists who are 'eclectic' or 'integrative' in a way that is not grounded in a single philosophical set of assumptions will confuse their clients. Clients will be confused if each week the client is required to relate differently to the therapist and to assume a different level of participation (i.e., sending contradictory messages). If the therapist is able to keep the philosophical assumptions consistent throughout therapy, then the therapist can adapt concepts and techniques from other approaches without sending conflicting messages. Standard I: Responsibility to Clients Non-discrimination, informed consent, multiple relationships, reporting, abuse, referrals, non-abandonment, consent to record. Standard II: Confidentiality Limits to confidentiality, releases, access to records. Standard III: Professional Competence and Integrity Competency, conflicts of interest, records maintenance, harassment, exploitation, gifts, scope of practice, misconduct. Standard IV: Responsibility to Students and Supervisees Exploitation, confidentiality Standard V: Research and Publication Protection of participants, informed consent, right to withdraw, confidentiality, publication, authorship, plagiarism. Standard VI: Technology-Assisted Professional Services Teletherapy, consent, confidentiality, location of services and practice, training Standard VII: Professional Evaluations Forensics, testimony, competence, informed consent, avoiding conflicts, child custody, professional opinions Standard VIII: Financial Arrangements Disclosure of financial policies, recovery procedures, bartering Standard IX: Advertising Professional representation, affiliations, educational credentials, qualifications National
AAMFT Code of Ethics Research Citations/A/@AAMFTCodeofEthics2015 Local State regulatory board, laws and codes When in doubt, consult! Reviews of psychotherapy outcome research document the empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of psychotherapy. Wide range of presenting problems. Diverse therapeutic approaches Therapeutic is effective. Treated families fare better than untreated. We need to evaluate the evidence t - What is the typee of evidence? - Targeting what outcomess? - For whom? Technical/model factors ‚ÄúInfluential Figures in CFT History.pdf‚Äù could not be found.

item.title: 5. Solution-Focused Therapy
item.description:
Steve de Shazer
Insoo Kim Berg Miracle question Rating/Scaling (1 to 10) Break After intermission, the therapist will give the client/family compliments, sometimes followed by a suggestion or homework. If it ain't broken, don't fix it. Once you know what works, do more of it. If it doesn't work, don't do it again, do something different. Solution-focused family therapy begins with clients' descriptions of how they want their lives to be different. It can be understood as beginning with the end of the story, rather than the beginning of the problem. The basic idea is to avoid escalating problem talk by instead focus on eliciting movement in a helpful direction (i.e., focusing on solutions). Focus is on solutions, on what works for clients. Respect clients own resources. Directed toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms. Future-oriented Focusing on those times when the problem was not present (exceptions). The task of therapy is to do something different. What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen? The most fundamental difference between the emphasis between problem-focused therapy and solution-focused therapy is the emphasis each give to the concept of 'solution.' Solution-focused family therapy seeks to identify exceptions to the problem and develop new solutions that work. What brings you in? What are your best hopes for this meeting? Therapists avoid diagnostic categories and preconceived notions of what may be healthy or unhealthy. Accept the client's version of what is, and what is not, the problem. It isn't necessary to know what causes problems in order to make things better. Families that come to therapy are capable of behaving effectively, but their effectiveness has been blunted by a negative mind-set. The model draws attention to forgotten capabilities, which release families from preoccupation with their failures and restores them to their capable selves. Problems are seen as overwhelming because families see them as always happening, times when problems are not happening, aren't noticed, or are dismissed. People are constrained by narrow views of their problems that perpetuate rigid patterns of false solutions. The meanings people attribute to behavior limit the range of alternatives they will use to deal with a situation. Changing the way people talk about their problems. The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions. Problem talk: Negative Focuses on the past Implies permanence of problems. Clients are experts in their own lives. Clients know what they need Is there anything else I should have asked you or that you need to tell me? The therapist needs to know how to set aside their own frame of reference as much as possible and explore those of their clients. People are resourceful. Problems are normal life-cycle complications. Families have the abillity to construct solutions that can enhance their lives. Solution-focused therapists steer families away from speculating about problem formation. Problems persist in the way people define situations and in the misdirected actions they persist in taking. Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems. Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance. The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible. The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives. The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable. What will you be doing instead? The model works by helping clients amplify exceptions to their problems ‚Äì effective solutions already in their repertoire. Changing the way people talk about their problems is all that needs to be accomplished. As the family and therapist talk more and more about the solution they want to construct together, they come to believe in what they are talking about. It is easier to get people to talk differently about their problems than it is to get them to change their behavior. Getting people to talk positively will help them think positively and ultimately act positively to solve their problems. Change perception helps with the change of behavior. As a picture of positive future develops, the family begins to see themselves differently and they respond to what they see. They begin living in the solution, not the problem. The 'virtuous cycle' gets going, the family gets unstuck, and they move forward. Time limited Sessions are made one at a time One may be enough Typical course includes 3-5 sessions Clients can return as-needed Often a week to a few weeks apart Once you know more of what works, do more of it Gather a brief description of the presenting problem. Move to directly asking clients about how things will be different in their lives then their probelms are solved. Ask about times in the clients' lives when their problems do not happen or are less severe. What do you think the problem is now? How will you know when the problem is solved? How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be? What will have to be different about others involved in the situation? What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen? What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back? Takes little intake information because they want to hear clients' constructions of their problems firsthand (in session). Asks more about perceptions than feelings. Affirms clients' positions by conveying understanding of their point of view. Doesn't function as an expert; clients are experts on what they want to change. Takes an active position in moving clients away from worrying about their predicament and toward steps to solution. Anyone who is concerned about the problem should attend sessions and are part of the solution. Consultant Guardian of the conversation Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk' Focus on what is right Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative. Therapist attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding. Focus on the 'here and now' The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes. Assumes a position of 'not knowing.' What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time? Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today? Constructing a more detailed description of the therapeutic goal. Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the client to assess their current level of progress toward
