item.title: @denscombeGroundRulesSocial2010
item.description: Bibliography: Denscombe, M. (2010). Ground rules for social research: Guidelines for good practice. Type: Book Title: Ground rules for social research: guidelines for good practice, Author: Denscombe, Martyn; Publisher: Open Univ. Press, McGraw-Hill, Location: Maidenhead, Series: Open Up study skills Year: 2010 ISBN: 978-0-335-23381-6 Keywords: In Progress (Denscombe, 2010, p. 17)‚Äúthe purpose of the research is something that needs to be understood concisely, precisely and right from the beginning.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚Äúa clear vision of the purpose of research provides a crucial basis for evaluating the research‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚ÄúThis allows readers to evaluate the research by providing benchmarks against which to judge the extent to which the research has been successful.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚Äúa clear vision of the purpose of research provides a good platform from which to conduct the investigation. This applies whether the research uses a quantitative, a qualitative, or a mixed methods approach‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚ÄúClarity of purpose also calls on the researcher to identify a relatively narrow and precise area for investigation rather than setting out to investigate some general area of interest. It requires the researcher to focus attention on specific aspects, specific questions, specific issues within the broader area of interest.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚Äúunless some quite specific topic is pinpointed, there is the very real danger that: ‚Ä¢ researchers will ‚Äòbite off more than they can chew‚Äô; ‚Ä¢ researchers will flounder in a sea of vast quantities of issues and data; ‚Ä¢ time will be wasted on the collection of unnecessary information; ‚Ä¢ time will be wasted on meanderings up blind alleys before a clear direction becomes evident; ‚Ä¢ vague questions might lead to vague answers.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)‚ÄúSocial research questions must be, in principle, testable. Explanations and theories must be open to proof or disproof‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)‚ÄúThe research should also offer something new.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)‚ÄúThe literature review is particularly important‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)‚ÄúTo offer something new or different, the research needs to build on existing knowledge and link to what is already known on a particular topic or issue.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)‚ÄúGood research avoids the pitfall of being over-ambitious in terms of its scale and its scope.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚Äúit is essential that the research does not set out to do something that is illegal or immoral.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚Äúthe project researcher should ensure that his/her activities accord with ethical standards and codes of conduct that operate for the discipline, the profession and the country in which the research is located.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚Äúdescriptive research, which provides detailed accounts of events or situations in order to gain a clearer picture of what is going on.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚Äúexplanatory research, which is mainly concerned with cause‚Äìeffect relationships. It builds on well-established theories with a view to developing them and using them to make predictions that can be tested. It aims to explain why things happen.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚Äúexploratory research, which investigates new areas and which seeks to generate new theories and concepts.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)‚ÄúThe rights and interests of participants and others directly affected by the research will be taken into consideration. The research will be conducted in accord with an appropriate code of research ethics. Approval will be sought from a relevant ethics committee or institutional review board. The research will be conducted in an honest, open and transparent manner ‚Äì as far as it is possible.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)‚ÄúEthics refers to the system of moral principles by which individuals can judge their actions as right or wrong, good or bad‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)‚Äúresearchers need to introduce a moral perspective to the way they design and conduct their investigations.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)‚Äúneed to consider what will be acceptable in the context of the values of the wider society in which the research is conducted‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)‚ÄúThe motivation for researchers to operate ethically should be a matter of professional integrity‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)‚Äú‚ÄòThe acceptability of social research depends increasingly on the willingness of social researchers to accord respect to their subjects and to treat them with consideration.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)‚ÄúResearch that does not do this will damage the reputation of social research‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)‚Äúwithout the good will and trust of the public large parts of social research will become starved of information.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)‚ÄúResearch‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)‚Äúmust take account of the moral and legal climate of the time and the boundaries this places on the topics of investigation that are deemed acceptable and the nature of the methods of investigation it tolerates.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74) Ground rule: Research should produce findings from which generalizations can be made. Either the research is based on a sample of people, events, or data that are representative of the wider population (generalizability). Or sufficient information is given about the characteristics of the sample or the cases used in the research for judgements to be made about the extend to which findings can be expected to apply more widely (transferability). Or the people, events, or data included in the research have been chosen because of their particular characteristics and the belief that these characteristics will be helpful for generating and developing theories (theory relevance). ‚ÄúA generalization involves drawing some conclusion about a whole group or category of things on the basis of information drawn from particular instances or examples. On the basis of what is found to exist in a relatively few instances or examples, propositions are made about the nature and qualities of the whole class.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 195) ‚ÄúResearchers usually wish to feel confident that their findings have been based on samples that are either representative of, or have particular characteristics that are significant for the analysis of, the broader class of thing being investigated. Another reason centers on the researcher's wish to produce generalized knowledge in the form of theories.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 195-196) ‚ÄúThe concern with generalizations relates to the way findings from specific pieces of research lend themselves to the development of propositions that work very widely ‚Äì possibly universally ‚Äì and that contribute to establishing rules or theories about the workings of social phenomena.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196) Generalizations Continue to be a crucial aspect of good research for all but a small minority of those operating under the umbrella of ‚Äòsocial research‚Äô Can be justified in different ways depending on the nature of the particular research and its underlying assumptions Need to be incorporated into the rationale for the research.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196) ‚Äúthe criteria for selection are the crucial starting point when it comes to generalizations.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196) ‚Äúthe selection of the items to be included in the study needs to be done on a logical basis ‚Äì a basis that allows generalizations from the data to be defended as reasonable and justifiable ‚Äì and within social research there are broadly two approaches to this matter. One way is to go for a representative sample. This tends to be favored by relatively large-scale survey research using quantitative data and a positivistic approach. The alternative is to select the items for study on the basis of their particular characteristics. Smaller-scale research involving case studies, qualitative data and an interpretivist approach tend to rely on this.‚Äù (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196) Do the findings from the research apply elsewhere? Have the criteria for selection of the people, events, or data been described and justified? Reflecting the criteria for selection, have an adequate number and appropriate diversity of people, events, or data been included in the research? Does the description of the sample or cases used in the research allow comparisons with others of their type? Research tends to focus on a reduced number of instances of the thing under investigation. It investigates a sample or it investigates specific cases. To what extend do the findings from the sample or case apply to other instances that were not included in the study? To be representative, samples need to: Cover all relevant types Have these types in proportion to the volumes found in the whole population A representative sample includes a balanced cross-section of all of the relevant instances. This justifies generalizing from the findings of the sample. To achieve representativeness: Use of random samples. Provided that the units included (people, observations, etc.) in the research are sufficiently large and are chosen on a genuinely random basis, the end result ought to be representative of the total population from which they were drawn. There is the selection of samples by quotas. On the basis of attributes of the population which are already known, the researcher can select samples deliberately to include all the relevant types and to cover these types in proportion to their profile in the total population. It is not always easy for researchers to obtain a sample that qualifies as 'representative' according to these strict criteria. It demands that we know relevant details about the whole population. Social researchers frequently rely on a less stringent version of representativeness in which the principle remains the same but the rigor of selection of the sample is relaxed somewhat. The principle is still that the instances used for the research allow for the findings of the research to be extrapolated to other instances not included in the research. The researcher does not claim that the sample necessarily meets all the criteria of representativeness. The claim is that the instances used for research are 'typical'. The word 'typical' carries with it some notion of being standard, of being normal, of being usual. It suggests that any findings from the sample will apply elsewhere because the instances included in the sample have no particularly unusual characteristics that mark them out from the rest. While claims to conducting research on 'typical' instances certainly retain the need to identify key features relevant to the investigation, the sample might not include all of the relevant categories. The claim to generalizability, however, persists through the emphasis on: Including the main type Achieving some balance of the numbers in each category A case study approach is used when a researcher's focus is on a limited number of instances. Researchers can make the strategic decision to concentrate their investigation on one or a few cases in order to allow greater depth to their research, more attention to the dynamics of the situation, better insights that come from a detailed knowledge and understanding of a specific example. (Qualitative researchers favor this strategy) Example: There is almost no chance of getting a sample that is large enough and widespread enough to satisfy the criteria for being representative, in a statistical sense, of the whole 'population.' The selection tends to rely on a more purposeful process in which examples are chosen for their particular qualities, as opposed to being chosen with no regard for their individual traits (random) or being chosen with respect to some general category (quota). There are 4 grounds on which cases might be chosen to reflect their particular qualities: Researchers can justify generalizations from their case study (or small sample) if they can establish that the instance included in the research was typical of other instances. The basis for the generalization is that whatever was found in the one instance actually studies was likely to appear in other instances because there was nothing unusual, nothing special, about the case that was investigated. Social researchers can opt to focus on instances that are anything but representative or typical. 'Extreme' instances may be selected deliberately because they have certain qualities that exaggerate the influence of a particular factor that is of interest to the researchers. Things might be visible in these circumstances simply because the situation is extreme or special, and that these might be impossible to detect in more 'watered down' instances. Things become visible here that would remain hidden under typical circumstances. (It can suggest the way things might develop if typical instances start to shift towards the special or extreme. The special/extreme example might act to alert is to factors that would otherwise have remained hidden under the typical circumstances. What was detected in the extreme instance should be looked for in the typical.) Researchers might decide to focus on instances which would appear to present a least likely scenario in terms of the theory or proposition they are investigating. Following the commitment to testing theories to destruction and challenging existing theories or suppositions through attempting to 'falsify' them, there is clear logic to choosing instances that might be expected to 'go against the grain' and prove the theory wrong. The selection of a case might reflect the fact that it constitutes an event or situation that is a special case - a one-off or extremely rare occurrence. It is almost certain that such events or situations are beyond the control of the researcher in the sense that he or she could not organize for them to happen, as in an experiment. The timing and the location of the event will be something to which the researcher responds rather than initiates. The degree to which the findings from the small number of events or cases being studies might be expected to apply elsewhere can be addressed by comparing and contrasting the nature of the specific units of study with the broader population of such units that exist. The selection of instances for research can be based on their usefulness in terms of the contrast they offer with other instances chosen to be included in the research. The researcher can deliberately set out to select examples that provide a stark contrast with one another and that represent the widest variation possible within the thing being studied. Choosing them to achieve a maximum variation allows the research to use the comparative method, controlling for key variables such as size and location, to see what other factors might appear to be linked with these. Selection on the basis of comparison can be useful: It can allow an element of 'triangulation' between alternatives. The researcher is able to see how a certain thing works in two or more very different settings. It is useful where the research design is emergent. Where the researcher selects cases as part of an unfolding path of discovery, then the idea that has emerged from the one example can be compared with the next sample, which might be consciously chosen as one that is different.

item.title: 2. Data Representation
item.description:
Useful for nominal and ordinal variables. Report counts and/or percentages A frequency table, bar chart, or pie chart might not be meaningful to depict interval/ratio variables. More graphs and statistics are available to represent interval/ratio variables. Similar to a frequency table, but data is categorized into groups. Show both raw data and shape of distribution (like a histogram). First find range of data (Max - Min) then break into multiple groups with equal intervals. Stem: Categories Groups Leaf: Data points Key: An example of the stem and leaf to show what number it represents. This allows readers to determine the placement of each digit in the stem and leaf. (SPSS reports the stem width) Example: 5|2 = 52 Frequency (Absolute Frequency): The number of times the observation occurred/recorded in an experiment or study.
Relative Frequency (between 0 and 1): The ratio of the frequency of a particular event in a statistical experiment to the total frequency.
Can be reported with intervals or real limits (the lower or upper value for a continuous variable measured on a ratio scale). For example: Interval: 50-59 Real Limit: (49.5-59.5) Visualize frequency of data. X-axis label can be midpoints of interval, or real limits, Y-axis can be frequency or relative frequency
The bars are equal intervals and continuous data (no gaps). Show the shape of the distribution. SPSS: Can modify the bin width in Chart Editor -> select columns -> Binning Proportion of scores from this category and lower. Related to percentile rank: Percentage of scores in a distribution that are equal to or less than that score. X-axis: Data (score)
Y-axis: Cumulative Relative Frequency (or Cumulative Frequency) Example
Global Customer Support Manager Salaries: The percentile rank of a given score is the percent of observations falling at or below that score. Start at the bottom (x-axis) to locate the score of interest, then move up to the ogive and over to the Y-axis. Example: Percentile rank for $50,000? PR $50,000 = 61% 61% of global customer support managers earn salary at or below $50,000. Every data point in a distribution has an associated percentile. Start on the Y-axis to locate the percent of interest, then move horizontally to the ogive and then down to the X-axis. Example: Find 80th percentile (P 80) P 80= $66,000 (approximately) About 80% of global customer support managers earn salary at or below $66,000. First make sure the measurement level has been set properly for the variable. Go to Graphs -> Chart Builder In Gallery, select Line and drag Simple Line to the preview section Mat gave to hit Reset from previous charts. Under Element Properties, Statistic, select Cumulative Percentage The preview does not make much sense, but it is okay. Just submit to see the actual graph. Minimum (or 10th percentile, P10) Q1: First Quartile (or 25th percentile, P25) Median (or 10 th percentile, P50) Q3: Third Quartile (or 75th percentile, P75) Maximum (or 90th percentile, P90) Each sections 25% of data. The box contains 50% of data: Interquartile range IQR = Q3 - Q1
Minimum: Q 1 = 1.5 X IQR (the data point above it) Maximum: Q 3 + 1.5 X IQR (the data point below it) Outliers (Circles): More than 1.5 IQR from the upper or lower of the box Extreme values (asterisks): More than 3 times the IQR!
Box plots are useful as they provide a visual summary of the data enabling resarchers to quickly identify: Median (center) of data Dispersion (spread) of data Skewness of data Potential outliers/extreme values
Box Plot Explained: Interpretation, Examples, & Comparison

Depict the relationship between two variables by plotting the pair of scores on x and y for each record on a two-dimensional figure (coordinate). X-axis represents the values for variable x (usually IV).
Y-axis represents the values for variable y (usually DV). The scatterplot is useful for providing a quick indication of the nature of the relationship among variables x and y (bivariate data). Direction of the relationship (positive or negative): A positive relationship occurs when both variables are increasing. A negative (inverse) relation occurs when one variable is increasing as the other is decreasing. Can draw a straight line (aka regression line) through the data points that cuts the bivariate distribution in hald. The slope of the regression line shows the direction of relationship. Alternatively, split the chart into 4 equal sections (quadrants) and examine how data points are spread across the 4 quadrants. Strength of the relationship: Strong relationships: Data points tend to fall close to the regression line. Weak relationship: Data points are widely scattered around the regression line. Summary of the scales of measurement Also referred to as Demographics Table In research, typically used to describe your sample Sex/Gender, Race/Ethnicity, Level of Education, etc. Only used to display discrete data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag variable (s) of interest (VOI) into 'Variables' box -> select 'Display Frequency Tables' box in bottom left-hand corner of the menu. Unfortunately, SPSS does not provide us with output that is 'APA-Ready' In order to create an APA-style frequency (demographics) table, you need to use Excel (or similar program) When do we use them? Nominal or ordinal data (discrete data) There are two ways to produce Bar Graphs, each produces the same graph. SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Bar Charts' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Bar' to the previewer, place variable of interest on x-axis. Note that the bars are separated by some space and do not touch one another, reflecting the nature of nominal data being discrete. When do we use them? Nominal or ordinal data (discrete data) In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Pie Charts' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Pie/Polar' to the previewer, place variable of interest on x-axis. When do we use them? Displaying interval and ratio data (continuous data) Checking for the shape of the distribution Skewness, normality There are three different ways to produce histograms using SPSS, but each produces the same graph. Typically making them while producing other descriptive statistics, so that will guide which menu you use. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Histogram' Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> 'Histogram' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Histograms' to the previewer -> drag the variable of interest to the x-axis.
Normal Distribution: Mode = Median = Mean Negatively Skewed (Skewed to the Left, tail toward the left): Mode > Median > Mean Positively Skewed (Skewed to the right, tail toward the right): Mode < Median < Mean Used to display interval and ratio data. Not used often in publications, but can be useful for visualizing your data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> 'Stem-and-Leaf' Not used as much in academic publications, but still valuable in visualizing your data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> it is clicked by default Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Boxplot' to the previewer -> drag the variable of interest to the x-axis and drag the scale variable to the y-axis. The box in the center displays the middle 50% of the distribution. The bottom edge of the box represents the 25 th percentile (or Q 1) The top edge of the box represents the 75 th percentile (or Q 3) The middle thick vertical line in the box represents the 50 th percentile (also known as Q 2 or the median) The lines extending from the box are known as the whiskers. The purpose of whiskers is to display data outside of the middle 50%. Range: Min - Max
Shape of the Distribution:
Used to display interval and ratio data Not used that often (histograms are the preferred display) In SPSS: Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Line' to the previewer -> drag the VOI to the x-axis On the right, change statistics to 'Cumulative Percentage' On the output window, double click on the graph and click 'Show Grid Lines' Select 'Both major and minor ticks' then click 'Apply' Percentile Score below which a certain percentage of the distribution lies P% = score Percentile Rank Percentage of a distribution of scores that falls below (or is less than a certain score) PRscore = % Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag VOI into the box -> Statistics -> select Quartiles and Percentiles -> type the number into the box to the right of percentiles and click 'add.' This gives you the percentile of the number and the first quartile (25 th percentile), second quartile (median / 50 th percentile) and third quartile (75 th percentile). A plot of two scale (interval or ratio) variables Helps to visually identify possible relationship between two variables. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Scatter/Dot' to the previewer -> drag one of the VOI to the x-axis and the other to y-axis.
In SPSS, you can create new variables from old variables. In the menu bar, go to transform. Select Compute Variable. In the pop-up window that shows up, give a name for the new target variable. Define your new variable in the Numeric Expression Box Click OK Recoding variables in SPSS involves altering variable values to create a new modified variable, typically done during data preparation and analysis to better suit analysis needs or simplify the data. In the menu bar, go to Transform. Select Recode to Different Variables. It is not recommended to Recode into Same Variables as this overwrites existing variables.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/2. Data Representation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Introduction to Educational Statistics
item.description:
Population: All members of a well-defined group (people, animals, parts produced in a factory, districts, schools, etc.)
Sample: A subset of a population. Generally, it is too difficult (time-consuming, costly, ineffecient) to collect data on the entire population (census) so we take a sample.
We draw a Sample (data) from the Population of research interest and make inference (Generalization) back to population.
Population of Interest
Draw Sample Compute Sample Statistics
Make Inference Back to the Population
Parameter: A characteristic of a population.
Statistic: A characteristic of a sample.
The parameters in Population are often unknown, but we can estimate them from our sample statistics. Parameters are usually notated by Greek alphabet. Sample statistics are usually notated by English alphabet.
A good Sample should be: Identical to the characteristics/properties of the population. Representative of a population. This allows the sample to be generalizable to the population. Results will be applicable to other samples drawn from the same population. Every member of the population of interest has an equal probability of being selected. Selection of one unit has no effect on the selection of another unit. Best technique to obtain a representative sample. Use a number table, a compute, a drawing, or a lottery system to generate random numbers. Use if one or more characteristics are focal research interest. The goal is to compare groupds (strata). The purpose is to make sure each group is represented in the sample. First divide population into groups (strata). Then a random sample is taken from each group. There are 'naturally occurring' groups in population, usually geographical or organizational. Randomly selected clusters. Then sample all units within each cluster, or random sample with each chosen cluster. Error is smaller if the clusters are similar to each other. Every k^th unit is selected from a list, where k=population/desired sample size. Have a list with all units in the population. Then take sample systematically. Make sure the list you are selecting from is random. Choose samples merely based on proximity without considering whether they represent the population or not. Readily available, quick, inexpensive.
Can reduce bias by using conveniance sample along with Simple Random Sample (SRS), taking multiple samples, or cross-validation. Is the sample representative of the population? (Are the findings generalizable?) Sample size? The larger sample does not mean more representative of the population. Required sample size depends on design, confidence level, desired effect size and statistical power. Generally, 30 or more per combinations of factors. How to report: Define your population Describe sampling procedure Indivate desired sample size Indicate actual sample size Provide descriptions of the sample and inferences from the analyses
Variable: Any characteristic of persons or things that is observed to take on different values. Constant: Any characteristic of persons or things that is observed to take on only a single value. Role of variables:
Dependent (outcome/target) vs. Independent (predictors/input) Types of variables: Qualitative (Categorical) Quantitative (Numeric) Phenomena or variables that can be used to describe a quality of a person or item. Categorical Dichotomous variables can only take on 2 different values (e.g., yes or no). Example: County of residence, religion, political affiliation, ethnicity Dichotomous: Sex assigned at birth (male or female) Whether a person voted in an election (yes or no). Variables that describe a numerical aspect of characteristic of a person or phenomena. Discrete: A numerical variable that arises from the counting process that can take on only certain values.
Continuous: A variable that can take on any value within a certain range, given a precise enough measurement instrument. Example: Discrete: Count of students enrolled in a course, # of clinic visits, agreement level to a survey item
Continuous: Distance between two cities, checking account balance, time to rune a marathon, GPA Numbers can be assigned to the possible outcomes or responses that can occur for any variable, regardless of how it is classified (i.e., qualitative or quantitative). Measurement: The process of assigning numbers to phenomena in order to represent or distinguish among responses. Represent the features and properties of a variable. Help us understand how to describe and analyze the data. S. S. Stevens (1951) developed 4 types of measurement scales that could be used for assigning these values: Usually used for qualitative/categorical variables Numbers mark distinctions between responses, and nothing more. The numbers have no inherent meaning, and the order does not matter at all. Example: County of residence (1=Franklin, 2=Delaware, 3=Union OR 1=Delaware, 2=Union, 3=Franklin) Sex assigned at birth (0=female, 1=male OR 10=female, 15=male) In SPSS, can set value labels and display either data or label. Numbers are assigned to represent ranks or order (usually discrete). Numbers have meaning, but only in terms of distinguishing order, from largest to smallest (or vice versa). Equal distance between two adjacent levels are not assumed. Example: Letter grades: A, B, C, D, E (1-5) Size of a cup of coffee (small, medium, large, 1-3) Socioeconomic status (SES) (low, middle, high, 1-3) Agreement (Likert Scale) (strongly agree, neutral, disagree, strongly disagree, 1-5) Sometimes data needs to be recorded to make interpretation more intuitive Equal intervals or increments along the scale Interval variables have an arbitrary zero point. Example: Temperature Celsius or Fehrenheit, SAT score, credit score Likert Scale (equal distance assumed): More choices for statistical methods are available for interval data than ordinal data. Decisions might depend on your data. Report range to help readers understand the measure. Equal intervals or increments along the scale and contains an absolute and true zero point (absence of the phenomena being measured, data measures from 0 and above). It is possible to compare 2 values and say one is 'twice as large' or 'two-third the size' Statistical Package for the Social Sciences Open the SPSS application File -> New -> Data File -> Open -> Data -> select the desired file File -> Open -> Data -> change 'Files of Type' to: Excel -> select the desired file File -> Import Data -> Excel -> select the desired file If the excel file has column titles, click 'Read variable names' from the first row of data. Each row represents a case (person, school, state, etc.) Each column represents a specific variable Must begin with a letter The rest can contain a combination of numbers and letters Can use periods and underscore, but no other symbol Numeric (most common) Date Dollar String (second most common, only Type where you can use letters) How many characters are allowed inside the cell (string variables) How many decimal places are allowed in the cell Where you can further define the variables Used when numbers in the data file represent something Where you can define certain values to be considered 'missing' Helps to adjust the size/width of the columns is data view Nominal: Used for nominal variables such as ID numbers and when numbers represent something Ordinal: Used for ordinal data Scale: Used for ratio and interval data

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Introduction and Fundamentals
item.description:
Behavioral and social scientists describe phenomena like drug use, psychiatric distress, and academic achievement using parametric statistical models. Common methods include analyzing Central Tendencies, Score Variations, and associations between characteristics. Behavioral and social scientists learn about phenomena by understanding how variables relate to each other. To grasp these relationships, we ask three fundamental questions: Are two variables related? What is the direction of their relationship? How strong is the relationship? Statistical Models = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1X1 + ùõΩ2X2 + ùõΩ3X3 Y: Dependent (outcome) variable : predicted score of Y Y - : Error Measuring Model Error Use subscript i to indicate the subject, e.g., e1 = Y1 - 1, e2 = Y2 - 2 ... Square each individual's error and sum them all:
Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) SSE measures the model's basic error. The goal of statistical modeling is to make small changes to improve the model. Test if the new model reduces error (smaller SSE) compared to the previous model. If a more complex model predicts Y better (lower SSE), we conclude the added complexity (new predictor X) improved the model. The general linear model (GLM) is a way to simplify and combine multiple linear regression models into a single, unified format. It is not a different type of model but a more efficient way to represent them. General form: Y = XB + U Data = Model + Error The key word is 'general.' The GLM can be used to make predictions from various models. Depending on the outcome variable, logistic regression, ordinal regression, or count models (Poisson) may be used - these are also forms of the GLM. Another term: Generalized Linear Models (GLIM) The GLM is actually a special case of (GLIM)! Types of Data
Binary
Nominal (Categorical)
Ordinal
Frequencies
Continuous
Pseudo-Continuous
Parameter
Predictor s, independent variables (x)
Outcome s, dependent variables (y) Factors, levels, groups
Mean The sum of all scores divided by the number of scores.
Median The middle score in a set of data that has been arranged in numerical order. If there are an even number of scores, you find the average between the two middle most scores.
Mode The most frequent score in the dataset.
Range The difference between the maximum score and the minimum score.
Variance A measure of the spread of the data around the mean.

Standard Deviation (SD) Also measures the spread of the data around the mean The square root of the variance. Shows how different the population mean is likely to be from the sample mean. ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àö*n Exact, uses the population standard deviation, which is usually unknown. Sx-bar = S √∑ ‚àö*n Estimate, uses the sample standard deviation, which is known. Skewness is a measure of symmetry or asymmetry of data distribution. Kurtosis measures whether data is heavy-tailed or light-tailed in a distribution. Considered normal if within +/- 2



Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell)
Median =MEDIAN (First cell, Last cell)
Mode =MODE (First cell, Last cell) Minimum =MIN (First cell, Last cell) Maximum =MAX (First cell, Last cell)
Skewness =SKEW (First cell, Last cell)
Kurtosis =KURT (First cell, Last cell)
Standard Deviation (SD)
Calculate the Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell) Calculate the Deviation = Data cell - Mean cell Square the Deviation =E 2^2
Calculate the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) (Square Deviations) =SUM (First cell, Last cell) Input the Degrees of Freedom DF = n - 1 Calculate the Variance =SS / DF Calculate the Standard Deviation ‚àö(Variance) =SQRT (Cell) Calculate the Standard Error = Standard Deviation / ‚àö(n) =F 21 / (SQRT (15))
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/GLM 1/In-Class Notes/1. Introduction and Fundamentals.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 8. Independent T-Test, Homogeneity of Variance
item.description:
AKA two-sample t-test, independent-samples t-test or student's t-test. Dependent (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare treatment and control groups. Independent variance (IV): The group characteristics (dichotomous) Intervention vs. No intervention Medicine vs. Placebo Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between two groups? Socioeconomic status (2 levels) Type of therapeutic intervention (2 types) -> Results of GAD-7 questionnaire over time Genre-based approach (yes/no) -> Writing skills Exposure to community violence (yes/no) -> Feelings of safety Teaching method (2 kinds) -> Students scores on the exam (TOEFL) Type of social emotional curriculum implemented in a school (2 types) -> classroom behavior, academic achievement scores Teaching style (2 types) -> reading comprehension skills of EFL middle school students Participant or non-participant in school sport -> student's cumulative grade point average. Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly different from group 2 (¬µ2) H0: ¬µ2 = ¬µ1 vs. H1: ¬µ2 ‚â† ¬µ1 Alternatively, H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 = 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â† 0 For experiment and control, usually group 1 is the experiment group. Directional: Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly greater than group 2 (¬µ2): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly smaller than group 2 (¬µ2): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0 tobs = (1 - 2) √∑ (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) 1 and 2 are the means for group 1 and group 2, respectively. sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2 is the standard error of the difference between two means, which is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference between two means: sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2 = spooled ‚àö(1 √∑ n1) + (1 √∑ n2) Where spooled is the pooled standard deviation computed as spooled = ‚àö ((n1 - 1) s12 + (n2 - 1) s22) √∑ (n1 + n2 - 2) where n1 is group 1 sample size, and n2 is group 2 sample size. Recall for paired-sample t-test: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön The observed t is then compared against the critical value from the t-table to determine a statistical decision. For independent t-test, tcrit has the degrees of freedom v = n1 + n2 - 2, at a particular level of significant ùõº (usually .05), for a one- or two-tailed test. Recall rejection region is outside of tcrit (s) toward the tail(s): sample data more extreme! Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < ùõº (SPSS output) ùõº level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Make sure to report t, df, and p-value to support your conclusion. Nondirectional: 100 (1 - ùõº)% CI: (1 - 2) ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) Recall for paired-sample t-test: 100 (1 - ùõº)% CI: ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar To test greater (treatment group is greater): 100 (1 - ùõº)% LCL: (1 - 2) - tdf, ùõº/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) To test smaller (treatment group is smaller): 100 (1 - ùõº)% UCL: (1 - 2) + tdf, ùõº/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) Group 1: City (n1 = 26) Mean: 55.23 SD: 19.371 Variance: 375.225 Group 2: Country (n2 = 22) Country (n2 = 22) Mean: 62.73 SD: 17.236 Variance: 297.065 Exploratory in nature (non-directional) and no treatment/control groups Research Question: Do people living in the city and in the country spend differently (spending) on July 4th fireworks? Group 1: City (n1 = 26) Group 2: Country (n2 = 22) Group 1 (Experiment): Mobile (n1 = 22) Mean: 1.2927 SD: 0.24631 Variance: 0.061 Group 2 (Control): In-Person (n2 = 31) Mean: 1.4839 SD: 0.40342 Variance: 0.163 Don't be confused with variable coding. In my SPSS file, variable order is coded as 1 = In-Person and 2 = Mobile
Research Question: Are burritos ordered (order) in-person significantly bigger (weight) than the ones via mobile orders? Group 1: Mobile (n1 = 22) Group 2: In-Person (n2 = 31) Since the research interest is if mobile orders are smaller, I'll treat the mobile group as experiment (group 1 in SPSS for independent t-test) and in-person as control (group 2 in SPSS for independence t-test). Don't be confused with variable coding. For the variable order, value 1 = In-Person and value 2 = Mobile (nominal coding is interchangeable) DV is usually recorded as one variable. IV is usually recorded as another variable to identify groups (dichotomous, or pick 2 groups at a time to compare). Analyze -> Compare Means -> Independent-Samples t-test Move DV to Test Variable(s) Move IV to Grouping Variable and define groups (Group 1 and Group 2) If there are treatment and control groups, group 1 is usually treatment and group 2 is control. The mean difference is group 1 minus group 2. You can refer to the descriptive statistics to confirm which group is higher. AKA homoscedasticity When comparing means, we need the dispersion to be similar in both groups. The distortion in spread can interfere with our investigation of difference between means. HOV assumes population variances for the two groups are equal. If design is balanced (n1 = n2), no need to worry about departure from HOV (independent t-test is robust in this case). HOV tests are sensitive to violations of other assumptions about the data, especially normality. So there are many versions of this test: An easy way (by hand) is the F-max test (aka Hartley's F-max test). SPSS uses Levene's HOV test for independent t-test. This is the first time we do not reject the null hypothesis. F has two degrees of freedom H0: ùúé12 = ùúé22 vs. H0: ùúé12 ‚â† ùúé22 Or alternatively, H0: ùúé12 √∑ ùúé22 = 1 vs. H0: ùúé12 √∑ ùúé22 ‚â† 1 (whether the ratio of 2 variances equals 1) For convenience we generally put the larger variance in the numerator and smaller variance in the denominator, and the ratio follows an F-distribution: Fmax = (s2) (larger) √∑ (s2) (smaller) Fmax is compared to a critical F value. For this test, we hope to retain (cannot reject) H0 so HOV is tenable (satisfactory)! Small Fmax or big p-value are good (i.e., equal variances)!

The F distribution is usually used to compare variances. Since variances are always a squared value and always non-negative, the F statistic does not go below 0, and it is not symmetric. The F-statistics has two sets of degrees of freedom: Numerator (v1) and denominator (v2). The pair of degrees of freedom determine the shape of the F distribution. When comparing two groups (sample sizes n1 and n2), v1 = n1 - 1 and ), v2 = n2 -1. If F-max test, v1 (dfnum) is the degree of freedom for group with larger variance, and v2 (dfdenom) is the degree of freedom for the group with smaller variance. Reject H0 if Fmax ‚â• F (Œ±, dfnum, dfdenom) but we don't want to reject it! Fmax = 375.225 √∑ 297.065 ‚âà 1.263 Critical F (. 05, 25, 21) = 2.045 Since 1.263 < 2.045, cannot reject H0 Fireworks spending for people living in the city has a variance comparable to that of in the country (HOV satisfactory)! H0: ùúé12 = ùúé22 = ... = ùúék2 vs. H1: At least 2 group variances are different (k = 2 for our purpose) [Optional] Test statistics Fobs Total sample size n divided into k groups (j = 1, 2, ..., k); We are just comparing 2 groups (k = 2) Sample size for each group is n1, n2, ..., nj, ..., nk i denotes the ith subject (data point) in group j zij = | xij - xj | is the absolute deviation from a data point to jth group mean Brown and Forsythe extended this to median or 10% trimmed mean Numerator: Between group variation (in terms of absolute deviation) Denominator: Within group variation (in terms of absolute deviation) We would reject H0 if Fobs > Fk - 1, n - k (here k = 2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < .05 Since we want to find no statistically significant difference in variances between the two groups, a p ‚â• .05 (big p-value) is desired here! We will let SPSS do Levene's HOV test for us! Just remember if we see a big p-value (p-value ‚â• .05), HOV is tenable (satisfactory). If p-value is small (p < .05), HOV is violated. The Welch's t-test (aka separate variances t-test, unequal variances t-test) is usually appropriate when the population variances are unequal and the sample sizes are unequal. [Optional] tobs = unstandardized b √∑ standard error Variance errors of the mean are computed for each group where s12 are sample variances for groups. The criteria to reject H0 are the same as independent t-test (extreme t or small p). We'll let SPSS do Welch's t-test for us! Just remember if we see a small p-value (p < .05), we can reject H0 and claim difference between the two group means is significantly different from 0 (or one-sided p-value to test greater/smaller). Make sure to report t, df, and p-value to support your conclusion.

First check HOV assumption: Satisfactory, F (1, 46) = 0.519, p = .475 (i.e., cannot reject H0 equal variance), so we can use independent t-test results from the first line (equal variances assumed). We are not trying to compute the observed F for Levene's Test, but the df is (k - 1, n - 2) = (1, 46). spooled = ‚àö(25 x 375.225 x 21 x 297.065) √∑ (46) = 18.4267 sx-bar 1 - x-bar 2 = 18.4267 ‚àö(1 √∑ 26) + (1 √∑ 22) = 5.3379 tobs = (-7.497) √∑ (5.3379) ‚âà -1.404 df = n1 + n2 -2 = 26 + 22 - 2 = 46 Since p-value (make sure we look at results from the first line) is quite large (p = .167), we cannot reject H0 -> Spending on fireworks did not differ significantly between people living in the city (M = 55.23, SD = 19.371) and the country (M = 62.73, SD = 17.236), t(46) = -1.404, p = .167. Notice 95% CI (-18.241, 3.248) also covers 0, agreeing with the non-significant t-test.

First check HOV assumption. Violated, F (1, 51) = 9.594, p = .003 (i.e., reject H0 equal variance), so we are using the results (Welch's t-test aka separate variances t-test) from the second line (equal variances not assumed). For Welch's t-test, it is difficult to calculate the degree of freedom (50.061) by hand. A one-tailed t-test was conducted (if mobile orders are significantly smaller than in-person orders). Since the p-value (make sure we look at results from the second line) < .05 (p = .019), we can reject H0 -> Mobile-Ordered Burritos (M = 1.29, SD = 0.246) are significantly smaller than burritos ordered in-person (M = 1.48, SD = 0.403), t(50.061) = -2.136, p = .019. Notice the 95% upper confidence limit (-0.04118) is below 0, agreeing with the significant t-test results. Cohen's d = (1 - 2) √∑ spooled Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ¬±0.2: Small effect d = ¬±0.5: Medium effect d = ¬±0.8: Large effect Use Cohen's d when HOV is satisfactory and sample size is large (total n at least 40 or 50) Hedges' g ‚âà (1 - 2) √∑ spooled (1 - 3 √∑ 4n - 9) Total sample size n = n1 + n2 Provides a bias correction to Cohen's d for small sample sizes Uses Hedges' g when HOV is satisfactory and sample size is small (n < 40 or 50) Glass's Delta (‚àÜ) = (1 - 2) √∑ spooled Uses only the control group's (group 2 in SPSS) standard deviation Use Glass's delta when HOV is violated (variances significantly different between groups) Use the same convention as Cohen's d to interpret Hedge's g or Glass's delta.
Since HOV is satisfactory and sample size is fairly large (n = 48), it's appropriate to use Cohen's d (-0.407) and Hedges' g (-0.400) effect size measures. Both indicate small effect size. Notice the standardizer (denominator) for Cohen's d is the same as the pooled standard deviation we calculated (spooled = 18.427). APA Style Writing Template: An independent t-test was conducted to determine if people living in the city spend differently on July 4 th fireworks compared to those in the country. Data on spending was gathered from samples of 26 city dwellers and 22 country folks. The sample mean for the city was $62.73 (SD = 17.236).
Levene's test for homogeneity of variance confirmed the assumption, F (1, 46) = 0.519, p = .475. The independent t-test indicated that the spending means were not significantly different for people in the city and country, t (46) = -1.404, p = .167. We failed to reject the null hypothesis that the spending was the same between locations at the .05 level of significance. Therefore, we can conclude that location is not significant factor in determining firework spending. Cohen's d was -0.407, suggesting a small effect size.
Since HOV is violated, we can use Glass's delta (-0.474) to measure effect size (in-person as control group), which indicates a small to medium effect size. Notice the standardizer (denominator) for Glass's delta is the standard deviation from the in-person (control group or group 2 in SPSS) (0.40342) APA Style Writing Template We wanted to determine if burritos ordered via mobile app are significantly smaller than burritos ordered in person. From a random sample, we weighed 22 burritos placed via mobile orders (M = 1.29, SD = 0.246) and 31 ordered in-person (M = 1.48, SD = 0.403).
According to Levene's test, the homogeneity of variance assumption was violated, F (1, 51) = 9.594, p = .003. Therefore, a separate variances t-test was conducted. The t-test result was significant at the .05 confidence level, t (50.061) = -2.136, p = .019. We can conclude that mobile-ordered burritos are significantly smaller than in-person orders. Glass's delta was -0.474, suggesting a small to medium effect size. Measure or characteristic is normally distributed in each of the two populations (i.e., the two groups). Observations are from a random sample, and the scores in each sample (people) are independent of each other. DV is measured on at least an interval level scale. HOV (homogeneity of variance): The variances in the two populations are comparable. If violated (and design is not balanced), use Welch's t-test (separate variances t-test) instead. Is vitamin C effective to treat colds? A health-researcher recruited a sample of 27 adults and followed them for a year to assess the number of colds they had in year 1. She then had them take weekly doses of vitamin C and followed them in year 2. Paired because it is a pre to post. A social studies teacher wanted to determine if the students in his school in the US have similar perceptions of world leaders compared to other countries. Where leaders are rated from 0 (worthless) to 10 (effective), the global norm on the 'World Leader Scale' is 6 with a standard deviation of 1.8. The teacher took a sample of 35 students from the school and had them fill out the same WLS. One sample z-test A counseling psychologist wanted to determine if prisoners who are depressed eat less of their meals than prisoners who are not depressed. There were 130 prisoners who volunteered for the study, and 42 of them were classified as depressed. The psychologist monitored the amount of each meal in ounces eaten by both groups for a week. Independent t-test A random sample of 39 museum visitors were questioned on how much they spend per month on cultural or arts-related events. The survey found that, on average, these visitors spent $40 per month with a standard deviation of $12. The researcher wanted to test whether the monthly expenditure for museum visitors is below $45. One sample t-test

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 8. Independent Samples t-test
item.description:
Used when we are comparing two separate groups of people in our sample Example: Boys vs. Girls (Quasi-experimental design); Treatment vs. Control (Experimental Design) State the H0 and H1 Define alpha level Compute t statistic Interpret the output Make decision Write conclusion Fred wishes to determine whether children in regular education are hurt or helped academically by the inclusion of special education students in their classes. He has gained the cooperation of the seventh-grade teachers in two similar junior high schools to participate in his study. One school recently integrated special education students into their regular classroom, while the other one has not. The teachers in both school supply Fred the students‚Äô raw scores on a standardized achievement test at the beginning of the year and at the end of the year. SPSS file contains 40 cases and 3 variables: Integ (1: regular education students who are not in integrated classroom; 2. Regular education students who are in the integrated classroom) Pretest (achievement test score of regular education students at the beginning of the year) Posttest (achievement test score of regular education students at the end of the year) Research Questions: Is there a mean difference in pretest achievement scores between regular education students who are not in integrated classroom and in the integrated classroom? State the H0 and H1 H0: ùúápretest not integrated = ùúápretest integrated H1: ùúápretest not integrated ‚â† ùúápretest integrated Define alpha level ùõº = .05 Compute t statistic In SPSS: Analyze -> Compare Means -> Independent-Samples t-test -> drag dependent variable (s) into the 'Test Variable (s)' box > drag the categorical variable into the 'Grouping Variable' box -> Define Groups -> enter the values of your grouping variables into 'Group 1' and 'Group 2' respectively t = (M1 - M2) / ‚àö(SD12/ n1) + (SD22/ n2) Before you assess the t-test results: You need to check the assumption of homogeneity of variance (equal variance) by checking the Levene's Test results. H0: The variances are the same. H1: The variances are different.
If significance level is ‚â• .05, we have met the assumption of homogeneity of variance. Assess the t-test with the top row, 'Equal variances assumed.'
If significance level is < .05, we have failed to met the assumptions of homogeneity of variance. Assess the t-test with the bottom row, 'Equal variances not assumed.' Interpret the output Group StatisticsIndependent Samples Test The result of the t-test is not significant (t = -1.167, df = 38 (n1 + n2 - 2 = 15 + 25 - 2 = 38), p = .250) at the Œ± =. 05 significance level. Therefore, we fail to reject H0 and conclude the means are equal between the two groups. The results of Levene's test is not significant (F (1,38) = .566, p = .465) at the Œ± = .05 significance level. Therefore, we fail to reject H0 and conclude the variances are equal between the two groups. Go to the top row, 'Equal variances assumed' (F(k-1, N-k)) (k: number of groups; N = sample size) Independent Samples Effect Sizes Effect Size: d = t x ‚àö(n1 + n2) / (n1 x n2) d = (-1.167) ‚àö (15 + 25) / (15 x 25) Make decision Fail to reject the null hypothesis because our obtained significance value was greater than our predetermined alpha level (p = .250) Write conclusion An independent samples t-test was conducted to determine if the mean pretest achievement scores of regular education students who were not in an integrated classroom differed from regular education studetns who were in the integrated classroom. The test results indicate that, on average, the pretest means were not statistically significantly different for students who were not in the integrated classroom (M = 92.93, SD = 14.56) and students who were in the integrated classroom (M = 98.56, SD = 14.88); (t (38) = -1.167, p = .250, d = -. 381). The null hypothesis that the pretest means were the same for students in the integrated and not in the integrated classroom was retained at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -. 381. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small effect. Is there a mean difference in posttest achievement scores between regular education students who are not in integrated classroom and in the integrated classroom? H0: ùúáposttest not integrated = ùúáposttest integrated H1: ùúáposttest not integrated ‚â† ùúáposttest integrated Group StatisticsIndependent Samples Test The results of the Welch's t-test is significant (t' = -2.731, df = 37.952, p = .010) at the Œ± = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0 and conclude the means are not equal between the two groups. The results of Levene's test is significant (F (1,38) = 14.620, p < .001) at the Œ± = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0 and conclude the variances are not equal between the two groups. Write-Up: An independent samples t-test was conducted to determine if the mean post-test achievement scores of regular education students who were not in an integrated classroom differed from regular education students who were in the integrated classroom. The test results indicate that, on average, the post-test means were statistically significantly different for students who were not in the integrated classroom (M = 94.47, SD = 11.51) and students who were in the integrated classroom (M = 108.16, SD = 20.19); (t (38) = -2.731, p = .010, d = - .678). The null hypothesis that the pre-test means were the same for students in the integrated and not in the integrated classroom was retained at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -.678, which is interpreted as a small effect.
