item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Midterm 2
item.description:
How to read description of a study and identify/infer relevant information such as: Independent Variable and Dependent Variable
Types of Variables
Sample Size
Number of groups for any Nominal Variable and Sample Size for each group
Number of Parameter s A description may or may not include all of the information above. How to look up the F-critical value and determine whether a model is significant How to look up the t-critical value & determine whether the t-test is significant How to run a t-test in SPSS
T-Test Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test Pick variable and enter the Test Value (¬µ0) SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided.
Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - ùúé)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from ¬µ0? How to write a regression equation
Stating the Null Hypothesis and Alternative hypotheses The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups.
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) The one-way ANOVA compares the means between the groups you are interested in and determines whether any of those means are statistically significantly different from each other. Specifically, it tests the null hypothesis:
Where ¬µ = group mean and k = number of groups. If, however, the one-way ANOVA returns a statistically significant result, we accept the alternative hypothesis, which is that there are at least two group means that are statistically significantly different from each other. The one-way ANOVA is an Omnibus test statistic, and cannot tell you which specific groups were statistically significantly different from each other, only that at least two groups were. To determine which specific groups differed from each other, you need to use a post hoc test. It is used to test research questions and hypotheses where you want to compare the means of three or more groups on a single dependent variable. You are asking if there is a significant difference between the groups based on a single categorical independent variable with multiple levels.

If you are dealing with individuals, you are likely to encounter this situation using two different types of study design: One study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then randomly split this group into three or more smaller groups (i.e., each participant is allocated to one, and only one, group). You then get each group to undertake different tests (or put them under different conditions) and measure the outcome/response on the same dependent variable. For example, a researcher wishes to know whether different pacing strategies affect the time to complete a marathon. The researcher randomly assigns a group of volunteers to either a group that (a) starts slow and then increases their speed, (b) starts fast and slows down or (c) runs at a steady pace throughout. The time to complete the marathon is the outcome (dependent) variable.
A second study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then split them into groups based on some independent variable. Again, each individual will be assigned to one group only. This independent variable is sometimes called an attribute independent variable because you are splitting the group based on some attribute that they possess (e.g., their level of education; every individual has a level of education, even if it is 'none'). Each group is then measured on the same dependent variable having undergone the same task or condition (or none at all). For example, a researcher is interested in determining whether there are differences in leg strength between amateur, semi-professional and provessional rugby players. The force/strength measured on an isokinetic machine is the dependent variable.

Every time you conduct a t-test there is a chance that you will make a Type I Errors. This error is usually 5%. By running two t-tests on the same data you will have increased your chance of "making a mistake" to 10%. The formula for determining the new error rate for multiple t-tests is not as simple as multiplying 5% by the number of tests. However, if you are only making a few multiple comparisons, the results are very similar if you do. As such, three t-tests would be 15% (actually, 14.3%) and so on. These are unacceptable errors. An ANOVA controls for these errors so that the Type I Errors remains at 5% and you can be more confident that any statistically significant result you find is not just running lots of tests. State H0 and H1
H1: At least 1 group mean is different Set the criteria for a decision. State Alpha Level = .05 Compute the test statistic. Make a decision. When you choose to analyze your data using a one-way ANOVA, part of the process involves checking to make sure that the data you want to analyze can actually be analyzed using a one-way ANOVA. You need to do this because it is only appropriate to use a one-way ANOVA if your data "passes" six assumptions that are required for a one-way ANOVA to give you a valid result.
Your dependent variable should be measured at the interval or ratio level (Interval Variable and Ratio Variable) (i.e., they are Continuous Variable; IQ score, exam scores, weight, etc). The dependent variable is normally distributed in each group that is being compared in the one-way ANOVA (technically, it is the residuals that need to be normally distributed, but the results will be the same).
For example, if we were comparing three groups (e.g., amateur, semi-professional, and professional rugby players) on their leg strength, their leg strength values (Dependent Variable) would have to be normally distributed for the amateur group of players, normally distributed for the semi-professionals and normally distributed for the professional player. You can test for normality in SPSS.
Testing for Normality
Your Independent Variable is Nominal Variable. There is homogeneity of variances. This means that the population variances in each group are equal. If you use SPSS Statistics, Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variances is included in the output when you run a one-way ANOVA in SPSS Statistics. SPSS: Make sure to select the option of 'homogeneity of variance test.' The assumption of the homogeneity of the variance is met if Levene's statistic is not significant (p > .05)
Independence of Observations. This is mostly a study design issue and, as such, you will need to determine whether you believe it is possible that your observations are not independent based on your study design.
Your Independent Variable should consist of two or more categorical, independent groups. Typically, a one-way ANOVA is used when you have three or more categorical, independent groups, but it can be used for just two groups (but an Independent Samples T-Test Independent Samples T-Test is more commonly used for two groups) Example independent variables that meet this criterion include ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist) and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations, which means that there is no relationship between the observations in each group or between the groups themselves. For example, there must be different participants in each group with no participant being in more than one group. This is more of a study design issue than something you can test for. If your study fails this assumption, you will need to use another statistical test instead of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., a repeated measures design).
If you are unsure whether your study meets this assumption, use Features - Statistical Test Selector | Laerd Statistics. There should be no significant outliers. Outliers are simply data points within your data that do not follow the usual pattern (e.g., in a study of 100 students' IQ scores, where the mean score was 108 with only a small variation between students, one student had a score of 156, which is very unusual, and may even put her in the top 1% of IQ scores globally). The problem with outliers is that they can have a negative effect on the one-way ANOVA, reducing the validity of your results.
Your Dependent Variable should be approximately normally distributed for each category of the Independent Variable. We talk about the one-way ANOVA only requiring approximately normal data because it is quite 'robust' to violations of normality, meaning that assumption can be a little violated and still provide valid results. You can test for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality, which is easily tested for using SPSS Statistics.


There needs to be Homogeneity of Variances. You can test this assumption in SPSS Statistics using Levene's test for homogeneity of variances. If your data fails this assumption, you will need to not only carry out a Welch ANOVA instead of a one-way ANOVA, which you can do using SPSS Statistics, but also use a different post hoc test. Levene's test tells us if we have met the assumption that the two groups have approximately equal variances on the dependent variable. If Levene's Test is significant ('Sig.' is less than .05), the two variances are significantly different. If Levene's Test is not significant, then the two variances are approximately equal, and the assumption is met.
The one-way ANOVA is considered a robust test against the normality assumption. This means that it tolerates violations to its normality assumption rather well. As regards the normality of group data, the one-way ANOVA can tolerate data that is non-normal (skewed or kurtotic distributions) with only a small effect on the Type I Errors rate. However, platykurtosis can have a profound effect when your group sizes are small. This leaves you with two options: Transform your data using various algorithms so that the shape of your distributions become normally distributed Choose the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis H Test which does not require the assumption of normality. There are two tests that you can run that are applicable when the assumption of homogeneity of variances has been violated. Welch Brown and Forsythe test. Alternatively, you can run a Kruskal-Wallis H Test. For most situations, it has been shown that the Welch test is the best. Both the Welch and Brown and Forsythe tests are available in SPSS. A lack of independence of cases has been stated as the most serious assumptions to fail. Often, there is little you can do that offers a good solution to this problem. Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Way ANOVA

Add Dependent Variable to the Dependent List box, and add the Independent Variable to the Factor box. Click Options. Check the box for Means Plot, then click Continue. Click OK when finished.
The Dependent Variable. This is the variable whose means will be compared between the samples (groups). You may run multiple means comparisons simultaneously by selecting more than one dependent variable.
The Independent Variable. The categories (or groups) of the independent variable will define which samples will be compared. The independent variable must have at least two categories (groups), but usually has three or more groups when used in a One-Way ANOVA. Specify contrasts, or planned comparisons, to be conducted after the overall ANOVA test. When the initial F-test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, contrasts are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you have specific hypotheses that you wish to test. Contrasts are decided before analyzing the data (i.e., priori). Contrasts break down the variance into component parts. They may involve using weights, non-orthogonal comparisons, standard contrasts, and polynomial contrasts (trend analysis).
Request post hoc (also known as multiple comparisons) tests. Specific post hoc tests can be selected by checking the associated boxes.
When the initial F test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, post hoc tests are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you do not have specific hypotheses you wish to test. Post hoc tests compare each pair of means (like T-Test s), but unlike T-Test s, they correct the significance estimate to account for the multiple comparisons.
Multiple comparisons options that assume homogeneity of variance (each group has equal variance). By default, a 2-sided hypothesis test is selected. Alternatively, a directional, one-sided hypothesis can be specified if you choose to use a Dunnett post hoc test. Click the box next to Dunnett and then specify whether the Control Category is the Last or First group, numerically, of your grouping variable. In the Test area, click either < Control or > Control. The one-tailed options require that you specify whether you predict that the mean for the specified control group will be less than (> Control) or greater than (< Control) another group. Multiple comparisons options that do not assume equal variances. The desired cutoff for statistical significance. By default, significance is set to 0.05. Clicking Options will produce a window where you can specify which Statistics to include in the output (Descriptive, Fixed and Random Effects, Homogeneity of Variance Test, Brown-Forsythe, Welch), whether to include a Means Plot, and how the analysis will address Missing Values (i.e., Exclude cases analysis by analysis or Exclude cases listwise). Click Continue when you are finished making specifications.
You will have calculated the following results or obtained them from SPSS. N is the total number of subjects and k is the number of groups

"There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021)." this is all you will need to write for the one-way ANOVA per se. However, you will probably also want to report means ¬± Standard Deviation (SD) s for your groups, as well as follow up a statistically significant result with a post hoc test. The general form of writing the result of a one-way ANOVA is as follow:
You should not report the result as 'Significant difference,' but instead report it as 'statistically significant difference.' this is because your decision as to whether the result is significant or not should not be based solely on your statistical test. Difference A one-way ANOVA was used to test for mean differences in science type depending on the intent to stay. It was predicted that there would be differences among the science types, though no specific group differences were made a priori. Assumptions of the one-way ANOVA were upheld. For example, data was generally normally distributed with histograms following a normal distribution curve and a significant Shapiro-Wilk‚Äôs test. Similarly, HOV was upheld via a significant F value (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021). There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021). No Difference A one-way ANOVA was used to test for mean differences in science type depending on the intent to stay. It was predicted that there would be differences among the science types, though no specific group differences were made a priori. Assumptions of the one-way ANOVA were upheld. For example, data was generally normally distributed with histograms following a normal distribution curve and a significant Shapiro-Wilk‚Äôs test. Similarly, HOV was upheld via a significant F value (F (1, 42) = .010, p = .086). The results of the omnibus test suggests that there not statistically significant mean level differences in science type depending on the intent to stay (F (1, 42) = .010, p = .086, R2 = .00). The small effect size suggests that 0% of the observed variance in the science type can be explained by the intent to stay. Report the result of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., 'There were no statistically significant differences between group means as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 1.397, p = .15). Running a post hoc test is usually not warranted and should not be carried out. You need to report your results. You then need to follow-up the one-way ANOVA by running a post hoc test. You need to perform the same procedures as above, but add into your results section that this assumption was violated and you needed to run a Welch F test. ANOVA test tells you whether you have an overall difference between your groups, but it does not tell you which specific groups differed - post hoc tests do. Because post hoc tests are run to confirm where the differences occurred between groups, they should only be run when you have a shown an overall statistically significant difference in group means (i.e., a statistically significant one-way ANOVA result). Post hoc tests attempt to control the experiment-wise error rate (usually alpha = 0.05) in the same manner that the one-way ANOVA is used instead of multiple t-tests. Post hoc tests are termed a posteriori tests; that is, performed after the event (the event in this case being a study). There are a great number of different post hoc tests that you can use. However, you should only run one post hoc test - do not run multiple post hoc tests. For a one-way ANOVA, you will probably find that just two tests need to be considered. If your data met the assumption of homogeneity of variances, use Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) post hoc test. Note that if you use SPSS Statistics, Tukey's HSD test is simply referred to as 'Tukey' in the post post hoc multiple comparisons dialogue box. If your data did not meet the homogeneity fo variances assumption, you should consider running the Games Howell post hoc test.
Your Dependent Variable should be measured on a continuous scale (i.e., it is either an Interval Variable or Ratio Variable). Examples of variables that meet this criterion include revision time (measured in hours), intelligence (measured using IQ score), exam performance (measured from 0 to 100), weight (measured in kg), and so forth.
If your Dependent Variable was measured on an ordinal scale, you will need to carry out ordinal regression rather than multiple regression. Examples of Ordinal Variables include Likert items (e.g., a 7-point scale from 'strongly agree' through to 'strongly disagree'), amongst other ways of ranking categories (e.g., a 3-point scale explaining how much a customer liked a product, ranging from 'Not very much' to 'Yes, a lot').
You have two or more Independent Variable s, which can be either Continuous Variable (i.e., an Interval Variable or Ratio Variable) or Nominal Variable (i.e., an Ordinal Variables or Nominal Variable)
Examples of Nominal Variable include gender (e.g., 2 groups: male and female), ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist), and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations (i.e., independence of residuals), which you can easily check using the Durbin-Watson statistic. Click Analyze > Regression > Linear
You will be presented with the Linear Regression dialogue box below:

Transfer the Dependent Variable into the Dependent box and the Independent Variable s into the Independent (s) box. Click on the Statistics button. You will be presented with the Linear Regression: Statistics dialogue box.
In addition to the options that are selected by default, select Confidence Intervals in the Regression Coefficients area leaving the Level(%) option at 95.

The R column represents the value of R, the multiple correlation coefficient. R can be considered to be one measure of the quality of the prediction of the dependent variable, in this case, VO2max. A value of 0.760, in this example, indicates a good level of prediction.
The R Square column represents the R2 value (also called the coefficient of determination), which is the proportion of variance in the Dependent Variable that can be explained by the Independent Variable s (technically, it is the proportion of variation accounted for by the regression model above and beyond the mean model). You can see from our value of 0.577 that our Independent Variable s explain 57.7% of the variability of our Dependent Variable, VO2max.

The F-ratio in the ANOVA table (see below) tests whether the overall regression model is a good fit for the data. The table shows that the Independent Variable s statistically significantly predict the Dependent Variable, F(4, 95) = 32.393, p < .001 (i.e., the regression model is a good fit for the data).
The general form of the equation to predict VO2max from age, weight, heart-rate, gender is: Predicted VO2max = 87.83 - (0.165 x age) - (0.385 x weight) - (0.118 x heart-rate) + (13.208 x gender)
Unstandardized coefficients indicate how much the Dependent Variable varies with an Independent Variable when all other independent variables are held constant. Consider the effect of age in this example. The unstandardized coefficient, B1, for age is equal to -0.165. This means that for each one year increase in age, there is a decrease in VO2max of 0.165 ml/min/kg. You can test for the statistical significance of each of the independent variables. This tests whether the unstandardized (or standardized) coefficients are equal to 0 in the population. If p < .05, you can conclude that the coefficients are statistically significantly different to 0. The t-value and corresponding p-value are located in the 't' and 'Sig.' columns, respectively.

You can see from the 'Sig.' column that all Independent Variable coefficients are statistically significantly different from 0. Although the intercept, B0, is tested for statistical significance. How to create a dummy code variable What is a reference group? How is it coded? What is the comparison group? How is it coded? How to create a contrast code variable When it is appropriate to use contrast coding (and when is it not)? How to run a regression model in SPSS With a single predictor With multiple predictors How to interpret the ANOVA table (Omnibus test) F-statistic and p-value, what do they tell us? R2, what does it tell us? How to interpret coefficients (for both output AND regression equation) How do you interpret the intercept?
How do you interpret the coefficients for a continuous variable? How do you interpret the coefficient for a contrast coded variable? How do you interpret the coefficients for a dummy coded variable? Assumptions Regression with 1 predictor
Regression with 2 continuous predictors What types of research questions/hypotheses can be tested with a two-way ANOVA? How to read and interpret a between-subjects table for:
Between group factor 1 including Degrees of Freedom, MS, F-statistic, and p-value
Between group factor 2 including Degrees of Freedom, MS, F-statistic, and p-value
Interaction between group factors 1 and 2 including Degrees of Freedom, MS, F-statistic, and p-value. How to use the ANOVA table to identify: How many categories an independent variable has Sample size How to run a two-way ANOVA in SPSS How to run a two-way ANOVA as a regression in SPSS Two-way ANOVA approach Regression approach Intercept Coefficients (for each variable and intraction) - how to use coding scheme to interpret How to use results to create regression equation and calculate means for each group The assumptions of two-way ANOVA How to check assumptions in SPSS Appropriate rationale for making a decision as to whether the assumption has been met The results indicated [a significant/no significant] (4a) main effect for [independent variable 1], F([independent variable1 df] (5a), [error df] (6)) = [F value] (7a), p = [p value] (8a), partial Œ∑2 = [partial Œ∑2] (9a); [a significant/no significant] (4b) main effect for [independent variable 2], F([independent variable 2 df] (5b), [error df] (6)) = [F value] (7b), p = [p value] (8b), partial Œ∑2 = [partial Œ∑2] (9b); and [a significant/no significant] (4c) interaction between [independent variable 1] and [independent variable 2], F([interaction df] (5c), [error df] (6)) = [F value] (7c), p = [p value] (8c), partial Œ∑2 = [partial Œ∑2] (9c).

item.title: 4. Normal Distribution (Z-Scores)
item.description:
The area of probability began in the Middle Ages (17th and 18th centuries). Royal and affluent gamblers consulted with mathematicians for advice on games of chance and gambling. Probability was also used for practical purposes to help determine life expectancy for life insurance policies. P(A) = S / T P(A) is probability of event A S is # of times event A can occur T is the total # of events possible Example with a fair six-sided die: P (4) = S/T = 1/6 P (x >/= 5) = 2/6 = 33.3% The sum of the probabilities for all possible outcomes is exactly 1 (i.e., 100% chance) The probability of any given event (a) cannot exceed 1 and (b) cannot be less than 0. An event having a probability of 1 means that no other event can possibly occur. "In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes." (Benjamin Franklin, 1789) Related to 0, although you cannot speak of an event occurring less than never, you can have an event with 0 probability. "You can't win the lottery if you don't buy a ticket." Long ago many disciplines found that a particular bell-shaed or normal curve occurred often with many different variables (recall histograms). Later in the 1700 s, mathematicians were called on to find an equation to approximate the normal distribution. If an equation could be developed then the probability associated with any point on the curve could be determined. Until 1920, the development of the equation was attributed to Karl Friedrich Gauss, and it was known as the Gaussian curve. Then Pearson, however, found this equation written earlier than Gauss's time in an article by Abraham DeMoivre in 1733 and renamed the curve as the normal distribution. F (x): probability density function ùúá: 'Location' parameter (center), can be estimated by sample mean ùë•. ùúé: 'Scale' parameter (spread), can be estimated by sample standard deviation s. ùúã ‚âà 3.14159 ùëí ‚âà 2.71828
Normal distribution follows a very specific pattern: Symmetric around the mean (mean = median = mode) Bell-shaped Unimodal Aymptotic (the curve goes on forever on both sides of ùúá) There are an infinite number of normal curves, one for every distinct pair of values of the mean and variance. Every member of the family of normal curves has the same characteristics except that the scale, mean, and variance can differ across different variables and populations. General Notation: ùë•i~ùëÅ(ùúá, ùúé2) Xi follow a normal distribution with mean ùúá and variance (ùúé2). Notice this notation reports variance (ùúé2), not standard deviation (ùúé). From a sample: ùë•i~ùëÅ(ùúá, ùúé2) For any random variable x, there are an infinite number of possibilities even within a small range. Theoretically, probability of x being a specific value is zero. P (x=xobs)=0
For continuous data, we find probability always within a range or interval, but we can make that interval as small as we like. Probability: Area under the curve between two values. Normal Curve (68-95-99.7 rule): 68.3% of scores are expected to fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean. (ùë• ¬± 1s) 95.4% of scores are expected to fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean (ùë• ¬± 2s) 99.7% of scores are expected to fall within 3 standard deviations of the mean (ùë• ¬± 3s) We can convert any normal distribution to a standard normal distribution (aka unit normal distribution or standard unit normal distribution). Z-score: The standardized scores. This allows us to evaluate an individual's performance relative to the scores in the distribution. Make comparisons between two different individuals, or across two different variables. Identify extreme values (outliers)
Notation: ùë•i~ùëÅ(0,1) Mean is 0. Variance (and standard deviation) is 1. To standardize, center mean to 0 and transform (stretch or compress) standard deviation to 1. Equation: zi = (xi-ùúá)/ùúé For sample data: zi = (xi-ùúá)/s Useful equation: Xi=(ùúá+zi)(ùúé) Xi=(x+zi)(s) for sample data A typical z-table reports cumulative probability given a z score (i.e., area under the curve to the left of z, think PRz=%). We can determine any area under the curve (below or above a give z, or between any two z values). We can also find a specific z value given the cumulative probability (think P%=z). 68.3% of data within 1 standard deviation from the mean? P (z ‚â§ 1) - P (z ‚â§-1)= 0.8413 - 0.1587 = 0.6826 95.4% data within 2 standard deviations from the mean? P (z ‚â§ 2) - P (z ‚â§ -2) = 0.9772 - 0.0228 = 0.9544 99.7% data within 3 standard deviations from the mean? P (z ‚â§ 1) - P (z ‚â§ -1) = 0.9987 - 0.0013 = 0.9974 In a recent census, the average income for several large rural counties was ùúá = $35, 285 and the standard deviation was ùúé = $7,200. What proportion of families have incomes below $35,000? Want to find P (x<35000) Convert x ($) to z, given mean and standard deviation: Z = (x-ùúá)/ùúé = (35000-35285)/7200 = -0.04 So we are looking for P (z ‚â§ -0.04) = 0.4840 About 48.4% of families had household incomes below $35,000. What was the 80th percentile household income? Use z-table to find the z score with cumulative probability 80% (area is 0.8000). Z = 0.845 (between 0.84 and 0.85 from table) Convert to $ (recall z = (x-ùúá)/ùúé): X = (ùúá + z)(ùúé) = (35,285 + 0.845)(7200) ‚âà 41369 The 80th percentile household income was $41,369. Learning a new instrument is exciting, but it takes consistent practicing to truly make music. A study shows aspiring musicians usually spend about 30 minutes practicing every day, with a standard deviation of 12.5 minutes. Assuming the practice time follows a normal distribution, what is the probability of a student practicing more than 70 minutes a day? We want to find P (x > 70) Convert x to z, given mean and standard deviation: Z = (x-ùúá)/ùúé) = (70-30)/12.5 = 3.2 So we are looking for P (z > 3.2) From z-table, P (z ‚â§ 3.2) = 0.9993 (table only gives area to the left. ) So P (z > 3.2) = 1-0.9993 = 0.0007 There is only a slight chance (0.07%) that a student would practice more than 70 minutes a day. The GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item assessment) is a short questionnaire used to screen for anxiety. GAD-7 scores range from 0 to 21 and indicate the severity of generalized anxiety. In a clinical study based on 90 participants, the distribution of GAD-7 scores followed a normal distribution with a mean of 6.3 and a standard deviation of 2.8. Given the descriptive statistics, how many participants were considered to have moderate anxiety? Probability between 10 and 15 is P (x ‚â§ 15) - P (x ‚â§ 10). I used range 10-15 to include the score of 14. P (z ‚â§ (15-6.3)/2.8) - P (z ‚â§ 3.11) - P (z ‚â§ 1.32) From z-table: 0.991 - 0.9066 = 0.0925 ‚âà 9.3% About 9.3% of the 90 participants had a GAD-7 score between 10 to 14. That is about 8 individuals (90 x 9.3% ‚âà 8) who were considered to have moderate anxiety. The average June daily high temperature in Ohio is 80ÀöF, with a standard deviation of 3 degrees. Normality assumed, what are the expected range (high and low) of daily high temperatures 95% of the time? Find the middle 95% range from z-table: each tail is (1-0.95)/2 = (0.05/2) = 0.025 Z for upper limit (can be notated as z0.025): 1.96 (area to the left is 0.9750) Z for lower limit: -1.96 (area to the left is 0.0250) Notice the two z scores have the same value but different signs (symmetric). Middle 95% range for z: 0 ¬± 1.96 or (-1.96, 1.96) Convert to temperature (ùúá ¬± 1.96 x ùúé): 80 ¬± 1.96 x 3 = 80 ¬± 5.88 = (74.86) 95% of the time, June daily high temperature in Ohio fluctuates between 74ÀöF and 86ÀöF. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives Check option Save standardized values as variables. Negative and decimal values occur in a standard normal distribution, thus other types of standardized scores have been developed, such as: SAT (College Board): ¬µ = 500, ùúé = 100 IQ: ¬µ = 100, ùúé = 15 Normal Curve Equivalent (NCE): ¬µ = 50, ùúé = 21.06 Many analyses require the normality assumption (i.e., variables should be normally distributed in the populaiton). Most tests are robust against such violations if sample size is large (30). However, non-normality is often associated with biased standard deviations, which affects decision making in hypothesis testing. If non-normality is severe, we might need to transform the data. For non-normal and small samples, other alternative nonparametric tests are available. Recall boxplot: Is the median in the middle of the box? Recall Central Tendency: Is median close to the mean? Compare Histogram (data) to normal curve (theory): SPSS: In Histogram, check option Display normal curve. Skewness and kurtosis ratios within ¬±2 or ¬±3. Forthcoming: Q-Q plot (quantile-quantile plot) Tests for normality: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and Shapiro-Wilk test "Whenever the smallest or the largest observation is less than one standard deviation from the mean, this is evidence of severe skew." This suggests that the distribution of scores is very compressed on one side of the mean. SPSS measures skewness by the 3 rd moment about the mean: ‚àë(z3/n) If normal, this measure should be 0. Negative (Skew to the left) Positive (Skew to the right) Skewed if standardized skewness |skew√∑se (skew)| ‚â• 2 (large sample) or ‚â• 3 (small sample) Se(skew) is the standard error of the skewness measure. Access "whether or not there are more or fewer extreme scores than expected in a normal distribution." Generally, kurtosis is less concerning than skewness. SPSS measures kurtosis by the 4th moment about the mean: ‚àë(z4√∑n) - 3 If normal (mesokurtic), this measure should be 0. Negative kurtosis (platykurtic): flat or broad Positive kurtosis (leptokurtic): slender or narrow Non-normal if standardized kurtosis |kurtosis√∑se (kurtosis)| ‚â• 2 (large sample) or ‚â• 3 (small sample) is the standard error of the kurtosis measure.
Statistics Skewness: / = (-0.978) / (0.083) = -11.78 Negative skew (to the left) Kurtosis / = (0.899) / (0.167) = 5.38 Leptokurtic (narrow) Descriptive Statistics Statistics Skewness: / = (0.089) / (0.083) = 1.07 Within ¬±2: Normal Kurtosis / = (-0.677) / (0.167) = -4.05 Leptokurtic (narrow)

item.title: 6. One-Sample T-Test, Power
item.description:
Midterm will cover the materials from lectures 1-6: Sampling, measurement, data representation, descriptive statistics, normal distribution, z-scores, CLT, hypothesis testing, one-sample t-test, and one-sample t-test. Questions will be posted in Carmen (Assignments -> Midterm) on 6/27 (Thursday) morning. A 'homework' named 'Midterm' will open in Top Hat. Multiple choice 30 questions Work through the problems and enter your answer in Top Hat by 7/2 (Tuesday) 11:59pm. Be aware of the hard deadline. Top Hat will automatically grade your exam and publish the answers after the due date/time. No class on 7/1 (Monday) or Lab on 7/2 (Tuesday) What is Central Limit Theorem (CLT) in a nutshell? When sample size is large, sampling distribution of the mean is normal or approximately normal regardless of population distribution. How to interpret a 95% confidence interval? The interval covers the population (true) mean 95% of the time. What is a null hypothesis? Null hypothesis is saying that the intervention is not working. Says there is no statistical significance between two variables. Alternative hypothesis is the expected outcome researchers have theorized. Most of the time you want to reject the null hypothesis because there would be no statistical significance between variables (not statistically significant) What is the confidence level corresponding to a 0.05 alpha (Type I error) level? 95% Type I error is falsely rejecting the null hypothesis. It should not happen a lot. How extreme our sample mean to make it not based on chance. You can only commit Type I error 5% of the time. It only allows M P value is always between 0 and 1. If your observed z-score needs to be grater than 1.96 standard deviations above or below the mean. Comparing Type 1 Error to p-value If your p-value is greater Used for questions about whether the population mean (¬µ) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (¬µ0). Non-directed (two-sided) or directional (one-sided) Population standard deviation (ùúé) is known. Assumptions: Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other. Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale. Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30). Used for questions about whether the population standard mean (¬µ) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (¬µ0). Non-directional (two-sided) or directional (one-sided) Population standard deviation (ùúé) is unknown: estimated by sample standard deviation (s). Assumptions: Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other. Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale. Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30). In most research projects, population standard deviation (ùúé) are usually unknown. But we can use our sample to compute a sample standard deviation (s). So we are now estimating two population parameters: Population mean (¬µ) is being estimated by the sample mean (x bar). Population standard deviation (ùúé) is being estimated by the sample standard deviation (s). Recall standard error of the mean: ùúéx bar = ùúé √∑ ‚àön (ùúé is known) Now we can estimate: ùúéx bar = s √∑ ‚àön. Recall for one-sample z-test: zobs = (x bar - ¬µ0) √∑ (ùúé √∑ ‚àön) (ùúé is known) Now it is estimated by: (x bar - ¬µ0) √∑ (s √∑ ‚àön) But is it still normally distributed? A new theoretical distribution for obtaining the critical values was developed: T-distribution (student's t-distribution) Developed by English statistician William Sealy Gosset under the pseudonym 'Student.'
Symmetric and bell-shaped like the normal distribution, but t-distribution has heavier tails (i.e., more prone to producing values that fall far from its mean). The shape of t-distribution depends on degrees of freedom (df or v). Shape of t-distribution depends on df (or sample size)
Q. What did the z-distribution say to the t-distribution? A: You may look like me but you are not normal. Non-directional (two-tailed): To test if mean where sample came from (¬µ) is significantly different from hypothesized mean (¬µ0). H0: ¬µ = ¬µ0 vs. H1: ¬µ ‚â† ¬µ0 Alternatively in terms of mean difference: H0: ¬µ - ¬µ0 = 0 vs. H1: ¬µ - ¬µ0 ‚â† 0 Directional (One-Tailed): H0: ¬µ ‚â§ ¬µ0 vs. H1: ¬µ > ¬µ0 H0: ¬µ ‚â• ¬µ0 vs. H1: ¬µ < ¬µ0 Reject H0 if tobs = (x bar - ¬µ0) √∑ (s √∑ ‚àön) falls into the critical region (determined by tcrit given the df) A t-table might be used to determine the critical values (tcrit) and rejection region. Different t-tables might be constructed differently. For the t-tables used in class, table entries are positive t values, given specific (common) probabilities of the upper tail. (Symmetric so you can figure out negative t) Look for t value given the degrees of freedom (df = n - 1) and ùúé level (Area is ùúé √∑ 2 for two-tailed and ùúé for one-tailed) or confidence level (default is two-tailed) At ùúé = 0.05 (95% confidence level), n = 30, two-tailed test, what is the t value? From the t-table, df = 30 - 1 = 29 Upper tail is 0.025 (or 95% at the bottom) On the t-table, t = 2.045. Recall z0.025 = 1.96, which agrees that a t-distribution has heavier tails than z-distribution. Theoretically, when sample size approaches infinity (‚àû), t equals z. However, t-table does not have all the possible sample sizes so we rely on SPSS (p-value reported). Consider the data we collected last time sample data of the prices of OSU students are willing to pay for Gardyn (aka, willingness to pay or WTP): n = 20 (Our class is small, but your samples are usually larger) x bar = 181.9 s = 231.2 (This is bigger than the ùúé, because we treated the class as population last time) Retail price is $899 with unknown population ùúé Research question: Is OSU's students' WTP (estimated by x bar) significantly different from the retail price (¬µ0 = 899) at 95% confidence level (i.e., should the company consider OSU students its target customers?) Average (mean) willingness to pay (WTP) is $181.9 with a standard deviation of $231.20. Skewness: 2.663 √∑ 0.512 ‚âà 5.2 -> Positive Kurtosis: 8.157 √∑ 0.992 ‚âà 8.2 -> Narrow


Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - ùúé)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from ¬µ0? Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test Pick variable and enter the Test Value (¬µ0) SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided. First section: Descriptive Statistics: Check ùúéx bar = 231.215 √∑ ‚àö20 = 51.701
Second Section: One-Sample t-test results Check t, df, and p-value
Last Section: Effect Size H0: ¬µ = 899 or ¬µ - 899 = 0 H1: Œº ‚â† 899 or Œº - 899 ‚â† 0 Mean difference: x bar - Œº0 = 181.9 - 899 =-717.1 (Check SPSS results) tobs = (x bar - ¬µ0) √∑ (s √∑ ‚àön) = -717.1 √∑ 51.701 = -13.87 Degree of Freedom (df) = 20 - 1 = 19 From t-table, tcrit = -2.093 Since tobs < tcrit, we can reject the null hypothesis (H0) and conclude that OSU students' WTP for Gardyn is significantly different (lower) from the retail price. Alternatively, build a 95% confidence interval for the mean difference and reject H0 if it does not cover 0. 95% confidence interval: (x bar - ¬µ0) ¬± tdf, ùúé/2 x (s √∑ ‚àön) -717.1 ¬± 2.093 x 51.701 ‚âà (-825.31, -608.89) Recall last time we created a 95% CI for x bar and checked if it covered ¬µ0. Sometimes hand-calculated numbers may have some rounding errors, but they should still be very close to the SPSS outputs. Since the 95% CI does not cover 0, we can conclude that OSU students' WTP for Gardyn is significantly different from the retail price. Finally, the easiest way: Compare p-value to Œ± (alpha, usually .05). Reject H0 if p < Œ± (alpha). According to SPSS (two-sided), our p-value is extremely small (p < .001). When p-value is extremely small (very close to 0), we‚Äôd report p < .001. NEVER report p = 0! Otherwise, report the observed p-value without the leading 0 (e.g., p = .003, p = .04, p = .52). ‚Ä¢Since p < Œ± (.05), we can reject H0 and conclude that WTP for Gardyn is significantly different from the retail price. For one-sample t-test (population œÉ unknown), we use Cohen‚Äôs d to report effect size. Cohen‚Äôs d = (x bar - Œº0) √∑ s Recall Cohen‚Äôs d for one-sample z-test: d = (x bar - Œº0) √∑ ùúé So, here sample SD (ùúé) is used to estimate ùúé. Notice, unlike z or t scores, effect sizes are not affected by sample size Size of Cohen's d (by convention): Small effect: d = ¬± 0.2 Medium effect: d = ¬± 0.5 Large effect: d = ¬± 0.8 Cohen's d = (x bar - Œº0) √∑ s = -717.1 √∑ 231.215 = -3.101 Large effect size (in reality, observing such a large effect size is highly unlikely!) SPSS also reports Hedges‚Äôs g: Cohen‚Äôs d appears to be biased for small samples (n < 20). Hedge‚Äôs g serves as an unbiased estimator of the population effect size. Hedges‚Äôs g ‚âà d √ó {1 - (3 √∑ (4 √ó df - 1)} Gardyn pricing example: Hedges‚Äôs g ‚âà -3.101 √ó {1 - (3 √∑ (4 √ó 19 - 1)} = -2.977
When the sample size is adequate (n = 20), we can use Cohen's d. (Your samples are usually larger.) The effect size is -3.101, indicating a large effect of the mean difference OSU students are unlikely to be Gardyn's target customers. A one-sample t-test was conducted at an alpha level of .05 to answer the research question: Is OSU students‚Äô willingness to pay (WTP) for Gardyn significantly different from the retail price $899? The null hypothesis stated that WTP would not differ from the retail price. The alternative hypothesis stated that WTP would differ from the retail price. Based on a random sample of 20 OSU students, there was a mean WTP of $181.9 and a standard deviation of $231.215. Then compared against the hypothesized mean of $899, the one-sample t-test was statistically significant, t(19) = -13.87, p < .001, indicating WTP is significantly different from $899. In addition, the effect size Cohen‚Äôs d was -3.101, generally interpreted as a large effect (Cohen, 1988), indicating that there is about 3 standard deviations difference between WTP and retail price, with the WTP lower than the retail price. SPSS reports both one-sided and two-sided p-values, but only two-sided CI is reported. To obtain one-sided upper or lower confidence limits, run a test doubling the ùõº (alpha) level This doe snot affect the p-values reported in the output. Say if you are conducting a directional test a 95% confidence level and want to see LCL or UCL, you can change the confidence interval percentage from 95% to 90% in Options. The lower end of reported 90% CI would be 95% LCL (Lower Control Limit), and the upper end of reported 90% CI would be 95% (Upper Control Limit). Any variation detected inside the control limits probably occurred by chance. On the other hand, variation outside of the control limits likely occurred due to special causes. The upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL) serve as boundaries for expected deviation in data.

Control Charts
We wanted to test if WTP is significantly lower than retail price $899. H0: Œº ‚â• 899 H1: Œº < 899 Can reject H0, t(19) = -3.246, p < .001 Report 95% UCL -627.7, which is below 0 so we can reject H0.
Definition: The probability that the test correctly rejects the null hypothesis when it's false (i.e., a specific alternative hypothesis is true). Power is determined by the following factors: Factors that can be controlled by the researcher: Level of significance (Œ±): As Œ± increases, power increases. Sample size (n): As n increases, power increases. Non-directional or directional test: Power is greater for a directional (one-tailed) test. Factors that cannot be controlled by the researcher: Size of population standard deviation (œÉ): As œÉ increases, power decreases. ‚Ä¢Difference between true population mean (Œº) and hypothesized mean (Œº0): As difference increases, power increases. A priori: Determined when planning a study. Usually used to compute required sample size, given Œ±, desired power and effect size. Completed Required Sample Size:
Post hoc (observed): Determined after a study has been conducted. Compute achieved power, given Œ±, sample size, and observed effect size. Compute Achieved Power:
Use GPower (free software) to explore statistical power:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G*Power (Optional) SPSS: Analyze √† Power Analysis When multiple hypotheses are tested (say m), the probability of observing a rare event increases, and the likelihood of incorrectly rejecting H0 (i.e., Type I error) increases. Bonferroni correction, named after Carlo Bonferroni, counteracts this problem by testing each individual hypothesis at a significance level of Œ± √∑ m, controlling desired overall (familywise) Œ± level. The simplest and most conservative method to control Type I error in multiple hypothesis testing. 6 t-tests were conducted (m = 6). To control the overall (familywise) Œ± level at .05, with Bonferroni correction, each item‚Äôs p-value is now compared to the critical value Œ± √∑ m = .05 √∑ 6 = .008. The 2nd question (p = .021) is no longer significant after Bonferroni correction. The 6th question (p = .003) remain significant. Can also create more conservative CI‚Äôs: 100 (1 - Œ± / m)%: 99.2% CI‚Äôs are wider than 95% CI‚Äôs, making them more likely to cover the test value (Œº0). One-sample z-test and one-sample t-test are considered robust for violations of normal distribution (i.e., assumption can be violated without serious errors). CLT assures that, for a large sample, the sampling distribution of the mean will be approximately normal regardless of the shape of population. However, when sample size is very small (e.g., n < 5), the test is not robust to non-normality. (Some studies also found the test is not as robust for one-tailed tests even with large samples). Non-normality can inflate the standard error of the mean, reduce power, and affect control of Type I error. Other non-parametric alternatives are available. They do not make assumptions on distribution.
