item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 5. Sampling Distribution of the Mean (One-Sample Z-Test)
item.description:
Here we begin to move from descriptive statistics to inferential statistics. After collecting sample data and generating sample statistics, we may also want to know to what extend we can generalize from these sample statistics to their corresponding population parameters (e.g., What does x tell us about ¬µ?) We already understand how probability and distribution(s) work. Now we want to know (a) how much uncertainty exists in our sample statistics, and (b) how much confidence can we place in our sample statistics. Inferential statistics allow us to make an inference or generalization from a sample to the population. Step 1: Population of interest Step 2: Draw sample Step 3: Compute sample statistics Step 4: Make inference back to the population Allows you to grow 30 plants simultaneously in just two square feet. Designed specifically for indoor growing - no dirt, no mess. LED-light column design boosts plant growth, makes it easier to maintain and brings natural beauty to your home. AI-powered with 24/7 plant monitoring. N = 20 Mean ¬µ = 181.9 225.36 Each sample has n = 4 All sample means ùë• have been calculated. Mean of the sampling distribution of the mean ¬µx = 165.36 Standard Error of the Mean ùúéx = 121.48 How does ùúéx compare to ùúé? In our Gardyn pricing experiment, we took random samples of size n = 4 students and recorded each sample's mean x1, x2, x3,‚Ä¶ and many other samples. Each sample mean is a point estimate of the population mean. We can construct a frequency distribution of sample means, known as the sampling distribution of the mean. It is the distribution of x for all possible samples of size n. The mean of the sampling distribution of the mean (¬µx) is the estimate of population mean (i.e., ¬µx = ¬µ). Sampling error (x - ¬µx): the difference (deviation) between a particular sample mean and the population mean. Variance error of the mean (ùúé 2/x): the variance of the sampling distribution of the mean. Standard error of the mean (ùúéx): the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean. As sample size n increases (say 30), the sampling distribution of the mean from a random sample more closely approximates a normal distribution. If the population distribution is normal, then the sampling distribution of the mean is also normal in shape. If the population distribution is not normal, then the sampling distribution of the mean becomes more nearly normal as sample size increases ('approximately normal') In reality, we'd only draw sample once and observe one sample mean x (i.e., ùúéx is not calculated from various samples). According to CLT, we can use x to estimate ¬µ with the standard error of the mean ùúéx = (ùúé √∑ ‚àön) CLT tells us the theoretical distribution of the sample mean x so we don't have to take hundreds of samples, find their mean and variance or create a histogram in order to use this information! We can create a confidence interval (CI) for the mean: Rather than a point estimate for a population parameter, we can construct an interval estimate (i.e., the likely range capturing the population parameter). Hypothesis tests about the mean. So we can make a decision about a parameter based on sample data. Allow us to move from descriptive statistics to inferential statistics. Recall last time: Convert a data point x to z-score: z = (x - ¬µ) √∑ ùúé Now, since sampling distribution of the mean follows a normal distribution: Mean: ¬µx = ¬µ Standard Error of the Mean: ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àön To convert a sample mean x to z score: Z = (x - ¬µ) √∑ ùúéx = (x - ¬µ) √∑ (ùúé √∑ ‚àön) Recall last time: In a recent census, the average income for several large rural counties was ¬µ = $35,285 and the standard deviation was ùúé = $7,200. Now, suppose a sample of n = 400 households was randomly selected from this region. Describe the sample distribution of the mean. What is the probability that the average income from the sample is: Below $35,000? Exceeding $39,000? Between $35,000 and $35,500? According to CLT, the sampling distribution of the mean is approximately normal. Mean: ¬µx = ¬µ = $35,285 Standard Error of the Mean: ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àön = $7,200 √∑ ‚àö400 = $360 Convert sample mean x to z score: z = (x - ¬µ) √∑ ùúéx = (x - 35285) √∑ 360. Or in one step: Z = (x - ¬µ) √∑ (ùúé √∑ ‚àön) = (x - 35,285) √∑ (7,200 √∑ ‚àö400) Use z table to find the corresponding probability smaller than z. P (x < $35,000) = P (z < (35,000 - 35,285)√∑360) = P (z < -0.79) = 21.48%. P (x < $39,000) = P (z < (39,000 - 35,285)√∑360) = P (z > 10.32) = 1 - P (z < 10.32) ‚âà 0. It is extremely unlikely to observe a sample mean more than $39,000. P ($35,000 < x < $35,500) = P ((35,000 - 35,285) √∑ 360) < z < ((35,500 - 35,285) √∑ 360) = P (-0.79 < z < 0.60) = P (z < 0.60) - P (z < -0.79) 0.7257 -0.2148 = 51.09% Given a confidence level 100 (1 - ùõº)%, we can build an interval estimates for the population mean from sample mean (x). The most common confidence level is 95% (ùõº = 0.05). Reported as lower confidence limit (LCL) and upper confidence limit (UCL), aka lower confidence bound (LCB) and upper confidence bound (UCB). General form: 100 (1 - ùõº)& CI = x ¬± za/2x ùúéx (Recall ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àön) 90% CI = x ¬± 2.645 x ùúéx 95% CI = x ¬± 1.96 x ùúéx 99% CI = x ¬± 2.575 x ùúéx Interpretation: The confidence interval will contain the true population mean 100 (1 - ùõº) out of 100 times. Here we define the area in the tails as ùõº. Since we have 2 tails, each tail is ùõº √∑ 2 This is for nondirectional CI. For directional, no need to find ùõº √∑ 2. Notice the table entry is the area under the curve to the left of z (i.e., PR), not the tail. Recall last time: The average June daily high temperature in Ohio is 80ÀöF, with a standard deviation of 3 degrees. 95% of the time, June daily high temperature in Ohio fluctuates between 74ÀöF and 86ÀöF. ¬µ ¬± 1.96 x ùúé: 80 ¬± 1.96 = 80 ¬± 5.88 (74, 86) Now, if we take a random sample of 100 June daily high temperatures from different dates/locations in Ohio, what is the sampling distribution of the mean? What is the 95% confidence interval (CI)? According to CLT, the sampling distribution of the mean is approximately normal. Mean: ¬µx = ¬µ = 80 Standard Error of the Mean: ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àön = 3 √∑ ‚àö100 = 0.3 95% CI: ¬µ ¬± 1.96 x ùúéx: 80 ¬± 1.96 x 0.3 = 80 ¬± 0.588 ‚âà (79.4, 80.6) Interpretation: With 95% confidence (i.e., 95 out of 100 times), our interval (79.5ÀöF, 80.6ÀöF) covers Ohio's true average June daily high temperature. 90% CI: ¬µ ¬± 1.645 x ùúéx: 80 ¬± 1.645 x 0.3 = 80 ¬± 0.4935 ‚âà (79.5, 80.5) 99% CI: ¬µ ¬± 2.575 x ùúéx: 80 ¬± 2.575 x 0.3 = 80 ¬± 0.7725 ‚âà (79.2, 80.8) Scores on a physical performance test for middle school students have been normed nationally for all students with a mean ¬µ = 175 and a standard deviation ùúé = 12. We took a sample of n = 120 students in Ohio found that the sample mean x = 162. Ohio population might be different from national norm so x = 162 deviates from ¬µ = 175. Suppose we'd like to estimate the population mean for Ohio based on this sample, what is the 95% confidence interval (CI)? Report the lower confidence limit (LCL) and the upper confidence limit (UCL). Population ¬µ = 175, ùúé = 12, Ohio Sample x = 162, n = 120 95% CI for Ohio population: x ¬± za √∑ 2 x ùúéx; or in one step: x ¬± za √∑ 2 x ùúé √∑ ‚àön 162 ¬±1.96 x 12 √∑ ‚àö120 = 162 ¬± 2.147 = (159.853, 164.147) Interpretation: We can be 95% confident that our interval covers the true population mean for Ohio (i.e., 95 out of 100 times, this CI would contain the true value of mean for the population to which we are generalizing). But is Ohio mean 162 significantly different from 175 (i.e., is the Ohio population from which we drew our sample the same population used to create the national norm)? Observation: Since 175 falls outside of the 95% CI (159.853, 164.147) of Ohio mean, it is likely that Ohio population deviates from the national norm. Hypothesis testing is a decision-making process where two possible decisions are weighed in a statistical fashion. Hypotheses are written for each decision and then sample data are used to help make the decision. Here we examine a statistical test to make inferences about a single mean with a known population standard deviation (ùúé):
One-sample t-test (6. One-Sample T-Test, Power)
Two samples, paired data: Paired (7. Paired-Sample T-Test)
Two samples, independent groups: Independent t-test (8. Independent T-Test, Homogeneity of Variance) Null hypothesis (H0): A statement about the value of an unknown population parameter. There is no difference or a 'null' difference between the population and hypothesized means (statistical hypothesis, chance model). Alternative Hypothesis (H1 or Ha): The opposite of H0. The scientific hypothesis that the researcher believes the outcome of the study will be, based on previous research and theory (research hypothesis, your theory). Hypothesis testing in a nutshell: Compare sample statistics to hypothesized distribution. If the data evidence is extreme, we can reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the event did not happen by chance. Instead, our theory is supported by data. Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - ùõº)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from ùúá0? Probability of Type I Error (what we want to avoid in decision making). Determine how far the sample mean needs to be from the hypothesized mean in order to reject H0. Set by the researcher or discipline, but the most commonly used values in the behavioral sciences and education are: ùõº = .05 (wrong 5% of the time, 95% confidence level) ùõº = .01 (wrong 1% of the time, 99% confidence interval) A statistician is a person whose lifetime ambition is to be wrong 5% of the time. Nondirectional (two-tailed): to test whether the population mean (ùúá) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (ùúá0). Critical region can be either right (upper) or left (lower) tail. H0: ùúá = ùúá0 H1: ùúá ‚â† ùúá0 Directional (one-tailed): To test whether the population mean (ùúá) from which we drew sample is significantly greater or less than a specific hypothesized value (ùúá0). Right (upper) tail (test if greater): H0: ùúá ‚â§ ùúá0 vs. H1: ùúá > ùúá0 Left (lower) tail (test if less): H0: ùúá ‚â• ùúá0 vs. H1: ùúá < ùúá0

Used when population ùúé is known, to test if sample is drawn from the same population (ùúá0: hypothesized mean). Consider the research question and decide nondirectional or directional. Set up null and alternative hypotheses. Calculate observed z-score from sample statistics. Recall: zobs = (x bar - ùúá0) √∑ (ùúé / ‚àöùëõ) Given confidence level and direction, find the critical z-score and region from table. Compare zobs to zcrit and reject H0 if zobs is in the critical region. Population ùúá = 175, ùúé = 12, Ohio sample x bar = 162, n = 120 Nondirectional (two-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: ùúá = 175 H1: ùúá ‚â† 175 Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - ùúá0) √∑ (ùúé / ‚àöùëõ) = (162-175) √∑ (12 / ‚àö120) ‚âà -11.87 Since ùõº = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is 0.25), look for z with area .0250: zobs = -1.96 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if zobs < -1.96 (or zobs > 1.96) Since zobs < -1.96, reject H0, indicating Ohio mean (162) is significantly different from national mean (175). Same physical performance test normed nationally: ùúá = 175 and ùúé = 12. We now have a sample of n = 80 students from Colorado and found that the sample mean x bar = 177. Is it reasonable to assume that Colorado sample is drawn from the same national population? Test using ùõº = .05. Population ùúá = 175 (ùúá0), ùúé = 12, Colorado sample ùë• bar = 177, ùëõ = 80 Nondirectional (two-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: ùúá = 175 H1: ùúá ‚â† 175 Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - ùúá0) √∑ (ùúé / ‚àöùëõ) (177‚àí175) √∑ (12 √∑ ‚àö80) ‚âà 1.49 Since ùõº = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is .025), look for z with area .9750: ùëßùëêùëüùëñùë° = 1.96 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if ùëßùëúùëèùë† > 1.96 (or ùëßùëúùëèùë†< ‚àí1.96) ‚Ä¢ Since ùëßùëúùëèùë† < 1.96, cannot reject H0, indicating Colorado sample comes from the same national norms. A high school has 49 seniors enrolled in a highly-ranked vocational program. The principal believes the mechanical ability of these seniors in the program is greater than their peers throughout the state. On a normed test of mechanical ability, the mean ùúá = 50 points with ùúé = 14 points. The sample average for the 49 seniors in the vocational program was found to be 53.4 points. At ùõº = .05, does the data support the principal‚Äôs claim? Population ùúá = 175 (ùúá0), ùúé = 12, our senior sample ùë• bar = 53.4, ùëõ = 49 Directional (one-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: ùúá ‚â§ 50 H1: ùúá > 50 To test if sample mean is greater, stop if x bar < ùúá0 (impossible to be greater) Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - ùúá0) √∑ (ùúé / ‚àöùëõ) (53.4‚àí50) √∑ (14 √∑ ‚àö49) ‚âà 1.7 Since ùõº = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is .025), look for z with area .9500: ùëßùëêùëüùëñùë° = 1.645 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if ùëßùëúùëèùë† > 1.645 Since ùëßùëúùëèùë† > 1.645, we can reject H0 so the data support the effectiveness of the program. Notice this test would have been non-significant if it was non-directional (ùëßùëêùëüùëñùë° = 1.96). Reject H0 if ùúá0 falls outside of the 100 (1 - ùõº)% confidence interval. Two-tailed: CI (x bar ¬± zùõº √∑ 2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ)) does not cover ùúá0 One-tailed: Testing if x bar is greater: LCL (x bar - zùõº √∑ 2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ)) above ùúá0. Testing if x bar is smaller: UCL (x bar + zùõº √∑ 2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ)) below ùúá0. Physical Performance in Ohio (ùúá0 = 175, œÉ = 12, x bar = 162, n = 120): 95% CI: x bar ¬± zùõº/2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ) = 162 ¬± 1.96 √ó (12/‚àö120) = (159.853, 164.147) Since 95% CI does not cover 175, we can reject H0 (Ohio mean is significantly different from national norm) Physical Performance in Colorado (ùúá0 = 175, œÉ = 12, x bar = 177, n = 80) 95% CI: x bar ¬± zùõº/2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ) = 177 ¬± 1.96 √ó (12/‚àö80) = (174.370, 179.630) Since 95% CI does cover 175, we cannot reject H0 (No differences detected between Colorado mean and national) Vocational Program Example (ùúá0 = 50, œÉ = 14, x bar = 53.4, n = 49) 95% LCL: x bar ¬± zùõº/2 √ó (ùúé √∑ ‚àöùëõ) = 53.4 - 1.645 √ó (14/‚àö50) = 50.11(159.853, 164.147) Since 95% LCL is greater than 50, we can reject H0 (Data supports the effectiveness of the program) Probability of obtaining a test statistic at least as extreme as the one observed. Visually, it is the area more extreme (same direction of critical region) than observed statistic. Therefore, comparing p-value to ùõº will reach the same conclusion as comparing observed and critical statistics. Reject H0 if p-value < ùõº (i.e., sample stats in rejection region). ùõº is usually .05 (95% confidence level). Notice p-values remain the same for tests with different ùõº levels, but p-value from a non-directional (two-tailed) test is 2 times larger than pvalue from a directional (one-tailed) test. For extreme cases p-values can be very close to 0, but theoretically p-values cannot equal 0. Therefore, report p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Physical performance in Ohio: Look up ùëßùëúùëèùë† (-11.87) on z-table, p-value is very small! Since ùëù < .001, reject H0 at 95% confidence level. (NEVER report ùëù = 0.) Physical performance in Colorado: Look up ùëßùëúùëèùë† (1.49) on z-table, p-value = 2 √ó (1 ‚àí .9319) = .1362 Since ùëù = .1362 (ùõº > .05), cannot reject H0 at 95% confidence level. Vocational program: Look up ùëßùëúùëèùë† (1.70) on z-table, p-value = 1 ‚àí .9554 = .0446 Since ùëù = .0446 (< .05), reject H0 at 95% confidence level. Notice this test would have been non-significant if it was non-directional (ùëù = 2 √ó .0446 = .0892, which would have been greater than .05). The idea is to compare sample statistics (say x bar) to the theorized distribution (say z). Reject H0 if data (zobs) shows extreme evidence (zcrit determined by ùõº level, usually .05). Three ways to reject H0 (one-sample z-test): The confidence interval constructed based on x bar does not cover ùúá0. zobs > zcrit (or negative values, zobs < zcrit) p < ùõº (usually .05) Hypothesis testing confirms if there is a significant effect (H0 rejected), but it does not tell us how large the effect is. The effect size tells us how large the effect is (i.e., how meaningful/practical the effect). Different statistics have been developed to report effect size for different statistical analysis. For one-sample z-test (population ùúé known), we use Cohen's d to report effect size. Cohen's d = (x bar - ùúá0) √∑ (ùúé) (i.e., how many SD's the difference is) Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ¬± 0.2: Small effect d = ¬± 0.5: Medium effect d = ¬± 0.8: Large effect Online Calculator:
Cohen's D Effect Size Calculator for Z-Test Physical performance in Ohio: d = (162 - 175) √∑ 12 = -1.083 (large) Physical Performance in Colorado: d = (177 - 175) √∑ 12 = 0.167 (small, recall test was non-significant) Vocational Program Example: d = (53.4 - 50) √∑ 14 = 0.243 (small) One-sample z-test is not available in SPSS menu, but there is a syntax available on YouTube by how2stats:
One sample z test - SPSS (Part1) - YouTube
One sample z test - SPSS (Part 2) - YouTube Notice the reported p-value is based on a two-tailed test. To obtain the one-tailed p-value, divide the two-tailed p-value by 2.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/5. Sampling Distribution of the Mean (One-Sample Z-Test).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Descriptive Statistics
item.description:
What do we do when we have research questions about a large sample of data? Carrying around the entire collection of data would be very difficult. Descriptive statistics summarize the data in an abbreviated fashion, but they provide sufficient information to depict the data. ùë•i: The score for ith person in the study or data set on variable x. Taking the sum of a set of scores is utilized quite often in statistics so we need a common system of notation for communicating about summation. En=1 xi: The sum of all data points of variable x. i=1 is the lower limit or beginning of the summation. i=n refers to the last person or the end of a data set. Ages from a sample of 10 coworkers: 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 n= 10 observations (subjects) Use N to notate size of the entire population. E10=1 xi = 24+26+28+28+31+31+31+35+38+47 = 318 Excel: =SUM (data range) All excel formulas in this class are optional (but useful) A single index or value summarizing the entire collection of scores. Three most popular measures of central tendency are mean, median, and mode. Mode: Most common or frequent value Median (Mdn): 50th percentile (or Q 2) or the middlemost value of an ordered set of scores. Mean: Arithmetic average The value in a distribution of scores that occurs most frequently. Sometimes there is no mode, and sometimes there are multiple modes. When there are two modes (bimodal distributions), some people report both modes. If they are adjacent, some people average the two modes. Goal is to faithfully describe the distribution of your data. Coworker example: 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 A new guy just joined the team: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Can be used with any type of measurement scales. Pros: simple to obtain, the only appropriate measure for nominal data. Cons: does not always have a unique value, not a function of all scores, difficult to deal with mathematically. We already know a lot about median (P50 or Q 2): Middle most value in an ordered set of data. After ordering the data, locate the ((n+1)/2) th observation. Coworker example (odd number): 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 New guy just quit (even number): 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Can be used with ordinal, interval, and ratio scales. Pros: Not influenced by extreme scores (outliers) Always has a unique value Cons: Not a function of all scores Difficult to deal with mathematically Sample Mean = (sum of xi)/n Coworker example: 318/10 = 31.8 Excel: =Average (data range) Used to estimate population mean The larger our sample, the better our estimate of the true population mean. Only appropriate for interval and ratio measurement scales. Pros: Function of every score. Always has a unique value. Easy to deal with mathematically. Most stable of the measures of central tendency. Cons: Influenced by extreme scores. Very unusual or 'extreme'values tend to draw the mean towards these values and contribute to skew in the data. Coworker example: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Mean: 31.8 Median: 31 Mode: 31 A retired guy just rejoined the team: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46, 75 Mean: 393/11 = 35.7 Median: 31 Mode: 31 For samples from a symmetric distribution (e.g., normal), mean, median, and mode should be very close to each other. When mean, median, and mode are far from each other, the data is skewed. Skewed to the right (long right tail, positive skew): Extreme large values Skewed to the left (long left tail, negative skew): Extreme small values
Sometimes we may have the means of several groups of people, and we still want to find the average. Two ways to do this: Weighted Average (average all the original scores): Takes into account of each group's sample size. Average is appropriate 'weighted' by number of observations in each group. Unweighted Average (simply take the mean of the averages): Does not 'weight' or take account of the different sample sizes. AKA: mean of means, grand mean, usually used for group comparison. Example (Weight Average): 8150/100=81.5 Unweighted average: (85+80+75)/3=80 The mean alone is not enough to tell us about the shape of a distribution. Measures of dispersion describe the amount of variability among the scores (i.e., do the scores fall close to the central tendency measure or are the scores spread out?)
There are no measures of dispersion appropriate for nominal data. We already know two measures of dispersion: Range and Interquartile range (IQR) Both are measures of dispersion, but not a function of all scores. They are informative measures, but don't have very strong statistical properties. Difference between the largest and smallest scores. Pros: Simple to obtain. Cons: Influenced by extreme scores, only a function of two of the scores, unstable from sample to sample. Difference between the third quartile (Q 3) and the first quartiles (Q 1) AKA H spread (stands for hinge, middle 50% of the distribution), developed by Tukey. Pros: Unaffected by extreme scores. Cons: Not a function of all scores, not very stable from sample to sample. The 'average' squared deviation from the mean for a set of scores. Variance is a better measure of dispersion than range and IQR, because it takes into account all the values for a set of scores (but might be affected by extreme values). Conceptually, the variance is a measure of the area of the distribution (i.e., the more spread out the scores, the more area or space the distribution takes up). The sample mean might not be the same as the population mean (usually unknown), and the deviations would be affected. Therefore, sample variance obtained would be systematically too small. In order to get an unbiased sample estimate of the population variance, a slight change in the computational formula was made. AKA Degree of Freedom (df) When we calculate a simple statistic based in part on another statistic, we have to consider the 'degrees of freedom' in our calculation. Given the sample mean, we do not need raw data from all n observations. We only need (n-1) observations, because the last missing score can be found from the mean (i.e., there is no 'freedom' in what this score might be). The denominator (n-1) in sample variance is called the degrees of freedom (df), which is related to sample size. You may see many different forms of formulas out there to compute variances and forthcoming descriptive statistics. They all come from the same 'definitional' formula, but after being modified/simplified given the mathematical properties, some 'computational' formulas are easier to deal with by hand. But excel or SPSS will compute them for us anyway. Since variance is a squared value, it is difficult to interpret. The standard deviation (SD) is the square root of the variance, and it is the most common measure of dispersion. For population: ùúé = square root of ùúé2 For sample: ùúé = square root of ùúé2 Measured on the same scale as original data. Interpretation: On average, the deviations from the mean, but on average the distance from the mean is about 2.92. The 68-95-99.7 rule (more next time): About 68% of data points fall within +/- 1 standard deviation from the mean. About 95% of data points fall within +/- 2 standard deviations from the mean. About 99.7% of data points fall within +/- 3 standard deviations from the mean. Measure the shared variance (or co-variance) between variables x and y.
Difficult to interpret, because the value of covariance depends on the scale of the variables. Other measures are needed. Correlation coefficients are measures of relationship that are easier to interpret. The first correlation coefficient we consider is the Pearson correlation coefficient (usually notated as r), which measures the relationship between two interval or ratio variables.
Pearson r ranges from -1 to +/- 1 The sign denotes the direction of the relationship (positive or negative). The value denotes the strength: 0 is the weakest correlation. +1 and -1 are the strongest correlation. Correlation does not imply causation. Don't need the leading zero in APA style writing, because r does not go beyond +/-1. Central Tendency and Dispersion: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies (uncheck option Display frequency tables) Descriptives Explore Correlation: Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate Correlation coefficients: Check Pearson To report covariance: Check option cross-product deviations and covariances Significances and p-values are also reported
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/3. Descriptive Statistics.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Paired-Sample T-Test
item.description: AKA dependent t-test: Dependent variable (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare post-score to pre-score Independent variable (IV): The treatment or intervention Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between the post-score and pre-score? Also used to compare twins, couples, eyeballs, etc. 20 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy -> Amount and severity of depressive symptoms Intervention -> Students' math proficiency Constraint induced movement therapy -> hand function One-group pretest-posttest design: O1 (pre) X O2 (post) One-group pretest-posttest design using a double pretest: O1 O2 X O3 One-group pretest-posttest design using a nonequivalent dependent variable: (O1A, O1B) x (O2B, O2B) The removed-treatment design: O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 The repeated-treatment design: O1 x O2 x O3 x O4 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (¬µ1) H0: ¬µ2 = ¬µ1 vs. H1: ¬µ2 ‚â† ¬µ1 Alternatively, in terms of mean difference: H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value! Directional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (¬µ1). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Directional: Test if post-score (¬µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (¬µ1): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0 One Sample StatisticsOne-Sample Test For negative emotion change (hypothesized to decrease), the one-sample t-test is significant, t(33) = -2.393, p = .011. The mean difference is -0.20 (negative emotion decreased after watching the video). The 95% upper confidence limit -.0585 below zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly smaller than 0). For positive emotion change (hypothesized to increase), the one-sample t-test is significant, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The mean difference is 1.06 (positive emotion increased after watching the video). The 95% lower confidence limit .7809 above zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly greater than 0). tobs = d √∑ sd-bar or d √∑ (sd √∑ ‚àön) d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores). n is the total number of pairs. Recall in one-sample t-test: tobs = ( - ¬µ0) (s √∑ ‚àön) Where is ¬µ0? Given ùõº level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available). Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail(s). Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < ùõº (SPSS) ùõº level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Nondirectional: 100 (1 - ùõº)% CI: ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar ¬± tdf, ùõº/2 x (sd-bar √∑ ‚àön) To test greater (significant increase in post-scores): 100 (1 - ùõº)% LCL: - tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores): 100 (1 - ùõº)% UCL: + tdf, ùõº/2 x sd-bar DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2. Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score. Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test For negative emotion change: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön = .48742 √∑ ‚àö34 = .08359 tobs = d-bar √∑ sd = - .2000 √∑ .08359 = -2.393 For positive emotion change: sd-bar = sd √∑ ‚àön = .95754 √∑ ‚àö34 = .16422 tobs = d-bar √∑ sd = 1.05882 √∑ .16422 = 6.448 Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to decrease (one-tailed test). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0 Mean difference d-bar = - .2000, SD sd = .48742, sd-bar = .08359 tobs = -2.393, df = 33, p = .011 Since the p-value (. 011) is smaller than the ùõº level (.05), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' negative emotion significantly decreased after watching the cat videos. Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to increase (one-tailed test). H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Mean difference d-bar = 1.05882, SD sd = .95754, sd-bar = .16422 tobs = 6.448, df = 33, p < .001 Since the p-value is very small (< .001), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' positive emotion significantly increased after watching the cat videos. Cohen's d = d-bar √∑ sd-bar Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test: d = ( - ¬µ0) √∑ s Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ¬±0.2: Small effect d = ¬±0.5: Medium effect d = ¬±0.8: Large effect Paired Samples Effect Sizes For negative emotion change, Cohen's d (- 0.410) suggests a small to medium effect. For positive emotion change, the effect size (d = 1.106) is quite large. The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The results from the pre-test (M = 13.5, SD = 2.4) and post-test (M = 16.2, SD = 2.7) memory task indicate that the presence of caffeine in the bloodstream resulted in an improvement in memory recall, t(19) = 3.1, p = .006. There was a significant increase in the volume of alcohol consumed in the week after the end of semester (M = 8.7, SD = 3.1) compared to the week before the end of semester (M = 3.2, SD = 1.5), t(52) = 4.8, p < .001 How to Report the Result of a T-Test (APA style) If you're hypothesis testing, restate your hypothesis. If your t-test is one-tailed, you need to say so. It's preferred to report the exact p-value unless it's smaller than .001. You need to state your alpha level (usually .05) early in the results section. If your p-value is smaller than .001, it's conventional simply to state p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Remember to drop the leading 0 from the p-value. No need to provide a formula for observed t in your paper. Observations are from a random sample, and the scores are independent of each other. Dependent variable of interest is measured on at least an interval scale. Difference scores (d's) are normally distributed. Typically considered robust to violations of non-normality, especially for big sample (n > 30) If one of the samples is highly skewed (particularly for a one-tailed test), a lot of error will tend to be built into the difference scores. Other non-parametric analyses would be better alternatives.

item.title: Standard Error
item.description:
A measure of the accuracy of a sample estimate. The standard error is the Standard Deviation (SD) of the sampling distribution of a statistic. Shows how different the population mean is likely to be from the sample mean. ùúéx = ùúé √∑ ‚àö*n Exact, uses the population standard deviation, which is usually unknown. Sx-bar = S √∑ ‚àö*n Estimate, uses the sample standard deviation, which is known.
Normal Distribution
Missing Data
Sampling Distribution
Regression Coefficient
Multilevel Analysis
Sampling
Confidence Intervals
Sample Size
Regression Analysis
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
Null Hypothesis
Independent Variable
Probability
Maximum Likelihood Estimation

item.title: 3. Descriptive Statistics
item.description:
Advantages and Disadvantages of Measures of Central Tendency Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Variable(s)' screen Under statistics, you can choose from a wide variety of statistics. You can also create the frequency distribution figures we discussed previous weeks under the Charts menu Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Variable(s)' screen. Under Options, you have the ability to choose from a slightly less wide variety of statistics. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Dependent List' screen Under Statistics, choose 'Descriptives' You don't have the ability to choose what descriptive statistics you want, but this menu gives you almost all 'Descriptives' Under Plots, you can also produce box-plot, histogram, and stem-and-leaf plot You can get descriptive information based on different groups in your dataset. Drag any categorical variables you are interested in into the Factor List box. This will produce separate charts and figures for each of the values in the variable you place in Factor List Means Analyze -> Compare Means and Proportions -> Means and Proportions -> Means -> drag dependent variable into the 'Dependent List' box Under Options, select the descriptive statistics you're interested in. You can also use this menu without comparing groups Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> .... Both variables x and y are interval and/or ratio level variables (scale variables) Population correlation is denoted by p (rho) Sample correlation is denoted by r: -1 < r < 1 -1.00: a perfect negative relationship 0: No linear relationship +1.00: A perfect positive relationship Characteristics of Correlations: Direction: Positive Negative Strength: The actual number calculated Can be any number from -1 to +1 A high correlation does not imply that one variable is causing the other; it simply means that these two variables are related in some fashion. Correlation does not imply causation. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Simple Scatterplot' into the preview box -> drag one VOI to the x-axis and one VOI to the y-axis. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Scatterplot Matrix' into the preview box -> drag all VOI to Scatter matrix box Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate -> drag VOIs into 'Variables' box Under 'Correlation Coefficients' select which type of correlation you want (Pearson) Under 'Test of Significance' select which type of test you want, based on your hypothesis. Steps: Double click your table Click 'Pivot Controls' Drag 'Statistics' into the 'layer' box Select Pearson Correlation Covariance Shared variance among x and y. Correlation is simply the standardized covariance.
Options -> Statistics -> Click Means and Standard Deviations AND Cross-Product Deviations and Covariances
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Labs/3. Descriptive Statistics.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Convenience Sampling
item.description: Choose samples merely based on proximity without considering whether they represent the population or not. Readily available, quick, inexpensive. Can reduce bias by using conveniance sample along with Simple Random Sample (SRS), taking multiple samples, or cross-validation.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/Convenience Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Systematic Sample
item.description: Every k^th unit is selected from a list, where k=population/desired sample size. Have a list with all units in the population. Then take sample systematically. Make sure the list you are selecting from is random.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/Systematic Sample.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Simple Random Sample (SRS)
item.description: Every member of the population of interest has an equal probability of being selected. Selection of one unit has no effect on the selection of another unit. Best technique to obtain a representative sample. Use a number table, a compute, a drawing, or a lottery system to generate random numbers.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/Educational Statistics 6641/Lecture/Simple Random Sample (SRS).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 9. Test for Correlation, Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
item.description:
We already know many ways to represent the association between two variables, both measured on at least an interval scale. Scatterplot Covariance sxy = (‚àëi = 1n (x1 - x-bar)(yi - y-bar)) √∑ n - 1 (ùúéxy for population) Pearson correlation coefficient rxy = (sxy) √∑ (sxsy) (ùúåxy for population) The correlation reflects the noisiness and direction of a linear relationship, but not the slope of that relationship, nor many aspects of non-linear relationships. To test whether the sample correlation between x and y is significantly different from zero (non-directional): H0: ùúå = 0 vs. H1: ùúå ‚â† 0 Directional alternatives are also possible. Assumptions:
Linearity The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship. Independence: Units or cases are randomly sampled from the population. tobs = r‚àö(n - 2) √∑ (1 - r2) tcrit: Given the ùõº level, t distribution with degrees of freedom (df = n - 2) Reject H0 if tobs > tcrit (or for negative values: tobs < tcrit) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < ùõº APA Style Writing Template: A Pearson correlation coefficient was computed to assess the linear relationship between x and y. There was a (weak / moderate / strong negative / positive) correlation between x and y, r (df) = (p-value). Notice: No need to report t. tobs = r‚àö(n - 2) √∑ (1 - r2) = (. 698)‚àö (858 - 2) √∑ (1 - .698)2) ‚âà 28.52 df = n - 2 = 858 - 2 = 856 (Optional) At ùõº = .05, tcrit = 1.963 -> Since tobs > tcrit, reject H0 From SPSS, p-value < .001 -> Reject H0 APA Style Writing Template: There was a strong positive correlation between GPA and ACT, r (856) = .598, p < .001. (Optional) Online calculators also available (section 3):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica Restricting the range of scores on one or both variables will reduce the strength of a correlation. If the size of the standard deviation for one variable is reduced, everything else being equal, then the size of correlations with other variables will also be reduced. In other words, we need sufficient variation for a relationship to be evidenced through the correlation coefficient value. HS GPA and ACT example: The strength of correlation between GPA and ACT will be lessened if we only focus on the graduates with summa cum laude (weighted GPA 4.2 or above). Correlation means the variables are related in some way, but correlations alone should not be used to infer cause. A high correlation between x and y might be a result of: x causes y y causes x A third variable z is causing both x and y (or even more variables are involved). Causality is not easy to prove. Application of complex statistical methods is not evidence for causality! Causation (x -> y) can only be inferred (formalized by the 19th-century philosopher John Stuart Mill) if: x proceeded y x was related to y We can find no other plausible alternative explanation for the effect on y other than x. Say we have data from 2 independent samples. We want to determine if the correlations between x and y are equal for these 2 independent samples. For example, is the correlation between GPA and ACT the same for Happy Valley HS (r = .654) and for Eureka HS (r = .765)? Happy Valley HS: r = .654 n = 155 Eureka HS: r = .765 n = 188 Hypotheses (Non-Directional): H0: ùúå1 - ùúå2 = 0 vs. H1: ùúå1 - ùúå2 ‚â† 0 Directional alternatives are also possible. Ranges of r is restricted so we use Fisher transformation to transform r1 and r2 to z1 and z2 respectively:
Fisher transformation - Wikipedia z = (1/2) ln ((1+r) √∑ (1-r)) = artanh (r) 'ln' is the natural logarithm function 'artanh' is the inverse hyperbolic tangent function Online calculators available (section 6):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica zobs = (z1 - z2) √∑ (‚àö (1 √∑ n1 - 3) + (1 √∑ n2 - 3)) zcrit: Find the critical z given the ùõº level (e.g., ¬± 1.96 at ùõº = .05) Reject H0 if zobs > zcrit (or zobs < zcrit for negative values) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < ùõº No SPSS procedure, but syntax and other online calculators available (section 1):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica This calculator is one-tailed though! You can multiply by 2 for a two-tailed test. Happy Valley HS (r1 = .654, n1 = 155): z1 = (1/2) ln ((1 + .654) √∑ (1 - .654)) = .782 Eureka HS (r2 = .765, n2 = 188): z2 = (1/2) ln ((1 + .765) √∑ (1 - .765)) = 1.008 zobs = (z1 - z2) √∑ (‚àö (1 √∑ n1 - 3) + (1 √∑ n2 - 3)) = (. 782 - 1.008) √∑ (‚àö (1 √∑ 152) + (1 √∑ 185)) = -2.064 (More extreme than -1.96) Can get p-value from z-table, Excel, or double the online calculator p-value (one-tailed) Reject H0 and conclude that the correlation between GPA and ACT for Happy Valley (r = .654) is significantly different from the correlation for Eureka HS (r = .765), z = -2.064, p = .04. 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ¬± .2 (weak) r = ¬± .4 (moderate) r = ¬± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ¬± .1 (weak) r = ¬± .3 (moderate) r = ¬± .5 (strong) Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y. Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR). You will learn regression models with multiple predictors, multiple linear regression (MLR), in more advanced stats classes. Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.
If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698 Square it: r2 = (. 698)2 ‚âà .487 This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA. Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2? Recall 'ballpark' effect size: Weak (|r| ‚â• .2) Weak (r2 ‚â• .04 or 4%) Moderate (|r| ‚â• .4) Moderate (r2 ‚â• .16 or 16%) Strong (|r| ‚â• .8) Strong (r2 ‚â• .64 or 64%) ACES (Adverse Childhood Experiences) -> Psychological symptoms Word exposure frequency and elaboration of word processing in incidental vocab learning -> incidental vocabulary acquisition and rentention through extensive reading The user's tech literacy or tech-savviness, overall product quality (design, build, execution, etc.), and many more -> User experience or user satisfaction of an EdTech product Student's participation -> Student's sense of belonging Grade point average -> Success in first year of college xi: IV data point for subject i yi: DV data point for subject i yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)
ùõΩ0: Intercept (Constant) ùõΩ1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit) One statistician movie fan decided to use statistics to study the movie ratings in his favorite movie guide, Movie and Video Guide (1996), by Leonard Maltin. Maltin rates movies on a one-star to four-star system, in increments of half-stars, with higher numbers being better. The guide also includes additional information on each film. The statistician used a random number generator to select a simple random sample of 100 movies rated by the Guide. Rating: Maltin rating (range is 1 to 4, in steps of 0.5) Length: Running time (in minutes) Year: Year the movie was released Cast: Number of case members listed in the guide Origin: Country (0 = USA, 1 = International) Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:
Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares: SSE = The optimal solution: b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar Regression line goes through both means of x and y! The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR) Usually you'd already review descriptive statistics and correlations before running a regression, but you can also ask SPSS to report Descriptive in the Statistics option. Many other options are for MLR only. The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line) Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: What we can explain by the model (regression) What we still cannot explain (error) Regression sum of squares (SSR) Error Sum of Squares (SSE) Total Sum of Squares (SSTO) SSTO = SSR + SSE SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) √∑ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE √∑ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive) In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |
Recall Pearson r = .318 (weak to moderate positive) Multiple R = .318 (weak to moderate relationship) R2 = .101, indicating 10.1% of variance in movie rating can be explained by running time.
Recall Pearson r = -.148 (weak negative) Multiple R = .148 (weak relationship) R2 = .022, indicating only 2.2% of variance in movie rating can be explained by the year a movie was released. Omnibus: Comprising several items "Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package." The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table. Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question: Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually Œ±=.05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: Œ≤1 = 0 H1: Œ≤1 ‚â† 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: œÅ = 0 (œÅ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: œÅ > 0 H0: œÅ2 = 0 H1: œÅ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < Œ± For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.
SSR = 4.918 SSE = 43.609 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (4.918 / 1) / (43.609 / 98) = 11.052 Since p = .001, reject H0 (significant model/predictor) Report F (1, 98) = 11.052, p = .001 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 4.918 / 48.528 = .101
SSR = 1.057 SSE = 47.471 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (1.057 / 1) / (47.471 / 98) = 2.182 Since p = .143, cannot reject H0 (model/predictor not significant) Report F (1, 98) = 2.182, p = .143 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 1.057 / 48.528 = .022

item.title: 4. Model Comparison (Simplest Model vs. Regression Model)
item.description:
Understand the bivariate regression in terms of the amount of error and the regression coefficients. Learn how to calculate the intercept (b0) and slope (b1) of bivariate regression using Excel and SPSS. Step 1: Get the mean Step 2:
9. Test for Correlation, Simple Linear Regression (SLR) True (sums of squares = sums of squared errors) True (B0) in the compact model = the mean of Y False (B0) True (SSEC = SST) False (SSEC - SSEA = R2, it actually equals SSEC - SSEA = SSRyou have to divide the total) A. Dependent Variable (Behavior Engagement) B. Predictors (Constant): Collective EfficacyA. Dependent Variable (Behavioral Engagement) Write up a research question and hypothesis that can be tested with this analysis. There is no relationship between collective efficacy and behavior engagement. As one increases, the other increases There is a positive relationship between student's collective efficacy and behavior engagement. You can determine if it is a positive or negative relationship. It is dependent on the theory and the empirical literature that has been done before. What is the slope coefficient? What does this value mean? 0.179 Constant is the Predictor variable is the slope () For every one unit increase, we are going to observe a .179 increase in their reported behavioral engagement. There is a significant relationship As one increases, so does the other, if the slope is Our p-value shows (<. 001) shows statistically significant What is the intercept? What does this value mean? 2.364 When students reported efficacy at 0, their reported levels of engagement will be 2.364.
What is the Effect Size? What does this mean? - 0.147 - The collective efficacy explains approximately 14.7% variance in the data we have observed.
- In Simple Linear Regression (SLR), R2 indicates the proportion of variance in dependent variable (DV) explained (accounted for) by the model. - 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: - r = ¬± .2 (weak) - r = ¬± .4 (moderate) - r = ¬± .8 (strong) - It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). - Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: - r = ¬± .1 (weak) - r = ¬± .3 (moderate) - r = ¬± .5 (strong) ùõΩ1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit)
Assumption of Normality of Error (Testing for Normality) P-P Plot
Assumption of Homoscedasticity (Testing Homoscedasticity) Regression standardized residual scatter plot
Assumptions of Independence of Error (Testing the Independence of Error) Durbin-Watson test in 'model summary' of SPSS output 1.5-2.5 Why? We want our data to be independent. Much of the time, our data is not independent. The data may be clustered or nested,
Assumption of No Extreme Outliers (Testing for Extreme Outliers) Cook's Distance in 'residual statistics' section of SPSS output Below 1 to pas
Assumption of Linearity (Testing Linearity) Scatter plot The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship. ANOVA Table (Alternative test) Note: the assumptions for any statistical analysis is about the outcome, not the predictors. Assumption of Linearity Scatterplot ANOVA Table: Deviation from linearity significance test, we want the value to not be linear
Deviation from Linearity: (Sum of Squares: 0.463) (df: 20) (Means Square: 0.023) (F: 1.226) (Sig: 0.320) In order to compare two models, they must be nested: Must predict the same outcome The smaller (compact) model must be present in the larger (augmented) model. Example: GPA = b0 + b1ClassMiss + ùúÄ GPA = b0 + ùúÄ The second model is nested within the first model. State the compact Model C and an augmented Model A. Identify the null hypothesis (H0). Count the number of parameters estimated by each model. Calculate the regression equation. Compute the total sum of squares (SSEC). Compute the sum of squares for Model A (SSEA). Compute sum of squares reduced (SSR). Compute the proportional reduction in error (PRE or R2). Complete the summary table. Decide about H0. Assumption of Linearity - Scatterplot - ANOVA table (deviation from linearity significance test, we want the value to NOT be linear)
Pay attention to the Deviation from Linearity

item.title: 3. Bivariate Regression
item.description:
Understand the bivariate regression in terms of the amount of error and the regression coefficients. Learn how to calculate the intercept (b0) and slope (b1) of bivariate regression using Excel and SPSS. Learn how to compute the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) for compact and augmented models. Effect size computation by comparing the sum of squared total (SST) and SSE The simple model (i.e., mean-only model) is not very informative and has a lot of error. Y = ùõΩ0 + ùúÄ Our model-building goal is to improve prediction and thereby reduce the error. To improve prediction and reduce error, we add a predictor variable (X) to the model. This enhanced model is the beginning of a 'predictive formula' that predicts individual outcome variable scores (Y) better than just predicting the mean. To use a bivariate regression model, identify two types of variables:
Predictor, or known variable (x)
Outcome, or to-be-predicted variable (y) Regression analysis provides an equation that corresponds to a line that best predicts y scores from x scores.
The model Population Parameter will be designated with a Greek letter (Œ≤). The estimate of the population parameter, which we calculate using our sample data, is designated by the Arabic letter b. We can predict a person's score on an outcome (dependent) variable (Y-Hat) based on what we know about that person's score on a predictor (independent) variable (x). If variables x and y are related to each other, then adding x to our model improves prediction and produces less error (SSE) than the simple model generated. Here we have two competing models: You can use bivariate regression to answer the following questions about the pattern of data points and the significance of a linear equation: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? More questions using Bivariate Regression: What is the nature of the relation between x and y? Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Interval for b. What is the effect size? How is the y variance partitioned between explained and unexplained? Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for bivariate linear regression? The error produced by Model C is the most error a parametric model can have. Thus, we often call this model as the simplest or null model.
We call the sum of squared errors generated by Model C the Sum of Squares Total (SST). We call the sum of squared errors by Model A SSEA. SST is almost always greater than SSEA. SST = SSEA + SSR Y-Hat = b0 + b1X Y-Hat: Predicted value of Y b0: Intercept, the value of Y when X = 0. b1: Slope, the change in Y relative to the change in X. We actually never know the true population value of parameter Œ≤; we only estimate with our data. Yi = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1Xi + ùúÄi We will calculate b1 first. Determine b0 and using b1. Conceptual Formula
Computational Formula



To estimate the error generated by this augmented model (SSEA) we need to Predict a score on Y for each subject. Find the difference between each subject's predicted and actual scores on Y. Square the differences. Add them up. Y = 10.268 - .776x + ùúÄ
It is difficult to judge is an error reduction of 64.383 is a lot or a little. To help us get a sense of how much error we reduced, we express this reduction in error as a percentage of the total error (SST). The regression model explained .805 (80.5%, effect size) of the original SST in variable Y.

For the simple mean-only model, ùõΩ0, was a constant equal to the mean of Y. Since the mean of Y was 6, ùõΩ0 = 6. The intercept, ùõΩ0, is the predicted value of Y when X is zero. Thus, if X has no meaningful value of 0, the estimated intercept is not informative. Centering the predictor of X to its mean can generate a better estimate because then the estimated ùõΩ0 is now the predictor value of Y when the predictor X is its mean. Think about the 1st year college CPA as the outcome (Y) predicted by the SAT score (X).

Y = 10.268 - .776 X + ùúÄ Y = 6 - .776 X' + ùúÄ This new regression equation shows the exact same relationship between Y and X' as we found for Y and X. If you calculate the error of this regression model, you will get the exact same SSEA Allows us to answer the following: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? What is the nature of the relation between x and y.
Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Intervals (CI) for b?
What is the Effect Size ?
How is the y Variance partitioned between explained and unexplained?
Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for Bivariate Regression? Compact Model Total Error SST (total possible error = SSEC) Augmented Model Error in Model A SSEA (error of augmented model) SST - SSEa = Explained Error SSR = Compact Model - Augmented Model OR SSR = SSEC - SSEA
Effect Size R2 = (SSEC - SSEA) √∑ SSEC Football lovers will be more confident in their GLM statistics abilities. Hypothesis: Students who report higher levels of love for football will more likely report higher levels of GLM efficacy. X: Football Y: Quant_Eff Yi (Quant_Eff) = ùõΩ0 (Intercept) + ùõΩ1 (Slope) Xi (Football) + ùúÄi (Residual) Hypothesis: Students' perceptions of their teachers' enthusiasm will positively predict students' engagement. Y: Student Engagement X: Teacher Enthusiasm Yi (Engagement) = ùõΩ0 (Intercept) + ùõΩ1 (Slope) Xi (Enthusiasm) + ùúÄi (Residual)
Assumption of Normality of Error (Testing for Normality)
Assumption of Homoscedasticity (Testing Homoscedasticity)
Assumption of Independence of Error (Testing the Independence of Error)
Assumption of No Extreme Outliers (Testing for Extreme Outliers)
Assumption of Linearity (Testing Linearity)
Note: The assumption for any statistical analysis is about the Outcome, not the Predictor . Point and click to ask SPSS to give you pop-up window for regression. (Analyze > Regression > Linear)
Move Dependent Variable to Dependent. Move Independent Variable (s) to the Independent(s). In Statistics, select Estimates (Under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (Under Residuals). Click Continue. In Plots, select Histogram and Normal Probability Plot (Under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. In Save, select Cook's (Under Distances). Click Continue. Click OK.

item.title: 2. Predicting Scores (Mean and Error of Prediction)
item.description:
Understand what the data, model, and error are in GLM framework. Understand how to quantify the ERROR: Learn how to compute the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE)
How to compute the variance and standard deviation (Standard Deviation (SD)) Use Excel to compute the SSE Hypothesis testing for a simple t-test
Data: Values derived from scientific experiments Data can refer to countless variables, scores, and sources of information To understand a phenomenon, a behavioral scientist must first operationally define it as a measurable variable. Common descriptive statistics are the mean and standard deviation. Prediction is one way to demonstrate understanding of something. A model that predicts a phenomenon well implies that we understand that phenomenon. An initial model that predicts the mean for every subject serves as the foundation on which subsequent models are based. Y = ùõΩ0 + ùúÄ (Simplest model that we use) The single predictive component of the model () is designated as ùõΩ0. Comparing the actual scores (Y) and the predicted scores reveals how much error exists in this simple model. Rarely would all of the scores on the dependent variable equal the mean. We study the error in our model in hopes that we can reduce the error to improve our model. To reduce the error, we must be able to measure error.
Conceptual Formula SSE = ‚àë (Yi - Y-Hati)2 It captures the concept of error by squaring and summing the differences between predicted and actual scores. It is a bit clumsy, especially when the mean is not an integer.
Computational Formula SSE = ‚àëY2 - (‚àëY)2 / N) This is more convenient to compute SSE compared to the conceptual formula. Variance (S2) and standard deviation (S) describe the variation of scores around a mean. Variance is SSE divided by the number of scores minus 1: SSE / (N - 1) Variance = Sy2 = (‚àëY2 - (‚àëY)2 / N)) / (N - 1) Since we squared the variable's scores to make them positive, we take the square root of the variance to return to the variable's score to return to the variable's origina; scale. The square root of the variance is called the standard deviation (S) We want to know whether the mean is statistically significantly different from 0. We use the one-sample t-test to examine whether Œº = 0 Hypothesis testing is a decision-making process where two-possible decisions are considered. H0 (Null or Statistical Hypothesis) H1 (Alternative or Research Hypothesis) Definition
A method for testing a hypothesis about a Parameter or Population, using data measured in a sample. Purpose
To test claims or ideas about a group or Population. Goal
To determine the likelihood that a Population Parameter, such as the Mean, is likely to be true. Four Steps of hypothesis testing State the null and alternative hypothesis
Null Hypothesis (H0) Statement about the population parameter that is assumed to be true. Center orange line. H0 = 3 Alternative Hypothesis (H1) Statement that contradicts the null hypothesis. Circled tails. H1 ‚â† 3 Set the criteria for a decision State the level of significance Criterion of judgement upon which a decision is made regarding the value stated in a null hypothesis. Typically the level is set at 5% in behavioral research studies. Compute the test statistic Test statistic Z-score How far a sample outcome is from the value stated in a null hypothesis z = (x - M) / SD zobt = (M - Œº) / œÉM The z-score can be used to make a decision regarding the null hypothesis. The larger the value, the further a sample mean deviates from the population mean. T-score tobt = (M - Œº) / œÉM Make a decision Based on the probability of obtaining a sample mean, given that the value stated in the null is true (represented by p-value). Reject H0 The sample mean is associated with a low probability of occurrence. Retain (fail to reject) H0 The sample mean is associated with a high probability of occurrence. Statistical significance If z-statistic falls within 2 SE of M, sample mean is 'normal' (p > 0.05) If z-statistic falls outside 2 SE of M, sample mean is 'extreme' (p < 0.05)
You need 3 pieces of information to use the t-table Sample size Œ±-level One-tailed or two-tailed? Reading a t-table is different from reading a z-table. You calculate t-value from your data and find the critical t-value from the table. If the calculated t is greater than the critical t, you reject the H0.
Data The phenomenon being studied must be defined as a measurable variable.
Model The part that predicts the phenomenon.
Error Shows how different the prediction is from the true value. Y = ùõΩ0 + ùúÄ Other terms such as 'the simple model' or the 'null model' We add predictors (or independent variables) to improve the accuracy of the model - by reducing the error. When we reduce the error, our model improves. We started calculating error using the computational formula last week.
We use the error (by calculating SSE or Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) to calculate the Variance and Standard Deviation (SD).
State the null and alternative hypotheses On average, students who took intro statistics report that they are somewhat confident in their statistic abilities. H0: M = 5 Students in the GLM class will report that they are less than somewhat confident in their statistics abilities. H1 M < 5
Set the criteria for a decision ‚ç∫ = .05 (95% CI) Compute the test statistic
Make a decision
t-critical value (look up with Degrees of Freedom and T-Table for one-tailed test) 1.697 | -3.857 | > 1.697 Decision Fail to reject the null hypothesis Specifying the direction (positive/negative, greater/lesser, etc.) during hypothesis testing Non-Directional
Example Is there a mean difference in motivation scores between students in a persistence-based curriculum as compared to the control curriculum? H0: ¬µpersistence motivation = ¬µcontrol motivation H1: ¬µ persistence motivation ‚â† ¬µcontrol motivation Directional:
Example Do students in a persistence-based curriculum report higher mean motivation scores than those in a control curriculum? H0: ¬µpersistence motivation = ¬µcontrol motivation H1: ¬µ persistence motivation > ¬µcontrol motivation 'Fail to reject the null' vs. 'Confirm [accept/support] the null' 'Fail to reject the null' Cons Double-negative, an editor at the communications will tell you that this is badly written, but there is a technical difference which matters. We are not determining whether we accept/confirm/support, but we are determining whether we reject the null. Pros Statistically accurate. Tip: Avoid using terms like 'confirm' (alternative: results provide support for the alternative hypothesis) Null Findings Pros Important for being good stewards of numbers to make inferences about people. Cons Bad for your academic career What is 'Significant'? Beware of terms like 'approaching significance' .05 - this is a kind of arbitrary number Don't remember the syntax? Start with the point & click method and use the paste button. Save templates/examples to reference in the future. For specific projects, use annotations to: Keep track of data management procedures Check your work for mistakes Revisit analysis (what did I do again?), replicate analysis, or revise analysis (oh, I forgot to do this...)

item.title: McMillin Observatory
item.description:
In 1896 on a hill overlooking what would become Mirror Lake, Ohio State's first astronomical observatory was build. It was named the McMillin Observatory after the New York banker who funded the project. He also provided the funds to beautify the area around the observatory, including Mirror Lake. At the time, the university had been considering laying a road through Mirror Lake, which was nothing more than a collection of interconnected bogs fed by an underground stream. \

(McMillin Observatory, 1897)

item.title: Standard Deviation (SD)
item.description:
A measure of the spread in a distribution derived from the sum of squared deviations from the mean of the distribution divided by the number of cases in the distribution. Since variance is a squared value, it is difficult to interpret. The standard deviation (SD) is the square root of the variance, and it is the most common measure of dispersion. For population: ùúé = square root of ùúé2 For sample: ùúé = square root of ùúé2 Measured on the same scale as original data. Interpretation: On average, the deviations from the mean, but on average the distance from the mean is about 2.92. The 68-95-99.7 rule (more next time): About 68% of data points fall within +/- 1 standard deviation from the mean. About 95% of data points fall within +/- 2 standard deviations from the mean. About 99.7% of data points fall within +/- 3 standard deviations from the mean. Excel Formula
Calculate the Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell) Calculate the Deviation = Data cell - Mean cell Square the Deviation =E 2^2
Calculate the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) (Square Deviations) =SUM (First cell, Last cell) Input the Degrees of Freedom DF = n - 1 Calculate the Variance =SS / DF Calculate the Standard Deviation ‚àö(Variance) =SQRT (Cell) Calculate the Standard Error = Standard Deviation / ‚àö(n) =F 21 / (SQRT (15))
Standard Error

Sampling

item.title: 8. Multiple Regression (Model Comparison Approach)
item.description:
Going to have question about Dont forget to mention holding X For every 1 unit increase in X1 , when holding X2 constant. The first coding scheme that we will use is contrast coding. Using contrast codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnoses is coded -1 The advantage of using the contrast codes is when the groups have equal N, the numerical values assigned to each group will sum to zero. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The estimated intercept coefficient (ùõΩ0) is the grand mean of outcome, Depression symptom score We will use the previous example with depression score as an outcome and the diagnosis variable as a predictor. Depression = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1Diagnosis + ùúÄ Using Contrast Codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnosis coded -1. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The sum of the new Diagnosis variable is 0. The intercept coefficient represents the mean of outcome (Dependent, y) (Depression) when the predictor (Independent, x) (Diagnosis) is 0, meaning that it is the mean for all subjects (grand mean). Predictor and Outcome The slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and the assigned group.
Regression model: Depression = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1Diagnosis + ùúÄ 13 (grand mean) + 6.5 (Difference between the grand mean and each group) x Diagnosis + ùúÄ Using Dummy Codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded 0 and another group is coded 1. Depressed are coded 1 and No. Diagnosis coded 0. The advantage of using the dummy codes is that it is very simple; only 0 and 1 are used. You choose a reference group to compare with other groups. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the mean for the 0 group (No Diagnosis) and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the reference group (coded as 0) and the comparison group (Depressed). Depressed are coded 1 and No Diagnosis coded 0. The intercept coefficient represents the mean of outcome (Depression) when the predict 2r (Diagnosis) is 0, meaning that it is the mean for No Diagnosis group. The slope coefficient represents the difference between the reference group (coded as 0) and the comparison group (coded as 1).

Regression Model: Depression = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1Diagnosis + ùúÄ 6.5 (mean for the 0 group) + 13 (difference between the reference group [coded as 0] and the comparison group [depressed]) x Diagnosis + ùúÄ We will expand our statistical models by adding more predictors to explain the outcome variable. From the previous augmented model (Model A) with a single predictor X, we will now have two predictors (X1 and X2) in Model A. This model comparison tests whether a model with two predictors (X1 and X2) is better than a model that just predicts the mean for every person. H0: ùõΩ1 = ùõΩ2 = 0 If the null hypothesis is not rejected, neither X1 nor X2 are related to Y. The multiple regression model is called the 'omnibus model' given that both regression coefficients of ùõΩ1 and ùõΩ2 are simultaneously estimated and tested. We will use the same example data for Y and X1 from the bivariate regression to analyze the multiple regression model with the new variable X2. State the compact Model C and an augmented Model A. Identify the null hypothesis (H0). Count the number of parameters estimated by each model. Calculate the regression equation. Compute the total sum of squares (SSEC). Compute the sum of squares for Model A (SSEA). Compute sum of squares reduced (SSR). Compute the proportional reduction in error (PRE or R2). Complete the summary table. Decide about H0. We use the data to estimate the regression equation for the omnibus Model A (Step 4). With bivariate regression, we easily calculated the regression coefficients (b0 and b1) by hand. We are not so lucky with multiple regression - or maybe we are very lucky, depending on your perspective. Although we could not compute the equation by hand, the formula consumes pages and would probably take an entire semester to calculate by hand (although admittedly I have only seen this equation once, during graduate school, and I have never tried to calculate a multiple regression by hand). I
