item.title: 10. SLR Continued
item.description: Regression Goal: Use IV (x) to explain the variability (variance) in DV (y) Partition Variance: SSTO = SSR + SSE Model Summary (Variance Explained): R2 = SSR √∑ SSTO In SLR: R2 = rxy2 ANOVA table (omnibus test): Is it worth using the regression model to explain y? Fobs = MSR √∑ MSE = (SSR √∑ 1) √∑ (SSE √∑ (n-2)) (the df here are for SLR only) Reject H0 if p < ùõº (usually .05), indicating significant model. Report omnibus test statistics: F (1, n-2), p-value (df for SLR only) Optional regression coefficient estimates (b0 and b1) were found by the ordinary least squares (OLS) estimate. For SLR: Intercept (Constance): b0 = y-bar - b1(x-bar) Regression line goes through both x and y means. Slope: b1 = rxy (sy√∑sx) Related to the Pearson correlation between x and y Same scale as y per x change y-hat = b0 + b1xi Describing the regression line y-hat is the fitted (i.e., expected/predicted) value (the line) y-hat = b0 + b1xi + ei Describing data points ei (ùúÄi for population) is the deviation between the data point and the fitted line (i.e., error, residual) for subject i Regression coefficients are available from the last table in SPSS output. Estimated by b0 = y-bar - b1(x-bar) Standard Error se(b0) = ‚àöMSE (‚àö (1 √∑ n) + ‚àë( - ) It is usually not meaningful to interpret (mean of the responses when x is 0), because 0 is often beyond the original observation range (extrapolation) or 0 is an impossible value. Hypotheses that test if ùõΩ0 is significantly different from 0: : ùõΩ0 = 0 : ùõΩ0 ‚â† 0 Reject if tobs = (b0) √∑ se (b0) > Critical t(n-2) (or < for negative values) or p < ùõº Regression through the origin (b0 fixed to 0)? Only when your theory strongly suggests it. Estimated by b1 = rxy (sy / sx) Standard error se(b1) = ‚àö(MSE) / ‚àö‚àë(xi - x-bar)2 Hypotheses: Is IV a good predictor? Reject H0 if tobs = b1 / se (b1) > Critcal t(n - 2) (or < for negative values) or p < ùõº In SLR, this t-test result should agree with the omnibus test. = 1.201 + 0.012 () What is the expected rating for a movie that is 90 minutes? = 1.201 + 0.012 (90) = 2.281 What is the expected rating for a. movie that is 91 minutes? = 1.201 + 0.012 (91) = 2.293 The difference in 2.293 - 2.281 = 0.012 (), which is the definition of the slope! If the change is too small to be meaningful, you can also interpret with a bigger change: For each 10-minute increase in running time, the movie rating is expected to increase by 0.12. = ‚âà 13.525

item.title: General Linear Model (GLM)
item.description: The GLM is a basic framework underlying many statistical analyses. It is often expressed in a regression-type formula in which the expected value of a random dependent variable is given as a function of independent variables. The general linear model (GLM) is a way to simplify and combine multiple linear regression models into a single, unified format. It is not a different type of model but a more efficient way to represent them. General form: Y = XB + U Data = Model + Error The key word is 'general.' The GLM can be used to make predictions from various models. Depending on the outcome variable, logistic regression, ordinal regression, or count models (Poisson) may be used - these are also forms of the GLM. Another term: Generalized Linear Models (GLIM) The GLM is actually a special case of (GLIM)! Multivariate Model
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/GLM 1/Key Terms and Concepts/General Linear Model (GLM).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: GLM 1 Midterm Study Guide
item.description:
Descriptive Statistics The summary of information in a collection of data.
Inferential Statistics Provides predictions about a population on the basis of a sample.
Population The total set of units of interest.
Sample A subset of the population of interest.
Parameter A number that summarizes (tells us something about) a population.
Statistic A number that summarizes (tells us something about) a sample.
Random Sampling The idea that each member of a population has an equal chance of being selected to be part of a sample. This is a very crucial idea in statistics.
Measuring the error of the model:
The basic measure of a model's error is the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) where you square each individual's error and then add up all the squared errors.
Model Comparison Make incremental changes than see if the more complex model predicts Y sufficiently better, and if it does then we conclude that adding that increased complexity (adding the new predictor X) benefited the model.
General Linear Model (GLM) A compact way of writing several multiple linear regression models in one linear model. Used when the data is normally distributed Examples: T-test Regression ANOVA Data = Model + Error Y = Œ≤0 +

Data (Y) the dependent variable or outcome variable. Specifically, values derived from scientific experiments.
Model (Œ≤ values) based on this model we can expect or anticipate the data. A model that predicts well implies we understand the phenomena. Examines the relationship between a single independent ('cause') variable and a dependent (outcome) variable. Multiple Correlation (R) In bivariate regression, same as standardized coefficient. Coefficient of Determination (R2) The amount of variance between variables. R2 = (SST - SSE) / SST Residual sum of squared errors (or Sum of Squared Errors, SSE) ‚àë (y - y-hat)2 Total Sum of Squares (SST) ‚àë (y - y-hat)2 F-value (and associated p-value) tells whether model is statistically significant. It is unlikely to get an F-value this large by chance. Pearson's r Measures the strength and direction of association between two quantitative variables. Matrices are symmetric on the diagonal. Correlation coefficient (r) Tells us how strong the relationship is and in what direction. Range is -1 to 1, with absolute values closer to 1 indicating stronger relationships. r = () State the compact Model C and an augmented Model A. Identify the null hypothesis (H0). Count the number of parameters estimated by each model. Calculate the regression equation. Compute the total sum of squares (SSEC). Compute the sum of squares for Model A (SSEA). Compute sum of squares reduced (SSR). Compute the proportional reduction in error (PRE or R2). Complete the summary table. Decide about H0. State the augmented and compact models. DV: GGPA, Graduate GPA IV: GREQ_time 2, GRE Quant post-test Compact mode Regression sum of squares (SSR) Error of Sum of Squares (SSE) Total Sum of Squares (SSTO) SSTO = SSR + SSR SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table y-hat = b0 + b1xi Describing the regression line y-hat is the fitted (i.e., expected/predicted) value (the line) y-hat = b0 + b1xi + ei Describing data points ei (ùúÄi for population) is the deviation between the data point and the fitted line (i.e., error, residual) for subject i Regression coefficients are available from the last table in SPSS output. Regression Goal: Use IV (x) to explain the variability (variance) in DV (y) Partition Variance: SSTO = SSR + SSE Model Summary (Variance Explained): R2 = SSR √∑ SSTO In SLR: R2 = rxy2 ANOVA table (omnibus test): Is it worth using the regression model to explain y? Fobs = MSR √∑ MSE = (SSR √∑ 1) √∑ (SSE √∑ (n-2)) (the df here are for SLR only) Reject H0 if p < ùõº (usually .05), indicating significant model. Report omnibus test statistics: F (1, n-2), p-value (df for SLR only) R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) √∑ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE √∑ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) √∑ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE √∑ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive) In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy | Nondirectional: Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly different from group 2 (¬µ2) H0: ¬µ2 = ¬µ1 vs. H1: ¬µ2 ‚â† ¬µ1 Alternatively, H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 = 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â† 0 For experiment and control, usually group 1 is the experiment group. Directional: Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly greater than group 2 (¬µ2): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â§ 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 > 0 Test if group 1 (¬µ1) is significantly smaller than group 2 (¬µ2): H0: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 ‚â• 0 vs. H1: ¬µ2 - ¬µ1 < 0

item.title: Contrast Coding
item.description: The first coding scheme that we will use is contrast coding. Using contrast codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnoses is coded -1 The advantage of using the contrast codes is when the groups have equal N, the numerical values assigned to each group will sum to zero. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The estimated intercept coefficient (ùõΩ0) is the grand mean of outcome, Depression symptom score We will use the previous example with depression score as an outcome and the diagnosis variable as a predictor. Depression = ùõΩ0 + ùõΩ1Diagnosis + ùúÄ Using Contrast Codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnosis coded -1. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The sum of the new Diagnosis variable is 0. The intercept coefficient represents the mean of outcome (Depression) when the predictor (Diagnosis) is 0, meaning that it is the mean for all subjects (grand mean). The slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and the assigned group.

item.title: ANOVA APA Write-Up Example
item.description: A one-way ANOVA was used to assess the effect of a mindfulness intervention on students‚Äô anxiety. It was predicted that students‚Äô anxiety scores would differ based on whether students were in the mindfulness intervention group (mindfulness) or the business as usual group (BAU). We first checked the normality of our data by calculating the skewness and kurtosis, visually examining histograms, and running Shapiro-Wilk‚Äôs test. The assumption of normality was upheld for both groups. The Shapiro-Wilk‚Äôs test was non-significant for both the mindfulness group, W(18) = .93, p = .17, and BAU group, W(18) = .94, p = .27. The skewness and kurtosis values were within acceptable rant for the mindfulness group (skewness = -0.10, kurtosis = -1.45) and the BAU group (skewness = 0.03, kurtosis = -1.34). Additionally, the assumption of homogeneity of variance was upheld by a non-significant Levene‚Äôs test (F(1, 34) = .61, p = .44), indicating that equal variances are assumed. The one-way ANOVA reached significance, F(1, 34) = 54.82, p < .001, Œ∑2 = .62. Given the significantly observed difference and effect size, our results support the conclusion that students‚Äô anxiety score varied significantly based on their group.
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/GLM 1/Examples/ANOVA APA Write-Up Example.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: GLM Quizzes
item.description: The criterion or level of significance in behavioral research is typically set at what probability value? 0.05 or 5% The likelihood that we reject the null hypothesis decreases the closer the value of a sample mean is to the value stated by the null hypothesis. In hypothesis testing, a researcher's decision is based on a probability, depends on the level of significance for a hypothesis test, and can be to retain or reject the null hypothesis. Hypothesis testing is also called significance testing. The criteria for a decision regarding the value stated in a null hypothesis is set by the level of significance. In hypothesis testing, a researcher can never prove that their hypothesis is correct. In Step 2 of hypothesis testing, researchers state a level of significance to minimize the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis. The power of the decision-making process is the likelihood of rejecting a false null hypothesis. Effect Size allows researchers to describe a.) how far mean scores have shifted in the population or b.) the percentage of variance that can be explained by a given variable. A researcher reports that the size of an effect in some population is d = .88. What is an appropriate interpretation? Mean scores shifted .88 standard deviations in the population Increasing sample size will increase the power of the decision. The t-distribution is similar to the z-distribution except it is associated with greater variability, 'thicker' tails compared with the z-distribution, and is associated with scores being more likely in the tails of the distribution. Key difference between t-statistic and z-statistic is the standard error is estimated to compute a t-statistic. Assumption for computing any type of independent sample t-test Data in the population being sampled are normally distributed (Assumption of ) Data were obtained from a sample that was selected using a random sampling procedure The probabilities of each measured outcome in a study are independent As a requirement for the t-test, researchers compute any type of t-test with samples selected from populations in which the population variance is unknown. To compute a sample t-test, a researcher must known the estimated standard error, sample size, sample mean, and sample variance. Matched Samples Design is a research design in which two or more groups of individuals are identical, or matching, in terms of the third variable. Repeated Measures Design is an experiment using a within-group design in which participants respond to a dependent variable more than once, after exposure to each level of the independent variable. What is the denominator of the test statistic for the related samples t-test? Estimated standard error for difference scores All other things being equal, as the degrees of freedom increase, what happens to the critical value for a related-samples t-test? The critical value decreases
item.guid: University Resources/Statistics Classes/GLM 1/Midterm 1/GLM Quizzes.md

item.title: Model
item.description: Prediction is one way to demonstrate understanding of something. A model that predicts a phenomenon well implies that we understand that phenomenon. An initial model that predicts the mean for every subject serves as the foundation on which subsequent models are based. Y = ùõΩ0 + ùúÄ (Simplest model that we use) The single predictive component of the model () is designated as ùõΩ0. Comparing the actual scores (Y) and the predicted scores reveals how much error exists in this simple model. Rarely would all of the scores on the dependent variable equal the mean. We study the error in our model in hopes that we can reduce the error to improve our model. To reduce the error, we must be able to measure error.

item.title: Variance
item.description: If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. The 'average' squared deviation from the mean for a set of scores. Variance is a better measure of dispersion than range and IQR, because it takes into account all the values for a set of scores (but might be affected by extreme values). Conceptually, the variance is a measure of the area of the distribution (i.e., the more spread out the scores, the more area or space the distribution takes up). The sample mean might not be the same as the population mean (usually unknown), and the deviations would be affected. Therefore, sample variance obtained would be systematically too small. In order to get an unbiased sample estimate of the population variance, a slight change in the computational formula was made. AKA Degree of Freedom (df) When we calculate a simple statistic based in part on another statistic, we have to consider the 'degrees of freedom' in our calculation. Given the sample mean, we do not need raw data from all n observations. We only need (n-1) observations, because the last missing score can be found from the mean (i.e., there is no 'freedom' in what this score might be). The denominator (n-1) in sample variance is called the degrees of freedom (df), which is related to sample size.

item.title: 9. Correlations and SLR (Part I)
item.description:
In a sense, regression is taking correlation a step further. Correlation captures the strength and direction of a linear relationship. Regression goes beyond looking at just the linear relationship. We are interested in predicting one variance with another. y: Dependent/Outcome Variance (we would like to predict) x: Independent/Predictor Variable(s) We are predicting y from x y-hat = b0 + b1X y-hat: Outcome Variable (DV) x: Predictor Variable (IV) b1: Slope (Regression coefficient) r ((sx)/(sy)) b0: y-intercept Y-bar - b1 (x-bar) John had 80 men complete a self-concept inventory that contains five scales. Four scales involve questions about how competent respondents feel in the areas of intimate relationships, relationships with friends, commonsense reasoning and everyday knowledge, and academic reasoning and scholarly knowledge. The fifth scale includes items about how competent a person feels in general. For this example, John is interested in conducting a regression analysis with the scale how competent respondents feel in relationship with friends as the predictor and the scale how competent they feel in general as the dependent variable. Descriptive Statistics Friends: Skewness ratio: -. 552 Kurtosis Ratio: .021 Both skewness ratio and kurtosis ratio statistics are within +/- 2 range. Therefore, the distribution of friends would be considered normal. General: Skewness ratio: .004 Kurtosis Ratio: -. 721 Both skewness ratio and kurtosis ratio statistics are within +/- 2 range. Therefore, the distribution of general would be considered normal. Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate -> drag VOIs into 'Variables' box Under 'Correlation Coefficients' select which type of correlation you want (Pearson) Under 'Test of Significance' select which type of test you want, based on your hypothesis Spearman's rank order correlation coefficient Measures the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables Example: Math and science scores of students Phi Coefficient Between two dichotomous variables Gender (male, female) Coin Flip (heads, tails) Cramer's V When variables have more than two categories Political affiliation Race Create the correlation table in SPSS and double click the table. Using the Pivot -> Pivoting Trays menu, remove 'Statistics' from the 'Row' box and place it in the 'Layer' bod in the top left of this pop-out menu (the process we went over in class) Click Format ->TableLooks -> select 'APA_TimesRoma_12 pt' Copy and paste this 'cleaned' correlation table into Excel/Word. When pasting, use the 'Match Destination Format' option Center align the correlation coefficients and the column headers (the row headers remain left-aligned) Delete the correlation coefficients above the diagonal Number the variables along the left side of the correlation table Replace the column header variable names with the corresponding numbers you just made. Replace the '1 s' that make up the diagonal with '-' Place borders: Below the last row Above and below the column headers Make sure the font is Times New Roman and the font size is 12. Correlation coefficients were computed among five self-concept scales. The results of the correlation analysis are presented in Table 1. The correlations of academic self-concept with other self-concept measures tend to be lower. The strongest correlation was between friends self-concept and intimate self-concept (r = .552). In research papers, correlations are typically discussed along with descriptive statistics, sometimes being reported within the same table. They are used to describe how the variables in your data relate to one another. Typically, correlations are just presented in a table, after (or with) the descriptive statistics. Having the legend of ** is common. Typically remove 'top diagonal' because the information is redundant Sometimes the top and bottom diagonal will represent two groups (i.e., males and females)
Analyze -> Regression -> Linear -> drag outcome variable into the 'dependent' box -> drag the predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive
The constant (b0) = 32.930 The slope (regression coefficient) = .386 The estimated model: Y-hat = b0 + b1X General-hat = 32.93 + 0.386 Friends Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Simple Scatterplot' into the preview box -> drag predictor to the x-axis and outcome to the y-axis To add the regression line, double-click the scatterplot, click the Add Fit Line at Total button

item.title: 7. Paired Sample t-test
item.description: Used when we are comparing the same group of people in our sample at two different time points. Example: Before and after a treatment State the H0 and H1 Define alpha level Compute t statistic Interpret the output Make decision Write conclusion Fred wishes to determine whether children in regular education are hurt or helped academically by the inclusion of special education students in their classes. He has gained the cooperation of the seventh-grade teachers in two similar junior high schools to participate in his study. One school recently integrated special education students into their regular classroom, while the other one has not. The teachers in both school supply Fred the students‚Äô raw scores on a standardized achievement test at the beginning of the year and at the end of the year. SPSS file contains 40 cases and 3 variables: Integ (1: regular education students who are not in integrated classroom; 2. Regular education students who are in the integrated classroom) Pretest (achievement test score of regular education students at the beginning of the year) Posttest (achievement test score of regular education students at the end of the year) Research Questions: Are there any significant differences between the pre-test and post-test achievement scores? State the H0 and H1 H0: ùúápretest = ùúáposttest H1: ùúápretest ‚â† ùúáposttest Define alpha level ùõº = .05 Compute t statistic Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test -> drag 'pre-test' VOI into the 'Variable 1' box and the 'post-test' VOI into the 'Variable 2' box. Interpret the output Cohen's effect size conventions for mean difference: Small Effect Size: .20 Medium Effect Size: .50 Large Effect Size: .80 Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test t = d / (s / ‚àön) = -6.575 / 2.257 = -2.91316 df = n - 1 = 39 Effect Size: d = x-bar / s or d = t / ‚àön = -2.913 / ‚àö40 = -. 4609 Make decision Reject the null hypothesis because our obtained significance value was less than our predetermined alpha level (p = .006). Write conclusion A paired samples t-test was conducted to determine if there was a difference in the mean pretest and posttest achievement scores of regular education students. The test results indicated that, on average, the pretest achievement scores (M = 96.45, SD = 14.83) and posttest achievement scores (M = 103.03, SD = 18.53) were statistically different from each other (t(39) = -2.913, p = .006, d = -. 461). The null hypothesis that the pretest and posttest means were the same was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -. 461. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as moderately small effect.

item.title: 6. One Sample t-Test and Power of a Test
item.description: (https://www.psychologie.hhu.de/arbeitsgruppen/allgemeine-psychologie-und-arbeitspsychologie/gpower) A one sample t-test evaluates whether the mean on a test variable is significantly different from a constant. Assumptions: The test variable is normally distributed in the population. The cases represent a random sample from the population. Scores on the test variables are independent of each other. State the H0 and H0 Define ‚ç∫ level Compute t statistic Look up critical value in t-table/interpret output Make decision Reject or fail to reject the H0. Write conclusion Janet is interested in determining if depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports are significantly different from the average male adolescent. To test this hypothesis, she obtains Kansas University Depression Inventory (KUDI) scores from 30 adolescent boys who have indicated on a questionnaire that they do not engage in sports outside of school gym classes. Past research has shown that the mean depression score for male adolescents in the population in the population is 50. Janet wants to determine if the mean KUDI score for the 30 adolescents is different from the value of 50. State the H0 and H1 H0: ùúá = 50 H1: ùúá ‚â† 50 Define ùõº level ùõº = .05 Compute t-statistic Look up critical value in t-table and interpret output Make decision Reject or fail to reject the H0 Write conclusion Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Sample t-test -> drag VOI into 'Test Variable(s)' box -> Enter the known population mean into the 'Test Value' box Click 'Estimate Effect Sizes' Click Options -> Enter Confidence Interval One Sample Statistics:One-Sample Test: tobs = 2.457 df = n - 1 = 30 - 1 = 29 tcrit = 2.045 Standard Error of the mean is: sy-bar = (sy) / ‚àön 10.327 / ‚àö30 = 10.327 / 5.477 = 1.8855 95% of the time, the true population mean difference will fall between .78 and 8.49 95% of the time, the true population mean will fall between 50.78 and 58.49. t is the t-test statistic value t = 4.633 / 1.886 = 2.4565 The result of the t-test is significant (t = 2.457, df = 29, p = .020) at the ùõº = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0. Take a look at the actual difference between the sample mean and the population mean: tobs = 2.457 vs. tcrit = 2.045 Are you comfortable calling that difference significant? Alternative (or Supplement) to significance value: Cohen's d Cohen's d is an effect size measure used to indicate the difference between two means. For one-sample t-test, d indicates how many standard deviations the sample mean is away from the hypothesized mean. If d = 1.0, the sample mean is one standard deviation away from the hypothesized mean. d = (x-bar - ùúá0) / s d = t / ‚àön Effect size measures strength of relationship: One-Sample Effect Sizes d = 2.457 / ‚àö30 = .4486 d = 4.633 / 10.327 = .4486 A lot of times before conducting your study you need to submit a power analysis. This lets you know what sample size you need to find an effect. Power is the probability that a test of significance will detect deviation from the null hypothesis if one truly exists. A Priori Power Determine how many cases you will need to have a good chance of detecting an effect of a specified size with the desired amount of power. Imagine you are designing a new study to see if depression scores are higher in a new group of students. Using alpha = .01, what sample size would you suggest to detect a 1/2 standard deviation difference from the population mean, with 90% power? In this example, we have one-tailed test. Effect size is 0.5, alpha level is 0.01 and the desired power is 0.90. Based on these criteria, the required sample size for our one-sample t-test is 55. A Post Hoc Power Determine how much power you would have if you had a specified number of cases. In SPSS example (Kudi), we have a two-tailed test. The observed effect size was 0.449. The alpha level we tested was 0.05, and the actual sample size was 30. Based on these criteria, the power hoc power is 0.662 A one sample t-test was conducted on the KUDI scores to evaluate whether their mean was significantly different from 50, the mean for male adolescent in general. The sample mean of 54.63 (SD = 10.33) was significantly different from 50, (t (29) = 2.46, p = .02). The 95% confidence interval for the KUDI mean ranged from 50.78 to 58.49. The effect size d of .45 indicates a medium effect (Cohen, 1988). The post hoc power of the test, given the sample size, two-tailed, alpha level, and observed effect size, was .662 (M = 54.63, SD = 10.33). Note for future reference: When SPSS reports a p-value of .000, we indicate it in the results section as 'p-value < .001.'

item.title: 5. Hypothesis Testing
item.description:
State the H0 and H1. Define alpha level. Determine the critical values and the rejection regions. Calculate observes test statistics. Make decision. Reject or fail to reject the H0. Write conclusion. Specifying the direction (positive/negative, greater/lesser, etc.) during hypothesis testing. Non-Directional: Research Question: Are depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports significantly different from the average male adolescent? H0: ¬µ = Mean depression score for population (50) H1: ¬µ ‚â† 50 Directional: RQ: Are depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports significantly lower than the average male adolescent? H0: ¬µ = 50 H1: ¬µ < 50 Occurs when a researcher rejects H0 when it is actually true Concludes that treatment has had an effect when it really hasn't; leads to the publication of false results Alpha level: The probability that the test will lead to a Type I Error. Occurs when a researcher fails to reject H0 when it's actually false Concludes that a treatment had no effect when it really did Probability of a Type II Error depends on a number of factors and cannot be reduced to a specific number Used when we are comparing a sample to the population Need: Œº (mean) and œÉ (standard deviation) State the H0 and H1 Define the alpha (ùõº) level Compute z statistic, recall: zobs = (x-bar - ¬µ0) / (ùúé / ‚àön) Look up critical value in z table Make decision to either reject or fail to reject the H0 Write conclusion Introduction to Syntax in SPSS (Ep.8) - YouTube
One sample z test - SPSS (Part1) - YouTube
[One sample z test - SPSS (Part 2) - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qrNagh2qGz8 A school psychologist administered an intelligence test (WISC) to n = 128 children. Normed data provides the following information on the WISC for children in the US: ¬µ = 100 ùúé = 15 The psychologist obtained an average WISC score for her sample of . Is it reasonable for her to assume that the sample of children she administered the test to is drawn from the population on which the test is normed? Test using ùõº = .05. SPSS Output: z-statistic: 1.54621 p-value .12205 Cohens d .13667 A z-test was conducted to find out whether there exists a significant mean level different between the average WISC score for a sample of students and the national average. It was hypothesized that the mean WISC score of the sample of students is different from the national average. The results was not statistically significant [z (128) = 1.55, p = .12, d = 0.14], indicating that there is no difference between the sample average and the population average. This results therefore indicates that the sample data comes from the same national norms.

item.title: Control Charts
item.description: Comparison of univariate and multivariate control data Control charts are used to routinely monitor quality. Depending on the number of process characteristics to be monitored, there are two basic types of control charts. The first, referred to as a univariate control chart, is a graphical display (chart) of one quality characteristic. The second, referred to as a multivariate control chart, is a graphical display of a statistic that summarizes or represents more than one quality characteristic. Characteristics of control charts If a single quality characteristic has been measured or computed from a sample, the control chart shows the value of the quality characteristic versus the sample number or versus time. In general, the chart contains a center line that represents the mean value for the in-control process. Two other horizontal lines, called the upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL), are also shown on the chart. These control limits are chosen so that almost all of the data points will fall within these limits as long as the process remains in-control. The figure below illustrates this. Why control charts "work" The control limits as pictured in the graph might be 0.001 probability limits. If so, and if chance causes alone were present, the probability of a point falling above the upper limit would be one out of a thousand, and similarly, a point falling below the lower limit would be one out of a thousand. We would be searching for an assignable cause if a point would fall outside these limits. Where we put these limits will determine the risk of undertaking such a search when in reality there is no assignable cause for variation. Since two out of a thousand is a very small risk, the 0.001 limits may be said to give practical assurances that, if a point falls outside these limits, the variation was caused be an assignable cause. It must be noted that two out of one thousand is a purely arbitrary number. There is no reason why it could not have been set to one out a hundred or even larger. The decision would depend on the amount of risk the management of the quality control program is willing to take. In general (in the world of quality control) it is customary to use limits that approximate the 0.002 standard. Letting X denote the value of a process characteristic, if the system of chance causes generates a variation in X that follows the normal distribution, the 0.001 probability limits will be very close to the 3œÉ limits. From normal tables we glean that the 3œÉ in one direction is 0.00135, or in both directions 0.0027. For normal distributions, therefore, the 3œÉ limits are the practical equivalent of 0.001 probability limits. Plus or minus "3 sigma" limits are typical In the U.S., whether X is normally distributed or not, it is an acceptable practice to base the control limits upon a multiple of the standard deviation. Usually this multiple is 3 and thus the limits are called 3-sigma limits. This term is used whether the standard deviation is the universe or population parameter, or some estimate thereof, or simply a "standard value" for control chart purposes. It should be inferred from the context what standard deviation is involved. (Note that in the U.K., statisticians generally prefer to adhere to probability limits.) If the underlying distribution is skewed, say in the positive direction, the 3-sigma limit will fall short of the upper 0.001 limit, while the lower 3-sigma limit will fall below the 0.001 limit. This situation means that the risk of looking for assignable causes of positive variation when none exists will be greater than one out of a thousand. But the risk of searching for an assignable cause of negative variation, when none exists, will be reduced. The net result, however, will be an increase in the risk of a chance variation beyond the control limits. How much this risk will be increased will depend on the degree of skewness. If variation in quality follows a Poisson distribution, for example, for which np = 0.8, the risk of exceeding the upper limit by chance would be raised by the use of 3-sigma limits from 0.001 to 0.009 and the lower limit reduces from 0.001 to 0. For a Poisson distribution the mean and variance both equal np. Hence the upper 3-sigma limit is 0.8 + 3 sqrt(0.8) = 3.48 and the lower limit is 0 (here sqrt denotes "square root"). For np = 0.8 the probability of getting more than 3 successes is 0.009. Strategies for dealing with out-of-control findings If a data point falls outside the control limits, we assume that the process is probably out of control and that an investigation is warranted to find and eliminate the cause or causes. Does this mean that when all points fall within the limits, the process is in control? Not necessarily. If the plot looks non-random, that is, if the points exhibit some form of systematic behavior, there is still something wrong. For example, if the first 25 of 30 points fall above the center line and the last 5 fall below the center line, we would wish to know why this is so. Statistical methods to detect sequences or nonrandom patterns can be applied to the interpretation of control charts. To be sure, "in control" implies that all points are between the control limits and they form a random pattern.

item.title: 4. Normality
item.description:
When we assume normality, we assume the distribution of sample means is normal. Look for extreme departures from normality. Checking for Normal Distribution Looking for extreme departures from normality. Skewness: A measure of symmetry (lack of symmetry) Type of Skewness: Positive Skew Mode < Median < Mean Negative Skew Mode > Median > Mean Distributions with medium kurtosis (medium tails) are mesokurtic. Distributions with low kurtosis (thin tails) are platykurtic. Distributions with high kurtosis (fat tails) are leptokurtic. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore Skewness Ratio: Skewness √∑ Standard Error Kurtosis Ratio: Kurtosis √∑ Standard Error If these values are between -2 and 2, we are good. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Move the variables of interest into the variable box -> click 'Charts' -> select 'Histograms' and click 'Show normal curve on histogram' If data points fall along the straight line, the data appears to be normally distributed. If the data points considerably deviate from the line, the data appears NOT be normally distributed. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Move the Variables of Interest into the 'dependent list' box -> Plots -> Check option 'Normality plot with tests' Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Q-Q plots -> move the variables of interest into the 'variable' box. Z-Score: Distance from the mean in standard deviation units. Indicates how much a given value differs from the mean. A positive z-score indicates the raw score is higher than the mean average. For example, if a z-score is equal to +1, it is 1 standard deviation above the mean. A negative z-score reveals the raw score is below the mean average. For example, if the z-score is equal to -2, it is 2 standard deviations below the mean. It standardizes the distribution so that M = 0 and SD = 1. If data normally distributed: Sample Population
In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives -> Click save standardized values as variables -> move the variables you want z-scores for into the variable box -> check 'Save standardized values as variables' Statistical symbols are italicized M, SD, p, etc. There is a space on either side of the equality sign. M = 558.41, p < 0.001 Only use leading zeros if the value can be greater than 1. The average length was small (0.42 ft.) p < .001

item.title: Mirror Lake
item.description:
Photo Courtesy of Ohio State:
Mirror Lake Islands Party (1878):
Mirror Lake with Visitors:
Mirror Lake Grotto: Was the first contact and not a person. A 'horiculture wagon' was pushed into the lake as a Halloween prank. "With the exception of running the caissons over the campus and dumping the Horticulture wagon in the lake, the students were as quiet as could be," The Lantern read on November 6th, 1895. "To guard against trouble the street car authorities had heavy guards at the end of the Neil avenue line and on High street near the University. They were entirely unnecessary, no trouble whatever occurring."
Mirror Lake Islands: First reference of freshmen being thrown into the lake. Front-page cartoon in 1909 depicting freshmen in the middle of the lake, dubbed the 'Freshman Bathtub'
Mirror Lake Islands:
Tug-of-war between freshmen and sophomores across the lake and Bucket and Dipper members being initiated by being thrown into the lake.
Mirror Lake Photographer and Seven Kids (1911): Mirror Lake Bridge (Two Men on Bridge) (1915): Windstorm Damage (1918): Snow Scene: But 1920 is when it seems the tradition became more serious with approval from student council and the university president. The rules: Freshmen must wear a specific cap at all times and not step foot on the Long Walk, the brick path across the Oval leading up to Thompson Library. Only assigned enforcers, members of the Bucket and Dipper club, were allowed to toss freshmen into the lake. 1922, the Lantern reported members of Bucket and Dipper would even defend freshmen from being dunked in the lake by those who were not permitted to do so, i.e. non-Bucket Dipper members. "Bucket and Dipper announces that no promiscuous 'ducking' or 'dipping' is to take place under the auspices of other organizations. Any attempt to haze freshmen in this manner by other organizations will result in Bucket and Dipper's strong-arm squad defending the freshmen." The student council rejected alternatives to the dunking in Mirror Lake put forth by faculty members. 1922 was the last tug-of-war across Mirror Lake. University president said, "The University is trying to make the lake a place of as much beauty as possible." 1926: Freshmen got fed up with dunking into Mirror Lake and planned an event to burn the hats they were forced to wear. A huge fight ensued and police were called to the scene. Sophomore was hospitalized. 1929: "For all practical purposes, freshmen rules are already a thing of the past. Although several attempts have been made to revive the freshmen taboos, and particularly the cap-wearing tradition, the rules have been virtually non-existent since Bucket and Dipper was shorn of its power to enforce them." Mirror Lake Fountain (1931): 1942: Tug-of-war made another appearance for tradition week and stuck around for May week in following years. Ariel View (1947): Mirror Lake (1950s): Last known reference of tug-of-war across the lake. In 1955, references to dunking popped back up in a Lantern editorial with the following reasons given for dunking: honorary initiates, fraternity seniors, pinned or engaged couples and any other willing soul. Mirror Lake facing North East (1961): 1964: An engaged couple 'quarreled' at the lake; the man took back the engagement ring and threw it in the lake, and the woman went searching for it in a bikini. She was arrested but the executive dean finally allowed her to resume the search in different attire. 1967: Last reference of Bucket and Dipper initiating members by dunking them in Mirror Lake. Man sitting in front of tree without leaves: Fountain and Path, Bike Rider:
