item.title: Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
item.description:
InterventionsCommunication StancesIndividual Client Phases of TreatmentUniversal Session TasksSession Template Based on TheoryStatus QuoStatus QuoSatir's Growth Model Stages.pngSatir's Growth Model Stages.png New Homeostasis takes hold. @satirNewPeoplemaking1988@satirNewPeoplemaking1988Irrelevant (Distractor)Irrelevant (Distractor)Five Communication Stances.png
Virginia Satir (1916-1988)
In the late 1950 s, she joined Don Jackson, Jay Haley, and others in developing the Mental Research Institute (MRI). Satir wrote one of the first books about family therapy, Conjoint Family Therapy, in which she provided transcripts of how she worked. Every person has resources available to them, but when troubled, they do not usually utilize these resources to their utmost abilities.
Self-Mandala: The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical.
Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem.
When people experience low self-esteem, they attempt to cope by using Survival Stances. These stances help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. The four survival stances are:
Placating (Placator): Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. The placating stance discounts self and privileges the other person and the context.
Blaming (Blamer): Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal.
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Privileges the context and discounts the self and others. Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships. Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect. To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
Irrelevant (Distractor): Discounts self, other, and context. Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem. People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis.
The goal of Satir's therapy is to help people enhance their own and others' self-esteem. When we do so, we function from a Congruent (Congruence) communication stance. This is the healthiest position we can operate from. The Satir Growth Model is a strength-based approach, focusing on the existing resources that family members bring with them. Faulty coping strategies maintain problematic interactions. Therapy provides a safe space for people to choose alternative ways of coping. Therapy increases people's self-esteem, leading them to be able to lean into their uniqueness and provide a space for their loved ones to feel comfortable in their own uniqueness as well. Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence) Self-Esteem Maintenance Kit: Detective Hat: Used when there is something new that the person wants to understand better. It helped them shift away from judging an experience to exploring it. Medallion: Two-sided and says 'yes' on one side and 'no' on the other. It is intended to help the person recognize that they can say either word, depending on what they truly want, so they can maintain their integrity. Wand (Empowering wand, courage stick, wishing wand): Helps people move from inaction based on fear to action based on desire. Golden Key: Opens any door - helping the person ask questions they might not have previously, so the unsayable, and do the undoable. Wisdom Box: Helps connect the person to the wider world and all that has come before them.
Experiential therapists are interactive in the therapy room. They try to use their whole self for contact. This includes adopting an I-Thou Perspective, where they try to promote human-to-human interaction. Since one of the main goals of therapy is to help the client become more congruent, it is important for the therapist to engage the client congruently. The therapist must be a real person who helps model a way of being for the client. Experiential therapists conceptualize a few main processes: Status Quo: The family is currently in this process, and is leading to difficulties bringing them to therapy. Foreign Element: The family's expression of the desire to change. Chaos: The therapist's introduction of novelty into the system. Integration: Family members put what they learn from therapy into practice. Practice: Involves trying out these learnings. New Status Quo: - New homeostasis takes hold.
The therapist raises the intensity of interactions so that people encounter their own experiences and can thus become more authentic. Therapy then helps people to allow others to be more authentic.
Sculpting: Sculpting helps people get in touch with their inner experience and express this experience to others in a way that bypasses the typical spoken word. Sculpting can be done in one of two primary ways: The client is asked to sculpt their family based on their experience of what it is like to be part of this family now. Then the therapist can sculpt the family based on their own inner picture of the family's experience. Family members are asked to place other people in physical poses spatially located around the room and then to position themselves somewhere within. This provides the family with a new way of engaging with self and other. This allows for new meanings to come forth, where people can become more authentically themselves. The therapist will begin with one member of the family. The choice of person will depend on the family organization, the presenting problem, and the therapeutic process. Once that person has presented their image of the family, the therapist acts as a guide for each family member, bringing forth their perceptions of this picture and what it represents about the various relationships in the family. Therapist then shifts to another family member to explore their experience, as every family member unique has their own way of seeing and being in the family. Therapist may also end the sculpt by having family members sculpt their desired picture of the family. This sculpt shifts the energy in the room from a focus on past problems and dysfunction to a future functional and supportive arrangement of relationships. Satir viewed people as housing energy and as able to transfer this energy through physical connections with one another.
Family Reconstruction: Designed to help an individual connect better to the historical and psychological interconnections of their family. By seeing self and family of origin with a new perspective, the individual might then feel more freedom to engage in new possibilities for the future.
Star: The person whose relationship with the family is being explored and worked on.
The therapist prepares the reconstruction by talking with the star about their family history. This involves developing a Family Map, or the primary family that can include the grandparents, a Family Life Chronology, highlighting three generations of the star's family, including important dates and historical events (similar to the genogram), and the Wheel of Influence, a chart including all the people who influenced the star when they were growing up. The therapist ('guide') begins the family reconstruction by telling the star's story; then sculpts the family of origin, the star's parents' families of origin, and the star's parents' relationship; and then resculpts the star's family of origin. The overall goal is to increase the star's self-esteem so they are empowered to engage with themselves and others in new and more productive ways. This should engender more hope in them for their future.
Parts Party: Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources. The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts. Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes. "The Growth Model," where the focus was on helping people access their inner resources as opposed to, "The Medical Model," where the emphasis was on pathology and symptom reduction.
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom. "The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341) Her goals for family therapy included helping the individual members increase their sense of worth and value by accessing their inner resources and by decreasing any emotional blocks. And for the family as a whole, she saw the goal as being to increase congruent communication and heart connections. She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were: It is not okay to see what is going on in the family. It is not okay to feel what you feel. It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel. It is not okay to ask for what you want. It is not okay to take risks. She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as: "What do you see going on between your and your ?" "What are you aware of feeling at this moment?" "Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?" "Can you ask your ___ for what you want?" "I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family."
She also helped them to make better connections with each other by decreasing their defensiveness. Satir identified the primary defensive stances as Blaming (Blamer), Placating (Placator), Distracting, and being Super-Reasonable (Computer). Forms of Fight:
Blaming (Blamer) (This is all your fault.)
Generalizing (You always think you are right.)
Labeling (You are so stupid.)
Threatening (You better shape up or else.) Physically Attacking the Other. Forms of Flight:
Placating (Placator) (Do what you wish, my needs don't matter.)
Being Super-Reasonable (Computer) (I don't care what you feel, just give me the facts.) Emotionally Withdrawing (Physically present but not emotionally present.) Physically Withdrawing (Leaving the room or hanging up on someone.) Cutting-Off (Refusing to talk to the other for days or longer.) Within a family system, these defenses can be played out in interactional patterns such as: Blame - Blame Blame - Withdraw Placate - Placate Blame - Placate Blame - Distract Withdraw - Withdraw Satir developed a process for helping people change and become more connected. Her process is described as having six phases: Phase 1 - Making Contact Satir would reach out using her body position, eye contact, and facial expression to make contact with each member. She would also consciously work to connect from her spirit to theirs. Phase 2 - Validating Satir worked to help people feel validated in many ways such as reflecting their feelings, affirming their values and highlighting their inner resources. Examples include: "You feel scared because your son got suspended from school." "You value education." "You are courageous to seek help." Phase 3 - Facilitating Awareness Satir had many different ways that she would attempt to bring awareness to a family about their defensive patterns in a non-blaming way.
Sculpting: Satir placed the members in body positions to give them a picture of their defensive behavior. For the blaming stance, she would position the person leaning toward another and pointing at them and for the placating stance, she would position the person down on one knee with their head down and their hand up in a pleading position. Satir would also bring awareness to members by exploring their inner experiences. She used the metaphor of an iceberg to help the family therapist to conceptualize the inner level so experience driving defensive behaviors. Above the water line were the inner levels of experience such as feelings, perceptions, expectations, beliefs, and yearnings. (What meaning are you giving to what your ___ said that is causing you to feel hurt? Is that a familiar place for you to go to when someone is disappointed in you? What is it you yearn for?) Phase 4 - Promoting Acceptance One of the ways that satir promoted acceptance was through 'normalizing,' that is, reassuring the family member that what they were experiencing was normal. ("It is normal to...") Another way that she promoted acceptance was by 'bridging' between conflicting parties. ("I am hearing that is is not easy for _, I would be interested to know how life was for you when you were their age?") Phase 5 - Eliciting Positive Choices and Changes Once Satir observed that the family members were aware of and accepting of their unhelpful patterns, she would lead them into seeing new possibilities for their interactions. After sculpting the family, she would ask them to each to stand in a balanced way and look at each other. She would then guide them in a dialogue helping them to express themselves in non-defensives ways. Other times she would simply have them sit face to face and she would guide the dialogue between them. "What happens for you when your says you choose over your ? You feel... Did you know that your felt __? What happened for you when you heard them express their feelings? You long to be more connected with them. You miss them. How do you feel to hear how much they miss you?" Phase 6 - Reinforcing Change Satir would often combine verbal responses with some supportive touch to reinforce a positive shift. The therapist also needs to work on their own personal growth. This is true for working with individuals but it is even more true when working with families as the chances of being triggered by your own family experience are even greater. As Satir used to say, "You are the most important instrument in the room!" Under threat and reward, change is painful: change is viewed as unnatural, the unknown is feared, the status quo is maintained, life's natural 'flow' is blocked, and the familiar is valued despite discomfort. The seed model has people viewing change more positively; as naturally occurring at a variety of levels (from cellular to cosmic) and as scary, but offering new opportunities. Discomfort is seen as a signal for change. Therapists using the seed model keep in mind that families entering therapy are problem-focused and will maintain the status quo as a necessary survival behavior. Therapist should make contact with each person to communicate a climate of acceptance (e.g., people do the best they can) and hear them out to discover 'what is.' Understanding the status quo stage is essential to clarify how the change process gets started or is blocked. This stage is explored further by examining resistance and readiness concepts in detail. The coin of change has resistance and readiness as its head and tail sides. Experientially, we may want to change in one moment and fear or sabotage it in the next. Then status quo is considered a trance, accounting for change resistance as well as a medium in which change may be fostered. Changing circumstances elicit shifts in perception, which in turn stimulate changes in thinking, feeling, and acting. But when circumstances shift back, behavior also reverts. Perception can appear to create change of behavior when the meaning of an event is reframed, but the underlying pattern is not altered. Altering the underlying pattern requires dealing with resistance to change. Resistance is a coping behavior intended to preserve the organism rather than obstruct change. Reframing resistance in terms of its positive intention. The way we are socialized has us, "Gradually acquiring a variety of commitments which constrain the person into following a consistent pattern of behavior." The effect is to develop a lifestyle that stabilizes the events in our lives, our interdependence of meaning of these events, and the way we define ourselves, as well as predisposing us to seek consistent situations. Experientially, change involves invoking the unfamiliar. Intellectualizing, avoiding feelings, compulsive activity, impatience about change, and dwelling in the past are all ways of dealing with the confusion by maintaining the status quo. The tasks at this stage are to cope with the threat to past security and sense of competence and self-esteem; deal with feelings of loss and longing for the past. Conservative impulse, the will to change has to overcome an impulse to restore the past, to resist the change. Survival depends on this impulse. By stabilizing perceptions, the conservative impulse enhances the ability to learn from experience. Only when it does not fit this construct is its 'newness' experienced.
Readiness refers to what Satir considered the unstable balance of elements in the Status Quo. Persons considering change are more open to consciousness-raising interventions, more aware of themselves, more conscious of their psychic distress, and more likely to seek out information about their problem. Variation in readiness for change (even in one person) depends on social circumstances, timing, opportunity, location, change goal, the degree of social pressure or support for the goal, alternations in environments circumstances, developmental crises, and physical or emotional pain. Four patterns emerge reflecting the relative influence of these readiness factors. These patters are based on the degree of difficulty involved in making the change and the degree of responsibility the person is wiling to take for making the change.
Preemptive Change: This pattern describes 'overnight' change. The inordinate strength of the motivating influences lowers the degree of difficulty in making the change. The degree of responsibility for the change is also low. The change in circumstances preempts issues of loss (leaving family and friends), self-efficacy ("Can I do it?"), and self-esteem ("Am I worth the effort?") that are ordinarily addressed in making changes. Problems maintaining the change may require attention at a later point in the change process. Change literally 'happens' to us in this pattern, but we have little sense of ownership of it.
Self-Managed Change: In this pattern, the influences motivating the change are less extreme or immediate than those noted in the preemptive patter. The person is influenced to take a conscious and self-responsible approach to change and is required to deal with one or more of the issues of loss, self-efficacy, and self-esteem in order to resolve the resistance to change.
Satir Family Therapy - YouTube Experiential family therapies include four approaches:
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Internal Family Systems Model Targeting emotional transactions Warmth, empathy, and the therapist's use of self Individual and family focus Five Communication Stances:
Congruent (Congruence) Able to acknowledge what you are thinking and feeling, what the other person may be thinking or feeling
Placating (Placator) Ignore their own thoughts and feelings and focus on the thoughts and feelings of others. Quick to put aside their own emotions for the sake of others. They often are so quick to deny their own feelings. Your job as a therapist is to help them learn to acknowledge their own thoughts and feelings but also the thoughts and feelings of others. They do not want to increase tension when needs are not met and risk having tension in the relationship. Minimizes self People-pleasing tendencies Needs less directive therapy methods
Blamer Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Minimizes other Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak)
Super-Reasonable (Computer) When they are feeling threated, they revert to the context. Some logical external system. They are typically not emotional. Minimizes self and others Logic and rules reign supreme Therapists must refer to context to gain validity Therapist should understand the logic and/or rules they use to organize their world. Therapists may need to refer to this context in order to gain validity. It is important to understand the logic of the system, but at the same time bringing in recognition and value to their own needs AND the needs and desires of others are valid. Learning how to teach them how to acknowledge all three areas of functioning.
Irrelevant (Distractor) Under distress, they distract. The class clown. When tension rises in a relationship, they distract with humor or something off-topic. They may distract. They are more likely to see this in schizophrenia. Your job as a therapist is to get the client reengaged with the difficult topic that they would prefer to just avoid in one way or another. Minimizes self, others, and context. No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Must increase ability to recognize thoughts and feelings of self and others. The focus for the therapist is on creating safety. Help them learn to recognize, and not be afraid of their thoughts and the thoughts of others. Stances acknowledge or minimize three realities: Self Other Context When we feel unsafe, we revert back to one of these communication stances. These are the stances used when someone is frightened. When we don't feel safe as children, we evolve communication stances to survive when we do not feel safe when we are young. You can use the communication stances to help better understand how to intervene, or how to communicate with your client. When you are working with a placator, be cautious if you are going to be making a suggestion it may help to give options. "Which do you think is the best fit or might work for you?" Ask them to give voice to their thoughts and opinions because they will be very quick even to please the therapist. Their task us to learn to assert themselves in a healthy way, how can they assert their needs so that they don't become resentful, depressed (needs do not get taken care of because they are not advocating for themselves) Therapy involves going through stages several times. Can be a new way of looking at the interactions and how to communicate in a more congruent way. The family is having to deal with this foreign element, this new way of interacting, this new idea, or new beliefs, this learning to tolerate direct emotional expression, etc.
That disrupts the family's Homeostasis Eventually the family integrates the new foreign element. People naturally tend toward positive growth All people possess the resources for positive growth Everything impacts and is impacted by everything else. Therapy is a process involving interaction between therapist and client; each person is responsible for themselves. Therapeutic presence (warmth and humanity) Making contact Making emotional contact. About real contact with the person at an intimate level. Contacting them in a very intimate, authentic, engaged way. Empathy Conveying hope Establishing credibility You must instill the hope to clients you can be helpful for them. Emotional Role of Symptom Symptom has a role in the family system Example: Child's exaggerated acting out may serve to reduce tension in marriage by getting parents on the same page. If the therapist can understand how symptom makes emotional sense, it will be easier to help find ways to interact successfully. Problematic family dynamics typically involve: Power struggles Parental conflicts Lack of validation Lack of intimacy Each person's role in family is assessed to understand the function of the problem. Possible roles: Martyr Victim or helpless one Rescuer Good child/parent Bad child/parent Timeline that includes major events in individual's or family's life. Births and deaths Important family events: Marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss Important historical events: Wars, natural disasters, economic downturns Gives both the therapist and client insight into the context of the problem as well as strengths and resources might exist. Child, mother, and father and quality of relationship between them. In this primary triad a child learns how to be human. The triad should serve as nurturing system for child. When the child is experiencing difficulty, the therapist considers how the nurturing function of these relationships can be improved. Layers of the iceberg: Behavior (Top Layer) Coping (Above) Feelings (Below) that are related to coping Perceptions, how is the person perceiving their life or how do they make meaning? Expectations, what are the expectations that are fueling all of this Yearnings (what are the primal yearnings) Helps clients transform their feelings about feelings to make change. Helps clients observe and evaluate themselves. Considers aspects of the self that the client values and aspects of which they are ashamed Self-Compassion: Better indicator of happiness than self-esteem As self-compassion and self-worth rise, Become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses. What extent does the client value themselves? How emotional issues may be manifesting in the body, either symbolically or functionally The way the body is used indicates a person's communication stance:
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted The goal is transformation Achieve optimal realization of a person's full potential Two sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Relationally-focused goals: Congruent communication Individual-focused goals: Self-actualization Therapist's self The way the therapist is in the room. Ingredients of an interaction Whenever the therapist is talking with clients about difficult situations and interactions with others, they ask a series of questions. Go back to the iceberg. What do I hear and see? What is happening at the behavioral level without any interpretation. What are the meanings I make of this? What are they saying? What feelings do I have about these meanings I am making? What feelings do I have about those feelings? What defenses do I use/am I using? How does this trigger me and what kind of defensive behaviors might I bring, that makes them ‚Ä¶. ? What are the rules within the system about how to comment about what's going on? What is allowed and what is appropriate? How am I responding and what part do I play in the system? Facilitating emotional expression What is allowed and what is appropriate? What is my response and what am I doing in this situation? Congruent expression, without the communication stances, turn chairs to each other directly, hold hands, make eye contact Softening family rules When families have rigid rules about who can say what, when, where, and how, she will soften some of these to create more space for everyone's particular way of communicating in a comfortable way to hopefully reduce the use of communication stances. Communication enhancement Helping each member of the family learn to communicate congruently in stressful circumstances, even when they do feel threatened by their partner or their child, Rather than reverting to a survival stance, to help them learn how to be fully congruent and present and to have more effective communications. Sculpting or spatial metaphor She would position each person in the family to metaphorically represent their role. (Example: A placator may be sculpted as being on their knees and begging, the blamer may be there pointing their finger angrily at someone, the irrelevant type might be in a strange position far off from everybody else, the super-reasonable might be sitting there in a very cold, distant, "I am citing the rulebook") Because it is more visual than verbal - you can add a verbal element to it by having each person say a motto of theirs (eg., "Please be nice to me," "Do what I say," "Follow the rules,") - that represents their position in the family. It can push past the survival stances, intellectual defenses, the family could sculpt themselves. It can be a powerful intervention. Touch Touch clients, help clients learn to hold and touch each other in nurturing ways, The therapist must be aware of cultures that have different attitudes towards emotional expression. The therapist adjusts to the client's level of intimacy. Used commonly in the LGBTQ community Focus is on the burden of societal rejection when being the authentic self. Combined main ideas from systemic and humanistic theories: Targeting emotional transactions from the interactional pattern Therapists use warmth, empathy, and self to facilitate desired change. Communication Stances: Give the therapist sense of how to most effectively communicate with the client.
Satir Family Therapy | Part 1 - YouTube Satir brought an unparalleled warmth and enthusiasm for human potential Focused on: Fostering individual growth Improving family interactions In order to facilitate change: - Used experiential exercises, metaphors, coaching, and self-of-the-therapist e
Healthy communication is 'congruent' Acknowledges perspective/needs of 'self' Acknowledges perspective/needs of 'other' Appropriate to context Development: Minimizes one or more essential parts of the total picture Develop in childhood when feel threatened Survival Stances:
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor) One can use more than one stance, but usually use one style predominantly. Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Acknowledge context Minimizes feelings/needs of self and others Prioritize a system of 'logic' (could be rational logic, religion doctrine, etc.) Therapeutic Implications: Reference and respect system of logic Help clients to also consider internal, subjective realities of self and others Might engage by starting with their bodily reactions, expectations, practical realities Avoidance No consistent grounding in self, other, or context Associated with most severe pathology Therapeutic Implications: Creates significant challenge for therapist Identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality Make the therapeutic relationship a place of upmost safety; less need for distracting communication Increase client's ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others Acknowledge the demands of context
Six-stage model of change that is based on research on Cybernetics systems and daws from humanistic principles. Model emphasizes that the therapist perturbs the system. 6 stages:
Status Quo Introduction of Foreign Element
Chaos Integration of New Possibilities Practice New Status Quo Satir's way of being in the world Unshakable hope and deep-felt respect for her clients Satir's presence in the room Put people at ease and allowed them to feel secure enough to relate to one another non-defensively This quality of being, or therapeutic presence, is difficult to define Few methods for systematically developing it More that therapists are congruent, the better they can create therapeutic warmth and humanity Satir et al., (1991) describe establishing a therapeutic relationship as 'making contact' Making Contact: Begins with the therapist being in contact with themselves, including all resources of the self in the self-mandala. Therapist works to make contact with each client in the room, engaging them on 'all channels': Mind Body Spirit Once the therapist has made contact with each person, the therapist works to help family members make contact with each other. Convey their understanding of clients' subjective, inner realities by expressing empathy Having empathy does NOT mean that a therapist: Takes the client's side Avoids confronting inconsistencies Ignores the client's responsibility Honoring the client's unique experience without validating it Makes it easier to move the client toward seeing that the other person has their unique experience, which is 'true' for that person Family Functioning: Role of symptom Family dynamics (power struggles, parental conflict, lack of validation/intimacy) Family Roles (Martyr, Victim, Rescuer, Good/Bad Parent/Child)
Family Life Chronology Survival Triad Assess Individual Functioning Survival Stances 6 Levels of Experience Self-Worth/Esteem Mind-Body Connection
Role of the Symptom in maintaining Family Homeostasis Family Dynamics (Power struggles, parental conflict, lack of validation/intimacy) Family Roles Martyr Victim Rescuer Good/Bad Parent Good/Bad Child
Family Life Chronology Timeline of key events: Birth Death Moves School Job Changes
Survival Triad Each Child + Mother + Father Levels are likened to an iceberg Behavior is the only visible layer Other 5 layers unseen beneath the surface
The Iceberg Model: Used to help individuals understand their intrapsychic experience Used for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonate with the other Behavior External manifestation of the person's inner world Coping
Defenses and survival stances (Placating (Placator); Blaming (Blamer); Super-Reasonable (Computer); Irrelevant (Distractor)) Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past based Using past events to interpret the present Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self Expectations Strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed Satir always assessed a person's level of self-esteem More useful to consider: Aspects of the self that a client values Aspects of which client are ashamed Research indicates that self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses Mind-Body Connection How emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally Also assess the role of nutrition and exercise Example: If a person is feeling burdened, this emotional feeling may manifest symbolically as stooped shoulders. Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's communication stance
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted Goal of Satir's model is transformation To achieve the optimal realization of a person's full potential Attention to individual goals reflects their humanistic foundations 2 broad sets of practical goals for treatment planning: Systemic/family goals Individual goals Relational Goal: Congruent communication Communicating authentically while responding to the needs of self and others Goal to help the family develop ways for members to communicate so the system's homeostasis does not need the symptoms Overarching individual goal is consistent with other humanistic approaches: To promote self-actualization Self-Actualization: Fulfilling one's potential and living an authentic and meaningful life. Specific Goal Example: Increase sense of self-worth and self-compassion Reduce defensiveness and use of survival stances Therapists' use of self Being authentically who they are is one of the most essential interventions in Satir's approach Creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently Ingredients of an interaction: Details the internal communication process Teaches clients about internal and relational processes Ingredient Questions: Used to help people better understand their interactions with others Can be used with individuals, couples, or families Walk the client through the ingredients of an interaction: What do I hear and see? What meanings do I make of what I hear and see? What feelings do I have about the meanings I make? What feelings do I have about these feelings? What defenses do I use? What rules for commenting do I use? What is my response to the situation? Facilitating Emotional Expression Help put difficult emotions into words Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor Coaching clients in how to have congruent communication in session May involve the 'ingredients of an interaction' with specific coaching strategies Satir's most distinctive intervention Done either with the family or in a group setting Puts family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Bypassing Denial/Resistance: Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses Satir used touch in therapy to: Connect with clients Encourage and reassure clients when they were practicing new ways of communicating In today's environment: Touching less common because it can easily be misinterpreted as harassment Carefully consider trauma history, culture, gender, legal/ethical issues of using touch Coaching clients to touch each other Experiential therapies can be challenging online. Require attending to emotions and affect, which are communicated non-verbally Requires Using more verbal communication to make up for the loss of non-verbal communication Adapting non-verbal communication Sculpting: With drawings View whole Experiential approaches value: Clear, congruent, emotional expression Willingness to be vulnerable Cautions Cultural Gender Social Class/Educational Norms for emotional expression vary tremendously May initially be too threatening for clients hwo have been mandated to receive treatment. Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)

In Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement), one of the four survival stances to help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. Privileges self and context while discounting the other. To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual. On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone. Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal. Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others. You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary. Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others. Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak) Acknowledge Self/Context Minimize other Best connect with those who blame by addressing their expectations Therapeutic Implications: Generally prefer more upfront and direct communication Increase blamers' awareness of others' feelings Learn how to communicate in ways that are respectful of others Direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship Therapists can best connect with those who blame through addressing their expectations. The goal often is to increase blamers' awareness of others' thoughts and feelings and help them learn how to communicate their personal perspectives in ways that are respectful of others. With these clients, direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship. Blamers generally prefer more upfront and direct communication than is generally tolerated in polite society. Blaming (Blamer)

The placator talks in an ingratiating way, trying to please, apologizing, and never disagreeing, no matter what. This is a 'yes man' who talks as though they could do nothing for themselves; they must always get someone's approval. They may experience feeling nauseous and wanting to vomit during conflict or disagreement. You may think of yourself as really worth nothing. You are lucky just to be allowed to eat. You owe everybody gratitude, and you really are responsible for everything that goes wrong. Naturally, you will agree with any criticism of you. You are grateful that anyone even talks to you, no matter what they say or how they say it. You would not think of asking anything for yourself. After all, who are you to ask? Besides, if you can just be good enough, it will come by itself. Think of yourself as being physically down on one knee, wobbling a bit, and putting out one hand in a begging fashion. Keep your head up so your neck will hurt, your eyes will strain, and in no time at all your head will ache. When you talk in this position, your voice Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Because placatory have people-pleasing tendencies, therapists use less directive therapy methods, such as multiple choice questions and open-ended reflections, to require them to voice their opinion and take a stand. Therapists should carefully avoid giving opinions, making it seem that they have an opinion, or offering too much personal information. Clients will use this type of information to know what parts of themselves to hide and what parts to foreground to gain therapist approval. Research indicates that some clients make up things to give the impression that therapy is progressing. Not until the placator regularly and openly disagrees with the therapist has rapport been established. Placating (Placator)
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom. "The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341) Unique Spirit She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were: It is not okay to see what is going on in the family. It is not okay to feel what you feel. It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel. It is not okay to ask for what you want. It is not okay to take risks. She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as: "What do you see going on between your and your ?" "What are you aware of feeling at this moment?" "Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?" "Can you ask your ___ for what you want?" "I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family." Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources. The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts. Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes. Parts Party Being authentically who they are is one of the most essential interventions in Satir's approach. Creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently. This is the cohnitive part of your brain. This lens tells you about the information you take in, the thoughts you have, and the meaning you give them. From this cognitive and rational part, you can get answers to such questions as, "What do I understand? How do I learn new things? How do I analyze situations and solve problems?" Integration of New PossibilitiesIntegration of New Possibilities Involves trying out these learnings. Foreign ElementForeign ElementChaosChaos This is the physical body with all its parts and systems. Find a good anatomy book in which you can see pictures of your bones, muscles, internal organs, together with all the different systems. Let yourself be awed and amazed at how wonderfully your body is engineered and what a treasure house of resources it contains. Apply this information to your own body. Are you, its owner, meeting its needs? Are you listening to it? It will tell you when you are tired, hungry, or over-stressed, or alert you to any part of you that needs special care. This is that of your emotions, your feelings. How free are you to recognize and acknowledge them? What restrictions do you put on your feelings? How do you express them? All feelings are human. They bring texture, color, and sensitivity to life. Without feelings, we would be robots. Your feelings about these feelings show you where your self-worth is in relation to your feelings. This has to do with your spiritual connection. This represents your relationship to your life force. How do you regard your life? Do you honor it? Do you use your spiritual connection in your daily life? This has to do with your context. This refers to the sights and sounds, the feel of things, the temperature, the light, the color, the quality of air, and the space where you live and work. Each of these factors has an important effect on your life. The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical. Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem.
This has to do with nutrition. What kind of food and drink do you put into your body? Satir's Self-Mandala Diagram.png This lets you know how you sense yourself. What is the physical condition of your sense organs? What freedoms do you give yourself to look, hear, touch, taste, and smell? Many of us were taught that we could only look at, touch, or listen to certain things. That often resulted in limiting our use of our senses. To acknowledge, honor, and fully and freely use our senses is the main way we interact with the outside world and stimulate ourselves internally. Diagnostic Assessment This shows how you interact with the people in your world. Your interaction shapes the nature of your relationships. How do you evaluate the quality of your various relationships? How do you use your power? Do you give it away and become a victim? Do you use it to become a dictator? Do you use it to develop harmony within yourself and with others, thus becoming an empowering leader? Do you use your power to nurture yourself or others, or to threaten? Do you team up with family members of others to do things together? Do you have fun, make jokes, and generally use good humor to make your life and that of others lighter and happier? Remember that humor and love are two very powerful healing forces. "Making Contact" Joining and building alliance Goal setting, what would the client like to get out of therapy? Clear presenting problem (presenting problem should be connected to goal, golden thread through all notes) Evaluating progress every session Joining and Alliance Satir's most distinctive intervention Done either with the family or in a group setting Puts family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family Bypassing Denial/Resistance: Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses Facilitating Emotional Expression Help put difficult emotions into words Naming emotions Locating in body Metaphor Coaching clients in how to have congruent communication in session May involve the 'ingredients of an interaction' with specific coaching strategies Iceberg Model.pngIceberg Model.png "Making Contact" Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence)Super-Reasonable (Computer)Super-Reasonable (Computer) Levels are likened to an iceberg Behavior is the only visible layer Other 5 layers unseen beneath the surface
The Iceberg Model: Used to help individuals understand their intrapsychic experience Used for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonate with the other Behavior External manifestation of the person's inner world Coping
Defenses and survival stances (Placating (Placator); Blaming (Blamer); Super-Reasonable (Computer); Irrelevant (Distractor)) Feelings Present feelings that are strongly past based Using past events to interpret the present Perceptions Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self Expectations Strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform Yearnings Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed Satir always assessed a person's level of self-esteem More useful to consider: Aspects of the self that a client values Aspects of which client are ashamed Research indicates that self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem. As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses Mind-Body Connection How emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally Also assess the role of nutrition and exercise Example: If a person is feeling burdened, this emotional feeling may manifest symbolically as stooped shoulders. Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's communication stance
Congruent (Congruence) Communication: Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator) Timid and reserved postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer): Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor): Hyper and distracted
The ideal communication stance, where a person is privileging self, other, and context.
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) Congruent (Congruence)
