item.title: @markScopingReviewPractice2020
item.description:
[!Cite] Bibliography: Mark, K. P., & Schuman, D. L. (2020). A Scoping Review of the Practice Recommendations of Secrets in Couple‚Äôs Therapy. Journal of Family Psychotherapy, 31(1‚Äì2), 56‚Äì71. https://doi.org/10.1080/08975353.2020.1759019 [!Synth] Contribution: [!md] Author: Mark, Kristen P. Author: Schuman, Donna L. Title: A Scoping Review of the Practice Recommendations of Secrets in Couple‚Äôs Therapy Year: 2020 Citekey: @markScopingReviewPractice2020 itemType: journalArticle Journal: Journal of Family Psychotherapy Volume: 31 Issue: 1-2 Pages: 56-71 DOI: 10.1080/08975353.2020.1759019[!Abstract] In couple‚Äôs therapy, secrets between the couple often arise, and couple‚Äôs therapists must navigate a balance between their ethical and therapeutic responsibilities. This paper provides a scoping review of the literature on how couple‚Äôs therapists handle secrets in the context of couple‚Äôs therapy and discusses the ethical and clinical considerations in the context of the ethical standards of the AAMFT. Online databases were used to systematically identify peer-reviewed academic, English-language articles that focused on recommendations for therapists in handling secrets between couples in therapy. Seven articles met the search criteria. The empirical evidence supports a model of professional judgment, whereby the therapist can use their discretion about whether or not to disclose a secret on behalf of a client. To operate within the confines of ethical practice, we recommend therapists pair professional judgment with a clearly informed and signed written client policy.
Self-Concealment: Defined secrets as 'life experiences, personal facts, thoughts, or feelings intentionally not disclosed.' Examples include concealing personal negative or distressing information.
Disclosure: Influenced by trust in the therapist and believing that self-disclosure would be beneficial. Promotes healing and attachment, but final decision about disclosure should be left to offending spouse. Voluntary consent should be obtained at the outset of therapy to avoid jeopardizing trust and to remain an equal advocate for both partners. Possible exceptions to disclosure: Serious or terminal illness of injured spouse; imminent divorce; potential for violence; significant psychopathology in either partner; many years have passed, and issue is unrelated facilitated disclosure; it is ethical for therapists to collude in keeping secrets. Honesty is vital to recovery. After disclosure most couples choose the challenges of healing over divorce. Disclosure of infidelity is best course of action to resolve potential conflicts and improve working alliance toward couple healing and renewal. Through voluntary facilitated disclosure (based on the desires of aggrieved spouse) or referral, therapists should avoid double-bind of doing therapy in cases of non-disclosed secrets. The choice to disclose is subjective - one person may readily disclose what another might choose to conceal.
Withholding Information: Though there is some literature on withholding information by the client within the context of individual therapy, the literature on the disclosure of secrets to the therapist by one member of a couple is quite sparse.
Secrets in CFT: Responsible handling of secrets between partners in couple's therapy is necessary to avoid ethical, legal, and therapeutic problems arising from the revelation, particularly due to the sensitive nature of secrets. Therapeutically, a secret has the potential to undermine the development of the therapeutic alliance between the therapist and the secret-disclosing partner if the secret is shared with the other member of the couple. Non-disclosure may also undermine the maintenance of the therapeutic alliance between the therapist and the other partner, who may perceive the therapist as triangulating with the secret holder, if the secret is not shared but arises later in the course of therapy. Additionally, there are potential ethical and legal problems that may emerge due to breaking the confidentiality of an individual through sharing a secret.
Family Systems Theory: Based on the premise that the family or couple functions as a singular emotional unit. Couple system in FST considered a discrete subsystem within a family. Secrets are viewed as indirectly influencing the couple system because of the consequences and symptoms of secrets are explicitly experienced, even if the underlying reasons for their occurrence are unknown to the na√Øve spouse.
Triangulation:Triangulation
Detouring conflict between two people by involving a third person, stabilizing the relationship between the original pair. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
University Resources/Research Citations/M/@markScopingReviewPractice2020: Occurs when third member is drawn into the dyad in an effort to either stabilize a conflicted system or manage the stress associated with the conflict. May be helpful if therapist stabilizes the dyad, but can result in hard if the therapist, wittingly or unwittingly, colludes with one member of the couple. But can result in harm if the therapist, wittingly or unwittingly, colludes with one member of the couple. The conjoint process provides an opening for a couple to grow and learn from one another that is often lost in traditional individual approaches. The therapist may not reveal any individual‚Äôs confidences to others in the client unit without the prior written permission of that individual. Many therapists work within this framework by having a policy around secrets explicitly stated in their consent form signed by clients at the beginning of therapy. crucial that the therapist points out the policy, as there is a scarcity of information about whether consent forms are reviewed by the client prior to signing - Highlight several courses of action that systems-oriented family therapists in hospital settings could take ‚Äì keeping no information confidential, maintaining confidentiality for all, holding some information confidential, or therapist‚Äôs discretion. - Highlight the option of keeping no information confidential could potentially limit the amount of information shared with the therapist, while the second and third options (full and partial confidentiality) risked the therapist‚Äôs collusion with the secret-holding partner (i.e., the one who knows the secret) and causing harm to the na√Øve partner (i.e., the one who does not know the secret). The final option ‚Äì therapist‚Äôs discretion could result in feelings of betrayal by family members, even if the secret-holder were informed of the possibility of disclosure from the start - Highlight four primary - Highlight approaches to handling secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy: no revelation, full revelation, partial revelation, and professional judgment - Highlight Taking the approach of no revelation, therapists must maintain confidentiality with all clients and respect selfdetermination and autonomy of clients‚Äô right to keep a secret from a partner - Highlight When therapists take the approach of full revelation, they refuse to keep a secret with one partner to avoid triangulation and maintain honesty - Highlight act of trust within the therapeutic alliance and restores power imbalances within a couple - Highlight also requires therapists to obtain written consent from both partners at the beginning of therapy to reveal confidential material and adhere to the AAMFT ethical code of conduct - Highlight should be secondary to potential threats of violence or undue harm - Highlight partial revelation for safety reasons, holding information confidential that could increase risk of harm to a member of the couple, or others, or allowing the offending spouse to ‚Äúunilaterally‚Äù determine what information to disclose - Highlight professional judgment, involves the therapist reserving the right to use their professional judgment about whether or not to disclose a secret on behalf of a client - Highlight most commonly documented approach to navigating secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy Highlight A scoping review is an emerging systematic approach to knowledge synthesis in which reviewers map evidence on a broad topic, identifying main concepts, theories, sources, and gaps in the literature - Highlight useful for exploring complex topics - Highlight written in English language, published 2001 or later, peer-reviewed - Highlight researchers have dedicated scant attention to couple‚Äôs therapists‚Äô disclosure of secrets within the context of couple‚Äôs therapy. - Highlight not significantly influenced by years of experience in couple‚Äôs therapy or by the number of couples the therapist had counseled - Highlight in an ethical examination of methods of disclosure that it is the therapist‚Äôs role to facilitate disclosure, especially around cases of infidelity, due to its potential to renew intimacy and promote deeper attachment between the couple. - Highlight Another factor influencing therapists‚Äô decision to disclose is their perception they are betraying their clients‚Äô trust - Highlight therapists use professional discretion, but that the secret should be disclosed if it poses a danger to the partner or impacts the connection between partners - Highlight Depending on the goals of therapy set out between the therapist and the client, a disclosure that impacts the goals in one situation may not impact the goals in another. - Highlight When secrets are embedded in the past and would not help the couple reach their goals, they are better left unrevealed - If someone cheats in the past but keeps it a secret then tells therapist. Ethical decision?? Highlight Specific to infidelity secrets, - Highlight clinicians who promote disclosure end up facilitating healing and attachmeant security, - Highlight best achieved - Highlight informed voluntary consent. - Highlight Clinicians have sparse empirical research to guide their policies regarding secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy Highlight clinicians overwhelmingly encouraged disclosure in the case of an affair (84%), a health issue such as an HIV-positive status (99%), or paternity (85%). - Highlight 70.0% did not have a policy in writing - Highlight 13.8% always used a written ‚Äòno secrets‚Äô agreement - Highlight options available to clinicians for addressing secrets within couple‚Äôs therapy. - Highlight no information is confidential within a couple; individually revealed information can be disclosed only with a separate waiver; some individually revealed information is confidential within a couple; or the degree of confidentiality within a couple relies on the therapist‚Äôs discretion. - Highlight 1) suggesting disclosure and coaching individual on how to do it; 2) giving the individual a limited time to stop secretive behaviors and then suggesting disclosure; 3) in cases of refusal, sharing information in conjoint session; 4) in cases of refusal, informing couple that information obtained from one partner makes it impossible to proceed. - Highlight the research is inconclusive regarding what type of policy or implementation practice is most effective or provides the best possible outcome for the client while respecting ethical guidelines - Even we do not know how to deal with one of the common yet heartbreaking things in relational therapy. Why don‚Äôt we have something?? Highlight over half of researchers use ‚Äúprofessional judgment‚Äù as a guide; whereas roughly one in five use full revelation and one in five use no revelation. - Highlight Keeping secrets in the context of therapy also depends on the nature of the secret (e.g., affairs are rarely disclosed), whether disclosure poses a danger to the partner or how impactful the consequences of disclosure would be, and the length of time which has passed since the secret event(s) occurred - Highlight Theoretical conjecture and advice about dealing with secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy is helpful but leaves little consistency in the guidelines of handling secrets - Highlight large gap in the literature for empirical evidence evaluating approaches to handling secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy - Highlight researchers used different language to describe issues with secret - Highlight to consider the utility of sharing a secret depending on the situation, falling under the category of professional judgment - Highlight large majority of clinicians are obtaining explicit consent from their clients regarding secrets - Highlight still a proportion of clinicians who are not handling secrets within the bounds of the AAMFT ethical standard - Highlight Not only would additional research be beneficial to further understand clinicians‚Äô underlying motivations, it would also raise awareness of this important issue and ensure clinicians are adhering to the ethical standards. - Highlight Revealing client motivations for disclosure is important, as revealing secrets may not always have relationally sensitive intentions - Highlight Future research should examine the ethical considerations and client impact of disclosure of a secret that is not relationally motivated - Highlight considerations of factors such as length of the - Highlight relationship, how far into the relationship the secret began, impact of the secret on progress of therapy, or seriousness of the secret - Highlight are all crucial considerations to the impact revelation would have on the goals of therapy - Highlight The content of the secret may also have an impact on disclosure and requires professional judgment - Highlight Future research would benefit from exploring content of secrets as another variable that may impact the outcomes of disclosure to provide some guidance to professional judgment. - Highlight Future research should also assess the role of sociocultural identities within the couple as it relates to secrets. The quality of the therapeutic alliance may also have an impact on the decision to reveal a secret to the therapist and/or to the partner within the context of therapy. Additionally, self of therapist issues may arise in the context of secrets in couple‚Äôs therapy - Highlight Further research is needed to understand the role of therapeutic alliance and self of therapist issues in the context of secrets within couple‚Äôs therapy - Highlight future research examines the client perspective, the impact of different policies on therapeutic outcomes from the therapist and client perspective, and the ethical implications of each option - Highlight We recommend that therapists‚Äô pair professional judgment with a written policy that both clients within a couple are clearly informed of and sign in order to operate within the confines of ethical practice. - Highlight the empirical evidence to guide clinicians on their policies is scarce - Highlight we recommend future research examines the impact of these policies on couples themselves, their willingness to dedicate time to therapy, and the impact of different policies regarding secrets on therapeutic outcomes. -

item.title: @karpelFamilySecretsConceptual1980
item.description: [!Cite] Bibliography: Karpel, M. A. (1980). Family Secrets: I. Conceptual and Ethical Issues in the Relational Context. II. Ethical and Practical Considerations in Therapeutic Management. Family Process, 19(3), 295‚Äì306. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1545-5300.1980.00295.x [!Synth] Contribution: [!md] Author: Karpel, Mark A. Title: Family Secrets:. I. Conceptual and Ethical Issues in the Relational Context. II. Ethical and Practical Considerations in Therapeutic Management Year: 1980 Citekey: @karpelFamilySecretsConceptual1980 itemType: journalArticle Journal: Family Process Volume: 19 Issue: 3 Pages: 295-306 DOI: 10.1111/j.1545-5300.1980.00295.x This paper is intended to help therapists recognize family secrets, to clarify the theoretical and relational contexts in which they are embedded, and to suggest guidelines and approaches for their therapeutic management. A related aim is to raise and address some of the ethical issues that are inseparable from a consideration of family secrets. Secrets involve information that is either withheld or differentially shared between or among people. Secrets tend, for the most part, not to be about feelings or thoughts, but about facts, real happenings or incidents. Importance of what Boszormenyi-Nagy and his coworkers have described as the ethical-existential dimension of human life in close relationships. This dimension concerns the facts of a person's life and their impact on him/her and those in relationship with him/her, as well as the actions of each person toward one another, especially as they affect mutual debts, entitlements, and trustworthiness. The network of persons involved in the secret as the awareness context. Refers to the network as a whole and includes those who are unaware of the secret as well as those who know it. A fairly simple typology of secrets can be drawn from the kinds of boundaries created in the relational system. From this perspective, three major types of family secrets emerge: (a) individual secrets; (b) internal family secrets; and (c) shared family secrets. Individual secrets involve those cases in which one person keeps a secret from the other person or persons in the family. In both cases, one person's secret is shared with no one else in the family. The boundary formed by the secret is located between the person holding the secret and the other(s). Internal family secrets involve those cases in which at least two people keep a secret from at least one other. Internal family secrets create sub-groupings within the family. Shared family secrets involve those cases in which all members of the family know the secret but are pledged to keep it from persons outside the family. Shared family secrets strengthen the boundaries separating the family as a whole from the outside world. The person or persons who know and keep the secret can be referred to as the secret-holder(s) and the person who does not know the secret as the unaware. The subject, meaning the person that the secret is about. Subject and secret-holder may be one and the same person, or they may be different. The confusion that surrounds secrets may make it difficult in some cases to make absolute distinctions between knowing and not knowing a secret. For some secret-holders, there may be absolute clarity about the fact that there is a secret, but others may be quite surprised to recognize the secret as such. There is a need for a way to identify secrets, even when the secret-holder is unaware of them as such. The therapist should immediately consider the possible existence of secrets any time the word "know" needs to be used more than once in a sentence either by the patient or the therapist. It is nearly impossible to overemphasize the significance of loyalty dynamics in the creation, maintenance, and eventual facing of secrets in families. Often, the secret-holder feels, or may actually be, "sworn to silence." S/he owes it to the other person(s) to keep the secret. Disclosing the secret would be experienced as an act of betrayal and would arouse guilt over disloyalty. These cases concern dynamics of loyalty to the secret-holder(s). But the awareness context is further complicated by the fact that a secret-holder may also feel loyalty to the unaware. Highlight - Highlight Boszormenyi-Nagy has described as a "split-loyalty pattern" - Highlight loyalty dynamics can contribute to the creation and maintenance of family secrets that, in turn, are likely to generate or exacerbate split-loyalty patterns. - Highlight In some cases of secrets, there is an element of "one-upsmanship;"; the secret-holder feels "one-up" on the unaware. - Highlight The power dynamics implied here exist in more subtle and often much more destructive forms in nominally more mature relationships; the secret-holder gloats in his/her secret knowledge and the other's ignorance. - Highlight the secret-holder has the threat of "un-used ammunition." - Highlight There is a dangerous and unstable tension inherent in these power dynamics of secrets because, in order to be able to savor the full effect of the secret, to squeeze every ounce of cruelty from it, the secret-holder must reveal it. Then s/he can see the reaction of the other person when s/he realizes s/he has been deceived. There is, therefore, an inherent instability in such patterns, always pressing toward destructive disclosures. - Highlight Internal family secrets create or strengthen boundaries and alliances within the family between secret-holders. Estrangements develop between secret-holders and the unaware in response to the secret-holder's inability or unwillingness to discuss the secret and to the deception or mystification that often follows in the wake of secrets. - Highlight A curious fact about secrets is that the boundaries created by them depend not only upon who knows the secret but knowing who knows. - Highlight the boundary created between the two sons is just as real as that created between the secret-holder and the unaware, even though both know the secret. - Highlight When all members know the secret and, unlike the case above, know they all know, the secret serves to strengthen the boundary between the family and the outside world. In extreme cases, it may make alliances between family members and persons outside the family virtually impossible if they feel they can neither reveal the secret nor become involved emotionally without revealing the secret. -

item.title: @mignoneConfidentialityFamilyTherapy2017
item.description: Bibliography: Mignone, T., Klostermann, K., Mahadeo, M., Papagni, E., & Jankie, J. (2017). Confidentiality and Family Therapy: Cultural Considerations. ARC Journal of Psychiatry, 2(1), 9‚Äì16. Author: Mignone, Theresa Author: Klostermann, Keith Author: Mahadeo, Melissa Author: Papagni, Emma Author: Jankie, Jillian Title: Confidentiality and Family Therapy: Cultural Considerations Year: 2017 Citekey: @mignoneConfidentialityFamilyTherapy2017 itemType: Journal Article Journal: ARC Journal of Psychiatry Volume: 2 Issue: 1 Pages: 9-16[!Abstract] Maintaining confidentiality in family and couple‚Äôs therapy can prove to be complicated due to the involvement of multiple parties; there are multiple avenues for problems to arise, and it is imperative for therapists to be able to decide when they should keep secrets and when they‚Äôre justified in breaching confidentiality. To add to this dilemma, therapists must also take into account individual personalities, which includes but is not limited to cultural differences between therapists and clients. As such, the purpose of the current paper is to determine the extent that culture influences marriage and family therapists‚Äô understanding of their duties and responsibilities related to issues around confidentiality, as well as clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality. Upon research, it became apparent that there is a dearth of information exploring clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality. Furthermore, there is a lack of research taking into account how cultural components may influence a client‚Äôs willingness to disclose, as well as how therapists‚Äô decisions may differ based on their own culture, or that of their clients. Thus, this literature review presents the need for additional refined research in (1) decision making in confidentiality as it relates to Western and non-Western therapists, (2) how non-Western clients view the confidentiality process, and (3) how ones‚Äô culture can influence their beliefs.Purpose: The purpose of this review is to determine the extent to which culture influences marriage and family therapists‚Äô understanding of their duties and responsibilities related to issues around confidentiality, as well as clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality The purpose of the current paper is to determine the extent that culture influences marriage and family therapists‚Äô understanding of their duties and responsibilities related to issues around confidentiality, as well as clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality. The present study seeks to address this issue by considering the role of culture on the therapist‚Äôs decision to disclose as well as differences related to culture around clients‚Äô feelings and expectations for privacy in therapy Introduction: Confidentiality in MFT can be complicated due to the various parties involved. (AAMFT) recommend that policies concerning confidentiality be discussed at the beginning of therapy during the informed consent process. A therapist is not allowed to reveal any individual‚Äôs confidence in the system-oriented therapy setting without the prior written permission of that individual. Gottlieb (1996) described four conceptually distinct variations of confidentiality that could be used with couples or families: 1) treat information disclosed individually as confidential; 2) inform each client that no information is confidential; 3) allow certain information to remain confidential as a matter of personal privacy; or 4) agree to allow certain information to be temporarily kept confidential, with the stipulation that it must be disclosed at a later time. May have very serious implications depending on the client (or family/couple) scenario. in cases of couple and family treatment, the therapist should outline the rules of treatment, defining who the patients are, as well as confidentiality and any limitations. There are no legal or professional ethics that directly address the issue of cultural mismatch. Maintaining confidentiality in family and couple‚Äôs therapy can prove to be complicated due to the involvement of multiple parties. Therapists must also take into account individual personalities, which includes but is not limited to cultural differences between therapists and clients. There is a dearth of information exploring clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality. There is a lack of research taking into account how cultural components may influence a client‚Äôs willingness to disclose, as well as how therapists‚Äô decisions may differ based on their own culture, or that of their clients. Need for additional refined research in (1) decision making in confidentiality as it relates to Western and non-Western therapists, (2) how non-Western clients view the confidentiality process, and (3) how ones‚Äô culture can influence their beliefs. One of the issues faced by therapists relates to whether or not secrets should be kept. Relational therapists‚Äô supported facilitated disclosure of infidelity, so long as it was in an informed and voluntary manner. The therapists felt that healing and attachment security were optimally achieved through disclosure. Findings revealed that therapists spent a great deal of time deciding how to handle secrets, used a ‚Äúprofessional judgment‚Äù approach, and informed clients verbally of their confidentiality policy. Results also revealed that 25% of the sample noted that a couple was unhappy or expressed concern over the manner in which a secret was handled and that the approach used to deal with the secret was not predictive of the number of complaints lodged. dilemma faced by marriage and family therapists when a child discloses information that a counselor is mandated to report suggest relying on sound professional judgment when deciding whether or not it is appropriate to breech confidentiality and suggest reviewing confidentiality and the limitations associated with it on an ongoing basis. Ethical issues surrounding disclosures by minor children in marriage and family therapy is grossly understudied. Marriage and family therapists be aware of their state‚Äôs laws prior to breeching confidentiality. In the event that a client is participating in illegal activity, the counselor should encourage the client to turn him or herself in to the proper authorities. Should a counselor choose to report a client‚Äôs illegal activity, the authors argue that he or she should refer the client to another therapist because the counselor has now become the accuser. Findings revealed differences in the ways of obtaining informed consent, approach to discussing confidentiality, information shared with parents or guardians, and the influence of client-specific factors on the management of confidentiality. Two factors play a large role in the therapist‚Äôs decision to breech confidentiality: 1) the negative nature of the client‚Äôs behavior, and 2) the desire to maintain the therapeutic process. A small percentage of respondents were not informing their clients about confidentiality (and its limits) until a problem arose. The author recommends review and discussion of written confidentiality policies with each client, the need for comprehensive written policies about limits to confidentiality that go beyond legally determined requirements to include collaborative relationships, third- party payers, and supervision, and training on ethical dilemmas related to confidentiality focusing on the areas identified in the study as areas of need including collaborative relationships, legal knowledge, and managed care. Grounded theory methodology revealed three main concepts: 1) defining who constitutes the therapy client, 2) maintaining privacy and confidentiality during the therapeutic process, and 3) handling private or secret disclosures made during individual breakout sessions. While some information is disclosed, other information typically considered important to the counseling relationship is not disclosed at the outset of therapy (e.g., limits of confidentiality, treatment risks). Many rehabilitation counselors do not fully inform their clients about the limits of confidentiality at the outset of counseling. Participants‚Äô view of privacy differed greatly from Western views and that the privacy protections used in the study created discomfort among participants. Any definition of privacy must take into account the cultural variations in defining and understanding this concept. Confidentiality is not a one-size fits all approach, particularly for practitioners working with a very diverse caseload. More research is needed to directly assess cultural influences on the confidentiality. Therapists can take steps to ensure that they become more culturally competent. They note that many Native Americans consider silence to be a sign of respect, and that they value careful listening. Some may even perceive too many questions as being rude or disrespectful, along with taking notes during an interview since it defers from vigilant listening. Asian American individuals may be less confrontational and yearn for harmonious relationships. They may also view direct eye contact as invasive, and may desire a level of formal respect. As with Hispanic/Latin American individuals, religion may take prominence over therapy; the Catholic Church is very influential within this group, and often plays a vital role in helping individuals with mental health problems. Some Hispanic/Latin American individuals may believe that their mental health is out of their control, which may create issues in situations where a therapist needs to aid the individual in establishing a locus of control. Individuals within cultures are very diverse, and it is unfair to assume that these guidelines will apply to every single person. It is still imperative for therapists to have knowledge of the possible cultural influences, as this can undeniably affect the client-therapist relationship including, but not limited to, the confidentiality process. There is a dearth of information exploring clients‚Äô perceptions and understanding of confidentiality and even less that takes into account how cultural components may influence a client‚Äôs willingness to disclose during sessions. The majority of studies focused on these issues without directly considering cultural influences. Therapists should be weary of clients‚Äô and their own cultural influences; careful care should be taken to ensure that the client understands the therapists‚Äô confidentiality terms and conditions when confidentiality terms or a secret may not be maintained. It is recommended that family therapists take into account the context of culture prior therapeutic decisions. Culture plays a large role in an individual‚Äôs decision-making process in terms of when it is appropriate to breech confidentiality as well as how the breech is perceived. Values may not always be considered ethical, which may create the possibility that a clinician‚Äôs personal values do not protect the welfare of his or her clients. A lack of understanding around the limits of confidentiality would limit the amount of information disclosed in sessions. Examined psychologists knowledge of legal and ethical guidelines and found almost 75% of participants were misinformed about their state laws, despite reporting a belief they were well aware of state statutes and ethical guidelines. Therapists‚Äô understanding of the confidentiality concept as well as the implications this may have for couples and families, has been grossly understudied. The influence of culture on the therapy process is an important area of inquiry which has implications for the therapeutic alliance, the type of information disclosed, and treatment effectiveness and outcome. Therapists from different cultures viewed confidentiality policies differently, and 2) clients from different cultural backgrounds reported significant differences in their understanding and comfort level with their rights to confidentiality and its limits. May support the notion that there is passive discrimination occurring in that individuals from non-Western cultures have different perceptions and understanding of the confidentiality process, which may influence their willingness to disclose, and thus, impact the outcome of treatment. Therapists should be more proactive in assessing clients‚Äô understanding of the confidentiality process. This lack of clear guidance has resulted in more and more providers deciding to not consult professionals in ethics or the law to resolve their ethical dilemmas; rather they are consulting supervisors and colleague. Neither the AAMFT code of ethics or New York State Mental Hygiene Law offers guidance regarding how non-Western therapists should proceed if their cultural values or worldview is inconsistent with our Western confidentiality policy. Reluctance among non-Western clinicians to breech confidentiality under any circumstance ‚ÄúIn practice, the decision to break confidentiality is multi-factored and complex, likely influenced by a combination of the psychologist‚Äôs own values, the items and factors discussed in the present study, and additional considerations that have yet to be discovered" Confidentiality may not be a one-size-fits-all concept. Results indicate that clients from non-Western cultures did not completely understand the concept of privileged communication or the limits to confidentiality. Confidentiality policies were limited and argued for their reexamination as they relate to therapy. For some clients, the concept of confidentiality was inconsistent with their beliefs, thus creating a disconnect between one of the benchmarks of therapy (i.e., confidentiality) and an individual or family‚Äôs culture of origin. Non-Western therapists expressed reluctance to breech confidentiality under an circumstance Confidentiality guidelines should be tailored to the particular context and individuals involved in treatment. Future research may wish to examine the decision- making process as it relates to confidentiality of non-Western therapists more closely with more diverse and larger samples. It is not the intent of clinicians to conduct ineffective treatment or behave unethically; however, there does seem to be a failure to recognize the role of personal values and culture. More specific information is needed directly from non-Western clients regarding how to modify the confidentiality process in a way that is respectful, yet still provides the safeguards intended It is imperative that clinicians find a culturally-respective way to make clients feel safe to reveal what may be embarrassing or personally sensitive information in treatment More precise comparative study is needed among cultures to better understand the influence of different beliefs. Ethical therapist behavior clearly requires more than good intentions, and the values permeating therapeutic efforts must‚Ä¶be more than a matter of personal bias and subjectivity Will inform a decision-making manual which can be easily disseminated to educators and treatment providers.

item.title: 12. African American and Latinx Populations
item.description: A labor acknowledgement is a statement that recognizes that much of the economic progress and development in a geographic area or industry resulted from the unpaid labor and forced servitude of People of Color - specifically enslaved African labor. Labor acknowledgements are one way to 'honor and remember the violent histories and legacies of settler colonialism' and to 'collectively begin to acknowledge the historical labor that has allowed our society to get and be where it is today, then we will continue to struggle to reconcile and redress those histories and legacies.' Terah TJ Stewart Like most modern day US institutions, Solid Ground benefits from the unaddressed legacy of stolen labor at the foundation of this nation and its vast and inequitable wealth. We respectfully acknowledge our debt to the enslaved people, primarily of African descent, whose labor and suffering built and grew the economy and infrastructure of a nation that refused to recognize their humanity. While the 13 th Amendment to the Constitution technically ended 'slavery' in the US, we know that slavery's ongoing impacts are still felt by countless people forced - through violence, threats, and coercion - to work in the US. We recognize our debt to exploited workers past and present whose labor was and continues to be stolen through unjust practices. We acknowledge our collective debt to the Indigenous peoples of this land whose labor was forced and exploited, the Chinese immigrants who built railroads that allowed for westward American development, Japanese Americans whose properties and livelihoods were taken from them while incarcerated during World War II, and migrant workers from the Philippines, Mexico, and Central and South America who have worked Pacific Northwest farms and canneries. We recognize the immigrant and American-born workers of African, Asian, and Central and South American descent whose labor remains hidden in the shadows but still contributes to the wellbeing of our collective community. We recognize that our economy continues to rely on the exploited labor of incarcerated people, largely people of color, who earn pennies an hour while generating billions in goods and services each year. And we know there are many other people, too numerous to mention, who are prevented from reaping the true value of their labor by unjust systems and cruel practices. We mourn their loss of life, liberty, and opportunity. We acknowledge that the theft of labor is the theft of generational progress. Nearly all people of color have been robbed of the opportunity and wealth that their ancestors might otherwise have passed on to them. What is the presenting problem? Indicate if there are 'identified patient (s)' Who initiated contact and why? In 2022, there were roughly 47.9 million individuals who self-identified as Black (14.4% of the U.S. population) Black Americans are diverse, presenting through the lens of four groups: Total US Black population Single-race, non-Hispanic Black people Multiracial, non-Hispanic Black people Black Hispanic people Help-Seeking refers to the process of finding support for dealing with relationship distress that occurs between couples. Professional help: Couples therapy is an evidence-based approach to improve marital quality, yet there are hesitancies and barriers to treatment. Other sources: Friends Family Church Relationship distress amongst spouses/partners 'Different state from the usual ups and downs of a marriage' Feeling fundamentally dissatisfied with the relationship Constant Features of contempt, withdrawal, violence, and loss of connection Impacts individual and the system Feeling dissatisfied, upset, 'trapped', stuck in a perpetual cycle, desperate for change Looks different between all couples Broader term Ultimately, unresolved relationship distress can lead to the dissolution of the relationship. Black Shadow: 'Internalized myth of Black inferiority that has conceived and propagated by slaveowners to justify the enslavement of African people more than 400 years ago' Systematic racism has perpetuated these beliefs, promoting White superiority and Black inferiority 'Systems of Power' highlights two states: Have Have nots Social hierarchy Some people have advantages, and some have disadvantages Remember: Ignoring slavery and the history of our country disempowers African Americans African American couples experience worse relationship quality and are less likely than other ethnic groups to seek professional help Face unique barriers: Stigma Representation Power Dynamics Mistrust and racism is not a 'past' system or issue Vaterlaus et al (2015) Prior to Treatment Stigma 'Weakness' (most significant deterrent) Concerns for cultural sensitivity Financial inability to pay Hubbard et al (2024) During Treatment Discrimination Microaggressions Fears of misdiagnosis "African Americans are more likely to be diagnosed with schizophrenia, while mood disorders often go underdiagnosed." Mussa et al (2023) point out that newlywed African American couples tend ot seek help in alternative ways: Help from God (prayer) Religious leaders Friends Family members Hubbard et al. (2024) 'The Black church,' along with friends and family Black churches emerged furing the time of slavery History of being a 'safe place' to express cultural heritage, develop community, and organize structure Entry point for mental health care

item.title: 9. Sexuality and LGBTQ+ Persons in Therapy
item.description:
Gender was invisible, implicitly binary, sexist, racist, and White cis-men were the standard. White feminist lens (i.e., White binary, heterosexual perspective, Patriarchy, and sexism) Postmodern approach to gender (still binary and biologically determined) Fmaily therapy theory rests on normative concepts of the traditional family and idealized conceptions of family relationships. Inequalities in the family associated with gender have been regarded as of little importance to the development of macro theory in the field. The two most influential therapeutic models, psychodynamic and systemic approaches, are each marked by gender bias. Feminist therapy is an integrative approach to psychotherapy that focused on the challenges that women face as a result of bias, stereotyping, oppression, discrimination, and other factors, and how those stressors can negatively affect their mental health. 'Feminist Family Therapy is the application of feminist theory and values to family therapy.' Acknowledge and examine the roles of values in therapy for both the therapist and the client (s). Intentionally introduce a discussion of gender into the therapy process using clinical language and techinques that acknowledge experiences across genders. Assess power inequalities in relationships rather than assuming equity in relationships. Include discussion of individual choice and responsibility in conceptualizations of family dynamics. Honor and appreciate the diversity inherent to families. Consider the clinical implications of interventions on both the family and on individual members of the family. Work actively to reduce power inequalities between therapist and client. (Leslie & Southard 2009) According to intersectional feminists, there is not enough emphasis on the intersection of patriarchy with other factors, such as race, religion, and class. Intersectional feminists argue that other types of feminism assume that all women are exploited in the same way in the family. Self of the therapist Locating the self Locating the client Unpacking gender stories in context Examining the use of power Seeking affirmation Reclaiming self and relationships Pillar 1: Intersectional Pillar 2: Systemic Pillar 3: Relational Pillar 4: Liberatory Pillar 5: Transformative Introduce yourself and pronouns and asking for your client/patient's name and pronouns Gather client/patient information using inclusive language Avoid assumptions around identity, body parts, and sexual practices Gather biopsychosocial/sexual history information End the session by thanking the patient Keeley (2022). Integrative Family Therapy with Transgender, Gender Diverse, and Non-binary (TGDNB) Young People Read peer-reviewed published literature to provide best support and understand terminology. Recognize the family as a key protective factor in mental health outcomes of TGNDB children and work with the whole system. Use the pronouns and name the young person requests you use. This may include checking in at each session and using a different name and pronoun when their family is present if this is more comfortable for them. Explore the power in the system and the political climate in which you are seeing a TGNDB person. Example: Be aware of news articles or the area the person lives in to check about transphobic experiences and/or discrimination Connect TGDNB young people to community and peers to build their sense of connection and reduce stigma and isolation Therapist will need to each out to local services and be aware of local networks This can include online community connection The lesbian, gay, and bisexual identity scale (LGBIS) is a 27-item measure designed to assess eight dimensions of lesbian, gay, and bisexual (LGB) identity that have been discussed in clinical and theoretical literature. The development of the LGBIS is fully described by Mohr and Kendra (2011) Accepting Concerns: Worry relating to potential rejection of one's sexual identity
Concealment Motivation: Being concerned with protecting one's sexual identity
Identity Uncertainty: How uncertain one is concerning their sexual identity.
Internalized Homonegativity: The degree to which to which one rejects their sexual identity.
Difficult Process: How difficult one's sexual identity develop was
Identity Superiority: How favorable one views sexual minorities compared to heterosexual people
Identity Affirmation: The association of positive thoughts with one's sexual identity
Identity Centrality: How central one's sexual identity is to one's overall identity

item.title: 8. Gender Therapy
item.description:
The early years: Gender was invisible, implicitly, implicitly binary, sexist, racist, and White cis men were the standard. Late 1970 s (White Feminist lens): Example: White binary, heterosexual perspective. Patriarchy, and sexism. 21st Century: Post modern approach to gender (still binary and biologically determined) Biological Sex Refers to the physical sex characteristics you are born with and develop including genitalia, chromosomes, hormones, etc. Biological sex is generally assigned at birth and is often categorized as male, female, or intersex.
Intersex: Describes variation in sex characteristics, such as chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones, or genitals. 'Intersex,' like 'female,' and 'male,' is socially constructed category that humans have created to label bodies that they view as different from those they would classify as distinctly 'female' or 'male.'
Gender The result of socially constructed ideas about the behavior, actions, and roles a. particular sex performs. Term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'
Gender Identity One's innermost concept of self as male, female, a blend of both or neither - how individuals perceive themselves and what they call themselves. One's gender identity can be the same or different from their sex assigned at birth.
Gender Fluid: A person who does not identify with a single fixed gender; of or relating to a person having or experiencing a fluid or unfixed gender identity.
Gender Expression: External appearance of one's gender identity, usually expressed through behavior, clothing, haircut or voice, and which may or may not conform to socially defined behaviors and characteristics typically associated with being either masculine or feminine.
Gender Non-Conforming: A broad term referring to people who do not behave in a way that conforms to the traditional expectations of their gender, or whose gender expression does not fit neatly into a category.
Gender-Expansive: Conveys a wider, more flexible range of gender identity and/or expression than typically associated with the binary gender system.
Transgender: An umbrella term for people whose gender identity and/or expression is different from cultural expectations based on the sex they were assigned at birth. Being transgender does not imply any specific sexual orientation. Therefore, transgender people may identify as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, etc.
Gender Dysphoria: Clinically significant distress caused when a person's assigned birth gender is not the same as the one with which they identify. According to the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistic Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), the term - which replaces Gender Identity Disorder - 'is intended to better characterize the experiences of affected children, adolescents, and adults.' Self of the therapist Locating the self Locating the client Unpacking the gender stories in context Examining the use of power Seeking affirmation Reclaiming self and relationships

item.title: 5. Multicultural Barriers in Therapy and Culturally Competent Assessment
item.description:
Sue et al (2019) (Chapter 7 and 13) (University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022)
McGoldrick & Hardy (Chapter 37) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Jones et al (2020) @jonesStandingGapContinued2020
Cultural Formulation Interview (Cultural Formulation Interview)
(Optional) Cognitive Biases Codex
(Optional) Kim Constructive Conversations Model Culture consists of all those things that people have learned to do, believe, value, and enjoy. It is the totality of the ideals, beliefs, skills, tools, customs, and institutions into which members of society are born (Ratts & Pedersen, 2014). Focus on the individual Verbal/emotional/behavioral expressiveness Insight Self-Disclosure (openness and intimacy) Scientific empiricism Distinction between mental and physical functioning Patterns of communication
' Family Systems Theory may be equally as culture - bound as any other form of therapy, and this limitation may be manifested in marital or couple counseling, parent-child counseling, or work with more than one member of a family.'
Family Systems Theory suggests that healthy families: Allow and encourage the free and open expression of emotion. View each member as having a right to be their own unique self (individuate from the emotional field of the family). Strive for an equal division of labor among family members. Consider egalitarian role relationships between partners desirable. Hold the nuclear family as the standard.
High-Context (HC) Communication Anchored in the physical context (situation) or internalized in the person. HC communication relies heavily on non-verbals, and the group identification/understanding shared by those communicating.
Low-Context (LC) Communication Place a greater reliance on the verbal part of the message. Characteristics of communication associated with race, gender, and other group identities often manifested in verbal and nonverbal communication language. 30-40% of what is communicated conversationally is verbal. What is the other 60-70%?
Proxemics Refers to perception and the use of personal and interpersonal space. Example: Physical closeness or distance when communicating
Kinesics The term used to refer to bodily movements Example: Facial expressions
Paralanguage Used to refer to other vocal cues that individuals use to communicate Example: Volume of voice Non-verbal communication tends not to be under conscious control. Non-verbal behavior provides clues to conscious deceptions or unconscious biases. 'Therapists who have not adequately dealt with their own biases and racist attitudes may unwittingly communicate them to culturally diverse clients.' Microaggressions are the 'everyday slights, indignities, and insults committed against marginalized groups because of their membership in those groups.'
The Kim Constructive Conversations Model (KCCM) is a guide to having difficult conversations about important topics with family, friends, and co-workers. The aim is to deepen engagement and mutual understanding in hopes of working and healing together. Informed by evidenced-based theories and tools, the KCCM emphasizes the following: Understanding barriers to constructive conversations Self-awareness and regulation Values as anchors Personal skills development Healing in relationship connection The KCCM Goal Barriers Values Openers Take Action Listen Respond Repeat Use both clinician skill and client perspective to understand the problem Collaborate and jointly define the problem. Jointly formulate a hypothesis regarding the cause of the problem. Jointly develop ways to confirm or disconfirm the hypothesis on the problem, continuing to consider alternative hypotheses. Test out the hypothesis using both the client and the therapist as evaluators. If the conceptualization appears to be valid, develop a treatment plan. If the hypothesis is not borne out, jointly collect additional data and formulate new, testable hypotheses. Deliberate practice is individualized training activities specially designed by a coach or teacher to improve specific aspects of an individual's performance through repetition and successive refinement. Deliberate practice is an evidenced-based method of skill development. Deliberate practice works best when training targets each student's personal skill thresholds or current ability. If a deliberate practice exercise is either too easy or too hard, the student is unlikely to benefit from it. To maximize training productivity, performers follow a 'challenging but not overwhelming' training principle. This means that deliberate practice requires ongoing assessment of the student's current skill and tailoring the difficulty of exercises to consistently target a 'good enough' challenge. Skill Criteria for Attention to Diversity Convey a brief empathic response to a client/family member that indicates you hear their problem or the session content. Reflect on the problem/session content, looking for opportunities to deepen the conversation as it relates to their identity and unique experiences. Ask a question that conveys continued empathy and curiosity about their identity and unique experiences with the problem.

item.title: 4. The Impact of Systemic Oppression in Therapy
item.description:
McGoldrick (Chapter 3 and 4) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Sue et al. (Chapter 4, 5, and 6) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022 When members of the dominant culture impose their standards upon culturally diverse populations without regard for differences. Refers to a belief in the superiority of one's group's cultural heritage over another, and the implications of those standards upon the less powerful group.
Cultural Encapsulation: Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
Cultural Racism: Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations. Belief in the Superiority of the Dominant Group Belief in the Inferiority of Others Power to Impose Standards Manifestation in Institutions The Invisible Veil Internal: Believe they are in control and take responsibility for their own actions. External: Blame external forces for their own circumstances.
People who have Internal Locus of Control believe that the outcomes of their actions are results of their own abilities.
People with an External Locus of Control attribute success or failure to luck or chance, a higher power, or the influence of another person. To produce conditions that allow for equal access and opportunity To reduce or eliminate disparities in education, health care, employment, and other areas that lower the quality of life for affected populations To encourage mental health professionals to consider micro, meso, and macro levels in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of clients and client systems. To broaden the role of the helping professional to include not only counselor/therapist but also advocate, consultant, psychoeducator, change agent, community worker, and so on. Critical Race Theory (CRT) states that, 'Racism and discrimination are matters of thinking, mental categorization, attitude and discourse.' (Stefancic and Delgado, 2012, p. 21) and it challenges the 'ontological and epistemological biases subtly inculcated in the law, policies, or in empirical research that would otherwise hinter contextualization of harm and dysfunction resulting from racial stratification.' (Brown, 2003, p. 294) CRT helps focus our attention on the recursive interactions between institutionalized and interpersonal discrimination. Through the application of CRT to counseling and psychotherapy it is possible to interrogate the Eurocentric, ethnocentric and individualistic ways in which mental health practices are undertaken. Clients in need of psychological support can then be given a safe space for them to explore (in their own vernacular if necessary) their experiences of living in a capitalistic, racist, and misogynistic world.
Remediation The action of remedying something, in particular of reversing or stopping environmental damage.
Prevention The action of stopping something from happening or arising.

item.title: 3. Understanding Oppression, Identity, and Intersectionality
item.description:
Crenshaw (1991) McGoldrick & Hardy (Chapter 9) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Kang et al (Unit I) @kangIntroductionWomenGender2017
Almeida & Tubbs (2020) @almeidaDecolonizingCouplesFamily2018
(In Practice) The Four I's of Oppression (In Practice) Decolonizing CFT
Intersectionality
Social Location
Social Constructionism
Power
Privilege
White Supremacy 1
Oppression
Historical Trauma
Cultural Paradigm
Critical Race Theory
Hegemony Any oppressive system has the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society. Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional. The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group. Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal. The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad. Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value. On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change. The -isms all work to establish a defined norm or standard of rightness under which everyone is judged. This defined norm is backed up with individual and institutional violence which makes the oppression possible. The defined norm is a notion that all of us might accept and promote for various reasons probably connected to a sense of inferiority or economic vulnerability. 'Whiteness as Poverty' argues that law has come to embody and legitimize benefits that accrue to citizens just because they are right. Despite the end to formal racial discrimination in the legal system race matters in how the law is carried out. Due to the embedded racism in American society, Whiteness can be considered a property interest. Right of Possession Right to Use and Enjoyment Right to Disposition Right of Exclusion Critics of Harris' argument suggest that distributive justice sets up harm for the dominant group (in this case whites). Harris argues, "Acknowledging Black identity does not involve the systematic subordination of whites, nor does it even set up a danger of doing so."
Equality Treating everyone the same (aims to promote fairness)
Equity Giving everyone what they need to be successful (may appear unfair) A tendency for people of a particular religion, race, social background, etc., to form exclusive political alliances, moving away from traditional broad-based party politics. Rather than organizing solely around belief systems, programmatic manifestos, or party affiliation, identity political formations typically aim to secure the political freedom of a specific constituency marginalized within its larger context. Members of that constituency assert or reclaim ways of understanding their distinctiveness that challenge dominant oppressive characterizations, with the goal of greater self-determination. Identity politics shifts out moral and political attention from individual wrongful acts against individuals - perhaps motivated by prejudiced attitudes or bigotry - to structural and systematic injustice against social groups. This process of recognizing as social and systematic that was formerly perceived as isolated and individual has also characterized the identity politics of marginalized groups (i.e., racial ethnic minorities and LGBTQ persons) For all these groups, identity-based politics has been a source of strength, community, and intellectual development. This occurs when social structures that create and organize different social groups, e.g., gender and race, interact to produce effects that may not be intended. Example: Domestic violence shelters that do not address the multiple needs of poor women, immigrants, and women of color, plausibly also trans women, e.g., by refusing to admit non-English speaking women. Patterns of subordination often intersect in women's experience of domestic violence. Oftentimes one burden interacts with pre-existing vulnerabilities to create another dimension of disempowerment. This occurs when the political movements working towards justice for different groups, e.g., feminism and antiracism, interact to exclude or marginalize the interests of some subset of the groups, or reinforced another form of injustice. Examples: For women of color anti-racist and feminist political agendas often conflict with one another This is the same for people of color regarding anti-racist and LGBTQ political agendas. Many times the experience of the dominant group within a targeted population shapes the political agenda. Therefore, both agendas fail to acknowledge the additional issue of race, patriarchy, or sexual or gender identity and are often inadequate in articulating the full dimensions of racism, sexism, or heterosexism. A concept that refers to the cultural construction of an identity, including the production and the contemporary critiques of the identity. This occurs when images or tropes are taken to be representative of the group ignore or distort the complexity of the group.
"Representational intersectionality would include both the ways in which these images are produced through a confluence of prevalent narrative of race and gender, as well as the recognition of how contemporary critiques of racist and sexist representations marginalize women of color." (@crenshawMappingMarginsIntersectionality1991, p. 1283) The experience of being a member of more than one social group that cannot be decomposed into the experience of being a member of each. Example: The experience of being a Black woman is not just the experience of being Black and the experience of being a woman. The experience of being a Black woman is a proper compound of the two. Critical Race Theory (CRT) states that, 'Racism and discrimination are matters of thinking, mental categorization, attitude and discourse.' (Stefancic and Delgado, 2012, p. 21) and it challenges the 'ontological and epistemological biases subtly inculcated in the law, policies, or in empirical research that would otherwise hinter contextualization of harm and dysfunction resulting from racial stratification.' (Brown, 2003, p. 294) CRT helps focus our attention on the recursive interactions between institutionalized and interpersonal discrimination. Through the application of CRT to counseling and psychotherapy it is possible to interrogate the Eurocentric, ethnocentric and individualistic ways in which mental health practices are undertaken. Clients in need of psychological support can then be given a safe space for them to explore (in their own vernacular if necessary) their experiences of living in a capitalistic, racist, and misogynistic world.

item.title: 2. Multiculturalism and Social Justice in Couple and Family Therapy
item.description:
Read University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019 Read
Cultural Competence The awareness, knowledge and skills needed to function effectively with culturally diverse populations.
Cultural Humility A complementary component to cultural competence associated with an open attitudinal stance or a multiculturally open orientation to work with diverse clients.
Cultural Responsiveness A complementary component to cultural competence associated with an open attitudinal stance or a multiculturally open orientation to work with diverse clients.
Worldview Composed of people's attitudes, values, and beliefs that affect how people think, define events, make decisions, and behave. Cultural competence is not just a majority group requirement We must consider the impact of socialization processes on the development of biases.
Implicit: Thoughts and feelings of which we are unaware 'Mistaken about their nature'
Bias A preference for (or aversion to) a person or group of people A bias or prejudice that is present but not consciously held or recognized. Attitudes toward people or associated stereotypes about people or groups that are not within our conscious knowledge.
How to Tackle Unconscious Bias as a Therapist | Lyra Health Identify your cultural blind spots and areas of inexperience
Take the Implicit Association Test Form a consultation and accountability group
Consider joining the AAMFT Topical Interest Network Margins to [Cultural Connections Among C/MFTs]( https://networks.aamft.org/marginstocenter/home Incorporate processes for multicultural specific assessment
Sign in to your account Practice contextual and collaborative conceptualization
Create Cultural Genograms with clients Consider reading texts focused on specifically on unconscious bias. Seek out continuing education and training on unconscious bias. Seek out continuing education and training on unconscious bias. Engage in dialogue about implicit bias with coworkers or other colleagues Sociocultural attunement refers not only to awareness of societal systems, culture, and power, but to willingness to pay close attention and be responsive to the experience of others.

Social Context: Shared meanings that define culture, inform identities, and situate experience. Including the dynamic interconnections of social systems that shape constraints and opportunities within spatial settings.
Power: A set of social process by which individual and collective interests are determined.
Third-Order Change: A shift in relationship to sociocultural systems that expands possibilities and enables transformation of one's life. Attune: Understand, resonate with, and responding to experience within societal contexts. Name: Identify what is unjust or has been overlooked (amplified silenced voices) Value: Acknowledge the work of that which has been minimized or devalued Intervene: Support relational equity - disrupt oppressive power dynamics Envision: Provide a space to imagine just relational alternatives
Transform: Collaborate to make what is imagined/real - Third-Order Change.

item.title: 1. The Multiple Dimensions of Identity
item.description:
Read Chapter 1 of @mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Review Syllabus HDFS 8880 Diversity Syllabus.pdf
Review Using 'I' Statements.pdf Please answer the following questions on a scale of 1-10 How comfortable do you feel discussing race? How comfortable do you feel discussing class? How comfortable do you feel discussing gender? How comfortable do you feel discussing sexuality? How comfortable do you feel discussing religion and/or spirituality? How comfortable do you feel discussing ability? How comfortable do you feel discussing age? How am I being? What do I want? What is my truth? What listening skills can I activate? What am I responsible for? How can I stay in alignment? Identity is shaped by multiple factors Individual characteristics Family dynamics Historical factors Social and political context Much of my identity is determined by who the world around me says that I am? (i.e. Who do my parents, peers, teachers, neighbors, the media, the culture say that I am?) 'The looking glass self' Charles Cooley Other people are the mirror by which I see myself This is a multidimensional reflection of myself The social, cultural, and historical context is the ground in which individual identity is embedded - Erik Erickson Identity formation is a process 'located within the core of the individual and yet in the core of their communal culture' We must then integrate our past, present, and future into a cohesive unified self over the life course. In the US, there are several categories of 'otherness' commonly experienced by people in our society. These categories are based on the following characteristics: Race or ethnicity Gender Religion Sexual orientation Socioeconomic status Age Physical or mental ability In relation to otherness there is always a form of oppression connected to the various categories (i.e. racism, sexism, heterosexism, classism, etc.) In every case there is a group considered dominant - systemically advantaged by society and a group considered subordinate or targeted (systemically disadvantaged) Inequitable social relationships are seen as the model for 'normal human relationships' I am from... (place, landscape, familiar, sights, smells growing up) I am from (traditions, music you remember growing up) I am from (ancestors, relatives, people in your life now, nonviolence heroes and sheroes) Multicultural counseling and therapy can be defined as both a helping role and a process that uses modalities and defines goals consistent with the life experiences and cultural values of clients; recognizes client identities to include individual, group, and universal dimensions; advocates the use of universal and culture-specific stratefies and roles in the helping process; and balances the importance of individualism and collectivism in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of client and client systems. (Sue & Torrino, 2005) Traditionalist Universalist Perspective (1960s - 1970s) Gender Perspective (late 1970s - early 1980s) Cultural Perspective (late 1980s - present) Family Therapy Redefined (?)
Culture: A system or web of shared meaning, shared understanding, and shared sense making. How do the relationships between fender, race, ethnicity, disability, sexuality, class, nationality, and other identifications impact an individual as they experience the world and have daily encounters?
Cultural Competence The awareness, knowledge and skills needed to function effectively with culturally diverse populations.
Cultural Humility A complementary component to cultural competence associated with an open attitudinal stance or a multiculturally open orientation to work with diverse clients.
Cultural Responsiveness An approach that takes into consideration and responds to the cultural values, lifestyles, strengths and assets of the client as they interact with the wider society.
Worldview Composed of people's attitudes, values, and beliefs that affect how people think, define events, make decisions, and behave.

item.title: @mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Book Title: Re-visioning family therapy: addressing diversity in clinical practice, Editor: McGoldrick, Monica; Hardy, Kenneth V.; Publisher: Guilford Press, Location: New York, NY, Year: 2019 ISBN: 978-1-4625-3973-4 "A leading text for courses that go beyond the basics of family systems theory, intervention techniques, and diversity, this influential work has now been significantly revised with 65% new material. The volume explores how family relationships--and therapy itself--are profoundly shaped by race, social class, gender, religion, sexual orientation, and other intersecting dimensions of marginalization and privilege. Chapters from leading experts guide the practitioner to challenge assumptions about family health and pathology, understand the psychosocial impact of oppression, and tap into clients' cultural resources for healing. Practical clinical strategies are interwoven with theoretical insights, case examples, training ideas, and therapists' reflections on their own cultural and family legacies"-- Provided by publisher Keywords: Need to Read
