item.title: 4. Beginning to Think Systemically - Family Systems Theory
item.description:
Circular Questioning A method of interviewing developed by the Milan Associates in which questions are asked that highlight differences among family members. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) "A person cannot do right in one department of life while attempting to do wrong in another department." - Gandhi What is a system? A set of objects (elements) that interrelate to form a whole Closed System: no interchange with its environment (doesn't apply to social systems) Open System: One that receives matter and energy from its environment (applies to communication). Consists of: Objects, or parts, elements, or members of the system These parts may be physical or abstract. System consists of attributes. Internal relationships among its objects (mutual effects). An environment. They are affected by their surroundings. Wholeness and Interdependence: In a system, the whole is more than the sum of its parts. It is a product of the forces or interactions among its parts. It's parts cannot be understood separately. The interdependence creates organization in the system (e.g., a family).
Hierarchy: Systems tend to be embedded within one another. Every complex system consists of subsystems. Given that systems are within systems, it is fuzzy as to where to locate the boundary between the system and the environment. Interchange with the Environment: Inputs and outputs. The system affects and is affected by the environment.
Balance (Homeostasis) Self-maintenance Sensing deviations from the norm and correcting those 'faults.' Self-Regulation and Control: Systems are often viewed as goal-oriented. They are governed by their purposes. The parts operate according to guidelines and adapt to the environment on the basis of feedback. This aspect of system functioning is cybernetics. Change and Adaptability: The system must adapt to its environment. Equifinality: A particular final state may be achieved in different ways. Family as a System:
This model of a family as a system is extrapolated from the work of Ludwig von Bertalanffy and his General Systems Theory. Holons: A single cell is made up of holons, just as a family is made up of individuals.
Cybernetics:
First-Order Cybernetics (1940s-1960s): Concepts:
Homeostasis Control of the Observed Mechanism
Self-Steering
Information vs. Noise Major Assumptions: Modern vs. Post Modern Level of analysis is the family or larger context. The observer remains outside the system. There is a particular way families 'should' behave. Reality is objective.
Second-Order Cybernetics (1960s-1980s): Concepts:
Stability vs. Homeostasis Interaction with (vs. control of) mechanism Observer's implication in the system Major Assumptions: Main difference is that the observer is a part of the system. Reality is self-referential (i.e., everything we know and see is based on our personal frame of reference). No reference to an outside environment. More to a System: Bounded:
A cell has a 'Feedback Loop,' enabling information to be transferred throughout the cell. All families have such a loop or Process for communicating. Interdependent: All holons are interdependent on each other. Change one and you change the system. The same holds true of individuals in the family system.
Homeostasis: All cells expend energy to maintain a steady state or homeostasis. This explains the difficulty of change within family systems. This thinking moves from linear causality to a more multi-dimensional approach to families. From A->B->C to interconnections between A, B, and C. Core Concepts: Problems: Understanding Problems: Your Clinical Theory Learning Problems vs. Problems about Learning Problems as Bad Solutions Problems arising from childhood wounds, outmoded, limiting coping styles Problems arising from Larger Societal Changes (and Issues) The Presenting Problem: A presenting problem is an initial symptom that causes a person to seek professional help. Describe the reason the client came to you. Include the client's definition of their problem. How long they've been experiencing the issue. Process: Understanding Process:
Content: Stories about what happened; shared at length and with extraneous details
Process: Access the client's internal experience and working through parts of it. Process Questions in Therapy:
When a client is discussing something important to them tell the initial story and listen until your client invites you to help them. Otherwise, and after initial sessions you should mostly ask 'Process' questions that: Focus on the client themselves and their internal experience Help the client 'slow down' and reflect on ideas or feelings that seem significant Use immediacy to ask about emotions you're noticing in a moment Focus on themes, patterns, and affect Example of Process Questions in Therapy: "What is it like for you when..." "I might be off here, but were you feeling... in that moment?" When you notice heightened emotion, you can ask, "What's coming up for you right now?", "How are you feeling, talking to me about this?" "What do you wish other people knew about what you are experiencing?" "Today or in our previous sessions, have you found yourself thinking 'I wish they'd ask me about....?" "What question do you need someone to ask you, that no one has?" "How did that make you feel about yourself, about your partner, about the relationship?" "What you just mentioned about X seems important, at least to me. Could we slow down and stay with this idea/feeling for a moment?" Patterns: Observable repeated behavior, thoughts, or interaction that often manifest in human interaction and may manifest in therapy sessions. For example, a client may have a patter of shutting down emotionally or becoming distracted whenever you approach painful material. Writing a Systemic Hypothesis: Circular Questioning: Circular questioning is a technique used in systemic family therapy to 'invite participants in a conversation to consider relational aspects of the topic being investigated.' Ask open questions to explore communication and relationship patterns Types of Circular Questions: Bridging the Past: Circular questions bridge the past and the present together to find a moment in time when a shift in the family occurred. If this moment can be identified, it can give clues as to how to help the family. Has conflict always happened like this in your family? What was it like before? When did it start happening like this? Thirds: Circular questioning often asks a third person for their thoughts on how a dyad operates. This often breaks an unspoken rule in families that states, 'We don't comment about others.' This technique invites reflection on how two people's actions impact the behavior or mood of another. These questions are often used to assess how families respond to their members in different situations. "Dad, when Son is showing signs of depression, what do you see Mom do?" "Mom, when Dad is taking care of Son, what do you think Dad gets out of?" Differences: When a behavior occurs or a significant change occurred different family members reacted in different ways. Circular questions help us understand the different ways people reacted and from that we can gauge how close people are, or how distant, enmeshment, and various other ideas. How is this different than before? Who is most likely to comfort...? Who is least likely? Has this always been true? Resistance: Being a Common Factors Informed Therapist:
Common Factors in Psychotherapy: Active therapeutic factors that appear to account for the majority of treatment outcomes in over 400 forms of psychotherapy theoretical models and are applicable and effective in the treatment of various psychiatric conditions. (Lambert, 1992, analysis) Client Factors (40%) Relationship Factors (30%) Placebo Factors (15%) Treatment Factors (15%) Contributions of specific and general effects on therapy outcomes (Wampold, 2001) General Effects (70%) Unexplained Variance (in part client variables 22%) Specific Effects (8%) Percentage of Improvement in Therapy Clients as a Function of Therapeutic Factors (Asay and Lambert, 1999) Client Variables and Extra-Therapeutic Events (40%) The Therapeutic Relationship (30%) Expectancy and Placebo Effects (15%) Technique and Model Factors (15%)
Big View of Common Factors: Client characteristics Therapist characteristics Therapeutic Relationship Expectancy Non-Specific Mechanisms of Change - Interventions that cut across all models Other mediating and moderating factors Common Factors Research in Couple and Family Therapy When two or more treatments compared to each other are designed based on a sound theory about how people change, and treatment sessions are structured to target those theoretical change processes (i.e., active treatments), there are typically very few differences in patient outcomes. Evidence-based research on common factors has shown that relationship factors in a therapeutic dyad or group setting predict the outcome of psychotherapy. Couple and Family Therapy Common Factors: Conceptualizing Difficulties in Relational Terms Disrupting Dysfunctional Relational Patterns Expanding the Direct Treatment System Expanding the Therapeutic Clinical Implications of Common Factors: Practice professional modesty Choose a model you believe in Practice your model flexibly Get honest feedback Capitalize on CFT Specific Common Factors
The Cycle of Change Precontemplation: A logical starting point for the model, where there is no intention of changing behavior; the person may be unaware that a problem exists Contemplation: The person becomes aware that there is a problem, but has made no commitment to change. Preparation: The person is intent on taking action to correct the problem; usually required buy-in from the client (i.e., the client is convinced that the change is good) and increased self-efficacy (i.e., the client believes they can make a change) Action: The person is in active modification of behavior. Maintenance: Sustained change occurs and new behavior(s) replaces old ones. Per this model, this stage is also transitional. Relapse: The person falls back into old patterns of behavior. Upward Spiral: Each time a person goes through the cycle, they learn from each relapse and (hopefully) grow stronger so that relapse is shorter or less devastating Specific Factors: Elements clearly delineated by proponents of a given therapy as the active causes of change. Empirically Supported Relationships: Therapeutic interventions that possess empirical support for the efficacy of the therapeutic relationship, client values and beliefs, and the working alliance between client and therapist.

item.title: Lecture on Structural Family Therapy
item.description:
Family is depicted as a system that comprised of Subsystem. A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world.
Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid). Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged. Major Concepts: Family
Family Structure Structure Predictable sequences or organized patterns in which families interact A set of rules governing behavior patterns Structures typically have some form of hierarchical structure. Reciprocal and complementary functions. Parental involvement with children, over versus under involvement. Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system. Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective.
Power Alliances
Structure: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact.
Subsystem: Subsystems are often formed based on the patterns of interactions in a family. Patterns of interaction are largely based on roles and rules. Covert coalitions are often more significant than obvious groupings. Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers.' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling
Boundaries Each subsystems is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries. Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse.
Rigid Boundaries (Disengaged Subsystem)
Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in Disengagement. Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support. Diffuse Boundaries (Enmeshed Subsystem):
Diffuse boundaries are result in Enmeshment. Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness can cripple initiative.
Coalition
Patterns
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system)
Triangles
Loyalties Assumptions: The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed. The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant. Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent. Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. Exploring dynamics of interaction. Recognizing the overall organizations of the family regulates those interactions. The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regulate contact between members. The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions. Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics. Theoretical Formulations: Basic assumption is that families are organized structurally in certain ways to cope with stress. Organized patterns ensure the survival of the system, all patterns have this purpose. Systems both responds and reacts to internal and external stressors. Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs. All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival. Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses. The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to each other. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Healthy families not defined by the abundance of problems. But rather by a functioning structure Healthy families can modify their structure to accommodate changing circumstances. Unhealthy families increase rigidity of structures that are no longer functional. Less adaptive families increase rigidity of structures and are no longer functional. Problems arise when there are: Weak hierarchies; conflict avoidance; cross-generational coalitions Inflexible structures Failure to adjust to changing circumstances Failure to reorganize themselves in order to deal with stresses in the home environment. The ultimate goal of therapy is structural changes to the family Alter the family structure so that the family can solve its own problems. General goal: create or strengthen executive subsystem Therapists have two types of assessment tools:
Enactment Spontaneous behavior sequences Enactments occur when a therapist stimulates a family to demonstrate how they handle problems Therapists guide the family how to modify the enactment, creating new behavior sequences. Joining and accommodating (effective therapy requires challenge and confrontation) "The structural therapist needs to relate to family members in a way that validates their experience but does not preclude a challenge to the status quo." Working with interaction (Use of enactments) Mapping structural patterns (Observing enmeshment and disengagement) Focus on the underlying family structure: Highlight and modify interactions Intensity (interrupt rigid and difficult patters) "Challenging to be effective must be predicated on the client's strengths. Contrary to a common misconception, it is not the 'opposite' of joining. Joining and challenging need to be seen as simultaneous qualities in any therapeutic intervention." Help people do things themselves Therapists can invite family members to participate and interact in ways that will Help them function more efficiently Transformation of family structure
Boundary Making Loosen boundaries in disengaged families Strengthen boundaries in enmeshed families Unbalancing
Reframing (adding cognitive constructions) Unbalancing Blocking Stopping usual transactions Exaggerating Encouraging or sustaining interactions Keeping silent When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one, thereby demanding the family to react. Manipulating the intensity Therapist's comfort level with intense emotions
Enactment
Complementarity Summarize the cycle of interaction and clarify the systemic nature of the symptoms, relieve blame from any one person, and direct the way to change.

item.title: Lecture on Narrative Therapy
item.description:
Modernism vs. Postmodernism: Postmodernism was a response in many ways to modernism and, hence, they can be considered to be two aspects of the same movement. But there are major differences between modernism and postmodernism. Two central tenets of the Enlightenment (beginning of the 'modern' period) were as follows: The perfectibility of human nature The belief in human progress through the development of human knowledge, especially the sciences. In the 20 th century, scientific findings, like quantum physics, seriously undermined the possibility of a deterministic model of the world. As a guiding principle, reason was still affirmed as was the belief in human progress. The project of modernism was to examine the impediments still holding society back. Individuals ceased to believe that art and literary works bore one unique meaning; rather, postmodernists believed in deriving their own meanings from works of art and literature. Modernism: It was an emancipatory project whose main idea was that traditional values and institutions were oppressive, divisive and inefficient and should, therefore, be replaced by rational values and institutions. Modernism led to progress in many spheres of life by changing the approach of mankind towards culture. Ultimately, modernism attempted to free humanity from its historical baggage through the use of philosophy and science. Postmodernism: Postmodernism was a reaction to modernism and was influenced by disenchantment brought on by the second world war. Postmodernism refers to the state that lacks a central hierarchy and one that is complex, ambiguous, and diverse. Postmodernists are the nihilists. Postmodernists like Heidegger, Derrida, and Lyotard attacked the modernist belief in rationality, objectivity and universalism in favor of relativism (the view that there is no objective truth) as well as identity. Grand narratives like freedom, societal progress, scientific progress were criticized by postmodernists, who instead emphasized that difference, rather than forced unity, should be celebrated. Postmodernism is a backlash against modernity. The collapse of tradition created a frightening situation whereby meaning became difficult to discern amid the horror of societal breakdown. Postmodernism, hence, represented a loss in faith in human reason. Postmodernism provides a bleak prognosis of the human condition and offers no real solutions. Conclusion: - Modernism and postmodernism were both movements that emerged from an analysis of events within the modern period from the perspective of the values of the Enlightenment. Postmodernism: Theory that knowledge of things are not real unless we give them meaning. The sense of self is a social construct. Our identity is created by interactions with other people and our reactions to society. Two threads: Weak (Social Constructionism): Proposes that social constructs are dependent on brute facts (most basic and fundamental facts and do not rely on other facts). Institutional facts are created by social conventions and rely on other facts. Strong (Social): The whole of reality is dependent on social habits. All knowledge is a social construct and there are no brute facts. It would say we created the idea of something and how to explain it. Main criticism: Does not take into consideration the effect of natural phenomenon that goes on in society. Social constructionism only explains reality through the thoughts of humans, not by using fundamental brute facts.
Michael White
David Epston
Gene Combs
Jill Freedman Knowledge is constructed. Therapy is concerned with the ways people interpret their behavior rather than how they behave. Experience is understood in interpretation and meaning making. Experiences can have multiple interpretations. The Narrative Metaphor: Focuses on self-defeating cognitions - the stories people tell themselves about their problems. \Problems affect people. Problems operate on people rather than problems being things people are doing. For clients to maintain their new narratives, they need supportive communities. Hence letter writing, outsider witness, reflecting teams. The truth of experience is not DISCOVERED, it is CREATED. Narrative accounts affect people's perceptions, stories don't just mirror life, they shape it. Instead of trying to solve problems, the focus is on enriching the narratives of people's lives - bringing forth 'thick descriptions' of those aspects of people's narratives that life outside the influence of problems. Alternative stories allow people to live out new identities, new possibilities for relationships, and new future. People find meaning in their lives by experiencing, telling, and circulating stories of un-stories aspects of their lives and relationships. Dominant discourses are socially constructed within our culture. We 'story' and create meaning of life events using available dominant discourses - broad social stories, practices, assumptions, and expectations about how we should live. 'Problems': Experienced when a person's personal life does not fit with these societal discourses and expectations. Process involves separating the person from the problem. Understanding Oppression: Dominant vs. Local Discourses Dominant discourses are culturally generated stories about how life should go. Local discourses occur in our heads, our closer relationships, and marginalized communities. Narrative therapists help clients become aware of how these different discourses are impacting their lives. Avoid judgements about what is 'normal.' Avoid categorizing. Avoid the idea of general principles of what causes problems or what resolves them. The stories people tell themselves. Interpret their experience in unhelpful ways. Patterns of tunnel vision. Problem-saturated stories take hold and encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story. Separate the problem-saturated stories to open space for: New and more constructive views of themselves. Look for unique outcomes 'Sparking events' Deconstruction: View the problem as an external entity to start challenging its influence. Unique Outcomes: Resistance to the problem's influence Opens room for counter stories Involves finding new ways to view, interact with, and respond to problems by defining the role of the problems in their lives. Broadly involves the following phases: Meeting Listening Separating persons from problems Enacting preferred narratives Solidifying Process thickens and enriches a person's identity and life accounts. Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time. At the end of each meeting, the therapists asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how? Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when? Meetings are typically 60 minutes Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between) Collaborative Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem Takes notes of what works and what doesn't Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation Meeting the person apart from the problem Separating people from problems: The problem is the problem Optimism and hope Co-author/co-editor Investigate reporter Problem-saturated stories Unique outcomes and sparkling events Dominant cultural and gender discourses Local and alternative discourses: Attending to client language and meaning Holds a position of curiosity. Cherishes each person/family's unique stories. Invite clients to develop and live out narratives that they prefer for their lives Is decentered, not an expert, but an interested collaborator. They are skilled at asking questions to bring forth the knowledge and experience carried in particular stories of the family. Narrative Therapy Principles: Therapist influential, but decentered. Person separate from problem. All problems have exceptions. Opposite of problem is preferred. Preferred story woven into identity. Impact of relationships explored. Deconstruct societal norms. Personal decision making supported. Instead of having a problem or being a problem, clients are struggling against their problems. The problem is the problem. Aren't interested in problem-maintaining sequences (strategic), structural issues (structural), or solutions (solution-focused), they are interested in the problem's impact on the family.
Social Constructionism: There is no absolute truth, instead shift toward deconstructing (reexamining) established truths that oppress people's lives. People have good intentions (they do not need or want problems). People are profoundly influenced by the discourses around them. People are not their problems. People can develop alternative empowering stories once separated from their problems and the cultural myths they have internalized. Therapist is interested in families' own evaluations of what is problematic and what is preferred. Clients name how the problem is affecting their lives and relationships. Therapist invites people to bring their 'best selves' into consideration of the problems that diminish their relationship and an exploration of how they might choose ways of living that diminish the effect of the problems on their relationship. Reject categorizing people. In the spirit of collaboration, the therapist situates themselves WITH clients. They disclose the beliefs that inform their therapy so that clients can know what they're getting into. Clients are encouraged to educate the therapist on their cultural predicaments and to correct the therapist when they make assumptions that don't fit for the client's experience. Problems are likely to persist as long as unhelpful stories remain fixed and obscure other more helpful versions of events. Cautious about applying terminology (diagnosis). Want to hear the family's stories of how the problems they name affect their lives and relationships. When one of these problems appears to have invaded a relationship, it is the therapist's responsibility to ask questions that invite family members to consider the effects of that problem on their relationship, and to consider the stand they want to take in relation to it. Problems are things that are separate from the families they afflict. Therapists look for problematic discourses and offer families the opportunity to describe and evaluate the effects of those discourses on their relationships and lives. Problem-saturated stories encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story Problems may be regarded as alien invaders Separate from problem-saturated stories (and destructive cultural assumptions) Open space for new and more constructive views of themselves. Separate individuals from problems and unite the family to fight a common enemy Search for unique outcomes (sparkling events, exceptions) - times when they resisted the problem or behaved in ways that contradicted the problem story. Help clients deconstruct unproductive stories in order to reconstruct new and more productive ones.
Deconstruction involves questioning assumptions
Reconstruction involves creating new and more optimistic accounts of experience Effects Questions: Elicit effects of the problem "How does the problem affect you? Your ideas about yourself? Your relationship?" "Clients can begin to notice areas of their lives where the problem has been less powerful." Identifying unique outcomes creates room for counterplots Telling and retelling, witnessing, and living out of multistoried lives. Once people notice how their stories are problem saturated and try to change their narratives, what they do and perceive will change as well. Facilitate this process by asking questions to highlight un-storied events and to encourage meaning making around those events, then tie the meaning to memorable actions and contexts. Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time At the end of each meeting, the therapist asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how? Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when? Meetings are typically 60 minutes Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between) CAUTION: Often therapy invites people to re-immerse themselves in their most problematic stories INSTEAD: narrative therapy invite families to explore, describe, and experience new directions in life that are already unfolding - new positions, new stories Counterstory Asking permission is central to the model At the start of the first meeting, the therapist ask if it would be okay to get to know the family in ways that have nothing to do with the problem before they describe what brought them to therapy. Later meetings often start by the therapist reading their notes from the previous session aloud and asking question, such as: Can you tell me about new developments that relate to what we were talking about last time Other times the therapist begins by wondering whether there have been important thoughts or events that connect to possibilities identified in the previous conversations Therapists use letters, documents, and videos to document and circulate alternative stories. For example, after a therapy session a therapist may write a letter posing questions that invite the family to develop an alternative story even further than they did in the session Or sending a document noting the stands the family has taken in regard to a problem Reading a document between sessions, and the conversations that can follow a reading, keeping a story alive and growing Collaborative Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem. With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem. Takes note of what works and what doesn't Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation Therapy is a relationship - a conversation Ask questions to expose gaps in problematic stories Open space for describing alternatives Invite families to add, subtract, or describe differently Encourage families to ask questions about the therapist's questions and comments The therapist wants the family to make meaning of their own experience, but the therapist's questions inevitably shape the inquiry. Families are in a better position to interpret, making meaning of, and evaluate their own experiences than outsiders are, even trained outsiders Therapists have more questions than answers It sounds as though problem is part of your life now. How long have you been noticing this problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? How does the problem impact your relationships? Does problem have an impact on your relationship with other family members? What do you think about the effects the problem is having on your life? Are you accepting what problem is doing? Are these effects acceptable to you or not? Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what problem is doing? How would you prefer things to be? People's lives are multi-storied, each new telling of a story generates new possibilities for making meaning and taking action. The therapist invites family members to: Evaluate their current situation Name the problems involved Evaluate their relationship to those problems Take a stand in regard to them Tell more satisfying stories of their lives Evaluate the usefulness of the alternative stories In telling and living out the newly developed strands of alternative stories, clients evaluate aspects of their lives. Private hopes and fears Family interactions Contributions of culture of origin Traditions, legacies Questioning: Is that the problem speaking? Whose values are guiding you in saying that? By exposing discouses that support problems, families can separate from the ways of being that are supported by those discourses, and identify and recognize preferred perceptions, attitudes, and actions. What name would you give the problem? What is it like to experience the problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other? What talks have you have about the problem in your family? What impacts has that had? What effects does the problem have on your other relationships? How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself? Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not? Are we talking about what you want to be talking about? Is this conversation useful? How is it useful? Externalizing conversations Relatice influence questions Who's in charge, the person or the problem? Identifying unique outcomes Reading between the lines of the problem story Can you remember a time... Reauthoring What does it say about you... Illuminating or creating the counter-story Reinforcing the new story Finding audiences, supportive witnesses, allies Letter writing Deconstructing destructive cultural assumptions Listen to stories as stories. Be attentive and responsive to their intended meaning in telling the story. Ask about non-problematic aspects of the life of family members and of their relationship. Make sure the problem does not trick us into mistaking 'them' for 'the problem.' Unless families insist on moving quickly into talking about problems, spend a while listening to stories about their preferences. At some point, families spontaneously start to tell problem saturated stories. Try to put yourself in their shoes. Do not assume you understand the meaning their experience holds for them Listen and ask Listen with focused attention, patience, and curiosity while building a relationship of mutual respect and trust. Listen 'deconstructively' to family stories - the listening is guided by the belief that those stories have many possible meanings. Ask families to tell their stories, look for opportunities to reflect our sense of what they said, they are saying, and to ask whether the meaning we are making fits with their intended meaning. We wonder aloud whether they are useful or desirable? And, what difference it makes to think of it 'that way'? Cultivate an awareness of the dominant (and dominating) stories in our society/ Develop ways of collaboratively examining the effects of those stories when we sense them at work win the lives and relationships of the families with whom we consult. There are 'taken-for-granted' realities at play. Deconstructive questions aim to examine problems in detail and expose discourses that suppose them, as well as those that might undermine those discourses. The person/family is not the problem; the problem is the problem. Externalizing - problems are seen as separate from people. As we listen to people's stories, we listen for the ways they refer to their problems in their lives. If we hear names like 'fear' or 'blowing up,' we orient to those things as entities or processes that are external to families. If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them. What would you call that something? What 'feeds' the problem? What 'starves' the problem? In what settings might the problem be useful? Who advocates for the problem? What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions? What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships? Naming a problem can open a way for examining it and thinking differently about it. As we ask people to evaluate their relationship to problems, they often tell us what they would prefer to have in their lives in place of the problem. What are the family's preferred directions? 'Standing against' the problem. Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes? Is the problem always with you? Listen for purposes, values, hopes, and commitments that are absent but implicit in family's narratives. Double listening. If a person experiences despair, they must have hopes, dreams, or visions of the future that are not being fulfilled. If a person experiences injustive, they must have a conception of a just world. When we hear problematic stories, we listen for these sorts of implications. Stories need listeners as well as tellers. Attentive witnesses. The therapist serves as a witness, but including other witnesses, especially those involved in people's lives, can be very helpful. What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying? What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking? It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions. Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care? What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them? Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who then amplify and accredit the stories that they witness. What stood out for them? What images it brought forward? How it resonated with their own experiences? Where they were transported by the interview? Situate their reflections in their own experience. Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives. We are interested in documenting and circulating the new stories that emerge in therapy to thicken them and keep them alive. We take notes in therapy to document new stories as they develop. We often refer back to these notes and read them aloud. We may create videos or documents about what they have learned, with their permission, that can be viewed or read by others facing similar problems. We sometimes write letters between therapy sessions. In these letters, we ask questions that we did not ask in the therapy session. Our intention in letter writing is to thicken and extend the knowledge that has begun to emerge in session. We might invite the family to share these documents with other people in their lives. Opening space questions (unique outcomes) Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but didn't? Preference questions (preferred experiences) Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how? Story development questions How is this different from when arguing is in control? Meaning questions What does it say about you that you were able to...? Questions that extend the story into the future What do you predict...? Aims to separate the individual from the issue and externalize problems instead of internalizing them. Reality is socially constructed. Reality is influenced by and communicated through language. Having a narrative can help us organize and maintain our reality. There is no 'objective reality' or absolute truth. Telling One's Story: A technique that involves re-telling your own story to find new meaning in old experiences. Externalization Technique: Externalizing helps you separate you from your problems, making it easier to change something you don't like about yourself. Deconstruction Technique: This technique involves breaking problems down into smaller, more specific issues that are easier to understand and address. Unique Outcomes Technique: To help you see from a new, more positive perspective, broaden your view to see more of your own storylines, and focus on one that doesn't include your most pervasive problems. Some families prefer a different kind of therapy than narrative, some are seeking instruction and expert advice. Regularly ask families how the therapy is going for them, and be open and willing to refer families if they are seeking a different kind of relationship. Most families coming to therapy are concerned less with how the therapy is structured than with whether their family relationships improve Emphasis on 'practice-based evidence' over evidence-based practice More qualitative research rather than quantitative studies Little empirical support currently exists Randomized controlled trials of narrative therapy do not yet exist.

item.title: Robert MacGregor
item.description:
Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) was pioneered by him. It is an intensive, crisis oriented form of family therapy where family members are treated in subgroups by a team of therapists. His clinic served a population that was scattered widely over southeastern Texas, and clients had to travel hundreds of miles.
He developed Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) in 1967 at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston. He wanted the maximum impact in a short amount of time. He worked intensively with families for two days. His team approach is a hallmark in the family therapy field.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/People in CFT/Robert MacGregor.md

item.title: @satirNewPeoplemaking1988
item.description:
Bibliography: Satir, V. (1988). The New Peoplemaking. Type: Book Title: The New Peoplemaking Author: Satir, Virginia Keywords: #In-Progress #Virginia-Satir To understand the world, we can study the family: issues such as power, intimacy, autonomy, trust, and communication skills are vital parts underlying how we live in the world. To change the world is to change the family. Family life is something like an iceberg: most people are aware of only about one-tenth of what is going on - the tenth that they can see and hear. Just as a sailor's fate depends on knowing that the bulk of the iceberg is under the water, so a family's fate depends on understanding the feelings and needs that lie beneath every family events. (What goes on under the table?) Over the years I have developed a picture of what human beings living humanly are like. They are people who understand, value, and develop their bodies, finding them beautiful and useful. They are real and honest to and about themselves and others; they are loving and kind to themselves and others. People living humanly are willing to take risks, to be creative, to manifest competence, and to change when the situation calls for it. They find ways to accommodate what is new and different, keeping that part of the old that is still useful and discarding what is not. The family is the context in which a person with such dimensions developers. And the adults in charge are the peoplemakers. Four aspects of family life: The feelings and ideas one has about oneself, which I call self-worth. The ways people use to work out meaning with one another, which I call communication. The rules people use for how they should feel and act, which eventually develop into what I call the family system. The way people relate to other people and institutions outside the family, which I call the link to society. In all the troubled families I noticed that: Self-wroth was low Communication was indirect, vague, and not really honest Rules were indirect, nonnegotiable, and everlasting The family's link to society was fearful, placating, and blaming In all nurturing families, I consistently see a different pattern: Self-worth is high Communication is direct, clear, specific, and honest Rules are flexible, human, appropriate, and subject to change The link to society is open and hopeful, and is based on choice The changes all rest on new learnings, new awareness, and a new consciousness. Everyone can achieve these. Families everywhere deal with the same issues. In all families... Every person communicates; the question is, How, and what happens as a result? Every person follows rules; the question is, What kind, and how well do they work for them? Every person is linked to society; the question is, In what way, and what are the results? Natural Family The man and woman who sired and conceived the child continue to care for that child until the child is grown One-Parent Family One parent leaves the family by death, divorce, or desertion, and all of the parenting is done by the remaining parent Blended Family Children are parented by step-, adoptive, foster, or gay parents Institutional Family Groups of adults rear groups of children, as in institutions, communes, or extended families The same forces will be at work in all families: Self-Worth Communication Rules Links to Society People are always doing the best they can. Developing a family is the hardest, most complicated job in the world. The very fact that you are reading this tells me that you care about yourself and the well-being of your family. Knowing something begins a change; experiencing makes it happen. If you feel shy or doubtful about inviting family members to participate in these exercises with you, become thoroughly familiar with what you are asking, feel it from your heart, and present your wish simply and directly. "Will you participate with me in an experiment that I think might be useful to use?" You maximize the opportunity for a positive response. Badgering, demanding, or nagging people to go along turns the transaction into a power struggle.
(I think this may be refer to the Battle for Structure and the Battle for Initiative) I see two kinds of pain: Pain of recognition of problems Pain of blame The first we can't avoid; the second we can. We can direct our effects to change what we can and to work out creative ways to live with what we can't change.
Serenity Prayer Grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, courage to change the things I can, and wisdom to know the difference. Does it feel good to you to live in your family right now? Do you feel you are living with friends, people you like and trust, and who like and trust you? Is it fun and exciting to be a member of your family? Family that is more or less troubled does not mean you have a bad family. It only means that people aren't very happy and have not learned ways to love and value one another openly. Families can be placed somewhere along a scale from 'very nurturing' to 'very troubled' The atmosphere in a troubled family is easy to feel. I quickly sense discomfort. Sometimes it feels cold. Sometimes it feels as if everything were constantly spinning, like a top; I get dizzy and can't find my balance. Or it may be an atmosphere of foreboding, like the lull before a storm, when thunder may crash and lightning strike at any moment. Sometimes I feel very sad and cannot find an obvious reason. I realize that's because the sources are covered up. I begin to understand why so many members of troubled families were beset with physical ills. Their bodies were simply reacting humanly to a very inhuman atmosphere. Everybody has physical reactions to individuals around him or her. The first step of change is to recognize what is happening. There is little evidence of friendship among individual family members, little joy in one another. The family seems to stay together through duty, with people just trying to tolerate one another. More often humor is caustic, sarcastic, even cruel. The adults are so busy telling the child and each other what to do and what not to do that they never get to enjoy themselves as persons. In some families, people simply avoided one another. The family can be the place where one finds love and understanding and support, even when all else fails; where we can be refreshed and recharged to cope more effectively with the world outside. No one would intentionally pick this troubled way of living. Families accept it only because they know of no other way. A nurturing family is where I would be listened to and would be interested in listening to others; I would be considered and would wish to consider others. I could openly show my affection as well as my pain and disapproval. I would not be afraid to take risks because everyone in my family would realize that some mistakes are bound to come with my risk-taking - that my mistakes are a sign that I am growing. I would feel like a person in my own right - noticed, valued, loved, and clearly asked to notice, value, and love others. I would feel free to respond with humor and laughter when it fits. The houses in which these people live tend to have a lot of light and color. Clearly a place where people live, these homes are planned for their comfort and enjoyment, not as showplaces for the neighbors. When there is quiet, it is peaceful quiet, not the stillness of fear and caution. Each person seems to know that they will have the chance to be heard. If one's turn doesn't come now, it is only because there isn't time - not because one isn't loved. People seem comfortable about touching one another and showing their affection, regardless of age. People show their loving and caring by talking openly and listening with concern, being straight and real with one another, and simply being together. Members of a nurturing family feel free to tell each other how they feel. Anything can be talked about. Nurturing families can make plans. If something interferes with the plan, they can readily make adjustments, often with a sense of humor. This way they are able to handle more of life's problems without panicking. Thus the incident would be used as a learning opportunity (which raises the child's self-worth) rather than as a cause for punishment, which puts that self-worth into question. In the nurturing family it is easy to pick up the message that human life and human feelings are more important than anything else. These parents see themselves as empowering leaders, not as authoritative bosses. They see their job primarily as one of teaching their children how to be truly human in all situations. The behavior of these parents matches what they say. How different from the troubled parent who tells the children not to hurt each other, but slaps them whenever displeased. Parents are people; they learn that good leaders are careful of their timing: they watch for an opportunity to talk to their children when they can really be heard. When a child has misbehaved, the father or mother moves physically close to offer support. This helps the offending child overcome fear and guilt feelings and make the best of the teaching the parent is about to offer. We can help make new contacts with others and pave the way for better ways of dealing with each other. Parents in nurturing families know that their children are not intentionally bad. If someone behaves destructively, parents realize some misunderstanding has arisen or someone's self-esteem is dangerously low. They know people learn only when valuing themselves and feeling valued, so they don't respond to behavior in a way that will make people feel devalued. Even when it is possible to change behavior by shaming or punishing, the resulting scar is not easily or quickly healed. When a child must be corrected, nurturing parents rely on being clear: Asking for information, listening, touching, understanding, using careful timing, and being aware of the child's feelings and natural wishes to learn and to please. Children learn from the modeling of direct behavior. Parents in a nurturing family realize problems come along, simply because life offers them, and they will be alert to creative solutions as each new problem appears. Troubled families, on the other hand, put all their energies into the hopeless attempt to keep problems from happening; when they do happen - and, of course, they always do - these people have no resources left for solving the crisis. Nurturing parents realize change is inevitable. They accept change as part of being alive and try to use it creatively to make their families still more nurturing. The human heart is always seeking love. Troubled families make troubled people and thus contribute to the devaluing of self. Giving ourselves full permission to make the family a place to develop people who are more truly human will reflect itself in a safer and more humanly responsive world. We can make the family a real place for developing real people. Each of us is a discovery, and each of us makes a difference. Most of the things that caused families to be troubled are learned after birth. Since they are learned, they can be unlearned, and new things can be learned in their place. You need to recognize that your family sometimes is a troubled family. You need for forgive yourself for past mistakes and give yourself permission to change, knowing that things can be different. Make a decision to change things. Take some action to start the process of change. Whatever may have happened in the past represented the best you knew how to do at the time. Chances are that the causes of your family pain have been invisible to all of you.
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth is a concept, an attitude, a feeling, an image; and it is represented by behavior. When I was a little girl, I lived on a farm in Wisconsin. On our back porch was a huge black iron pot, which had lovely rounded sides and stood on three legs. My mother made her own soap, so for part of the year the pot was filled with soap. When threshing crews came through in the summer, we filled the pot with stew. At other times, my father used it to store manure for my mother's flower beds. We came to call it the "3-S pot." Anyone who wanted to use the pot faced two questions: What is the pot now full of, and how full is it? When people told me about themselves - whether they felt full, empty, dirty, or even 'cracked' - I thought of that old pot. Pot is a plain word in this use, almost a nonsense word. Families often find it easier to express themselves in pot terms and to understand when other people express themselves this way. When I say 'pot,' I mean self-worth or self-esteem. Every person has a feeling of worth, positive or negative. As with my old family pot, the questions are: Is my self-worth negative or positive at this point, and how much of it is there?
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth is the ability to value one's self and to treat oneself with dignity, love, and reality. Anyone who is loved is open to change. The crucial factor in what happens both inside people and between people is one's self-worth, one's pot. Integrity, honesty, responsibility, compassion, love, and competence - all flow easily from people whose self-esteem is high. We feel that we matter, that the world is a better place because we are here. We have faith in our own competence. We are able to ask others for help, yet we believe we can make our own decisions and are, in the end, our own best resources. Appreciating our own worth, we are ready to see and respect the worth of others. We radiate trust and hope. We don't have rules against anything we feel. We also know that we don't have to act on everything we feel. We can choose. Our intelligence directs our actions. We accept all of ourselves as human. Vital people feel high-pot most of the time. But vital people treat these temporary low-pot feelings as just what they are: a crisis of the moment. This crisis might well be the birth pains of some new possibility for us. We may feel uncomfortable at the time but do not have to hide. We know we can emerge from this crisis whole. When people feel they have little worth, they expect to be cheated, stepped on, and depreciated by others. This opens the way to becoming a victim. Expecting the worst, these people invite it and usually get it. To defend themselves, they hide behind a wall of distrust and sink into the terrible feeling of loneliness and isolation. Thus separated from other people, they become apathetic, indifferent toward themselves and those around them. It is hard for them to see, hear, or think clearly, and therefore they tend to step on and depreciate others. People who feel this way build huge psychological walls behind which they hide, and then defend themselves by denying they are doing this. Fear is a natural consequence of this distrust and isolation. Fear constricts and blinds us; it keeps us from risking new ways of solving our problems. Instead, we turn to still more self-defeating behavior. (Fear, incidentally, is always fear of some future thing) As soon as a person confronts or challenges whatever they are afraid of in the present, the fear vanishes. When persons with constant low-pot feelings experience defeat, they often label themselves as failures. After enough of these reactions, the self is vulnerable to drugs, alcohol, or others flights from coping. Feeling low is not the sameas low-pot. Low pot essentially means that when you experience undesireable feelings, you try to behave as though those feelings did not exist. It takes a lot of high self-worth to acknowledge your low feelings. Persons of high self-esteem can feel low. The difference is that people who are feeling low don't label themselves as worthless or pretend that their low feelings do not exist. Nor do they project their feeling on someone else. It makes a big difference whether one condemns one's self or sees this low time as a human condition with which one needs to cope. I shall be frequently calling your attention to this process of coping. Feeling low and not admitting it is a form of lying to yourself and others. Devaluing your feelings this way is a direct link to devaluing yourself, thus deepening the conditions of low pot. Much of what happens to us is the outcome of our attitude. Since it is attitude, we can change it. To build your self-worth: Relax for a moment now. Close your eyes and feel your condition now. How are you feeling about yourself? What has happened or is happening at the moment? How are you responding to what is happening? How are you feeling about how you are responding? If you are feeling tight, give yourself a message of love, physically relax yourself and consciously be in touch with your breathing. Now open your eyes. You will feel stronger as a result. We need a lot of practice to break the taboo against sharing our feelings. An infant coming into the world must rely on experiences with people and their messages about their worth as a person. For the first five or six years, the child's self-esteem is formed almost exclusively by the family. After the child starts school, other influences come into play; the family remains important. Every word, facial expression, gesture, or action on the part of a parent gives the child some message about self-worth. Tonight, when the family has settled around the table for dinner, notice what is happening to your feelings about yourself when other members speak to you. There will be some remarks to which you have no special response. However, you may be surprised to find that even "Pass the potatoes, please" can give you a feeling of or depreciation, depending on the speaker's tone of voice, facial expression, timing (did the message interrupt you, or ignore something you said?), and how good you are feeling about yourself. If you are feeling good about yourself, you may find that you have a lot of options for how you respond. If you are feeling low, however, you might find that your options are limited (see chapter 6 on communication). Halfway through dinner, change the perspective. Listen to what you are saying to others. Try to be in the other's shoes and imagine how you might feel if you were talked to as you are doing now. Would you, for instance, feel loved and valued? Tomorrow night explain this little game to the other members of the family and invite them to join you. It will be helpful to read this chapter aloud before you do this as a family. After dinner, talk together about what you discovered and how you felt. Feelings of worth can flourish only in an atmosphere in which individual differences are appreciated, love is shown openly, mistakes are used for learning, communication is open, rules are flexible, responsibility (matching promise with delivery) is modeled and honest is practiced - the kind of atmosphere found in a nurturing family. Children in troubled families often feel worthless, growing up as they must amid 'crooked' communication, inflexible rules, criticism of their differentness, punishment for their mistakes, and no experience in learning responsibility. Such children are highly at risk of developing destructive behavior toward themselves and/or others. Much of an individual's potential is held in abeyance when this happens. Parents with high self-esteem are more likely to create nurturing families, and low self-worth parents to produce troubled families. The system evolves out of the architects of the family: the parents. I do hold parents responsible for accepting the consequences of their actions and learning to do differently. This is a good first step to improving the whole family situation.
It is possible to raise anyone's Self-Esteem or Self-Worth, no matter what one's age or condition. Since the feeling of low worth has been learned, it can be unlearned, and something new learned in its place. The possibility for this learning lasts from birth to death, so it is never too late. "There is always hope that your life can change, because you can always learn new things."
My Declaration of Self-Esteem Our body language and activities reflect our thoughts and emotions. When we appreciate and love ourselves, our energy builds. When we use this energy positively and harmoniously to make a smoothly running system within each self, it creates a strong foundation from which that self can cope creatively, realistically, and compassionately with what life presents. "When I feel good about myself and life myself, the chances are excellent that I will be able to meet life from a position of dignity, honesty, strength, love, and reality." If a person's feeling toward themselves is one of depreciation, limitation, disgust, or any other negative attitude, the energy becomes diffused and fragmented. The self weakens, becoming a victim defeated by life: "If I do not like myself, I devalue and punish myself. I meet life from a position of fear and impotence, creating a state in which I feel victimized and act according. I punish myself and others blindly. I become interchangeably subservient and tyrannical. I hold others responsible for my actions." A person feels they do not count, feel a constant threat of rejection, and lacks the ability to look at themselves, others, and events in perspective. This is a state of low self-esteem. A person who does not value themselves will expect someone else to be responsible for bestowing that value. This often leads to endless manipulations that usually backfire on both parties. To avoid being against others, people have been taught to love others instead of themselves. This results in self-depreciation. The question also arises, if one does not love self, how can one know how to love others? We have plenty of evidence that loving oneself makes it possible to love others; self-worth and selfishness are not the same. I have found that the first step toward diminishing fear is to acknowledge it openly. Then check your perception: "Is that true?" Fear of Rejection Good human relations and appropriate and loving behavior stem from persons who have strong feelings of self-worth. Simply stated, persons who love and value themselves are able to love and value others and treat reality appropriately. Having a strong sense of self-worth is the way to become more fully human, to having health and happiness, gaining and maintaining satisfying relationships, and being appropriate, effective, and responsible. When one cares for oneself, one will not do anything to injure, degrade, humiliate, or otherwise destroy oneself or another, and will not hold others responsible for one's actions. People who care for themselves would not violate their relationships to others through violence. Those who do not love themselves can easily become instruments of hate and destruction by unscrupulous people. They essentially give away their power, which often leads to emotional slavery. Perpetual placating exemplifies this. The stronger one's self-worth, the easier it is to have and maintain the courage to change one's behavior. The more one values oneself, the less one demands from others. The less one demands from others, the more one can feel trust. The more one trusts oneself and others, the more one can love. The more one loves others, the less one fears them. The more one builds with them, the more one can know them. The more one knows another, the greater is one's bond and bridge with them. Self-worth behavior will thus help end the isolation and alienation between persons, groups, and nations today.
(MA: is this referencing Differentiation of Self?) Fact 1: Everyone has fingerprints and each set of fingerprints is unique, belonging to that person. I really am the only one exactly life me in this whole world. Therefore, I am guaranteed to be different from everyone in some ways
There are seemingly universal patterns in the way people communicate. Over and over again I observed four ways people had of handling the negative results of stress. These four patterns - which I call Placating (Placator), Blaming (Blamer), Super-Reasonable (Computer), and Irrelevant (Distractor) - occurred when one was reacting to stress and at the same time felt one's self-esteem was diminished‚Äî‚Äîthat "the pot got hooked." In addition, the "hooked" one could not say so.

item.title: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy
item.description: He originally was from the field of psychoanalysis. He founded the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute in Philadelphia in 1957. He worked with James Framo, a psychologist in the early family therapy movement, and Geraldine Spark, a social worker. He added ethical accountability to usual therapeutic goals and techniques. He believed neither pleasure nor expediency is sufficient to guide human behavior. He believed family members have to base their relationships on trust and loyalty, and must balance the ledger of entitlement and indebtedness.
