item.title: @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
item.description:
Bibliography: Patterson, J., Williams, L., Edwards, T. M., Chamow, L., & Grauf-Grounds, C. (2018). Essential skills in family therapy: From the first interview to termination (Third edition). The Guilford Press. Contribution:: Author: Patterson, JoEllen Author:: Williams, Lee Author:: Edwards, Todd M. Author:: Chamow, Larry Author:: Grauf-Grounds, Claudia Title: Essential skills in family therapy: from the first interview to termination Year: 2018 Citekey: @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018 Type: Book Publisher: The Guilford Press Location: New York ISBN: 978-1-4625-3343-5**Essential skills in family therapy: from the first interview to termination[!Abstract] This book focuses on students, a pragmatic approach to treatment, regard for multidisciplinary perspectives, and respect for the influence of families on clients. Chapter 1 identifies concerns that new therapists frequently have, such as building confidence in their clinical work. Chapters 2-6 follow the usual time sequence of therapy--from initial contact with clients, to comprehensive assessment, to treatment planning and intervention. Chapters 7-10 deal with specific clinical situations based on presenting problems and the nature of client families. We examine major issues and approaches for working with children and adolescents, older adults, couples, and families that are struggling with serious mental illness. Chapter 11 highlights some common obstacles all therapists encounter, and provides concrete ideas on how to get unstuck when treatment is not progressing. Chapter 12 focuses on an often overlooked part of therapy--termination. In Chapter 13, we conclude the book by looking at emerging issues within family therapy" While family therapy offers a unique and important perspective in clinical work, much of what goes on in treatment shares common assumptions with all therapies. assessing the appropriateness of a family therapy treatment for a specific problem is an essential clinical skill. It is important to be able to recognize when a problem is outside the scope of a family therapist‚Äôs practice (or skill level) and could best be treated by another mental health professional or in tandem with another healthcare professional. A growing focus on treatment teams and multidisciplinary treatment approaches means that therapists must increasingly attend to the biological component of the biopsychosocial model and learn to collaborate with other healthcare professionals. Beginning therapists frequently experience feelings of inadequacy and insecurity about their clinical abilities Therapists and supervisors alike need to see confidence issues from a developmental perspective Paradoxically, the more one learns about how to do therapy, the more one realizes how much one doesn‚Äôt know. Although the intensity of these feelings and the ways of coping will vary from therapist to therapist, every beginning therapist struggles to some degree with these feelings. This disclosure helps the beginning therapist to accept that these struggles are developmentally appropriate rather than a sign of being unsuited for the profession the therapist‚Äìclient relationship is inherently therapeutic. A therapist doesn‚Äôt need to do something for clients to have a positive experience. early experiences in seeing clients often involve a steep learning curve It takes time, however, to gain enough experience so that many situations become familiar. examine if distorted cognitions or unrealistic expectations are contributing to their fears or struggles with confidence. Beginning therapists can struggle with perfectionistic tendencies or critical self-talk The only pathway to becoming an experienced therapist was to go through the learning process that he was going through Experienced clinicians indicated that after 5‚Äì7 years (or about 5,000‚Äì7,000 hours) of clinical experience, they had encountered most clinical issues or problems several times. The intense feelings of anxiety and being overwhelmed that are common in the beginning generally subside after 1‚Äì3 months of seeing clients. Therapists trained in individual therapy generally go through three stages of development when learning to do family therapy. In the first stage, they focus on acquiring the skills necessary to work with families. In the second stage, they learn to apply systemic theory to their clinical work, and in the third, ‚Äúself of the therapist‚Äù stage, they focus on more personal issues in relationship to their clinical work The initial skills stage is characterized by the therapist trying to figure out what to do with clients. This focus then shifts in the theory stage to how to think. In the final stage, the therapist focuses on the use of self in being with a family. Beginning therapists report feeling overwhelmed by the experience. Many report going home after seeing clients and crying, while others report that the stress results in headaches, difficulty sleeping, stomachaches, or changes in appetite. Learning to relax and be present in the therapy room with clients is a good place to start. A solid assessment and effective treatment hinge on the therapist‚Äôs ability to listen and attend to the client‚Äôs story, and to show the client that he or she is understood. Beginners can learn to replace their anxiety about ‚Äúdoing something‚Äù with relaxed curiosity and empathy. This approach leads to useful questions and inquiries, which is where therapy begins. The therapeutic relationship is a necessary but not always sufficient ingredient for change. To be effective, interventions must be rooted in a clear understanding of family dynamics. ‚ÄúI know I should be focusing on the process, but I feel like I‚Äôm stuck in the content.‚Äù Beginning therapists are able to develop good insights and hypotheses, but will have difficulty connecting these pieces together into a coherent picture or treatment plan Many therapists find it helpful to adopt a particular theoretical orientation for conceptualizing cases Explore how the therapist-as-self is both an asset and a liability in therapy. Many of our personal experiences can become catalysts for new ideas and understanding in therapeutic work Therapists‚Äô unresolved issues or ‚Äúgrowth areas‚Äù can become impediments in therapy. The growth and insight derived from working on these issues can provide the perspective necessary to make constructive use of life experiences in therapy. Thinking (or even obsessing) about clients is something that tends to subside with time and experience. One reason for this change is that the therapist gradually gains a greater sense of clinical mastery by virtue of experience. Therapists learn to balance objectivity and emotional involvement with clients. therapists learn how to construct an emotional boundary The potential for burnout among beginning therapists exists because of several factors. Learning to do therapy can be demanding. Therapists have other stressors outside of their clinical work The courses or clinical work may raise personal issues for you as you learn to do therapy. To avoid burnout, practicing good self-care is essential Taking time for yourself seems counterintuitive when faced with an overwhelming number of tasks to accomplish, but the time lost is often made up by being able to work with renewed energy and efficiency. (many therapists are willing to give this advice to their clients but have difficulty following it themselves.) Be willing to set limits. As therapists gain experience, they often will become more willing to set some limits on their availability, giving them some protected time for themselves. You also need a strong social support network Being with family and friends outside the field will allow you to temporarily escape the demands of being a beginning therapist. Connecting and obtaining support from your peers within your program is invaluable Keep the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù in mind and recall the benefits of being a therapist. Keep the following ‚Äòreminders‚Äô at hand:** Becoming a therapist takes time. This is an opportunity for you to be a learner; you are not expected to be an expert. Becoming an effective therapist takes several years of training. Make sure you take care of yourself. Use constructive means for stress reduction. Develop resources for support from other students, peers, and colleagues. Self-doubts are normal. Be patient with yourself, focus on the positive, and pay attention to the developmental tasks of becoming a therapist. Use the skills that brought you to the field. While you are learning lots of new theory and material, continue to pay attention to your intuition, your desire to work with others, and your natural abilities. The first contact is about to take place, and it can easily make or break a future collaboration where healing work can be done. One of the most critical points in the therapeutic experience: the period before therapy ever begins. During this fragile period prospective clients decide if they want to risk going to therapy. It is not uncommon for families to be at their wit's end when they finally decide to seek treatment or are referred and call for an appointment. Chances are they're worn out, fed up, and feeling hopeless. Individual family members may differ remarked For therapists and clients alike, beginning therapy can elicit feelings of fear, excitement, and nervous anticipation. Each client will take you on a different journey. In the first stage, the therapist welcomes the clients to therapy. The goal of this stage is to do introductions and put the clients at ease. Administrative issues are addressed in the second stage. The purpose of this stage is to ensure clients have a clear understanding of the therapy process, including confidentiality, videotaping, and fees. The goal-setting phase. Here the therapist learns what the clients hope to accomplish through therapy. The time devoted to goal setting will also depend on the number of clients being seen. Soliciting everyone‚Äôs perspective on goals within a family will generally take longer than working with an individual. Being able to establish goals for therapy is a realistic expectation. Assessment phase, which typically extends beyond the first interview. Therapist needs to accomplish several important tasks to make the initial interview successful. At each stage of the initial interview, you should be working on building your relationship with your clients. Important assessment information may also come out at any point in the first session, even before the therapist has begun a more formal assessment phase. The most crucial task of therapy is to successfully join with your clients.
- Joining means that clients feel a sense of connectedness with you, which usually arises when they feel you understand, respect, and care about them. Joining is both a technique (developing rapport) and an attitude. - It is the foundation for future work. Failure to successfully join with your clients will hamper all of your efforts, from assessment to treatment.
- Failure to join with clients can lead to Premature Termination (PT) of therapy. - The therapist missed an opportunity to connect with the client and create a safe environment for therapy to take place. - Joining is a process that should be carefully attended to throughout the entire initial interview. - When you begin the session, you should attempt to put your clients at ease given that they are most likely anxious about coming to therapy. - Ideally, you will be able to identify something you have in common with your clients that will help develop a sense of connection. - Joining also takes place at other points throughout the initial interview. - Highlight Reflective listening, maintaining direct eye contact, or leaning forward can also reinforce for your clients that you are interested in them and concerned about what they are saying. Concluding the initial interview with a positive message for your clients can be another way to strengthen your connection. - Highlight Although skills to facilitate joining can be learned - Highlight developing a relationship with another person cannot be reduced to a recipe or set of techniques. - Highlight who you are is the greatest asset you bring to therapy. Your personality, attitudes, life experiences, and compassion become a part of and help create the relationship. - Highlight therapist characteristics can create a barrier to developing a connection. Therapists who have prejudices or negative preconceptions - Highlight about people based on race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, or religious orientation will likely have difficulty establishing a connection with clients who have these characteristics. - Highlight you should be vigilant in assuring that personal issues or prejudices do not interfere with your developing a relationship with your clients. - Highlight One of the early tasks in an initial interview is to address administrative issues so clients understand the therapy process. - Highlight the therapist who is attuned to the process and not just the content when handling administrative issues may discover important opportunities for assessment or even intervention. - Highlight need to be informed not only of the confidential nature of therapy, but also of the possible exceptions to confidentiality - Highlight It is best practice to cover confidentially both orally and in writing with your client. The consent form for treatment - Highlight should include what is and what is not kept confidential in therapy. - Highlight Therapists working with couples and families must also consider how confidentiality among family members will be handled. - Highlight The therapist must address the extent to which information obtained during these individual sessions will be kept confidential or shared with other family members. - Highlight offer clear guidelines as to the bounds of confidentiality at the beginning of therapy. - Highlight You may want to consult with other individuals or institutions connected with particular cases, such as previous therapists, psychiatrists, physicians, teachers, lawyers, courts, or parole officers. - Highlight need to have clients sign a release of information form, - Highlight to permit communication between you and the other parties. - Highlight The signatures of all participants in therapy are required for the release of information. - Highlight If others contact you about your clients, you should not even acknowledge that they are in therapy unless you have obtained the appropriate release of information. - Highlight obtain a written release of information before discussing a case. - Highlight Therapeutic issues may arise when discussing confidentiality with clients. - Highlight You can tell your clients that you regularly consult with your supervisor, and that videotaping allows your supervisor to witness firsthand what happened in therapy. - Highlight ‚Äútwo heads are better than one.‚Äù - Highlight videotaping allows you to review what happened in previous sessions and perhaps have a new insight, - Highlight recording a session gives the therapist the option to replay part of the session for clients. - Highlight You should inform the client who will view the recordings, emphasizing that videotapes are considered confidential information. - Highlight recordings are not kept permanently, but are regularly erased or recorded over. - Highlight Clients should be asked to sign a form giving their consent for videotaping sessions. The form should - Highlight outline the purpose of the videotaping, who will view the recordings, and what will happen to the recordings after therapy is completed. - Highlight Some clients may be reluctant to be videotaped. - Highlight You should carefully explore what is behind their reservations. - Highlight You should pay careful attention to clients who are insistent about not being videotaped given they are the exception rather than the rule. These clients often have sensitive information that they wish to protect or keep secret. - Highlight If therapy will include live supervision or the use of observing/ reflecting teams, discuss this with your clients. - Highlight helpful to allow clients, at their request, to meet supervisors or team members who observe the sessions from behind the one-way mirror. - Highlight It is difficult to assign a monetary value to therapy, and therapists often feel uneasy about charging fees while acting in a helping role. Therapist anxiety about fees can easily be transferred to clients and can create conflict and stress in therapy. Comfort in handling fees will increase with therapeutic experience and confidence in your ability to provide a worthwhile service. - Highlight There is a business aspect of the therapy relationship and discussing fees should be handled in a business-like manner. - Highlight the client is purchasing a service. - Highlight Most programs or clinicians establish a minimum fee and then work within a range. - Highlight ou should discuss acceptable forms of payment, when the fee should be paid, and the fee for late cancellation or ‚Äúno-show‚Äù appointments, if applicable. - Highlight useful to have a written agreement that discusses the fees and policies regarding fees. - Highlight third-party payers limit the number of sessions, or the types of presenting problems or diagnoses they will reimburse. - Highlight If a third-party payer is involved, the therapist should verify insurance coverage at the outset of therapy. Issues that need to be addressed may include provider eligibility, annual deductibles, rate of reimbursement, limitations on the number of sessions, or types of treatments covered. Usually a DSM-5 diagnosis will need to be assigned to the insured patient. - Highlight As with other administrative issues, working out the details for payment can be part of the diagnostic process and help to clarify the family‚Äôs expectations of and responsibilities for therapy. - Highlight Generally, free services tend not to be valued by clients. A fee, even a small one, provides some incentive to make effective use of services. Paying a fee also indicates that the therapy has value to the client. - Highlight therapists may be required to discuss with clients their professional qualifications. - Highlight Many agencies and practitioners have clients read and sign an informed consent statement that generally includes a brief description of what therapy is, including the potential risks, such as being asked to examine painful issues. - Highlight define clients‚Äô expectations for what therapy will accomplish and how it will be conducted. This is essential to ensure that clients‚Äô needs are compatible with what you, as the therapist, can or are willing to offer. - Highlight The first step in defining expectations is to ask your clients what they would like to accomplish through therapy. - Highlight How can I be helpful to you?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat are you hiring me to do? - Highlight Clients hope that you will be able to fix these problems. Individuals will often say what they want to eliminate - Highlight and have a harder time articulating what they want - Highlight If possible, encourage your clients to describe desired changes in positive language (what will be happening) rather than in negative language (what won‚Äôt be happening) - Highlight It is important that each family member is given the opportunity to be heard when discussing problems and goals. This will help in joining with each individual. - Highlight you may discover there is disagreement about the problem itself or who has the problem. - Highlight You don‚Äôt want to anger the person who talks excessively, but if you fail to interrupt this behavior, other family members may lose faith in your ability to lead the session. - Highlight In defining goals, a number of challenges can arise. Your clients may identify multiple problem areas, with little distinction of priorities. - Highlight you will need to obtain your clients‚Äô perspective on the relative importance of their problems. - Highlight ‚ÄúOf the issues you have presented, which is most important, and which is least important?‚Äù - Highlight your clients may not have a clear idea of what the problem is or what their goals for therapy are. - Highlight may need to contract for a limited number of sessions to explore and define problem areas and goals. - Highlight Another potential problem is that clients may have unrealistically high expectations or goals. - Highlight Setting goals may be further complicated by the unstated agenda of a client, one that he or she feels is not appropriate to disclose. - Highlight Sometimes, even the clients may not be totally aware of their reasons for seeking therapy. - Highlight Alternatively, individuals in couples or families may define goals that initially appear incompatible. - Highlight In these situations, you may need to creatively reframe the goals in such a way as to make them compatible or link them together. - Highlight Once you have a clear understanding of what your clients want or expect from therapy, you need to decide whether it is appropriate for you to take on the case. - Highlight you must assess whether the case is within your scope of practice, that is, whether the clients are expecting help for issues that would be considered appropriate for a family therapist to treat. - Highlight The scope of practice is defined for therapists by the laws that license or certify therapists in their state. - Highlight If the case falls outside your scope of practice, you will need to refer your clients to an appropriate professional. - Highlight you need to assess if the case falls within your scope of competence. - Highlight do you have the necessary skills, training, - Highlight or experience to effectively treat the issues? - Highlight If not, you need to refer the clients to another therapist who has the appropriate skills or qualifications. - Highlight you may be able to treat clients provided you take appropriate measures during treatment to gain the necessary competence. - Highlight could do a literature review on treating this condition and seek supervision on the case. - Highlight if you are working within an agency setting, you will need to evaluate if the services the clients are seeking fit within the agency‚Äôs scope of practice. - Highlight Some agencies specialize in addressing specific issues or problems, and may not want therapists working with clients who are seeking help for other concerns. - Highlight Seek consultation with your supervisor if these concerns arise, especially if there is any ambiguity around whether the issues fit under the agency‚Äôs scope of practice. - Highlight there may be occasions where your clients‚Äô needs are best met by working on other goals first before addressing the goals with which they initially present. - Highlight You will need to present a rationale to your clients as to why a particular sequence of treatment will ultimately be in their best interest. - Highlight Client goals are often defined in terms of what problems or issues need to be resolved. In contrast, therapist goals generally reflect what changes clients need to make to resolve their problems. Client goals tell the therapist where they want to go, whereas therapist goals describe how the client will get there. - Highlight Many clients not only bring in expectations about what therapy will accomplish, but also about how therapy will be done. - Highlight helpful to assess what clients expect therapy will be like. - Highlight Whenever a client has had previous therapy, it is often beneficial to explore what the experience was like, as it can strongly shape (both positively and negatively) a client‚Äôs expectations regarding therapy. - Highlight What did the client find most useful? What about the process didn‚Äôt work for him or her? More specific questions will generate a clearer picture of what occurred and how you might apply it to the current therapy situation. - Highlight the therapist may need to educate clients about the therapy process - Highlight Clients may hold expectations about therapy in a number of different areas. - Highlight You need to assess if their expectations align with what you think is realistic. - Highlight Clients can also have expectations about who will be in therapy. - Highlight It is also important that the therapist and client share similar views on the purpose of therapy. - Highlight If the therapist and client are not on the same page in this regard, then problems are likely to arise. - Highlight The therapist and client will need to discuss what therapy is about and hopefully reach a mutually agreed-upon understanding. - Highlight It is also possible that other client expectations may impede the therapeutic process. - Highlight In some instances, you may decide against continuing therapy because the expectations are too restrictive and would severely limit your ability to be effective. - Highlight Clients come to therapy with varying degrees of motivation. - Highlight The initial interview is a good time to assess and perhaps begin to build motivation for therapy. - Highlight A logical time to assess motivation is when you are defining goals for therapy. Answers to the question ‚ÄúWhat brings you to therapy?‚Äù will differentiate motivated from unmotivated clients. - Highlight some of these clients can become quite committed to therapy as they experience its benefits. - Highlight You should also inquire as to who first suggested therapy or called for the appointment. Generally this person is the most motivated for therapy. A good question to ask your clients is what led them to come - Highlight to therapy now, rather than sooner or later in their lives? - Highlight Where clients are on the Stages of Change Cycle - Highlight may determine their motivation for change. This cycle recognizes that clients spend a great deal of time (precontemplation and contemplation stages) thinking about changing before they decide to take action and change. In addition, the cycle recognizes that maintaining changes, - Highlight can be challenging. Thus, addressing relapse is part of the process leading to permanent change. The therapist must match his or her interventions to where the client is in terms of their stage of change. - Highlight Motivational interviewing - Highlight suggests that the therapist‚Äôs job is to help the client resolve his or her ambivalence about change. Instead of using confrontation, the empathic therapist validates the client‚Äôs perspective and freedom to decide. - Highlight Pain around unmet needs often drives clients to change. - Highlight it is important that you are clear on what the unmet needs are for your clients, and how much pain or distress they experience around these unmet needs - Highlight You will need to figure out why the client is minimizing the problem, which will guide how you approach the situation. - Highlight it can helpful to explore with clients why others believe there is a problem and the possible negative consequences of not addressing it. - Highlight Sometimes clients will deny that a problem exists out of fear of consequences or injury to their self-image. - Highlight Therefore, building motivation for therapy will need to be done in conjunction with addressing the client‚Äôs denial - Highlight If a mandated client refuses to acknowledge that a problem exists, you can suggest that there is at least one problem‚Äîhe or she is being told to come to unwanted therapy. If your client agrees (which is typically the case), then you can explore what needs to happen so that the client is no longer required to come to therapy. This approach allows you to join with your client, while at the same time working on intermediate goals that address the problem. - Highlight Some clients may have poor motivation because they do not anticipate any benefit from therapy, believing that therapy is useless or the situation is hopeless. - Highlight Building a positive expectation that therapy can be helpful will be vital for these clients - Highlight For clients who lack confidence in their ability to change, you may need to highlight their strengths or help them challenge their negative self-talk. Noting exceptions to the problem might help build confidence and motivation. - Highlight Using the above strategies does not guarantee client motivation. - Highlight In these situations, you need to become comfortable with using the leverage for change provided by the courts. - Highlight A common struggle that beginning therapists may face is when they are more motivated than their clients. - Highlight This dynamic suggests that the therapist needs to step back, review the reasons for therapy, and once again evaluate the clients‚Äô motivation. - Highlight At times, clients might seem motivated ‚Äúfor the wrong reasons.‚Äù - Highlight You don‚Äôt need to agree with the clients‚Äô motivations. Usually, it is enough that clients, for whatever reason, will face the demanding process of change. - Highlight key issue that the beginning therapist must frequently deal with in the initial session: the issue of credibility. - Highlight In order for clients to have hope or an expectation of change, they must see the therapist and therapy as credible, or they may prematurely terminate therapy. - Highlight assess early on if any issues of credibility need to be addressed. - Highlight do the clients see therapy as an effective way to solve problems? - Highlight do the clients see you, in your role as the therapist, as being competent or credible? - Highlight If you suspect there is a credibility problem, you should attempt to pinpoint where and why credibility is lacking. - Highlight The more precise your understanding of why the client does not see you or the therapy as credible, the more likely your intervention will be ‚Äúon target‚Äù in addressing this issue. - Highlight In cases where clients are resistant to therapy in general, you may be able to reframe the process in a way that builds its credibility. - Highlight you must work to reduce the stigma. You can compare therapy to coaching, in that even the best athletes, - Highlight use coaches. - Highlight When clients question a therapist‚Äôs credibility, they usually focus on the lack of professional or life experience. Often you can redefine for the client what type of experience is needed to be helpful. - Highlight If you are concerned about your age and lack of experience, it may also be helpful to dress professionally and present in a professional manner. - Highlight you may need to directly address with your clients how you will compensate for your lack of experience with a particular problem or population. - Highlight you might express your willingness to learn from them about their culture. - Highlight While some clients are open to this approach, others will feel it is not their responsibility to educate the therapist about their culture. - Highlight Especially for these clients, it will be important for you to take the initiative to educate yourself through reading the literature. - Highlight If clients still harbor doubts, a frequently effective strategy is to contract with them for a set number of sessions (perhaps three). This gives you time to demonstrate your competence. - Highlight Nearly all clients are willing to give you this chance, provided the number of sessions is reasonable. - Highlight In these situations, you need to identify a problem that can be quickly resolved to build credibility with your clients. - Highlight It is important that you not become defensive if your credibility is being questioned. If you can deal with your clients‚Äô concerns in a nondefensive and respectful manner, this may actually build your credibility. - Highlight you must be clear in your own mind what you do have to offer, even if you have limited clinical or life experience - Highlight you need to recognize that clients value having someone compassionately and respectfully listen to their story at a difficult time in their lives. - Highlight In simply being present with another human being, you have something important to offer your clients. - Highlight you can frequently offer important insights to your clients because you do not have the kind of emotional involvement in the situation that they do. - Highlight even the inexperienced therapist has access to clinical knowledge that most clients do not possess or could not easily access. - Highlight initial interview is a critical time - Highlight Developing a connection and establishing credibility with your clients is essential for their return for a second session. Defining goals and expectations for therapy, building motivation, and properly handling administrative issues are also crucial. - Highlight You need to remain connected or joined with your clients in order to effectively confront and challenge them at all stages. Likewise, the goals or expectations for therapy may need to be revisited and redefined as therapy proceeds. -

item.title: Nathan Ackerman
item.description:
Ackerman sought out to understand a family to diagnose problems and develop family treatment. He was a child psychiatrist. He worked at the Menninger Clinic. In 1937, he became the chief psychiatrist of the Child Guidance Clinic. He followed the child guidance model of psychiatry to treat the child while the social worker saw the mother. He began having the same therapist see both the mother and child around the 1940 s. he began to see the family as the basic unit of treatment. In 1955, Ackerman organized the first session on family diagnosis at the Meeting of American Orthopsychiatric Association. Don Jackson, Murray Bowen, Lyman Wynne (1954), and Nathan Ackerman learned about each others' work and joined in a common practice. The Family Institute was founded in 1960. They renamed the Family Institute to Ackerman Institute following his death in 1971. He believed, even though families may give the appearance of unity, underneath they are split into competing factors.
His ideas were similar to the Psychoanalytic Family Therapy model Despite the apparent unit of personality, families are actually minds in conflict driven by warring drives and defenses. He believed families confront some issues while avoiding others, such as conflicts involving sex and aggression. He saw his job as bringing the family secrets into the open. He was unrestrained to encourage families to relax their emotional restraint. He first sided with one member of the family and later with another. He believed balance was achieved in the long-run by moving back and forth in giving support now to one, later to another family member. He was described as unabashingly blunt. He stated people get more reassurance from honesty than from false promises.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/People in CFT/Nathan Ackerman.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Multiple Impact Therapy (1967)
item.description:
An intensive, crisis-oriented form of family therapy developed by Robert MacGregor in which family members are treated in various subgroups by a team of therapists.
Robert MacGregor
He developed Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston. His clinic served a population that was scattered widely over southeastern Texas, and clients had to travel hundreds of miles. He wanted to have a maximum impact in a short amount of time. He worked with families for two days.

item.description:
(1921-2017) Structural Family Therapy
Enmeshment:
Disengagement:
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change Became the director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic in 1965. In 1981, Minuchin started his own center in New York, where he continued to practice and teach until 1996, when he retired and moved to Boston. He retired (again) and moved to Boca Raton, Florida, in 2005, where he conducted professional trainings and taught courses at Nova Southeastern University until his death in 2017.

item.title: Ingredients of an Interaction Activity for Couples
item.description:
This details the internal communication process and can be used to teach about internal and relational processes. The ingredients questions are used to help people understand their interactions with others. When you may experience a troubling interaction, use the following seven questions to walk through the 'Ingredients of an Interaction' DESC Model: Utilize to discuss conflict or requests for change. ‚ÄúDESC Model.png‚Äù could not be found. What do I HEAR and SEE? Describe behaviorally what happened without adding interpretations. Similar to the DESCRIBE in the DESC Model. What MEANINGS do I make of what I hear and see? Discuss how you interpreted the behaviors you heard and saw. Meanings often connect back to past experience. What FEELINGS do I have about the meanings I make? This helps identify specific feelings about the meanings and interpretations. Similar to EXPRESS in the DESC Model What FEELINGS do I have ABOUT these FEELINGS? This asks whether you can accept or tolerate your feelings. If a person is not accepting, communication stances will be triggered. Similar to EXPRESS in the DESC Model What DEFENSES do I use? During communication, we may use one of the five communication stances to respond to interaction with others. Below are the four survival stances. Placator
Blamer

Computer

Distractor

What RULES FOR COMMENTING do I use? Each person's family and early significant others impart rules for commenting on interactions that may limit self-worth, restrict choices, and determine what actions are 'allowed' and 'appropriate.' Much of these rules are unspoken and brought into future relationships without reflection on whether they are appropriate or useful. What is my RESPONSE in the situation? How do I respond behaviorally and verbally?

item.title: Placating (Placator)
item.description: The placator talks in an ingratiating way, trying to please, apologizing, and never disagreeing, no matter what. This is a 'yes man' who talks as though they could do nothing for themselves; they must always get someone's approval. They may experience feeling nauseous and wanting to vomit during conflict or disagreement. You may think of yourself as really worth nothing. You are lucky just to be allowed to eat. You owe everybody gratitude, and you really are responsible for everything that goes wrong. Naturally, you will agree with any criticism of you. You are grateful that anyone even talks to you, no matter what they say or how they say it. You would not think of asking anything for yourself. After all, who are you to ask? Besides, if you can just be good enough, it will come by itself. Think of yourself as being physically down on one knee, wobbling a bit, and putting out one hand in a begging fashion. Keep your head up so your neck will hurt, your eyes will strain, and in no time at all your head will ache. When you talk in this position, your voice Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring. Acknowledge Other/Context Minimizes self (sometimes context) People-pleasing tendencies Therapeutic Implications: Acknowledge own thoughts, feelings, needs Assertiveness/clear communication of needs Less directive therapy methods Multiple choice options to practice sense of agency Because placatory have people-pleasing tendencies, therapists use less directive therapy methods, such as multiple choice questions and open-ended reflections, to require them to voice their opinion and take a stand. Therapists should carefully avoid giving opinions, making it seem that they have an opinion, or offering too much personal information. Clients will use this type of information to know what parts of themselves to hide and what parts to foreground to gain therapist approval. Research indicates that some clients make up things to give the impression that therapy is progressing. Not until the placator regularly and openly disagrees with the therapist has rapport been established.

item.title: Family Systems Theory
item.description:
Murray Bowen
"Based on the assumptions that the human is a product of evolution and that human behavior is significantly regulated by the same natural processes that regulate the behavior of all other living things. A corollary assumption is that clinical disorders are a product of that part of man he has in common with the lower animals." (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Family Systems Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Murray Bowen
item.description:
Murray Bowen was a psychiatrist who specialized in schizophrenia Emphasized theory Bowen began his clinical work at the Menninger Clinic in 1946, where he studied mothers and their schizophrenic children. His major interest at the time was mother‚Äì child symbiosis, which led to his concept of Differentiation of Self (autonomy and levelheadedness). From Menninger, Bowen moved to the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), where he developed a program to hospitalize whole families with schizophrenic members. This project expanded the focus on mother‚Äìchild symbiosis to include the role of fathers and led to the concept of Triangle s (diverting conflict between two people by involving a third).
Beginning in 1955, when Bowen started bringing family members together to discuss their problems, he was struck by their Emotional Reactivity. Feelings overwhelmed reason. Bowen felt families‚Äô tendency to pull him into the center of this Undifferentiated Family Ego Mass, and he had to make a concerted effort to remain objective (Bowen, 1961). The ability to remain neutral and focus on the process, rather than content, of family discussions is what distinguishes a therapist from a participant in a family‚Äôs drama. To control the level of emotion, Bowen encouraged family members to talk to him, not to each other therapists weren‚Äôt immune to being sucked into family conflicts Whenever two people are struggling with conflict they can‚Äôt resolve, there is an automatic tendency to involve a third party
Triangle: Triangle is the smallest stable unit of relationship Process of complaining to third party means less likely to address the problem at its source Triangling process is destructive when it becomes regular feature of a relationship Repeating what someone says to you about someone else is one way to stop triangling in its tracks Triangles spread out Bowen Family Life: In 1966 an emotional crisis in Bowen‚Äôs family led to a personal voyage of discovery that turned out to be as significant for Bowen‚Äôs theory as Freud‚Äôs self-analysis was for psychoanalysis. Bowen, the oldest of five children from a tightly knit rural family, kept his distance from his parents and the rest of his extended family. Like many of us, he mistook avoidance for emancipation. Unfinished emotional business stays with us, making us vulnerable to repeat conflicts we never worked out with our families Bowen‚Äôs most important achievement was detriangling himself from his parents, who‚Äôd been accustomed to complaining to him about each other
Differentiation of Self: Best accomplished by developing personal relationships with as many members of the family as possible.
Differentiating one's self from the family is completed when these relationships are maintained without becoming emotionally reactive or taking part in Triangles.
Family Systems Theory
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Bowen Family System Theory/Key Terms and Concepts/Murray Bowen.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Lecture on Bowen Family System Therapy
item.description:
"The overall goal of counseling is to help family members become 'systems experts' who could know their family system so well that the family could readjust itself without the help of an expert." Overview: Centers around two counterbalancing/competing life forces: Togetherness (Fusion) and Individuality (Emotional Cutoff) Central Premise: Unresolved emotional attachment to one's family must be resolved before one can differentiate a mature, healthy personality. Anxiety and Differentiation of Self.
Differentiation of Self: Degree to which one balances emotional and intellectual functioning and intimacy. And autonomy in interpersonal relationships. Ability to think and reflect - to not respond automatically to emotional pressures. More highly differentiated individuals can experience strong emotion. But can also shift to logical reasoning for decision making and problem solving Undifferentiated individuals tend to act based on emotional reactions. Undifferentiated individuals find it difficult to maintain their own autonomy.
Emotional Triangles: Emotionally significant relationships shadowed by third parties. Friends, family Anxiety is the driving force behind emotional triangles. Can be temporary or fixed.
Triangulation freezes conflict in place and becomes a chronic diversion that undermines relationships. Nuclear Family Emotional Process: The emotional forces in family - excessive emotional reactivity or fusion. Problems can include: Reactive distancing between spouses. Emotional dysfunction in one spouse. Marital conflict. Projection of the problems onto children. Family Projection Process: The process by which parents transmit their lack of differentiation to their children. Emotional fusion in a couple leads to: Conflict, emotional distance, or reciprocal over-and-under functioning. Spouses with unresolved family-of-origin issues create a family environment. An intense focus on one or more children. The child who is the object of the projection process becomes the child most attached to the parents and has the least differentiation of self. Multigenerational Emotional Process: Defined as the family emotional process across multiple generations. In each generation, the child most involved in the family's fusion moves toward a lower level of differentiation of self. The last involved child moves toward a higher level of differentiation. Couple establish new family which influences a child's ability to regulate emotionality. Problems in the family are products of the relationships with parents.
Emotional Cutoff: How people manage anxiety between generations. Denies the importance of his/her family Boasts of his/her independence from family Has infrequent communications with family Exaggerated fa√ßade of independence Finds intimacy extremely threatening Societal Emotional Process: Emotional process in society; influences the emotional process in families Background influence affecting all families. Prolonged increase in social anxiety can result in gradual lowering of the functional level of differentiation in families. Normal Family Development: Families vary along single continuum of differentiation, low to high Optimal development when: Individuals are relatively differentiated Anxiety is low Parents are in good emotional contact with their families Development of Behavior Disorders: Symptoms come when stress exceeds the system's ability to handle it. Emotional fusion is the genesis of psychological problems. Family symptoms reflect: Level of chronic anxiety Level of differentiation in family system Undifferentiation in family leads to marital problems in nuclear family Goals of Therapy: Not interested in solving problems. Therapist helps client get past blame to examine their own role in the family. Goals of therapy: Decrease anxiety, increase differentiation Help individuals gain insight into their family-of-origin patterns Examine process and structure of therapy:
Process: patters of emotional reactivity
Structure: patterns of interlocking triangles Modify marital system to change the family: Increase parent's ability to manage their own anxiety Help couple have less anxiety in their family-of-origin Conditions for Behavior Change: Understanding, not action, is the vehicle of cure Bowen differed from most systems therapists in believing that: Meaningful change does not require the presence of the entire family Extended family Therapy: Assessment: Description and history of relationship context of problem.
Genogram: Traces significant relationship patters through at least three generations. Assess emotional patters and stresses endured and adaptation. Change occurs as one learns about the larger family. Typically work with couples or individuals. If individuals, the goal is differentiation of self: Knowledge of how family systems function Strong motivation to change Therapeutic Techniques: Process questions: Encourage family to think about how they react and respond with other family members. Used to slow people down, diminish reactive anxiety Genograms
Therapeutic Triangle Relationship experiments Becoming aware of system processes (pursuer/distancer) The I-Position Multiple Family Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Bowen Family System Theory/Family System Theory/Lecture on Bowen Family System Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 6. Narrative Family Therapy
item.description:
Salvador Minuchin, MD at the Evolution of Psychotherapy Conference - YouTube Knowledge is constructed. Therapy is concerned with the ways people interpret their behavior rather than how they behave. Experience is understood in interpretation and meaning making. Problems affect people Problems operate on people rather than problems being things people are doing. For clients to maintain their new narratives, they need supportive communities. Hence, letter writing, outsider witness, reflecting teams The truth of experience is not discovered, it is created! Narrative accounts affect people's perceptions, stories don't just mirror life, they shape it. Instead of trying to solve problems, the focus is on enriching the narrative of people's lives - bringing forth 'thick descriptions' of those aspects of people's narratives that life outside the influence of problems. Alternative stories allow people to live out new identities, new possibilities for relationships, and new futures. People find meaning in their lives by experiencing, telling, and circulating stories of un-storied aspects of their lives and relationships. Dominant discourses are socially constructed within our culture. Holds a position of curiosity Cherishes each person/family's unique stories. Invites clients to develop and live out narratives that they prefer for their lives. Is decentered, not an expert, but an interested collaborator. They are skilled at asking questions to bring forth the knowledge and experience carried in particular stories of the family. Therapist influential, but decentered Person separate from problem All problems have exceptions Opposite of problem is preferred Preferred story woven into identity Impact of relationships explored Deconstruct societal norms Personal decision-making supported Instead of having a problem or being a problem, clients are struggling against their problems. The problem is the problem. Aren't interested in problem-maintaining sequences (strategic), structural issues (structural), or solutions (solution-focused), they are interested in the problem's impact on the family.
Social Constructionism There is no absolute truth, instead shift toward deconstructing (re-examining) established truths that oppress people's lives. People have good intentions (they do not need or want problems) People are profoundly influenced by the discourses around them. People are not their problems. People can develop alternative, empowering stories once separated from their problems and the cultural myths they have internalized. Therapist is interested in families' own evaluations of what is problematic and what is preferred. Clients name how the problem is affecting their lives and relationships. Therapist invites people to bring their 'best selves' into consideration of the problems that diminish their relationship and an exploration of how they might choose ways of living that diminish the effect of the problems on their relationship. Reject categorizing people In the spirit of collaboration, the therapist situates themselves with clients. They disclose the beliefs that inform their therapy so that clients can know what they're getting into. Clients are encouraged to educate the therapist on their cultural predicaments and to correct the therapist when they make assumptions that don't fit for the client's experience. Problems are likely to persist as long as unhelpful stories remain fixed and obscure other more helpful versions of events. Cautious about applying terminology (diagnosis) Want to hear the family's stories of how the problems they name affect their lives and relations. When one of these problems appears to have invaded a relationship, it is the therapist's responsibility to ask questions that invite family members to consider the effects of that problem on their relationship, and to consider the stand they want to take in relationship to it. Problems are things that are separate from the families they afflict. Therapists look for problematic discourses and offer families the opportunity to describe and evaluate the effects of those discourses on their relationships and lives. Problem-saturated stories encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story. Problems may be regarded as alien invaders. Separate from problem-saturated stories (and destructive cultural assumptions) Open space for new and more constructive views of themselves. Separate individuals from problems and unite the family to fight a common enemy. Search for unique outcomes (sparkling events, exceptions) - times when they resisted the problem or behaved in ways that contradicted the problem story. Help clients deconstruct unproductive stories in order to reconstruct new and more productive ones.
Deconstruction involves questioning assumptions.
Reconstruction involves creating new and more optimistic accounts of experience. Effects Questions (elicit effects of the problem) How does the problem affect you? Your ideas about yourself? Your relationships? Clients can begin to notice areas of their lives where the problem has been less powerful. Identifying unique outcomes creates room for counterplots. Telling and retelling, witnessing, and living out of multi-stories lives. Once people notice how their stories are problem-saturated and try to change their narratives, what they do and perceive will change as well. Facilitate this process by asking questions to highlight un-storied events and to encourage meaning making around those events, then tie the meaning to memorable actions and contexts. Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time. At the end of each meeting, the therapist asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how? Then, the therapists asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when? Meetings are typically 60 minutes. Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between). CAUTION: Often therapy invites people to re-immerse themselves in their most problematic stories. Instead: Narrative therapy invite families to explore, describe, and experience new directions in life that are already unfolding - new positions, new stories. Counterstory Asking Permission is central to the model. At the start of 1 st meeting, the therapist asks if it would be okay to get to know the family in ways that have nothing to do with the problem before they describe what brought them to therapy. Later meetings often start by the therapist reading their notes from previous session aloud and asking a question, such as: "Can you tell me about any new developments that relate to what we were talking about last time?" Other times the therapist begins wondering whether there have been important thoughts or events that connect to possibilities identified in the previous conversations. Therapist use letters, documents, and videos to document and circulate alternative stories. For example, after a therapy session a therapist may write a letter posing questions that invite the family to develop an alternative story even further than they did in the session. Or sending a document noting the stands the family has taken in regard to a problem. Reading a document between sessions, and the conversations that can follow a reading, keep a story alive and growing. Collaborative Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem. With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem. Takes notes of what works and what doesn't. Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation. Therapy is a relationship - a conversation! Ask questions to expose gaps in problematic stories. Open space for describing alternatives. Invite families to add, subtract, or describe differently. Encourage families to ask questions about the therapist's questions and comments. The therapist wants the family to make meaning of their own experience, but the therapist's questions inevitably shape the inquiry. Families are in a better position to interpret, making meaning of, and evaluate their own experiences than outsiders are, even trained outsiders. Therapists have more questions than answers! It sounds as though [problem] is part of your life now. How long have you been noticing this [problem]? What effect does the [problem] have on your life? How does the [problem] impact your relationship? Does [problem] have an impact on your relationship with other family members? What do you think about the effects [problem] is having on your life? Are you accepting what [problem] is doing? Are these effects acceptable to you or not? Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what [problem] is doing? How would you prefer things to be? People's lives are multi-storied, each new telling of a story generates new possibilities for making meaning and taking action. The therapist invites family members to: Evaluate their current situation Name the problems involved Evaluate their relationship to those problems Take a stand in regard to them Tell more satisfying stories of their lives Evaluate the usefulness of the alternative stories In telling and living out the newly developed strands of alternative stories, clients evaluate aspects of their lives. Private hopes and fears Family interactions Contributions of culture of origin Traditions, legacies Questioning Is that the problem speaking? Whose values are guiding you in saying that? By exposing discourses that support problems, families can separate from the ways of being that are supported by those discourses, and identify and recognize preferred perceptions, attitudes, and actions. What name would you give the problem? What is it like to experience the problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other? What has it talked you into about your family? What impacts has that had? What effects does the problem have on your other relationships? How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself? Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not? Are we talking about what you want to be talking about? Is this conversation useful? How is it useful?
Externalizing Conversations
Relative Influence Questions Who is in charge, the person or the problem?
Identifying Unique Outcome s Reading between the lines of the problem story Can you remember a time... Reauthoring What does it say about you... Illuminating or creating the counter-story Reinforcing the new story Finding audiences, supportive witnesses, allies Letter writing
Deconstructing destructive cultural assumptions Deconstruction Some families prefer a different kind of therapy than narrative, some are seeking instruction and expert advice. Regularly ask families how the therapy is going for them, and be open and willing to refer families if they are seeking a different kind of relationship. Most families coming to therapy are concerned less with how the therapy is structured than with whether their family relationships improve. Emphasis on 'practice-based evidence' over evidence-based practice More qualitative research rather than quantitative studies Little empirical support currently exists Randomized controlled trials of narrative therapy do not yet exist Listen to stories as stories Be attentive and responsive to their intended meaning in telling the story Ask about non-problematic aspects of the life of family members and of their relationships Make sure the problem does not trick us into mistaking 'them' for 'the problem' Unless families insist on moving quickly into talking about problems, spend a while listening to stories about their preferences At some point, families spontaneously start to tell problem saturated stories Try to put yourself in their shoes Do not assume you understand the meaning their experience holds for them Listen and ask Listen with focused attention, patience, and curiosity while building a relationship of mutual respect and trust Listen 'deconstructively' to family's stories - the listening is guided by the belief that those stories have many possible meanings As families to tell their stories, look for opportunities to reflect our sense of what they said, they are saying, and to ask whether the meaning we are making fits with their intended meaning We wonder aloud whether they are useful or desirable? And, what difference it makes to think of it 'that way'? Cultivate an awareness of the dominant (and dominating) stories in our society Develop ways of collaboratively examining the effects of those stories when we sense them at work in the lives and relationships of the families with whom we consult There are 'taken-for-granted' realities at play Deconstructive questions aim to examine problems in detail and expose discourses that support them, as well as those that might undermine those discourses The person/family is not the problem; the problem is the problem Externalizing - problems are seen as separate from people As we listen to people's stories, we listen for the ways they refer to their problems in their lives. If we hear names like 'fear' or 'blowing up,' we orient to those things as entities or processes that are external to families If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them What would you call that something? What 'feeds' the problem? What 'starves' the problem? Who benefits from the problem? In what settings might the problem be useful? Who advocates for the problem? What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions? What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships? Naming a problem can open a way for examining it and thinking differently about it As we ask people to evaluate their relationship to problems, they often tell us what they would prefer to have in their lives in place of the problem What are the family's preferred directions? Counterplot / counter-story 'Standing against' the problem Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes? Is the problem always with you? Listen for purposes, values, hopes, and commitments that are absent but implicit in family's narratives Double listening If a person experiences despair, they must have hopes, dreams, or visions of the future that are not being fulfilled If a person experiences injustice, they must have a conception of a just world When we hear problematic stories, we listen for these sorts of implications Stories need listeners as well as tellers Attentive witnesses The therapist serves as a witness, but including other witnesses, especially those involved in people's lives, can be very helpful What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying? What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking? It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care? What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them? Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who them amplify and accredit the stories that they witness What stood out for them? What images it brought forward? How it resonated with their own experiences? Where they were transported by the interview? Situate their reflections in their own experience Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives We are interested in documenting and circulating the new stories that emerge in therapy to thicken them and keep them alive We take notes in therapy to document new stories as they develop We often refer back to these notes and read them aloud We may create videos or documents about what they have learned, with their permission, that can be viewed or read by others facing similar problems We sometimes write letters between therapy sessions In these letters, we ask questions that we did not ask in the therapy session Out intention in letter writing is to thicken and extend the knowledge that has begun to emerge in session We may invite the family to share these documents with other people in their lives Opening space questions (unique outcomes) Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but did not? Preference questions (preferred experiences) Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how? Story development questions How is this different from when arguing is in control? Meaning questions What does it say about you that you were able to...? Questions that extend the story into the future What do you predict... Narrative therapy aims to separate the individual from the issue and externalize problems instead of internalizing them.
Reality is socially constructed. (Social Constructionism) Reality is influenced by and communicated through language. Having a narrative can help us organize and maintain our reality. There is no 'objective reality' or absolute truth. Telling One's Story A technique that involves re-telling your own story to find new meaning in old experiences. Externalization Technique Externalizing helps you separate you from your problems, making it easier to change something you don't like about yourself. Deconstruction Technique This technique involves breaking problems down into smaller, more specific issues that are easier to understand and address. Unique Outcomes Technique To help you see from a new, more positive perspective, broaden your view to see more of your own storylines, and focus on one that does not include your most pervasive problems. Existentialism The belief that the world holds no inherent meaning, and that we all must make our own meaning in life.
