item.title: 10. HIPPA and HITECH
item.description:
Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA): Makes health information portable so that individuals can maintain health insurance between jobs. Ensure that health care plans and providers are held accountable with regard to keeping health information private Provides federal privacy protections for physical and mental health information known as protected health information (PHI).
Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH): Increases patient rights over their PHI Increases restrictions over disclosure of PHI Increased fines for HIPAA violations Funding for compliance audits HIPPA/HITECH Compliance: If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE). If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE. If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care. State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc. When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can‚Äôt be. Biggest concerns are about electronic medical records and breaches of confidentiality Use only HIPAA compliant software which encrypts and has lots of safeguards against hackers including back-ups etc. HITECH compels CE‚Äôs to notify anyone effected by a breach of confidentiality within 60 days of the discovery of the incident with a risk analysis. Follow your agencies rules and regulations and report any breach to supervisor, they should then follow what ever procedure is set up.
Telehealth: Standards of care: (Know your state's regulation) In Ohio, relaxed the rule that you have to see the person in-person at least once. Now you have to have a way to identify that you are treating the person they say they are (some form of picture ID). Have to have procedures for emergencies (local therapists, or other agencies that can respond if client is suicidal/homicidal). Have to have a signed consent form. Can't practice across state lines Billing? Must be HIPAA compliant. Zoom is not HIPAA compliant, have to have a platform that is. Most studies suggest that telehealth is just as effective as in-person therapy. For CFT's, how do you pay attention to process via telehealth? Need to find creative ways to engage all members of the system on a small screen.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Ethics (7770)/Lecture/10. HIPPA and HITECH.md

item.title: 14. Older Adults and Person with Disabilities
item.description:
People age 65+ = 16% of the population in 2019 (51.1 million) Expected to be 21.6% by 2040. Nearly 1 in 4 older adults were members of a racial/ethnic minority population: African American (not Hispanic): 12% Asian American (not Hispanic): 13% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander (not Hispanic): 10% American Indian and Alaska Native (not Hispanic): 12% Hispanic: 8% Persons identifying as two or more groups: 6% In Ohio persons 65+ represented 17.51% of the population (2,046,320) This represents a 27.31% increase from 2009-2019. 8.3% of persons 65+ in Ohio live below the poverty line. In 2020, a larger percentage of older men (70%) than older women (48%) were married. Of older adults age 65+ living in the community, 61% lived with their spouse/partner in 2020. About 27% lived alone The 2019 median income of older persons was $27,398 ($36, 921 for men and $21,815 for women) In 2019, 4.9 million people age 65+ lived below the poverty level. Another 2.6 million were 'near-poor' The median household income of older homeowners was $36,200 in 2019. In 2020, 9.8 million Americans age 65+ were in the labor force (working or actively seeking work). Consumers age 65+ averaged out-of-pocket health care expenditures of $6,833 in 2019, up 41% from 2009. In 2019, about 1.1 million people age 60+ were responsible for the basic needs of at least one grandchild under age 18 living with them. During COVID-19, between March and April 2020, the unemployment rate for adults age 65+ more than quadrupled. Negative stereotypes and discrimination (ageism) Mental deterioration Some cognitive slowing is associated with normal aging (e.g., periodic minor memory difficulties, such as forgetting names or phone numbers or misplacing objects) About 1 in 7 adults 71+ have dementia Alzheimer disease Elder abuse and neglect Substance abuse Social isolation, depression, and suicidality Please identify the following for Older Adults: Characteristics Strengths Ethnic or Cultural Values What emotional stressors are specific to older adults? What are possible ways to support the client in feeling with these emotional stressors? How can we think about care with older adults as suicide prevention? As clinicians, what can we do to address the physical limitations that an older adult client may face to make sure these challenges do not impede the treatment process? 26% of adults in the US have some types of disability (61 million) 2 in 5 adults age 65 years and older have a disability 1 in 4 women have a disability 2 in 5 non-Hispanic American Indians/Alaskan Natives have a disability Adults living with disabilities are more likely to be obese, smoke, and have heart disease and diabetes. 1 in 3 adults with disabilities 18 to 44 years do not have a usual health care provider 1 in 3 adults with disabilities 18 to 44 years have an unmet healthcare need because of cost in the past year 1 in 4 adults with disabilities 45 to 64 years did not have a routine check-up in the past year. Over 3 million children (4.3% of the under-18 population) in the US had a disability in 2019. The most common disability type among children both years was cognitive difficulty American Indian and Alaskan Native (AIAN) children had the highest rate of childhood disability of all racial groups, at 5.9% in 2019. In the moral model (or religious), disability is seen as having meaning about the person's or family's character, deeds, thoughts, and karma. From this perspective, disability can carry stigma, shame and blame, particularly if the disability is seen as a mark of wrongdoing. It can also be seen as a sign of honor, faith, or strength (although this is less common) The moral model is very prevalent worldwide and is often depicted in the media The Medical model views disability as resulting from an individual person's physical or mental limitations The Medical Model focuses on find a 'cure' or making a person more 'normal' The Medical Model uses the terms 'Disability,' 'Disease,' 'Dysfunctional,' 'Disorder' to categorize type of symptoms, differences in mechanisms, below average based on standardized measure of functioning, that causes challenges in life. ‚ÄúPasted image 20240410205740.jpg‚Äù could not be found. This model 'proposes that what makes someone disabled is not their medical condition, but the attitudes and structures of society. It is a civil rights approach to disability.' If modern life was set up in a way that was accessible for people then they would not be excluded or restricted Based on basic human rights principles, "It recognizes that disability is a natural part of human diversity that must be respected and support in all its forms. People with disability have the same rights as everyone else in society," and disability, "must not be used as an excuse to deny or restrict people's rights" Using both models, we can begin to see people with disabilities correctly: as human. We must consider how we can become better allies for individuals with disabilities by ensuring that society is accessible (Social Model) We must examine how we interact with and view people with disabilities.. We must ensure that our policies and practices support the Human Rights Model and encourage full inclusion and participation for individuals with disabilities Therapist make the environment comfortable for their clients.
The Tilt Parenting Podcast: a top podcast about learning disabilities, special education, ADHD, autism, giftedness, twice-exceptionality, and more.
Caregiver Action Network: the nation‚Äôs leading family caregiver organization working to improve the quality of life for the more than 90 million Americans who care for loved ones with chronic conditions, disabilities, disease, or the frailties of old age.
Franklin County Board of Developmental Disabilities (FCBDD): Services are provided for children from birth to age 21 who have developmental delays and disabilities.
The Ohio Center for Autism and Low Incidence (OCALI) serves families, educators and professionals working with infants, preschool and school-age children and adults with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and low-incidence disabilities ‚Äì including hearing impairments, visual impairments, multiple disabilities, orthopedic impairments and other health impairments. Parents raising children with Autism encounter more psychological distress, financial strain, worries for the child's future, and adaptation problems than those parents of children with typical developments The qualitative research will present experiences of parents raising a child with Autism during the pandemic and provide clinical recommendations.
Solution-Focused Therapy for 6 mothers of children with Autism in TX Identified 4 major themes: COVID impacts Financial strain Relational strain Emotional strain Uncertainty with the pandemic Proactive Advocacy Not enough (parental role strain) Supports Instrumental Informational Emotional Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS-15) (5-7 minutes to administer) ‚ÄúGeriatric Depression Scale Short Form English Scoring.pdf‚Äù could not be found. Can be used with people who have a cognitive disorder (such as in beginning of stages of dementia) PHQ-9 (normed, because likert scale, it is not as accessible) Depression in Older Adults Scale (DIAS) (commonly used in hospital settings, has fewer questions, removed questions that would make it difficult for someone who is medically hospitalized) Asks yes or no questions (great if person is not feeling well or has a cognitive impairment) Asks questions such as, "I can enjoy my life even when things are sometimes difficult." "I tend to worry a lot." Hospital anxiety and depression scale (HADS) Cornell Scale for Depression in Dementia (CSDD) ‚ÄúCornell Scale for Depression in Dementia.pdf‚Äù could not be found. Screening tool for identifying a person's vulnerability to depression in the context of dementia May be good for people for mild or moderate Given by caregiver, answers questions about person's mood or belief system. Starts by interviewing Is the caregiver noticing behavioral disturbances? Are they noticing physical signs? Changes to cyclical behaviors? Discuss with caregiver concerns of possible depression, "I'm concerned you may be experiencing depression, let's find a provider that specializes in working with older adults." How to start conversation when concerned Start conversation in calm, straight-forward, compassionate way Describe what you observed Can I help you connect with people who can help? Due to added caregiving responsibilities that are necessary for individuals with disabilities, members of families affected by disabilities have an increased prevalence of physical, psychological, and relational distress. Parents, spouses, and siblings of children with disabilities experience higher rates of mental health concerns such as anxiety and depression. Caregivers have higher rates of health problems and reports a variety of physical symptoms such as migraines, heart conditions, and sleep problems. The mental and physical health effects lead to reports of decreased quality of life and general wellbeing. Many of the adverse physical, mental, and relational health effects described by family members of individuals with disabilities are compounded by a lack of social support. Families often explain that there is a notable deficit in available social support, which they generally attribute to two main reasons: Family members‚Äô lack of free time to socialize with friends and family due to the added caregiving responsibilities Societal stigma associated with disabilities that may be attributed to personal shame and embarrassment of family members or the disapproval and ostracization by others Clinicians working with families affected by disabilities can support caregivers by connecting them with appropriate online platforms to increase social support, which acts as a protective factor against the harmful effects of caregiver stress and burnout.

item.title: 6. Examining Spirituality, Religion, and Non-Western Indigenous Methods of Healing and Native Americans and Alaskan Natives
item.description: Requires us to acknowledge positions of privilege and marginalization in the room. Potential Barriers: In general, therapists are less religious than their clients and the population at large. There is a historic divide between science (psychology) and religion In the United States there is a desire to maintain separation between church and state Some therapists avoid the topic to avoid imposing their own beliefs Some therapists lack confidence in how to address religion and spirituality ethically and effectively. An organized system of beliefs, rituals, practices, and community, oriented toward the sacred. Tends to focus on formal organizations with specifically defined and widely accepted beliefs, practices, and traditions. Transcendent beliefs and practices lived out in daily life and relationships. It can be experienced outside religious structure. "A process through which people seek to discover, hold on to, and when necessary, transform whatever they hold sacred in their lives." Spiritually integrated psychotherapy is based on findings in psychotherapy research and the psychology of religion. It is the practice of purposefully assessing clients' spiritual/religious belief systems and worldviews in the context of psychotherapy, while integrating spiritually oriented interventions. Clinical Spiritual Moral Any inquiry about topics commonly related to spiritual themes (i.e., meaning making, coping, social support, and morality) Explore client's worldview and/or personal philosophies Listen for client's use of 'spiritually laden' words Explore client's current experience of congruence Acknowledge client's spontaneous statements of spiritual beliefs' Inquire about their spiritual beliefs and practices Inquire about how they connect spiritual, clinical, and moral dimensions of life. Express agreement with the client's spiritual beliefs or sensibilities when such self-disclosure could be therapeutic. Articulate client's dilemma without giving your own position. Point out contradictions between the client's beliefs and clinical realities or moral issues. Challenge the client's way of handling spiritual beliefs based on your own spiritual, moral, or clinical beliefs. Any method of direct inquiry about a client's spirituality or religion. The purpose of spiritual reflection is twofold: Understand ourselves in our work with clients Understand clients from their own point-of-view Increasing our understanding helps us fulfill the role of spiritually integrated therapists by not placing our beliefs and/or bias onto the client. Questions to consider: How are these clients encountering a search for meaning? How do these clients and their presenting problem represent a theme from religious tradition or spiritual worldview (e.g., hope, reconciliation, pillars of faith) Regarding this case, what is an experience of the sacred/divine/spirit? Spirituality and religion as distinctive concepts Ethical implications of integration religion and spirituality in practice Start with a strong understanding of one's own social location 'Indigenous' describes any group of people native to a specific region. In other words, it refers to people who lived there before colonists or settlers arrived, defined new borders, and began to occupy the land. The term 'indigeneity' has emerged to describe the state of being indigenous or related to Indigenous-ness. There are over 476 million indigenous people living in 90 countries across the world, accounting for 6.2% of the global population: Of those, there are more than 5,000 distinct groups. Healing-informed care is care based on Indigenous wisdom about wellness and what is necessary to heal. Balance Relational Strength-based Healing has been defined as 'transition toward meaning, wholeness, connectedness, and balance.' Holistic: Interconnectedness underlies all of human experience Balance: Because of the interdependencies of all life, achieving and maintaining balance is important both to the individual and the larger group. Moral Code: The physical and metaphysical worlds are linked to a moral code. Respect: Respect of all living things and each other is essential for balance.

item.title: 7. Racial Identity Development and Working with Multiracial Populations
item.description: Has a positive attitude toward and preferences for dominant cultural values Places considerable value on characteristics that represent dominant cultural groups May devalue or hold negative views of own race or other racial/ethnic groups Begins to question identity Recognizes conflicting messages and observations that challenge beliefs/stereotypes of own cultural groups and value of mainstream cultural groups Develops growing sense of one's own cultural heritage and the existence of racism Moves away from seeing dominant cultural groups as all good. Embraces and holds a positive attitude toward and preference for his or her own race and cultural heritage Rejects dominant values of society and culture Focuses on eliminating oppression within own racial/cultural group Likely to possess considerable feelings - including distrust and anger - toward dominant cultural groups and anything that may represent them Places considerable value on characteristics that represent one's own cultural groups without question; develops a growing appreciation for others from racially and culturally diverse groups Begins to question the psychological cost of projecting strong feelings toward dominant cultural groups Desires to refocus more energy on personal identity while respecting own cultural groups Realigns perspective to note that not all aspects of dominant cultural groups - one's own racial/cultural group or other diverse groups - are good or bad May struggle with and experience conflicts of loyalty as perspective broadens Has developed a secure, confident sense of racial/cultural identity Becomes multicultural Maintains pride in racial identity and cultural heritage Commits to supporting and appreciating all oppressed and diverse groups Tends to recognize racism as a societal illness by which all can be victimized. White is a socially constructed category of 'race' with no biological/scientific foundation The racial category white only exists in relation to other racial categories The racial category white was created by white power holders to codify the superiority of white people over others The definition of white has changed over time and has been (and continues to be) determined by the people in power Structural Advantage A privileged position within society and its institutions for whites. A standpoint from which white people look at [themselves], others, and at society - one that allows [them] to see [themselves] as individuals, as 'just human'
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Lecture/2. Race, Religion, and Gender/7. Racial Identity Development and Working with Multiracial Populations.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: @sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022
item.description: Bibliography: Type: Book Title: Counseling the culturally diverse: theory and practice, Author: Sue, Derald Wing; Sue, David; Neville, Helen A.; Smith, Laura; Publisher: Wiley, Location: Hoboken, NJ, Year: 2022 ISBN: 978-1-119-86190-4 "For over four decades, Counseling the Culturally Diverse: Theory and Practice (CCD) has been considered the "gold standard" in culturally competent mental health care. Its cutting-edge presentation of multicultural counseling and therapy (MCT) is used in an overwhelming majority of graduate training programs in counseling and clinical psychology, and it has produced generations of culturally sensitive mental health practitioners. It now forms the multicultural knowledge base of licensing and certification exams at both the masters and the doctoral levels in psychology. In 2021, Social Science Space identified the book as one of the most important works across social science disciplines that has contributed to the ongoing need to understand, analyze, resist, and dismantle racism, bias, and bigotry. In essence, CCD has become a "classic" in the field of mental health practice, and leads the profession in the theory, research, and practice of MCT. CCD upholds the highest standards of scholarship, and is the most frequently cited source in multicultural psychology and mental health. The expert and global perspectives of the four co-authors, each active researchers and practitioners in the field, strengthen the newly minted ninth edition of CCD. As a result, instructors will note the continued fresh, scholarly, and exciting perspective in the content of CCD, as it continues to rank as the most up-to- date text in the field"-- Keywords: Need to Read
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Readings/@sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 8. Neurodevelopmental Disorders
item.description:
Intellectual Developmental Disorders Intellectual Developmental Disorder
Global Developmental Delay
Unspecified Intellectual Developmental Disorder Communication Disorders
Language Disorder
Speech Sound Disorder
Childhood Onset Fluency Disorder (Stuttering)
Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorder
Unspecified Communication Disorder
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
Attention-Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
Specific Learning Disorder
Motor Disorders
Developmental Coordination Disorder
Stereotypic Movement Disorder
Tic Disorders
Tourettes Common feature is developmental differences that produce impairments of personal, social, academic, or occupational functioning. A group of conditions with onset in the developmental period Typically manifest early in development Often before the child enters grade school Are characterized by developmental diffeences in brain processes that produce impairments of personal, social, academic, or occupational functioning. The range of developmental differences and possible deficits varies from very specific limitations of learning or control of executive functions to global impairments of social skills or intelligence.
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
Attention-Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Differences in social communication and social interaction. Restricted repetitive behaviors, interests, or activities. Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in functioning (social, academic, occupational) There is not just one cause of ASD There are many different factors that have been identified that may make a child more likely to have ASD, including environmental, biologic, and genetic factors. Although we know little about specific causes, the available evidence suggests that the following may put children at greater risk for developing ASD: Having a sibling with ASD Having certain genetic or chromosomal conditions, such as fragile X syndrome or tuberous scierosis Experiencing complications at birth Being born older parents Developmental monitoring (collecting or gathering information) and screening (testing). Surveillance or developmental monitoring is an active ongoing process of watching a child grow and encouraging conversations between parents and providers about a child's skills and abilities. CDC's Learn the Signs Act Early program has developed free materials, including CDC's Milestone Tracker app, to help parents and prociders work together to monitor children's development and know when there might be a concern and if more screening is needed. Screening is when a parent or provider completes a checklist or questionnaire specifically designed to identify problems that need further evaluation. General developmental screening should occur at the 9-, 18-, and 24- or 30-month well child visits and whenever a concern is expressed. Autism-specific screening should additionally occur at the 18- and 24- or 30-month visits and whenever a concern is expressed. 1% of the population Unclear whether higher rates reflect expansion of diagnostic criteria, increased awareness, or true increase. Intervention and support may mask difficulties in at least some contexts. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the severity of the condition, developmental level, and chronological age; hence the term spectrum. Diagnoses are most valid and reliable when based on multiple sources of information: clinical observations, caregiver history, self-report (when possible) 'Red Flags' for autism. Do not use this language when discussing symptomatology. DSM-5 perpetuated that "only a minority of individuals with autism spectrum disorder live and work independently in adulthood; those who tend to have superior language and intellectual abilities and are able to find a niche that matches their special interests and skills." DSM-5-TR: While it was once the case that only a minority of individuals with autism spectrum disorder lived and worked independently in adulthood, as diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder is made more frequently in those who have superior language and intellectual abilities, more individuals are able to find a niche that matches their special interests and skills and thus are productively employed. Access to vocational rehabilitation services significantly improves competitive employment outcomes for transition-age youth with autism spectrum disorder. In general, individuals with lower levels of impairment may be better able to function independently. 1 in 11 children Boys are twice as likely to be diagnosed as girls Symptoms can change over time Hyperactive/impulsive symptoms may decrease, but inattentive symptoms often remain Inattention and impulsivity can put children's health at risk from injury and disease. Best treated with behavior therapy, specifically parent training, and medication. Most common treatment is medication 2 in 3 children with ADHD take ADHD medication ADHD Rating Scale IV (ADHD-RS-IV) With Adult Prompts Adult ADHD Clinical Diagnostic Scale (ACDS) v 1.2 Adult ADHD Investigator Rating Scale (AISRS) Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) v 1.1 Adult ADHD Self-Report Screening Scale for DSM-5 (ASRS DSM-5) Screener Adult ASRS Symptom Checklist v 1.1 Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS-11) Brown Attention-Deficit Disorder Symptoms Assessment Scale (BADDS) for Adults Clinical Global Impressions (CGI) Conners' Adult ADHD Rating Scales (CAARS) Diagnostic Interview for ADHD in Adults (DIVA) 2.0 Wender Utah Rating Scale (WURS) Medication Psychotherapy and support CBT Family Therapy Parent Training

item.title: 4. Depressive Disorders
item.description:
Common feature is the presence of sad, empty, or irritable mood, accompanied by somatic and cognitive changes that significantly affect the individual's capacity to function. What differentiates the diagnoses? Duration, timing, and etiology of symptoms. Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder: Diagnosis should not be made for the first time before age 6 years old or after age 18. By history of observation, the age of onset is before 10 years old.
Major Depressive Disorder: Major depressive disorder may first appear at any age, but the likelihood of onset increases markedly with puberty. In the United States, incidence appears to peak in the 20 s.
Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymic Disorder) The essential feature of persistent depressive disorder is a depressed mood that occurs for most of the day, for more days than not, for at least 2 years, or at least 1 year for children and adolescents. Persistent depressive disorder often has an early and insidious onset (i.e., in childhood, adolescence, or early adult life) and, by definition, a chronic course.
Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder Onset of premenstrual dysphoric disorder can occur at any point after menarche.
Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder Onset of premenstrual dysphoric disorder can occur at any point after menarche. Major Depressive Disorder Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder Major Depressive Disorder Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) Depression is a common mental disorder. Globally, it is estimated that 5-10% of adults suffer from depression. Depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide and is a major contributor to the overall global burden of disease. More women are affected by depression than men. Depression can lead to suicide. There is effective treatment for mild, moderate, and severe depression. History of other mental health disorders, such as anxiety disorder, eating disorders, or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). History of other mental health disorders, such as anxiety disorder, eating disorders, or post-traumatic stress disorder. Abuse of alcohol or recreational drugs. Serious or chronic illness, including cancer, stroke, chronic pain, or heart disease. Certain medications, such as high blood pressure medications or sleeping pills. Environmental factors: Continuous exposure to violence Neglect Abuse or poverty May make some people more vulnerable to depression Certain personality traits, such as low self-esteem and being too dependent, self-critical, or pessimistic. People with low self-esteem, who are easily overwhelmed by stress, or who are generally pessimistic appear to be more likely to experience depression. Differences in certain chemicals in the brain may contribute to symptoms of depression. Traumatic or stressful events, such as physical or sexual abuse, the death or loss of a loved one, a difficult relationship, or financial problems. Blood relatives with a history of depression, bipolar disorder, alcoholism or suicide. Depression can run in families. For example, if one identical twin has depression, the other has a 70% chance of having the illness sometime in life. 5+ symptoms during the same 2-week period Represents a change from previous functioning At least one of the symptoms should be either Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. Diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day. Significant weight loss or gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day. Insomnia or hypersomnia A slowing down of thought and a reduction of physical movement (observable by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down) Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other functioning. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition. Not better explained by another disorder. There has never been a manic or hypomanic episode. The DSM-5-TR is not specifically designed for collective diagnosis. Understanding depressive disorders in fmilies requires exploration of the etiological aspects shaping the development of depression. We are born into families Family systems theories provide us with a framework for understanding individuals within context. Depression is an interaction of a family member's inner experiences and various outer systems affective the individual within the family. Relational and cultural factors influence depression. There are familial risk factors for depressive disorders Families shape views about the disorder and influence treatment Families are sources of strength and support Caregiver burden is important to consider There are systemic implications for treatment (relationships with other providers, particularly with primary care providers/behavioral health) Twin and adoptive studies The description, definition, assessment, and management of depression are influenced by cultural factors (e.g., gender identity, sexual orientation, race, ethnicity, religion, SES, etc.) Psychotherapy Psychoeducation Medication What is the problem as the family views it? Who has defined the problem? Who within the family is more involved in the problem? Who within the family is uninvolved and why? What are the family's experiences with the problem? Medication
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) Attachment-Based Family Therapy

item.title: 5. Bipolar and Related Disorders
item.description: The main thing to remember about the difference between Bipolar I and II, Mania is more problematic and have more disturbing behavior. Impulsive spending, gambling, and sex. May put themselves in risky situations (involving money, sex, drugs), some may be hyperfocused. Full blown mania usually have serious consequences. Some part of their life was profoundly impacted. Think about the time part. Severe because it can lead to serious consequences. How long did it last. Bipolar I and II is not a difference. Is it lasting for a long period of time or a short period of time? It is a common misperception that children cannot have bipolar disorder. Although most people are diagnosed with bipolar disorder in adolescence or adulthood, the symptoms can appear earlier in childhood. In children, happiness, silliness, and ‚Äúgoofiness‚Äù are normal in many social contexts; however, if these symptoms are recurrent, inappropriate to the context, and beyond what is expected for the developmental level of the child, they may meet the Criterion A mood requirement of abnormally elevated mood. For the happiness or silliness of a child to meet Criterion A, it must be distinctly increased from the child‚Äôs baseline and accompanied by persistently increased activity or energy levels that to those who know the child well are clearly unusual for that child. For a child‚Äôs symptoms to meet criteria for a manic episode, the symptoms must also meet Criterion B for mania and must also represent a change from the child‚Äôs usual baseline. In children, overestimation of abilities and belief that, for example, they are the best at a sport or the smartest in the class is normal; however, when such beliefs are present despite clear evidence to the contrary or the child attempts feats that are clearly dangerous and, most important, represent a change from the child‚Äôs normal behavior, the grandiosity criterion should be considered satisfied. The increased activity criterion can be difficult to ascertain in children; however, when the child takes on many tasks simultaneously, starts devising elaborate and unrealistic plans for projects, develops previously absent and developmentally inappropriate sexual preoccupations (not accounted for by sexual abuse or exposure to sexually explicit material), then Criterion B might be met based on clinical judgment. It is essential to determine whether the behavior represents a change from the child‚Äôs baseline behavior; occurs most of the day, nearly every day for the requisite time period; and occurs in temporal association with other symptoms of mania. The peak age at onset of bipolar I disorder across studies is between 20 and 30 years, but onset occurs throughout the life cycle. Special considerations are necessary to apply the diagnosis in children. Because children of the same chronological age may be at different developmental stages, it is difficult to define with precision what is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù or ‚Äúexpected‚Äù at any given point. Therefore, each child should be judged according to his or her own baseline in determining whether a particular behavior is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù or evidence of a manic episode. Although bipolar II disorder can begin in late adolescence and throughout adulthood, average age at onset is the mid-20s, which is slightly later than for bipolar I disorder but earlier than for major depressive disorder. Age at onset does not reliably distinguish between bipolar I and II disorder. The illness most often begins with a depressive episode and is not recognized as bipolar II disorder until a hypomanic episode occurs. For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode and numerous periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode. Cyclothymic disorder usually begins in adolescence or early adult life and is sometimes considered to reflect a temperamental predisposition to other disorders in this chapter. The vast majority of youth with cyclothymic disorder experience the onset of mood symptoms before age 10. Bipolar I Disorder Bipolar II Disorder Cyclothymic Disorder Bipolar I disorder is a manic-depressive disorder that can exist both with and without psychotic episodes. Bipolar II disorder consists of depressive and manic episodes which alternate and are typically less severe and do not inhibit function. Cyclothymic disorder is a cyclic disorder that causes brief episodes of hypomania and depression. Bipolar I (Mania) Bipolar II (Hypomania) Lasts at least one week, or any length if hospitalized due to mania Abnormal and persistent extreme expression of emotion or irritable mood and abnormal and persistent increase in activity or energy. During Criterion A symptoms, three or more of these symptoms (four if mood is only irritable) Inflated self-esteem and grandiosity Decrease in need for sleep More talkative than baseline or fast talking Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing Distractibility (reported or seen) Increase in goal-oriented activity (especially, at work, school, or sexually) or movements that serve no purpose Excessive engagement in activities with high risk of painful results (e.g., unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretion or foolish business investments) Mood disturbance severity Causes marked impairment in social or occupational functioning OR Requires hospitalization to prevent harm OR There are psychotic traits Differential diagnosis Substance use and medical causes are ruled out Distinct period that lasts at least four consecutive days and is present most of the day, nearly every day. Abnormally and persistent extreme expression of emotion or irritable mood and abnormal and persistent increase in activity or energy. In context of Criterion A above, three or more of these symptoms (four if mood is only irritable) have persisted and are markedly different from baseline and have been present to a significant degree. Inflated self-esteem and grandiosity Decrease in need for sleep More talkative than baseline or fast talking Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing Distractibility (reported or seen) Increase in goal-directed activity (socially, at work, school, or sexually) or movements that serve no purpose Excessive engagement in activities with high risk of painful results (unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions or foolish business investments) Unambigious change in functionining not characteristic of the person when not symptomatic Mood disturbance and change in function are observable by others Episode does not cause significant impairment and is not severe enough to require hospitalization If there are psychotic features, it is a manic (not hypomanic) episode. Not attributable to different diagnosis Substance use and medical causes are ruled out Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day Diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day Significant weight loss or gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day Insomnia or hypersomnia A slowing down of thought and a reduction of physical movement (observable by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down) Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode and numerous periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode. During the above 2 year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not been without symptoms for more than 2 months at a time. Specify if: With anxious distress With anxious distress With mixed features With melancholic features Atypoical features With psychotic features With catatonia With peripartum onset With seasonal patter Rapid cycling (Removed) Bipolar does not operate solely in an individual, but appears in relationships with disturbing force The challenges of bipolar are shared with families Family systems also impact the disorders' course and treatment. How do family members respond to the affected members? How much support is offered? How does the family respond to stressors? How do the larger support systems impact family functioning? Bipolar affects and is affected by the family system. Treatment is enhanced when family members understand the course and treatment of bipolar, and offer support. Identifying information Presenting problem History of the presenting problem including mental health history Medical history Family history Personal history that includes a developmental timeline Mental status exam Appearance, behaviors/psychomotor activity, attitudes, affect and mood, speech and thought, perceptual disturbances, orientation and consciousness, memory and intelligence, reliability/judgement/insight Biopsychosocial History Legal problems, substance use, spirituality/religion, cultural/racial/ethnic background, suicidal ideation/planning/attempts, financial concerns and SES, resources and resilience factors Psychopharmacology Lithium bicarbonate or other mood stabilizers Antidepressants Atypical antipsychotics Good sleep hygiene is one of the easiest and best ways to help prevent triggering mania Medication compliance is an issue Hospitalizations, intensive outpatient programs Family interventions Pharmacologic intervention integrated with individual psychotherapy has been found to be more effective than either protocol alone Focus is on symptom reduction and prevention of future episodes The disorder cannot be separated from the individual's psychosocial context and influences Family Focused Treatment which is an integrative approach to treatment combining psychoeducation and family therapy Psychoeducation Communication enhancement Problem solving

item.title: 3. Diagnostic Assessment
item.description: Includes conditions and psychosocial or environmental problems that are not considered to be mental disorders but otherwise affect the diagnosis, course, prognosis, or treatment of an individual's mental disorder. These conditions are presented with their corresponding codes from the ICD-10-CM (usually Z codes) A condition or problem in this chapter may be coded with or without an accompanying mental disorder diagnosis: If it is a reason for the current visit If it helps to explain the need for a test, procedure, or treatment If it plays a role in the initiation or exacerbation of a mental disorder If it constitutes a problem that should be considered in the overall management plan Suicidal behavior and nonsuicidal self-injury Abuse and neglect Relational problems (e.g., Relationship Distress with Spouse or Intimate Partner) Educational, occupational, housing, and economic problems Problems related to the social environment, interaction with the legal system, and other psychosocial, personal, and environmental circumstances (e.g., problems related to unwanted pregnancy being a victim of crime or terrorism) Problems related to access to medical and other health care Circumstances of personal history (e.g., personal history of psychological trauma) Other health service encounters for counseling and medical advice (e.g., sex counseling) Additional conditions or problems that may be a focus of clinical attention (e.g., wandering associated with a mental disorder, uncomplicated bereavement, phase of life problem) Neurodevelopmental Disorders (Neurodevelopmental is a term referring to the brain's development of neurological pathways that influence performance or functioning, reading ability, social skills, memory, attention or focus skills) Intellectual Developmental Disorders Intellectual Developmental Disorder Global Development Delay Communication Disorders Language Disorder Speech Sound Disorder Childhood-Onset Fluency Disorder Social Communication Disorder Autism Spectrum Disorder Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Specific Learning Disorder Motor Disorders Developmental Coordination Disorder Stereotypic Movement Disorder Tic Disorders Tourette's Disorder Persistent Motor or Vocal Tic Disorder Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders (Psychotic should be called 'thought disorders'; People with psychosis typically experience delusions (false beliefs) and hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that others do not)) Schizotypal Personality Disorder Delusional Disorder Brief Psychotic Disorder Schizophreniform Disorder Schizophrenia Disorder Bipolar and Related Disorders (Mood Disorders) Bipolar I Disorder Bipolar II Disorder Cyclothymic Disorder Depressive Disorders (Mood Disorders) Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder Major Depressive Disorder Persistent Depressive Disorder Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder Anxiety Disorders (Anxiety is not a mood disorder. However, anxiety often precedes or coexists with mood disorders.) Separation Anxiety Disorder Selective Mutism Specific Phobia Social Anxiety Disorder Panic Disorder Agoraphobia Generalized Anxiety Disorder Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders (In DSM-III, DSM-III-R, and DSM-IV, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) was classified as an anxiety disorder) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder Body Dysmorphic Disorder Hoarding Disorder Trichotillomania Excoriation Disorder Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorders (Trauma- and Stressor-related disorders are those disorders precipitated by events or circumstances that overwhelm the child or adolescent and that often threaten or cause serious injury, neglect, or death) Reactive Attachment Disorder Disinhibited Social Engagement Disorder Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) Acute Stress Disorder Adjustment Disorder Prolonged Grief Disorder Dissociative Disorders Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) Somatic Symptom and Related Disorders Somatic Symptom Disorder Illness Anciety Disorder Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder Factitious Disorder Feeding and Eating Disorders Pica Rumination Disorder Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder Anorexia Disorder Bulimia Nervosa Binge-Eating Disorder Elimination Disorders Enuresis Encopresis Other Elimination Disorder Sleep-Wake Disorders Insomnia Disorder Hyposomnolence Disorder Narcolepsy Breathing-Related Sleep Disorders Parasomnia Sexual Dysfunctions Delayed Ejaculation Erectile Disorder Female Orgasmic Disorder Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder Premature Ejaculation Gender Dysphoria Gender Dysphoria Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorder (Conduct/Behavior) Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) Intermittent Explosive Disorder Conduct Disorder Antisocial Personality Disorder Pyromania Kleptomania Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders Alcohol-Related Disorders Alcohol Use Disorder Alcohol Intoxication Alcohol Withdrawal Caffeine-Related Disorders Caffeine Intoxication Caffeine Withdrawal Cannabis-Related Disorders Cannabis Use Disorder Cannabis Intoxication Cannabis Withdrawal Hallucinogen Phencyclidine Use Disorder Other Hallucinogen Use Disorder Phencyclidine Intoxication Inhalant-Related Disorders Inhalant Use Disorder Inhalant Intoxication Opioid-Related Disorders Opioid Use Disorder Opioid Intoxication Opioid Withdrawal Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic-Related Disorders Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Intoxication Stimulant-Related Disorders Stimulation Intoxication Stimulation Withdrawal Tobacco-Related Disorders Tobacco Use Disorders Tobacco Withdrawal Neurocognitive Disorders (Cognitive decline, not developmental) Delirium Major and Mild Neurocognitive Disorders (Major previously called dementia) Personality Disorders Cluster A Personality Disorders Paranoid Personality Disorder Schizoid Personality Disorder Schizotypal Personality Disorder Cluster B Personality Disorders Antisocial Personality Disorder Borderline Personality Disorder Historic Personality Disorder Narcissistic Personality Disorder Cluster C Personality Disorders Avoidant Personality Disorder Dependent Personality Disorder Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder Paraphilic Disorders (Abnormal Sexual Desires) Voyeuristic Disorder Exhibitionistic Disorder Frotteuristic Disorder Sexual Masochism Sexual Sadism Disorder Pedophilic Disorder Fetishistic Disorder The relationship comes first Making a diagnosis is a team effort Open-ended and check-list questions Use screeners/questions to hone in on the diagnosis Pay attention to clinical significance Risk/Benefit analysis of diagnosis Understand comorbidity Be cautious about 'other' categories Document your thinking Remember the stakes are high

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 2. Diagnostic Principles
item.description:
DSM-TR is a manual for assessment and diagnosis of mental disorders and does not include information or guidelines for treatment of any disorder. Determining an accurate diagnosis is the first step toward being able to appropriately treat any medical condition, and mental disorders are no exception. DSM-5-TR is helpful in measuring the effectiveness of treatment, as dimensional assessments will assist clinicians in assessing changes in severity levels as a response to treatment. 1840: Category 'insanity' first attempt to quantify and name psychiatric diagnoses. 1844: APA published a predecessor of the DSM: A classification of institutionalized mental patients Early 1900s: First description of schizophrenia by Emil Kraeplin. 1917: Statistical Manual for the Use of Institutions for the Insane, included 22 diagnoses. 1952: First DSM, 130 pages long, 106 disorders 1994: DSM IV, 886 pages long, 297 disorders 2000: DSM IV-TR, 943 pages long, 365 disorders 2013: DSM 5, 991 pages long, 157 disorders 2022: DSM-5-TR, 1050 pages long A mental disorder is a syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotion regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning. Mental disorders are usually associated with significant distress or disability in social, occupational, or other important activities. An expectable or culturally approved response to a common stressor or loss, such as the death of a loved one, is not a mental disorder. Socially deviant behavior (e.g., political, religious, or sexual) and conflicts that are primarily between the individual and society are not mental disorders unless the deviance or conflict results from dysfunction in the individual, as described above. The DSM is a classification of mental disorders with associated criteria which facilitate diagnosis. It is the standard reference for clinical practice in mental health. Please also be familiar with the World Health Organization's International Classification of Diseases (ICD) (ICD-10 Codes) The science of diagnosis and mental disorders continues to evolve. Too rigid a categorical system does not capture clinical experience or important scientific observations. The validity of diagnosis is important (that is... the degree to which diagnostic criteria reflect the comprehensive manifestation of an underlying psychopathological disorder). Clinical training and experience is needed to use the DSM for determining a diagnosis. The diagnostic criteria identify symptoms, behaviors, cognitive functions, personality traits, physical signs, and durations that require clinical expertise to differentiate from normal life variation and responses to stress. Reliable diagnoses are essential for: Guiding treatment Identifying prevalence rates Identifying clients for clinical research Documenting public health information Standardizes billing and coding Standardizes diagnoses and treatment Guides research Guides treatment Oversimplifies human behavior Increases risk of misdiagnosis or over-diagnosis Provides labels, which can be stigmatizing Growing scientific evidence favors dimensional diagnosis of mental disorders. Takes into account individual subjective report of symptom experience and clinician interpretation. Integrates both objective and subjective data to enhance the accuracy of the diagnostic process. Integrates measures administered at initial interview and over time to track symptom status and response to treatment. A categorical approach to assessment relies on diagnostic criteria to determine the presence or absence of disruptive or other abnormal behaviors, whereas a dimensional approach places such behaviors on a continuum of frequency and/or severity. Ask Categorical (Yes/No) Ask Frequency (How often?) Ask Intensity/Severity (Rating: mild, moderate, severe) Ask Duration (How long does it last?) Disorder-specific and correspond closely to the diagnostic criteria. Some are self-completed by the individual, couple, or family. Interpreted by clinician Shared back with the individual, couple, or family Others require a clinician to complete Categories: Cognition (understanding and communicating) Mobility (moving and getting around) Self-Care (hygiene, dressing, eating, and staying alone) Getting Along (interacting with other people) Life Activities (domestic responsibilities, leisure, work and school) Participation (joining in community activities) A generic assessment instrument for health and disability Used across all diseases, including mental, neurological, and addictive disorders Short, simple and easy to administer (5 to 20 minutes) Applicable in both clinical and general population settings A tool to produce standardized disability levels and profiles Applicable across cultures, in all adult populations Directly linked at the level of the concepts to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (ICF) An assessment of the member's needs based on: Baseline measurements Symptoms Behavior Skills Abilities Resources Vulnerabilities Safety Assessment methods and use of standardized assessment tools. Clinical summary, including recommendations and prioritization of needed mental health or other services. Involvement of the member and member's family in the assessment and his or her preferences or referrals to services. Sufficient data to support findings on all axes of the current Diagnostic and Statistic Manual (DSM), and any differential diagnosis. Understanding the cultural context of illness is essential for effective diagnostic assessment and treatment. Culture: Systems of knowledge, concepts, rules, and practices that are learned and transmitted across generations, including language, religion, spirituality, family structure, lifecycle stages, ceremonial rituals, customs, legal systems.
Race: Culturally constructed category of identity that divides humanity into groups based on superficial physical traits attributed to biological characteristics
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Ethnicity: Culturally constructed group identity used to define people and communities. Rooted in a common history, geography, language, religion, or shared characteristics. Describe the client's racial, ethnic, and cultural group (s) that might influence relationships with others, access to resources, and developmental and current challenges. Involvement with host culture and major culture. Language abilities, access to care, social integration, need for interpreter. Religious affiliation, socioeconomic background, family of origin, migrant status, gender identity, sexual orientation, etc. Describe the cultural constructs that influence how the individual experiences, understands, and communicates symptoms. Cultural syndromes, idioms of distress, and cultural explanations for symptoms. Use of professional, tradition, alternative, and complementary sources of care. Identify key stressors and supports in the social environment. Local and distant. Role of religion, family, and social networks (e.g., friends, neighbors, coworkers) in providing emotional, instrumental, and informational support. Levels of functioning, disability and resilience. Identify differences in culture, language, social status, gender identity, sexual orientation, education, etc that may cause difficulties in communication, diagnosis, and treatment. Experiences of racism and discrimination. Problems in eliciting symptoms or misunderstanding the cultural and clinical significance of symptoms. To avoid misdiagnosis To obtain useful/relevant clinical information To build rapport and engagement Speak the language of the client To improve treatment efficacy To guide clinical research To clarify cultural epidemiology Assessment Measures Pgs. 841-858 Culture and Psychiatric Diagnosis Pgs. 859-880

item.description: Use Abuse Dependence Excessive use of psychoactive drugs, such as alcohol, pain medications, or illegal drugs. It can lead to physical, social, or emotional harm. Even simpler Pathological pattern related to use of the substance Features Increased over times in extent

item.title: 12. Sexual Dysfunctions; Gender Dysphoria; Paraphilic Disorder
item.description: A group of disorders that are typically characterized by a clinically significant disturbance in a person's ability to respond sexually or to experience sexual pleasure. Disturbances in sexual response or sexual pleasure. Clinically significant. Destigmatize clinical assessment of sexual dysfunctions. Understand the risk factors. Assess for sexual functioning in the clinical interview. Remember that in many couples, underlying sexual dysfunctions exacerbate the presenting problem - whether that be issues in intimacy, communication, conflict resolution, infidelity, mood disorders, etc. Conduct the evaluation in comfortable surroundings and ensure privacy Be empathic, nonjudgmental, and understanding Preferably use the language in which patient is comfortable Use neutral terms (as opposed to vulgar terms) and proper medical terms as long as there are in common usage (e.g., use 'penis' and 'vagina,' but perhaps 'lips' rather than 'labia') Use anatomical drawings to understand patients knowledge and explain sexual issues to the patient Reassure the patient that sexual dysfunction or adjustment problems are common and treatable. ("It is common for some people to...") Explain things in simple, clear and specific terms. Some patients may not be able to understand the language which is commonly used by clinicians and may feel embarrassed to admit this. Hence, whenever new terms are used, provide alternatives or explanations. Check with the patients that they understand the terms used Start with general, non-threatening questions first (e.g., "Do you have a regular partner?") then ask more specific and potentially embarrassing questions (e.g., "Do you also experience this problem when you masturbate, that is, when you touch or stimulate yourself?") Assumptions must be avoided (e.g., sexual orientation, numbers of partners, sexual practices) If a couple has presented together, gather the information for a sexual history from each individual separately (i.e., not in each other's presence) Conduct the evaluation in presence of a female attendant/relative while examining patients of opposite gender Make sure that the 'problem' does not just reflect a lack of knowledge or unrealistic expectations on the part of the presenting individual or their partner. Understand the cultural and religious factors which influence sexual issues Although sexual dysfunction may occur in isolation, in many cases there may be co-existing problems contributing to the dysfunction (e.g., relationship difficulties, psychiatric or physical illness) - prioritize the treatment goals in such situations Assess psychological sophistication and motivation of the patient/couple Bio / psycho / social Trauma Insecurity Exposure / Introduction to Sex Distraction Depression Anxiety Poor Communication Myths Self-Image It is usually not just one thing. There may be multiple drivers. Remember, all behavior makes sense in context. Rule out physical / biological, then proceed to psycho / social contributors.

item.title: 11. Schizophrenia Spectrum; Somatic Disorders; Sleep-Wake Disorders
item.description: Scattered Not alone Disjointed Disconnected Schizophrenia is a serious mental illness that affects how a person think, feels, and behaves. People with schizophrenia may seem as though they have lost touch with reality, which can be distressing for them and for their family and friends. The symptoms of schizophrenia can make it difficult to participate in usual, everyday activities. Delusions Hallucinations Disorganized Thinking (Speech) Disorganized or Abnormal Behavior Negative Symptoms (Mood) Altered perceptions (e.g., changes in vision, hearing, smell, touch, and taste), abnormal thinking, and odd behaviors. People with psychotic symptoms may lose a shared sense of reality and experience themselves and the world in a distorted way. Specifically, individuals typically experience: Hallucinations, such as hearing voices or seeing things that aren't there Delusions, which are firmly held beliefs not supported by objective facts (e.g., paranoia - irrational fears that others are 'out to get you' or believing that the television, radio, or internet are broadcasting special messages that require some response) Thought Disorder, which includes unusual thinking or disorganized speech. Loss of motivation, disinterest or lack of enjoyment in daily activities Social withdrawal Difficulty showing emotions Difficulty functioning normally Specifically, individuals typically have: Reduced motivation and difficulty planning, beginning, and sustaining activities Diminished Pleasure in every day life "Flat Affect", or reduced expression of emotions via facial expression or voice tone. Problems in attention, concentration, and memory For some individuals, the cognitive symptoms of schizophrenia are subtle, but for others, they are more prominent and interfere with activities like following conversations, learning new things, or remembering appointments. Specifically, individuals typically experience: Difficulty processing information to make decisions Problems using information immediately after learning it Trouble focusing or paying attention Schizophrenia Schizoaffective Disorder
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diagnosis (HDFS 8881)/Lecture/11. Schizophrenia Spectrum; Somatic Disorders; Sleep-Wake Disorders.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Introduction
item.description: Family systems texts have case examples to look into. Get the spiral bound DSM Some MFTs are not using insurance but rather billing for self-pay. Collaborate with your client to use the DSM with transparency. If you are to put a diagnosis in the record, you must discuss this with the diagnosis. It is not consensual if the client is not aware of the diagnosis. You must be respectful of the client and their wishes. It is important to ensure trust with the public. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) is the handbook used by health care professionals in the US and much of the world as the authoritative guide to the diagnosis of mental disorders DSM contains descriptions, symptoms, and other criteria for diagnosing mental disorders. It also provides a common language for researchers to study the criteria for potential future revisions and to aid in the development of medications and other interventions.
