item.title: Announcements
item.description:
Ohio History Connection Mozarts The oval Scioto deer Varsity club The shoe North market Kelton house In this week's spotlight for attractions, we have Ohio History Connection (https://www.ohiohistory.org/Links to an external site.)! The Ohio History Connection, formerly the Ohio Historical Society, is a statewide history organization with the mission to spark discovery of Ohio‚Äôs stories. As a nonprofit organization chartered in 1885, the Ohio History Connection carries out history services for Ohio and its citizens focused on preserving and sharing the state‚Äôs history. This includes housing the State Historic Preservation Office, the official state archives and the Community Engagement Department and managing more than 50 sites and museums across Ohio. I participated in their event on site. They hosted a bunch of reenactors there to reenact the 1950s! That event should also be happening again around the beginning of the year, so I hope to see you there! This museum is really cool to walk through, and they are always hosting events. 
For our restaurant, this week I chose Mozart's (https://mozartscafe.com/Links to an external site.)! Mozart's has been a Clintonville destination for over 20 years. Mozart‚Äôs brings Europe to Columbus through breakfast, lunch, dinner, and an incredible variety of decadent European pastries. This "taste of Austria" is accompanied by live piano music and jazz on select nights. Make sure you also check out the beautifully restored building, which was built in the 1920s.Columbus lore... Columbus was first laid out in 1812 and incorporated in 1816. Columbus was not the original capital, but the state legislature chose to move the state government there after short periods in both Chillicothe and Zanesville. Columbus was chosen as the site for the new capital because of its central location within the state and access to transportation routes (primarily rivers) at that time. The legislature chose it as Ohio's capital over a number of other competitors, including Franklinton, Dublin, Worthington, and Delaware. Prior to the state legislature's decision in 1812, Columbus did not exist. The city was designed from the first as the state's capital, preparing itself for its role in Ohio's political, economic, and social life.During the twentieth century, Columbus continued to grow and prosper. Due to lighted arches that spanned over the city's major north-south thoroughfare, High Street, Columbus earned the reputation of being the most "brilliantly illuminated city in the country." Most of these arches disappeared by mid century, but in 2002, the city began to construct new ones to celebrate Columbus' past. If you would like to add any suggestions, please feel free to comment below!I hope this weather clears up and we get some sunny fall days. The leaves are falling! Where does the time go. Have a wonderful week, and please reach out to myself or Anna, our TA, if you have any questions or concerns. Warmest regards,Lynn ReidingerAnother week, another (late) announcement,I hope you are having a great week, we are halfway through, whether that's the semester or the week you decide! This week we will begin to look at the basic patterns of sexual orientation and behavior. We also look at the critiques on sexual attitudes, sex education, and the sexual double standard. By the end of this module, you will be able to answer some questions such as... What is sexual orientation? How have attitudes toward homosexuality changed in the medical and scientific communities? According to researchers, what is the role of genetics, evolution, and social environment in determining sexual orientation? REMINDER: Please put aside enough time to watch 'How to Lose Your Virginity' (1 hour and 6 minutes) and 'Sex 101' (20 min). 
In this week's restaurant, I chose Belle's Bread. Tucked away in the Japanese marketplace located on Kenny Centre Mall, Belle‚Äôs BreadLinks to an external site. is a family-owned and -operated, French-inspired Japanese bakery. Takashi Takenaka opened the business after immigrating from Japan in 1972, and he pays homage to childhood treats with his red bean roll, frank roll, and curry and boiled egg doughnuts. The bear-shaped strawberry cream bun is all over social media, but the best-kept secret is the Mont Blanc roll with its layers of delicate, airy sweet cream and chestnuts. 
In Columbus Lore this week, our amazing student Doug Motz wrote this piece on the AIU & The LeVeque TowerLinks to an external site.. I learned so much information from this article, and it is just one piece of history from our city. Please take a moment to read through this article, if you get the chance. You know that big building that has those beautiful lights displayed at the top? Yup, that's this place! It has gone through it's fair share of history, and many owners. Apparently, the floodlights that were installed in 1989 had theatrical gel placed by hand to add the color to the tower. Though, this was updated in 2017 with LEDs that allow for color changes with ease. No more applying that gel by one very brave man. Thank you, Doug!! Just a wonderful piece of history to share with you all. Go outside and play in the leaves, take a moment to breathe. You have done so well, and I am so proud of you! Keep working hard as you always have, and remember to take care of yourself this week. :)Warmest regards,Lynn ReidingerGoooooooood Evening Buckeyes! Describe the contemporary social scrip that characterizes romantic relationship formation for college students and young adults. Evaluate how relationship rituals such as texting, hooking up, online dating, datings apps are changing partner selection and intimate relationships. Describe the roles that attraction and attractiveness play in mate selection and define personality characteristics that make someone attractive. Critique marital attitudes over the past 150 years and their effect on mate selection. On this week's Columbus lore, I thought I would bring it a little closer to home and look into OSU's history. You know that beautiful building you most likely walk by regularly called University Hall? Well, do I have some interesting facts for you.This was the first classroom building opened in 1873! 
‚ÄúAnnouncements-1.png‚Äù could not be found. ‚ÄúAnnouncements-2.png‚Äù could not be found.
On the first day of classes in September 1873, the students entered an unfinished University Hall. This first building on campus was a classroom building, library, administrative office building, and it had apartments for faculty and dormitory rooms for male students. (The students moved out when the first dormitory opened in 1874). It even housed the Geology Museum until Orton Hall opened in 1893. University Hall had a chapel as well, which was originally used for a daily religious service.
In the spring of 1968 concern about the building's structural integrity led to a study of its safety. It was determined to be unsafe, and on May 9, 1968, the Board of Trustees instructed the administrative officials of the University to move everything out of the building. University Hall was torn down in September 1971. Today‚Äôs University Hall occupies almost exactly the same spot as the original University Hall (it is slightly east). When the original University Hall was torn down, there was quite a bit of discussion over which architectural style the new building should have. Eventually, University officials decided to make the new University Hall look the same as the original building on the outside. Although less ornamental, and smaller, today‚Äôs University Hall is still a landmark on campus. It was completed in 1976. (https://library.osu.edu/site/buckeyestroll/university-hall/Links to an external site.)For a random Columbus restaurant, I wanted something close to campus. I chose Emmett's Cafe! This bakery/cafe is located in the Old North. Inspired by Australian coffee culture, Emmett‚Äôs is the top pick for morning hangouts with a flat white or cold brew. This laid-back spot recently opened a second, much larger and brighter location at the Open Air building, a renovated school building in Old North. Open until 2pm during the work week, the cafe offers wifi and plenty of space to spread out with a few coworkers. Food options go far beyond pastries, with options like overnight oats, filling breakfast sandwiches, grain bowls, wraps, and even a wagyu burger. A random attraction, one that is certainly not everyone's taste, but I thought I would share nonetheless, Wagner-Hagans Auto Museum! This auto museum is a private collection here in Columbus that is free and open to the public. This is a small museum without regular staff, so you do need to call and schedule an appointment to tour the museum.I am certainly not one to be personal, but I thought it was only appropriate to share. I got married this weekend! My husband and I decided to elope and read our vows in Hocking Hills. It was only appropriate we read our vows near Ash Cave, since that is the new last name I am taking. If you see me signing Millie Ash, that is my new name! You are more than welcome to call me Lynn or Millie. I will include a picture of Ted and me at the trailhead!I hope the cool weather is a welcomed relief to the blistering heat we had over the last several weeks. Get that pumpkin spice latte for yourself, you deserve that treat! I can't wait to see the leaves falling all over campus. Warmest regards,Millie Lynn Ash (Lynn Reidinger)Hey Class,I apologize for missing our weekly announcement last week, but I was unfortunately not feeling well. We can't skip this week, what if some of you are waiting on this week's Columbus lore? As always, I will have interesting history, activities, and suggested restaurants below.You worked through your midterm, WOO! I am so proud of each of you for getting to this point in the semester. I can't believe we are almost finished. It has been a pleasure getting to know each and every one of you. Thank you to each of you that congratulated me on my marriage, and this week seems very fitting!This week we look at marriage and cohabitation. Be mindful as we reflect on diversity, inequality, and social change in terms of marriage. We will consider how marital quality changes across the life course and illustrate the hallmarks of poor marital communication. Do you know what are the predictors of a high quality, satisfying marriage? What specific relationships come to mind when you think of a healthy marriage?This week's assignments are outlined below. As always, we accept your assignments 24-hours late with a 2-point deduction on your essays and discussions, and a 1-point deduction for your weekly reflections. We are unable to accept your InQuizitive quizzes late. Please read: Chapter 8 of The Family - Cohen (2020) The Suffocation Model: Why Marriage in America Is Becoming an All-or-Nothing Institution (Finkel, 2015) The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse (Why Marriages Succeed and Fail - Gottman, 1994) Class Differences in Cohabitation Processes (Sassler and Miller, 2011) Reminders,  InQuizitive: Chapter 8 (Cohabitation and Marriage): 10/25/2023 Engage Discussion 8: Cohabitation: 10/27/2023 Essay 8: The True Hard Work of Love and Relationships: 10/30/2023 Reflection 8: 10/30/2023 Columbus Lore: The Oval!


Originally, there was no formal plan for an Oval. The space in front of University Hall was intended to be a large rectangle, in the tradition of an English manor.By 1900, however, the Oval began to form as buildings cropped up around the open space. In 1905 there were no sidewalks and students joked of people disappearing into the mud. The mud paths were studied and eventually their locations influenced where sidewalks were placed.The Oval also contains several memorials. The most well-known is perhaps ‚ÄúThe Five Brothers,‚Äù which is composed of five elm trees planted as a class gift. The originals were planted in 1891 and succumbed to Dutch Elm Disease, the last in 1971; the replacements were planted in 1987. Other memorials include the flagpole in front of Bricker Hall, dedicated in 1917 to graduates killed in WWI, and a sundial, a gift from the class of 1905, which now stands in Sphinx Plaza.The Oval has been home to commencements, rallies, student demonstrations, cavalry drills, contests, and even a musical chairs contest for charity.
Riveting Restaurants: Anthony Thomas Candy Company.!
Anthony Zanetos immigrated to the United States from Greece in 1907. His first job was as an apprentice candy maker in a local candy shop in Columbus, Ohio. It was in 1916, when Anthony experienced the urge to go into business for himself. This decision molded the lives of four generations. In 1932, Anthony opened the Co-op Dairy at the corner of Chicago Avenue and Broad Street in Franklinton. It was Anthony‚Äôs dream for a father and son business. In 1945 Anthony‚Äôs son Tom, returned home from service following W.W.II. Together they started Anthony‚Äôs Confectionary where the Co-op Dairy used to be. Following the war, sugar was rationed and Veterans that were in the candy business could get a 30,000-pound annual allotment of sugar, which made Tom a valuable asset and an instant partner with his father. Realizing the quality of the candy was creating a demand, Tom and his father decided to make it a full time trade, and using their first names they formed the Anthony-Thomas Candy Company in 1952.Astounding Activities: The Scioto Deer ‚ÄúAnnouncements-8.png‚Äù could not be found.You may have probably seen at least one of the three bronze deer sculptures located throughout Columbus, but do you know why they‚Äôre actually there? It‚Äôs okay, neither did I. These friendly, relaxed-looking deer were added to the Scioto Mile as part of the big rehabilitation project in 2014 that turned the area into the incredible multi-use park and trail space it is now.There are a total of three deer along the Scioto River admiring the river, and they were put in during the renovation. Two of these funky art pieces are behind COSI and the other is on the Rich Street Bridge watching over our beloved city. So don‚Äôt worry everyone, the deer are protecting us. I hope you all have a great week. I should be on tomorrow for our office hours if you may need anything (My office hours are Tuesdays from 1p-2p). Please take some time this week to soak in some sun and enjoy this fall weather. You have worked so hard to get to this point!Warmest regards,Millie Lynn AshIT'S HALLOWEEN!!!This is my favorite holiday, and it makes me so happy to see people dressed up while walking around campus. Make sure to grab some candy for yourself (... getting it on sale tomorrow does in fact count), and take it easy this week. This week's topic some of you may already have some experience with, whether directly or indirectly, parenting. We will analyze societal expectations and attitudes around parenthood and childlessness. We will also look at concepts of intensive motherhood, helicopter parenting, and co-parenting. REMINDERS:InQuizitive (Chapter 9): 11/1Discussion (Intensive Parenting): 11/3Essay 9: 11/5Reflection 9: 11/5
On this week's Columbus lore, we are back on campus with my personal favorite: Mirror Lake
It is very fitting to choose this wonderful place as our topic for Columbus Lore. The first contact with the lake was not with a person, as its history might suggest, but a horiculture wagon! Students rolled the wagon into the lake as a Halloween prank in 1895. The lake has a history of dunking freshman and tug-of-war across the lake. The Lantern depicted a freshman in the middle of the lake, dubbed the 'Freshman Bathtub.' In the 1920s, the tradition of dunking freshmen into the lake had been given approval from the student council and the university president. The rules: Freshmen must wear a specific cap at all times and not step food on the Long Walk, the brick path across the Oval leading up to Thompson library. Only assigned enforcers of the Bucket and Dipper club were allowed to toss freshmen into the lake. The last the lake would see of any tug-of-war across the lake was around the 1950s. It was stated the 3 minutes it took for one side to take over the other felt like 3 hours for people in attendance! In 1964, an engaged couple 'quarreled' at the lake; the man took back the engagement ring and threw it in the lake, and the woman went searching for it in a bikini. She was initially arrested but the executive dean finally allowed her to resume the search in different attire. She found the ring!‚ÄúAnnouncements-9.png‚Äù could not be found.
Riveting Restaurants: Thurn's Specialty MeatsOn easter weekend in 1886, Alois 'Grospop' Thurn opened up a stall at the old Central Market and began selling old world style, processed items. He immigrated to Columbus from Germany a few years before and had begun working at a processing plant. He used the scraps to make meals for his family, and then his neighbors. In 1958, with the new interstate encroaching, his son, Alois, along with his grandsons, Robert, Paul and Leo, began construction on a new plant and storeroom.  This facility is still in use today.  In 1965, the Thurn brothers moved out the Central Market, 2 years before its demise.  Since that time, 530 Greenlawn Avenue is the only place to buy Thurn‚Äôs products.Astounding Activities: ‚ÄúAnnouncements-10.png‚Äù could not be found.
For those of you who have not heard, Columbus has a very special field of corn. The Field of Corn is an art installation that playfully reshapes the landscape. Rows of towering concrete corn cobs invite contemplation on themes of agriculture, transformation, and artistic expression. Unearth the artist‚Äôs vision behind this unique creation and its role in Columbus‚Äôs cultural tapestry.There was the first frost, and I definitely felt slow getting to class this morning. Mr. Ted has been coming to campus with me, so if you ever see us walking by don't be afraid to say hi!Have a fantastic week!Warmest regards,Millie Lynn AshHi Buckeyes!Though we are not covering anything this week, I wanted to send an announcement out to all of you regarding the event that will take place for each of you tomorrow. Thanksgiving is a time to gather with our families, eat some nice hearty food, and take a wondrous carb nap afterwards! For some, you may not celebrate or do anything at all. My home is open to each and every one of you if you do not have anyone to celebrate the holidays with. You have become a part of my family over this semester, even if I still have yet to actually meet you in person. As we have learned, family is a broad spectrum that includes a variety of circumstances, contexts, and people. Our family includes those we love, those we don't, those who would answer their phone in the middle of the night, those we turn to in times of need, those we learn from, and so many more. Whatever role your family plays in your life, please know you will be forever in mine. I will always be here to support you on your journey to wherever you are going. To change tune a bit, do you really know the origins of Thanksgiving? Thanksgiving is known for its yummy food and terrible traffic, but did you know the first European Thanksgiving in the United States was celebrated in 1564? This tradition, though centuries old, was not the first. The credit for that event goes to Native Americans.From contemporaneous records, we know that the Pilgrims and Native Americans had turkey and other game birds, as well as sea foods, venison, Indian corn, beans, berries, and nuts. They drank mostly beer, wine, and whiskies - all safer than the local water. Thanksgiving as a holiday originates from the Native American philosophy of giving without expecting anything in return. In the first celebration of this holiday, the Wampanoag tribe provided not only the food for the feast but also the teachings of agriculture and hunting (corn, beans, wild rice, and turkey are some specific examples of foods introduced by Native Americans).Though you may have known about the information above, did you know that the fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving) is recognized as the National Day of Mourning for Native Americans and their families.  For many Native Americans, Thanksgiving is a day of mourning and protest since it commemorates the arrival of settlers in North America and the centuries of oppression and genocide that followed. While some Native Americans have chosen to reject the Thanksgiving holiday entirely, many embrace the positive messages of the day and choose to put aside thoughts about its complex history. This is because the idea of giving thanks is central to Native heritage and culture. In this way, Thanksgiving is simply a chance to appreciate the good things in life, like family, community, and the riches of the land. Long before settlers arrived, Native tribes celebrated the autumn harvest and the gift of Mother Earth's abundance. Native American spirituality, traditionally and today, emphasizes gratitude for creation, care for the environment, and recognition of the human need for communion with nature and others. Now, regardless of the day's ambiguous origin, many Native Americans will gather with friends and family and use the day to eat good food (many of the classic Thanksgiving dishes are inspired by indigenous foods) and give thanks. I hope you learned something from above, and remember to actually rest over break. I know how easy it is to just work through it, as I probably will. Do as I say, not as I do! Take care of yourselves, and drive safe. Tonight is the heaviest drinking night of the year, and I passed many accidents on my way today. Your life and safety matter more than those extra couple minutes you save. Whether you celebrate or don't, be kind, grateful, and gentle with yourself and others this break. Don't add to the population, don't subtract from the population, and don't get sent to prison. I can't becoming an auntie just yet!We are almost finished, I can't believe how quickly the time has flown by. It has been an absolute pleasure getting to know each and every one of you over the last several months. Remember, you always have a home with me. Warmest regards,Millie Lynn AshHappy Tuesday everyone!Though this announcement will be reaching you a day later than usual, I still wanted to check in on everyone. This week's content is critical to consider in our current political sphere. We will analyze social issues that have impacted inequality and social change with regard to family life among Native Americans, African Americans, Latinos, Asian Americans, and Americans from the Middle East. I want you to examine your own racial/ethnic identity and privilege and how it manifests in family life. We discuss examples of implicit bias and microaggressions and how they impact the individual and family. 
We will be reading Chapter 3 in Cohen (2020) this week, which is posted under the top module labelled 'Textbook Information.' You will also be taking a look at a few videos on racism and microaggressions. Things to keep in mind for this week:
Chapter 3: Race, Ethnicity, and Immigration (due January 29th)
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Family Development (2200)/Announcements.md

item.title: Relationship Questionnaire
item.description: How did you and your partner meet? Tell me your story. What attracted you to your partner? What are some of the strengths of your relationship? Currently, what is the most serious threat to your relationship? When did you first notice problems of a serious nature? Do you wish to please your partner? What are the actions you currently do to please your partner? What are the actions your partner takes to currently please you? What actions would you like your partner to take to please you? What attributes do you like about your partner? What attributes does your partner likes about you? What behaviors of your partner do you find irritating? What behaviors of yours does your partner find irritating? What are some negative attributes of your family origin? What are some positive attributes of your family origin? What are some negative attributes of your partner's family origin? What are some positive attributes of your partner's family origin?
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Relationship Questionnaire.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Questions for Clients
item.description: Questions for both: What happened to your marriage that's gotten you to the point where divorce is a possibility? Can you tell me what you have done to try to fix the problems in the marriage, whether on your own or with help? What role, if any, do your children play in your decision making about the future of your relationship? Can you tell me about a time in your relationship, since the time you met, when you felt the most connection and joy? Questions for Leaning-Out partner (see this person first): Tell me more about your pain and reasons for considering divorce. (Within no more than 10 minutes) switch to a conversation about the paths. Find out how far they have gone in formalizing divorce plans (contacted attorney, papers drawn up, etc.) Ask them their perspective on their contributions to the problems in the marriage. Prepare a summary statement for the other partner about something they have taken away from the individual time, then invite partner 2 in the room to hear the summary statement. Now work with the leaning-in partner: Help them articulate that they understand their partner's concerns and can understand why their partner might be interested in divorce. Ask about their perspective on their own contributions to the problems in the relationship. Help them figure out how to respond without being too anxious or withdrawing completely. Summary statement: Must convey the sense that the leaning-in partner understands why their partner is contemplating divorce, and some empathy for this position. Once both people are in the room again, and the leaning-in partner has shared their summary statement, then the therapist shares their observations. What themes have you noticed, and your perception of how they got to this place. Couple does not have to agree on a path at the end of this session, but they may, they recommend that the couple return for at least a 2 nd discernment session before deciding, especially Path 3. What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen? What do you think the problem is now? How will you know when the problem is solved? How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be? What will have to be different about others involved in the situation? What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen? What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time? Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today? So, what has to happen to get your mother off of your back? What is the minimum we need to accomplish so that you won't have to keep coming for more sessions? What would it take to get your family (or court) off of your back? Between now and next time we meet, I would like you to observe what happens that you want to continue to have happen? What brings you here today? How can I be helpful to you? What changes have you noticed since you first made the call to set up this appointment? When in the past might the problem have happened but it didn't? How did you do that? How did you get that to happen? How have you managed to cope, ensure, keep going? What will it take to move from a 3 to a 4? On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being absolutely no hope, and 10 being complete hope, what number would you give your current level of hope? Therapy begins with a description of the clients' problem. How were you hoping I could help you? Asking for clients' perceptions Acknowledge clients' perceptions, using clients own language as much as possible. As clients what they've already tried to resolve their difficulties. It sounds as though [problem] is part of your life now. How long have you been noticing this [problem]? What effect does the [problem] have on your life? How does the [problem] impact your relationship? Does [problem] have an impact on your relationship with other family members? What do you think about the effects [problem] is having on your life? Are you accepting what [problem] is doing? Are these effects acceptable to you or not? Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what [problem] is doing? How would you prefer things to be? What name would you give the problem? What is it like to experience the problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other? What has it talked you into about your family? What impacts has that had? What effects does the problem have on your other relationships? How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself? Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not? Are we talking about what you want to be talking about? Is this conversation useful? How is it useful? Who is in charge, the person or the problem? Reading between the lines of the problem story Can you remember a time... What does it say about you... If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them What would you call that something? What 'feeds' the problem? What 'starves' the problem? Who benefits from the problem? In what settings might the problem be useful? Who advocates for the problem? What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions? What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships? Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes? Is the problem always with you? What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying? What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking? It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care? What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them? Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who them amplify and accredit the stories that they witness What stood out for them? What images it brought forward? How it resonated with their own experiences? Where they were transported by the interview? Situate their reflections in their own experience Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives Opening space questions (unique outcomes) Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but did not? Preference questions (preferred experiences) Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how? Story development questions How is this different from when arguing is in control? Meaning questions What does it say about you that you were able to...? Questions that extend the story into the future What do you predict...
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Questions for Clients.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Preparing for Co-Therapy
item.description: Before each session co-therapists should have a pre-session meeting. Therapists pre-session so that co-therapists are on the same page. During pre-sessioning you should decide on the following: The intention or goals for the session Agreement on a theoretical model Create a session specific game plan Discuss previous sessions, hypotheses, and evaluation of progress Make decisions about next steps in treatment You should also consider the following questions amongst yourself: What would blow you out of the water? What would be so shocking that you wouldn't know what to do? Let's brainstorm what we would do if XYZ occurred in session Examples (arguing, escalation, high conflict, desire to end relationship, risk, etc.) How would you manage that? What do you anticipate? What is your theory of what's going on--your theory of the problem? Strategies for the therapy room As a co-therapy team you should determine which strategies you are going to use in the room. What is the role of each therapist and how will you work together. Some strategies to consider: Tag team One starts speaking, while the other would be writing questions, and perhaps nodding occasionally, or making validating and summarizing statements. Then, when number one (i.e. the one who was speaking) runs out number two is ready. They're ready, because they've been writing questions, and they can jump in with those questions. Preparation and sharing airtime Who will do what in the session? Who is handling assessment or genogram? Will we ever spend time one on one or break up subsystems of the client system? Split the joining tasks Before you go into the room, you decide which member of the couple each therapist will focus on with joining. For example: You're going to join with the husband, and I'm going to join with the wife. It's very specific who we're each validating, empathizing, and summarizing. If you start asking questions of the husband, it's my job to ask the follow-up questions of the wife. In the same vein with the wife, so that we're like two advocates. Reflecting Team As co-therapists there may be times when you find it appropriate to turn to one another and talk about what is going on or what you notice in the room. This could be used as an intervention or to help determine the next steps in the session. Example: Co-therapists turn to one another and debate or argue about what is happening with the client system. Have a discussion or debate about what is going on, and then turn back to the couple and say, "Where are we going wrong?, or "How are we getting it right?"
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Preparing for Co-Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: ECR-SF Scoring
item.description: Results consist of two scores for the two separate factors; Attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance. The minimum score for each scale is 7 and a maximum score of 42. In addition, scores are represented in terms of percentile ranks compared to a normative sample. A percentile of 50 represents typical (and healthy) attachment, whereas higher percentiles represent more difficulties with adult attachment compared to peers. Attachment avoidance is defined as involving fear of dependence and interpersonal intimacy, an excessive need for self-reliance, and reluctance to self-disclose. Attachment anxiety is defined as involving a fear of interpersonal rejection or abandonment, an excessive need for approval from others, and distress when one‚Äôs partner is unavailable or unresponsive. People who score high on either or both of these dimensions are assumed to have an insecure adult attachment orientation. By contrast, people with low levels of attachment anxiety and avoidance can be viewed as having a secure adult attachment orientation (Brennan et al., 1998). In addition, higher scores are significantly and positively related to depression, anxiety, interpersonal distress, or loneliness.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/ECR-SF Scoring.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Strategies for Working with High Conflict Couples
item.description: Why are couples behaving so badly? "The average couple waits 6 years before seeking out therapy." (Gottman) In those 6 years there is: Build up of resentments Reinforced bad habits No boundary enforcement Erosion of positive perspective Unconscious bias kicks - assumptions about purposeful poor behavior choices Missed bids for attention Depletion of emotional bank account Never had any positive role models to begin with From a survey conducted in September 2020: Increases in substance misuse: Alcohol (88%) Marijuana (37%) Prescription Opioids (15%) Domestic violence cases increased by 25%-33% globally. How are these influences showing up in the clients in the therapy room? Passive/aggressive behaviors Shut down/Withdrawn/Stonewalling Withholding Sex or Avoiding Intimacy Narcissistic Behavior Responses Gaslighting Anger High Conflict Boundary Crossing Persistent and Ongoing Flooding Unwilling to Repair/Apologize/Take Responsibility How to prepare yourself for the unexpected: When you open your office door, look for body language and non-verbals. Have confidence and KNOW that you are the expert in the room. Own it and be brave. Set the tone at the beginning of the session when you feel something is off. Let the clients know what you feel when you feel it, and be willing to talk about what is happening. (Do not wait for clients to bring it up or ignore it) Model for your couples that you are going to talk about it, not let things be passive-aggressive or avoid dealing with hot topics. Remind clients who escalate that they are not in therapy to repeat old patterns. Pause and interrupt when you see unacknowledged emotion happening in the room. That is your job. Don't let your couples argue or verbally explode on each other. They can do that at home for free. Take Control. Develop your phrase to create stop-action with clients. Say things like, 'pause, stop,' or call out your client's name, etc. Be direct. What is acceptable and what is not acceptable about words or behavior in the room. What you would like your clients to do instead (as for their positive need). Why it's not okay for them to say or do the thing that you witnessed in the room. Let the clients know how painful it is for you to witness, so you can't imagine what it's like for their partner. Keep your eyes on each client in the room. Are you letting one partner high jack the session? Stop the speaking partner and ask, 'What's coming up for you?' Notice if the other partner checks in. Be mindful of the need to stop and tend to the party not speaking. This is how you keep explosions from getting out of control because you have been checking in on what is happening on the other side of the couch. Step in for clients when they don't have words and find a way to speak their pain to their partner. Keep it fair, so both partners feel you are connected with their pain, needs, and wanted outcomes. Normalize high emotion and disappointment of partner not being able to acknowledge perspectives not because they don't love you. Differences on family of origin, difference in expectations, etc. Prior traumas and life experiences make it hard for partners to always regulate their emotions in ways they would hope. Untreated mental health issues impact ability to manage emotions. Not finished working on the 'Me' stuff versus the 'We' stuff and bleeding over into our relationship. Discuss the impact of substances and the impact it has on being able to manage emotions. Gottman Method: Flooding is expected because partners are experiencing physiological arousal. Utilize pulse oximeters to help validate their elevated heart rate. Be okay with breaking it up. Sometimes you need to have one couple leave the room while you do some one-on-one with the other partner. Let an explosive partner leave if they want. Don't chase them or try to convince them to stay or come back. Talk about the flooding in the room and share ways to help self-regulate, like taking deep breaths or pausing to find ways to reframe. You need to be prepared when working with couples that you might need to a break from couples therapy or stop all together based on how the clients present. This is your call as a therapist to evaluate if working with the couple is contraindicated because of co-occurring mental health, substance, unresolved trauma, suicidal ideation, personality disorders, characterological DV, or anger management issues. Often necessary to request that clients seek out individual therapy to strengthen their individual coping skills before attempting additional couples' therapy. Expect your clients to disagree and give you pushback. Attitude is everything in this conversation. Remember, your clients are not your peers, and we often have to make unpopular decisions about the course of care. When you feel anxious and flooded as the therapist: Notice where you are breathing. Plant both feet on the floor. Take your shoulders back against your chair, take a deep breath into your belly, and repeat to yourself: "This is not my pain to feel." Get in touch with your client's inner 5-year-old old in the room. What is hurting them, and what is the catastrophe scenario that is playing out for them? When I de-escalate, so do my clients. When my voice gets softer and quieter, so does my clients, and they can often match my tone and calm demeanor. Don't shy away from acknowledging they have the right to feel upset, and it makes sense they would be even if their partner does not agree. Ask their partner to find something they said that they can validate for their partner. Remind them this is not the same as agreeing. Focus on the behavior or the words you heard. We can help facilitate meaningful conversation about the emotions each partner is feeling. Ask the partner who is feeling a big emotion related to their partner to name their emotion. Then talk the behavior they say their partner do or the words they heard them say. Remind and monitor clients to avoid telling their partner their evaluation of why their partner did it or the mind set they were in when it happened. This often happens and only creates defensiveness in their partner. No one likes to be told how they feel. Ask for your positive need. Even if the answer is no - you need to hear yourself asking for your need. Gottman Method Stress Reducing Conversation 10-minutes each partner. Listening for understanding and share emotion. (Not problem-solving) How do clients know it's working? Does your partner feel hear and understood? Then yes. Use of open-ended questions to help partners attune, connect, and provide empathy and support. Questions that allow for each partner to draw out their partner's experience, such as: "What is this like for you? What do you need? What don't you like about this situation?" Gottman Method Dreams within Conflict Asks clients to suspend problem-solving so they can have a better understanding of the childhood stories, values, or core ethics and beliefs that keep their partner rooted in their perspective. Clients take turns asking each partner a set of questions so they can better experience what it's like to walk in their partner's shoes. Preparation for compromise like partners who love each other. Gottman Method Injuries Exercise Helps partners find a structured and safe format to talk about old injuries in a way that helps facilitate compassion, acceptance, and understand about prior and shared traumas. Creates awareness and insight about the impact and ways these traumas have shaped the way each partner views their world. Helps evaluate how clients have learned to cope and survive. Can help some clients gain insight on how they behave in relationships in ways that no longer serve them. Helps couples therapist normalize and make recommendations of ways those old injuries get triggered in the relationship and behavior changes that might be beneficial. Gottman Method Appreciations Exercise Changes tone and energy in session. Allows each partner to find something positive to notice about their partner to demonstrate holding each other from a positive perspective. Makes deposits into each partner‚Äôs emotional bank account. Starts conversations about how to do small things often in the relationship for highly disconnected couples. Way to end session, so couples can ground before leaving in turmoil. If apologies are made, they are often expressed as implying you misunderstood something but without remorse for poor behaviors Outside behaviors or the other person is ALWAYS the source of conflict or turn it around on the other person implying they are really the culprit for the issue Self-doubt creeps in and the partner being gaslit internalizes their lack of hard work in the relationship as the cause of all the problems. Guilt develops about bringing up issues in the relationship. It feels very much like the result of narcissistic behavior responses. The partner who is doing the gaslighting may do so unconsciously to gain control or power in the relationship when they feel out of resources or support. Manipulation that involves making someone question their own reality, feelings, and experiences of events, in order to maintain CONTROL over that person. Deflecting the other person by use of lack of acknowledgement, negative body language, and minimizing statements about the other person‚Äôs perspective or feelings. Unwillingness to accept any part of the responsibility for a misunderstanding or conflict. Intentional implication that the other person is over-reacting or has fabricated a situation in order to create doubt or challenge the other person‚Äôs reality Being cut off from making points, asking questions, or providing input during a disagreement. No acknowledgment of your hurt feelings when expressed. Lacks Empathy. Clients are often overly invested in using narcissist label with each other. Only 5% of population are diagnosable with narcissistic personality disorder You should be aware that most clients who have diagnosable narcissistic personality disorder are not going to be served in couples therapy and may be contra-indicated. Gottman Interventions to Bring into Session Introduces the idea that anything our partner does for us is a gift - they are not required to do so because we are in a relationship with each other. Softened Start Up: This is helpful for the narcissistic leaning partner to learn how to be clear in their needs and learn how to share why it is important to them. This helps them to slowly understand they are not entitled to anything. Appreciations: Help the narcissistic partner to think about what the other person adds to their life and to acknowledge it. Accept the things you can't change. Helpful for both partners to understand there are some things that are unlikely to ever completely be different in their dynamics. Helps partners make a choice about the relationship from that space of acceptance. Aftermath of a Regrettable Incident: Introduction to Narcissistic person about their role in feeling disrespected or unappreciated. Active listening exercises like the Gottman-Rapport You must interrupt patterns of rage, repeated interruptions, storming off, or screaming. Be on the lookout for a partner who has NPD to be overly charming or makes big declarations of victimhood, or says their only goal is ‚Äúto fight for the relationship.‚Äù Avoid becoming a victim of triangulation or becoming caught up in buying into the hope that you can fix the narcissistic behaviors. You MUST be comfortable being direct, holding a strong position of authority in the room, and be willing to call out poor behavior that is impacting the relationship. Strongly suggest and sometimes require that both partners be in individual therapy and check in with this therapist to make sure they are aware of the dynamics happening in the relationship. The only goal you may accomplish is validating the victim that they are correct in their reality and that they can trust their intuition. You may serve as the objective voice this person needs to get clear and end the relationship. Don‚Äôt fight, argue, or try to overpower the narcissist. There is a very strong likelihood that despite your support that these sessions may not go as you hope! Many clients who have narcissistic behaviors can and will use the tools they learn in session to abuse, further manipulate, or weaponize against their partner. True NPD will NOT be ok with the change in or loss of power and will retaliate. Evaluate if the partner is becoming more agitated, aggressive, and if you suspect there is an increased likelihood for physical abuse-stop sessions. Recognize you can and potentially should take a break from therapy with the couples. Should you refer them to seek individual therapy for a while and then re-evaluate if they are good candidates for couples therapy? Couples therapy can re-traumatize the partner who is being victimized. Consider if this is in the scope of your practice? Do you need to refer out? Make time before letting clients go to let them know that it was a hard session and how important it was to have it. Let your partner know that if they are flooded when they will come back and talk about it with you. Make a date with each other to come back and process. Check in with each partner about what they will do to self-soothe. Remind clients that emotions and feeling hurt or misunderstood happens in relationships. The couple is not in this situation because they don‚Äôt love each other but because the stakes are so high. This is your person and if we are not ok then nothing feels ok. Let them know you are proud of them for doing the work.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Training/Strategies for Working with High Conflict Couples.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: De-Escalation through a Trauma-Informed Care Lens
item.description: Increase understanding of the prevalence, characteristics and impact of trauma on individuals. Understand the neurobiology of trauma and how the stress response system impacts functioning. Identity and apply trauma-informed strategies for deescalating crisis situations and working with people who are emotionally distressed. An event, series of events, or set of circumstances that is experienced by an individual as physically or emotionally harmful or life threatening and that has lasting adverse effects. Abuse, neglect, experiencing or witnessing violence, incarceration of family members, family substance abuse, sudden or expected loss of a loved one Exposure to war, political violence, torture, forced displacement, migration and acculturation stressors, fears of deportation Pain, injury and serious illness; invasive medical procedures or treatments Lack of resources, support networks, or mobility; financial stressors; homelessness Hurricanes, fires, floods Accidents, wars, environmental disasters, acts of terrorism Robberies, shootings, assault, gang-related violence, hate crimes, group trauma affecting a particular community Threats, fights, school shootings, bullying, loss of a student or staff member Exposure to multiple traumatic events from an early age. The immediate and long-term effects of these experiences over development. "The cumulative emotional and psychological wounding across generations, including the lifespan, which emanates from massive group trauma." (Braveheart) Examples: American Indian and Alaskan Native communities Communities of color Holocaust survivors Japanese-American survivors of internment camps LGBTQ communities Potentially traumatic experiences resulting from: Direct experiences of racial harassment Witnessing racial violence toward others Experiencing discrimination and institutional racism A single traumatic event that is limited in time Experiencing multiple traumatic events Exposure to chronic trauma which impacts the child's development Usually caused by adults entrusted with the child's care NORMAL response/reaction to stress and even trauma (4-6 weeks) Exaggerated and prolonged stress response beyond 4-6 weeks and even years later Dysregulation of stress chemistry - stress hormone levels don't decrease Increased activation of Sympathetic Nervous System (heart rate, startle response, fight response) 70% of adults in the US have experienced some types of traumatic event at least once in their lives. 223.4 million people In public behavioral health, over 90% of clients have experienced trauma. Trauma is a risk factor in nearly all behavioral health and substance use disorders. Collaboration between the CDC and Kaiser Permanente study of over 17,000 adult patients in health maintenance organizations (1995-1997); 2 waves of data collection Gathers information about health history and exposure to the following events prior to age 18: Recurrent physical abuse Recurrent emotional abuse Sexual abuse An alcohol or drug abuser An incarcerated household member Someone who is chronically depressed, suicidal, institutionalized or mentally ill Mother being treated violently One or no parents Emotional or physical neglect ‚ÄúHow ACEs influence health and wellbeing through lifespan.png‚Äù could not be found. Nearly two-thirds Ohioans have been exposed to ACEs Ohioans more likely to experience multiple ACEs: People of color People with low-income People with a disability Residents of urban and Appalachian counties Stress: Unpredictable, Severe, Prolonged -> Vulnerability Predictable, Moderate, Controlled -> Resilience Natural response to the prolonged uncertainty and disruption caused by a pandemic Lack of motivation Stress over tasks that would generally be managed well Changes in eating or sleeping habits Irritability Feelings of hopelessness Difficulty concentrating At any given point in time, we have a limited supply of 'adaptive energy' In the best of conditions, this reservoir is quite high and will allow us to meet unusual challenges Chronic and prolonged stress related to COVID-19 and other stressors has depleted the reservoir of adaptive energy, making us all more vulnerable to stress. The amygdala senses threat and sets off the alarm. Thinking brain assess the situation. Thinking brain goes offline. Emotional brain activates fight or flight response. Thinking brain helps shut off the alarm and helps us to calm down. An experience becomes traumatic when it overwhelms our system for responding to stress. The emotional brain continues to sound the alarm and send messages to fight or flee, even after the threat has passed. Autonomic Nervous System: Direct role in physical response to stress. Sympathetic Nervous System: 'Fight or flight' response Body shifts energy resources toward fighting off or fleeing a threat Signals release of adrenaline and cortisol Heart beats faster, respiration rate increases, blood vessels in arms and legs dilate, digestive process changes, glucose levels in blood (sugar energy) increase Parasympathetic Nervous System: Facilitates recovery once acute stressor is over Over-activity can contribute to stress reactions Chronic stress can result in a long-term drain on the body Wear and tear Continuous activation of the nervous system can be problematic in all systems. Musculoskeletal System: Muscles in body are in constant state of guardedness Muscle tension, headaches, migraines, back pain Respiratory System Shortness of breath Rapid breathing Cardiovascular System Elevated heart rate, elevated blood pressure, elevated stress hormones, inflammation Endocrine System Increased production of cortisol Gastrointestinal System Changes in gut bacteria, pain, bloating, discomfort Esophagus Eat more or less than usual, increased use of substances, heartburn/acid reflux History of previous exposure to trauma Age of exposure Gender Cognitive ability Self-efficacy Biological factors (e.g. flexibility in thinking, emotional regulation) Nature of the traumatic event Proximity to the traumatic event Culture and ethnicity Level of social support Quality of parent-child relationships, parent mental health, and parental history of trauma Health of the broader community Positive: Resilience A positive, adaptive response to significant adversity. Adaptable, caring, and supportive relationship with an adult. A sense of mastery over life circumstances. Strong executive function and self-regulation skills. Affirming faith or cultural traditions Individuals may demonstrate resilience in one type of situation but not another. Coping skills that support resilience can be developed at any age. Children do not develop the capacity to positive adapt to adversity in isolation. Regardless of resources, individuals who face extreme adversity are likely to be significantly impacted. We all play an important role in fostering resilience. Recovery Post-traumatic growth Negative: Severe persisting distress Decline Stable maladaptive functioning We need to presume the clients we serve have a history of traumatic stress and exercise ‚Äúuniversal precautions‚Äù by creating systems of care that are trauma-informed. Understanding trauma and its impact Promoting safety Ensuring cultural competence Supporting control, choice, autonomy Collaboration and mutuality Integrating care Healing happens in relationships Recovery is possible Bringing a volatile and potentially explosive situation to a peaceful, calm resolution by verbal means... and no one getting hurt. Key Components: Body language: Facial expression Posture Position Tone of voice Active listening Judgement/Bias/Fatigue/Distractions Body language: Facial expression Posture Position Tone of voice Being in tune with your stress signals Do you have a good sense of how your body communicates when it is overwhelmed? Your PERCEPTION of your ability to effectively manage crisis situations. Body language History of aggression/violence/belligerence Self image Life circumstances Legal issues, work stress, social support, financial situation Drug and alcohol use/abuse Physical health Mental functioning Emotional health Trauma exposure Affect person's perception of self, the world, and the future Affect person's: Ability to trust others Sense of personal safety Effectiveness in navigating life's challenges Difficulty processing information Short-term memory impairment Perceptual field narrows Ability to regulate emotions effectively Feeling helpless and hopeless A sense that one can never do enough Hypervigilance Diminished creativity Inability to embrace complexity Minimizing Chronic exhaustion/physical ailments Dissociative moments Sense of persecution Guilt Fear Anger and cynicism Inability to emphasize/numbing Addictions Grandiosity: Inflated sense of importance Overcrowded? Loud? Overstimulating? Other clients present? Kids present? Other staff visible? Able to support/get help if needed? Person kept waiting? Ignored? Objects around that could be used for violence? Open path to exit? Think and plan ahead Be familiar with agency policies/procedures Develop plans for 'high risk' clients in advance Develop plans for common scenarios based on your role, department, program, etc. Monitor and manage your own stress level Clients in crisis require structure and boundaries to help re-establish stability Engaging client in discussion (repeated concerns can inadvertently contribute to chaos and triangulation; following the identified plan is the best way to support and care for these clients) Parallel Process: Don't get pulled into the chaos Setting firm, clear boundaries creates safety and minimizes potential for triangulation and miscommunication Identifying single point of contact for clients help ensure we have clear, consistent communication and avoids potential for triangulation People are doing the best they can to get their needs met Escalation is likely a learned behavior Be PROACTIVE, not REACTIVE Attend to person before things escalate Stage 1: Anxiety/Agitation Stage 2: Argumentative/Defensive Stage 3: Verbally, Physically Threatening Stage 4: Assaultive The more threatened the individual, the more 'primitive' (or regressed) becomes the style of thinking and behaving. When a traumatized person is in a state of alarm: They will be less capable of concentrating They will be more anxious They will pay more attention to non-verbal cues Tone of voice, body posture, and facial expressions Trigger: Any stimulus that acts as a reminder of past overwhelming experience Internal: Body sensations, emotions, etc. External: Sounds, sights, smells, facial expressions, etc. Common triggers: Unpredictability, sudden change, transitions Loss of control Feeling vulnerable Feeling rejected Confrontation Loneliness Sensory overload Intimacy (safety, love, security, family) Peace, calm, quiet 'Re-Experiencing' can lead to out-of-control behavior When someone with a trauma history begins to escalate, it may be because they are remembering or re-experiencing a traumatic event They may be reminded of the trauma and be flooded or overwhelmed with memories of that earlier traumatic event. Remember your superpowers: Body language Facial expression Posture Position Tone of voice Active listening Calm and caring attitude Ask for help Someone who is escalated is under stress and not likely to think clearly Your perception of your ability to cope with the situation is going to impact your own stress level when managing these interactions De-escalation skills start with self-awareness. Understanding how stress affects how you act, think, and communicate Speak in a calm, slow, warm, clear voice Show that you care Be aware of your non-verbal communication Acknowledge feelings Maintain eye contact (but don't stare) You may need to repeat yourself; the client may be distracted Be patient; give the situation time; time is on your side Remain a friendly tone and join with the client Helps the client see that you and the client are a team "We are going to figure this out" Allow the client to vent ("Tell me more about that") Use 'Please' and 'thank you' often Accept the client's feelings, thoughts and behaviors without judgement Remember that most of us have been irrational and said inappropriate things when we are under extreme stress Effective communication often depends as much on how you say the words you choose as much as the words themselves Be vigilant and aware of your surroundings Alert others, if needed Evaluate each situation for violence Keep an open path Remove yourself/others if situation is getting out of control Open up clear lines of communication Build trust and validate the client's situation (even if you don't agree) Get the client talking about concerns as a route to calming Gather the necessary information to make a good resolution If a client is escalated, they feel out of control which tells us that their normal coping measures are not working Keep your focus. You are trying to give the client a sense that they are in control. When someone feels out of control, they are more likely to escalate Your ability to engage a client in conversation successfully can resolve the conflict If it seems you may not get there, ask for help Shows interest Close-ended questions may be necessary but client is more likely to tell you what you want to hear "What can I help you with today?" vs. "Do you want to schedule an appointment?" "What time of day works best for you?" vs. "Can you come at 2 pm?" "Can you tell me..." Being expressively/explicitly kind Builds rapport and nurtures competence "I appreciate you telling me what's wrong." "It took a lot of courage for you to reach out today." "You've done a great job of keeping your appointments in the past. We really appreciate that." Validates and shows you‚Äôve heard the client Mirror back what you‚Äôre hearing is going on ‚Ä¢ Allow further explanation of the concern by not inserting your opinion Listen for feelings, themes, motivations, unmet need ‚ÄúIt sounds like you‚Äôve had a really tough time.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really angry about what‚Äôs happened.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre ____.‚Äù Insert any emotion‚Äî‚Äúmad,‚Äù ‚Äúupset,‚Äù ‚Äúfrustrated,‚Äù ‚Äúworried,‚Äù etc. You can‚Äôt do it wrong! ‚ÄúSounds like‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúSeems like‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúIt feels like‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúTo you, it looks like‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúI am hearing‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚ÄúI am wondering if‚Ä¶‚Äù Help transition the client to resolution: ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôve been through a lot and you‚Äôre really upset about everything that‚Äôs happened before. It sounds like we need to get you in to talk to someone. Would it be okay to get you scheduled for an appointment?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe last time you were here, you thought you got the run around and didn‚Äôt have time to see the provider. You were really frustrated by all that. How about if we get you scheduled again and see if we can get things resolved?‚Äù Remember the overall goal - client care If you take a LESS authoritative, LESS controlling, LESS confrontational approach, you actually will have MORE control in the situation. Responding angrily Not listening Criticizing Being defensive Arguing with the client Engaging in power struggles Ordering the client what to do Threatening (to cancel an appointment, etc.) Minimizing the importance of the client's concern Moving quickly (can be perceived as aggressive) Saying "You need to calm down" Trying to be right Giving commands "lower your voice" Arguing with the client Taking the words or actions of the client personally (even if the client tries to make it personal) Minimizing the situation ("It is not that bad") Asking a lot of questions Asking 'Why' questions Forcing discussion Do not express anger, impatience, or irritation Breathe Take a moment away, if possible Never use inflammatory language ("You are acting crazy") Notice if you are feeling as though you have to rush or feeling like you are stuck if it takes time to get to work through the client interaction Breathe through it, be patient Request help, if needed Don't intervene too quickly or try too hard to control the interaction by interrupting or talking over the client Follow agency policy Document Debrief Strategies to manage/avoid similar situations in future What went well? What didn't go well? Did anything contribute to the escalation? Did anything help diffuse the situation? Support for staff, clients, and individuals involved People are coping the best way they can - our job is to help them find a better way Requires building trust, creating safety, and creating a trauma informed culture that provides a safe and healing environment Healing takes more than therapy Support services can create therapeutic, healing experiences - a place of safety Screen for trauma history Deepen attunement skills - learn to interpret behavior effectively as communication Employ person-centered, strengths-based thinking and language Provide stability and empowerment Consider the physiological, psychological, and social risks of physical interventions - choose the least restrictive option as a last resort if somebody is a danger to themselves or others Prioritize debriefing after a crisis to help foster resilience and develop successful coping skills Be empathetic and non-judgemental Respect personal space Use non-threatening non-verbals Avoid overreacting Focus on feelings Ignore challenging questions Set limits Choose wisely what you insist upon Allow silence for reflection Allow time for decisions
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Training/De-Escalation through a Trauma-Informed Care Lens.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Counseling Against Lethal Means (CALM)
item.description: The acute phase of a suicidal crisis is when a person is ready to actually make an attempt to end their life. Suicidal crises are often brief. While some attempts follow a long period of deliberation, other attempts are acted on hastily and may be difficult to predict. Most people who attempt suicide don't necessarily want to be dead, but they want the pain they feel to stop. Most people who attempt suicide and survive do not ultimately kill themselves - even people who make a very serious suicide attempt. Acute Suicidal Crisis: The period when a person transitions from being at risk for suicide or considering suicide to being ready to actually make an attempt. Can come on rapidly Can be difficult to predict Can lead to an unplanned suicide attempt People were asked when they has first started thinking about making an attempt; 48% said they starting thinking about it within 10 minutes of attempting. Often brief The period during which a person is actually ready to take their life is usually brief. Rarely is it a chronic state. The impulse to die often fades. It may never recur, or it may flare up episodically. Duration of Suicidal Crisis: Evidence by Attempters: 0-10 minutes: 48% 11-60 minutes: 2% 1-24 hours: 9% 1-7 days: 16% 1-4 weeks: 15% 1-12 months: 11% Long-Term Survival: More than 90% of people who attempt suicide and survive do not actually kill themselves. 60% of people who commit suicide die on their first attempt. (Means reduction saves lives by decreasing the likelihood that an attempt will be fatal) In describing the moment he jumped from the Golden Gate Bridge, Ken Baldwin said, "I instantly realized that everything in my life that I'd thought was unfixable was totally fixable - except for having just jumped." It is not easy to determine. Examples: Clients who have suicidal thoughts. Clients who are in distress and have attempted suicide in the past. Clients who are struggling with mental health or substance misuse issues, especially if they are also coping with painful life crises. A clinician should ask directly about suicidal thoughts and feelings. Talking about suicide does not create or increase risk, in fact, it can reduce the risk of suicide. A clinician‚Äôs ability to calmly, compassionately, and matter-of-factly explore suicidal thoughts and behaviors may encourage an individual to disclose suicidality, if it exists. Often, clients who have considered suicide will be relieved that you raised the subject. Use direct questions about current or past suicidal thoughts and behavior. Let the client know that other people have similar thoughts and feelings. Any of your clients who have a prior history of suicidality or current distress could benefit from lethal means counseling. If your conversation with your client results in disclosure of past suicidal thoughts or behaviors, probe more about current suicidal feelings. Find out specific details about their suicidal thoughts and behaviors. Some Questions to Ask: Tell me about a couple of times in the past few months when things were the worst for you‚Äîdid you think about suicide? If yes, then ask: Did you take any specific steps toward an attempt? What methods did you think about? What kept you alive?  Tell me about the last couple of days‚Äîhow much would you say suicide has been on your mind, if at all?  If so, then ask: Are there specific methods you‚Äôve thought about? Have you thought about how you'd kill yourself?  If yes, then ask: Have you thought about when or where you'd kill yourself? If they mention a specific method of suicide, then ask: What other methods are you thinking about? Is there a specific scenario where you think you would attempt suicide? Have you ever attempted suicide in the past, or started to? Don't rely solely on disclosure of suicidal thoughts, behaviors, and plans. Lethal means counseling makes sense for anyone at risk. Individuals who struggle with mental health and/or substance use issues, and who are experiencing a major crisis, stress, or trauma, are also at risk of suicide and should receive lethal means training. Individuals who currently have suicidal thoughts would benefit from lethal means counseling. Individuals who have attempted suicide in the past and are currently in distress would benefit from lethal means counseling. Individuals who struggle with mental health/substance abuse issues, especially when they are also experiencing painful life crises, would benefit from lethal means counseling. Ask clients at risk directly about suicidal thoughts, behaviors, and plans. Ask clients at-risk specifically about their suicide plans, such as how and when they would do it. Don't rely solely on disclosure of suicidal thoughts, behaviors, and plans. People sometimes deny these even when they exist. Also, suicidal thoughts can emerge rapidly and many attempts are unplanned. Lethal means counseling should take place before a suicidal crisis occurs. Firearms is the method used most frequently in suicidal deaths. Suicidal Death Rates by Method: 51% Firearms 26% Suffocation/Hanging 12% Poisoning/Overdose (Poisoning from intentional drug or medication overdoses) 3% Gas Inhalation (Inhaling gas, usually carbon monoxide from motor exhaust) 2% Jumping/Falling (Jump from high place like bridge) 2% Cutting (Sharp instruments like razor) 4% Other Methods (like drowning) The lethality of the method used in a suicide attempt is one of the biggest factors determining whether the person lives or dies. While the intent matters, means also matters. If the method a person wants to use for suicide if not available when they are actually ready to go through with an attempt, one of two things is likely to occur: They will delay the attempt as they try to get access to the method they want to use. The greater the delay, the greater the chance the suicidal crisis will pass. They will substitute another method. If the substituted method is less lethal, this increases the chance the person will not die. And most people who survive an attempt do not later go on to kill themselves. The two methods used in the majority of nonfatal suicidal attempts are overdosing with medications and cutting with sharp instruments. Many people think these two methods are far more deadly than they actually are. This misperception may save a lot of lives. We recommend that you do not share specific information with your clients about the low lethality of sharp instruments and medications. Which suicide methods are amenable to a means reduction approach? It depends on the following criteria: Number of Suicide Deaths: The number/percent of suicide deaths caused by a specific method. Lethality: The proportion of attempts by a given method that end in death (case fatality rate). Irreversibility: The inability for someone attempting suicide to stop once it has begun or to be rescued. More people stop an attempt than carry through with it. Accessibility: The immediate availability of the method. Access is particularly important when attempts occur rapidly with little or no planning. Acceptability: Cultural and/or individual tolerance or preference for using a particular method to kill oneself. Cutting: Low Number of Deaths Low Lethality Low Irreversibility High Accessibility High Acceptability Jumping/Falling: Low Number of Deaths High Lethality High Irreversibility Low Accessibility Low Acceptability Gas Inhalation: Low Number of Deaths Moderate Lethality Low Irreversibility Moderate Accessibility Low Acceptability Poisoning/Overdose: Moderate Number of Deaths Low Lethality Low Irreversibility High Accessibility High Acceptability Suffocation/Hanging: Moderate Number of Deaths Moderate Lethality Low Irreversibility High Accessibility Moderate Acceptability Firearms: High Number of Deaths High Lethality High Irreversibility High Accessibility High Acceptability Firearms are used in more suicide deaths in the US than all other methods combined. They are also highly lethal irreversible, and easily accessible in many homes with guns (one-third of homes have guns). Since gun owners can voluntarily undertake steps to reduce access, you will want to discuss safe firearm storage with all clients at-risk of suicide. Medication Overdoses are not as lethal as firearms (though some medications and poisons are very lethal). It is also usually possible for someone to stop an overdose mid-attempt or to be rescued. However, overdose is by far the most frequent method of attempt, and medications are easily accessible in most homes. Therefore, it is wise to routinely advise at-risk clients to dispose of unnecessary medications and keep accessible only quantities that do not pose a lethal threat. When your client's suicidal ideation focuses on any other method, you will want to discuss with them ways to reduce access to that method. More suicide deaths are from firearms than any other method in the US. Firearms, jumping, and suffocation are most lethal than other methods. Cutting and poisoning/overdose have low lethality, on average. The method used in a suicide attempt can determine whether the person lives or dies. Use a method reduction approach for any lethal method that is mentioned by clients at risk. How amenable each method is to a means reduction approach depends on the following criteria: Frequency Lethality Irreversibility Accessibility Acceptability Since firearms are used in most suicide deaths and they are also highly lethal, acceptable, and accessible (in homes with guns), be sure to ask all clients at risk if they have access to firearms and discuss ways to reduce access. A method is considered lethal if a high proportion of attempts by that method end in death. Approximately 80%-90% of intentional, self-inflicted gunshot wounds are fatal, according to data from emergency departments and death certificates. Only 1%-2% of intentional, self-inflicted wounds from sharp instruments, like a razor, are fatal. Cutting is not a highly lethal method. However, it is the second most commonly used method in attempts. Only 1%-2% of intentional overdoses or poisonings are fatal, according to data from emergency departments and death certificates. This is on average, however, certain medications and poisons are far more lethal than others. In addition, medication overdoses are the most common method of suicidal attempts. People who attempt suicide typically struggle with ongoing mental health or substance abuse issues. While some attempts are planned, many are not. Acute suicidal crises are often brief, and escalation from thought to action can occur rapidly. The lethality of the method used in an attempt can determine whether that person lives or dies. If a highly lethal means is not available, the individual's chance of survival is greater. Over 90% of people who attempt suicide and survive do not take their life later on, so reducing access to lethal means can save many lives. An effective way to protect clients at risk of suicide is to reduce their access to highly lethal means before they experience an acute suicidal crisis. Feasibility: Can the client or their family actually take the steps at home to reduce access to the method? Reducing access to firearms and medications used for poisoning/overdose could feasibly be accomplished at home and doing so could potentially save thousands of lives in the U.S. if routinely implemented with people at risk for suicide. Access can be feasibly be reduced for these two methods: Firearms: Firearms are used in roughly half of all suicide deaths, are highly lethal, and are very accessible if they are kept at home. Medications: Medication overdoses are by far the most common method in suicide attempts. Although the vast majority do not result in death, some medications and medication combinations are highly lethal - and, if kept unlocked at home, very accessible. We recommend routinely discussing firearm and medication storage with all clients at risk of suicide. If a client's suicidal ideation focuses on a method other than firearms or medication, we also recommend discussing ways to reduce access to that method as well. When discussing firearm storage with clients and their family members, the goal is to maximize the client‚Äôs safety by reducing immediate access to firearms as much as possible while they are at risk for suicide. There are two main options for reducing access to firearms. Safest: Store firearms away from the home: Storing firearms away from home is the most effective way to ensure clients don't have easy access to a gun if they experience a spike in suicidal feelings. Off-site options are listed in the next section.
