item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder
item.description:
Severe recurrent temper outbursts manifested verbally (e.g. verbal rages) and/or behaviorally (e.g. physical aggression toward people or property) that are grossly out of proportion in intensity or duration to the situation or provocation. The tempter outbursts are inconsistent with developmental level. The temper outbursts occur, on average, three or more times per week. The mood between temper outbursts is persistently irritable or angry most of the day, nearly every day, and is observable by others (e.g., parents, teachers, peers). The mood between temper outbursts is persistently irritable or angry most of the day, nearly every day, and is observable by others (e.g., parents, teachers, peers). Criteria 1-5 have been present for 12 or more months. Throughout that time, the individual has not had a period lasting 3 or more consecutive months without all the symptoms in Criteria 1-5. Criteria 1 and 4 are present in at least two of three setting (i.e., at home, at school, with peers) and are severe in at least one of these. The diagnosis should not be made for the first time before age 6 years or after age 18 years. By history or observation, the age at onset of Criteria 1-6 is before 10 years. There has never been a distinct period lasting more than 1 day during which the full symptom criteria, except duration, for a manic or hypomanic episode have been met. Developmentally appropriate mood elevation should not be considered as a symptom of mania or hypomania. The behaviors do not occur exclusively during an episode of major depressive disorders and are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), Separation Anxiety Disorder, Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymic Disorder))
This diagnosis cannot coexist with Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Intermittent Explosive Disorder, or Bipolar Disorder, though it can coexist with others, including Major Depressive Disorder, Attention-Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Conduct Disorder, and Substance Use Disorder s. Individuals whose symptoms meet criteria for both disruptive mood dysregulation disorder and oppositional defiant disorder should only be given the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. If an individual has ever experienced a manic or hypomanic episode, the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder should not be assigned. The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical or neurological condition. Chronic, severe, persistent irritability. This severe irritability has two prominent clinical manifestations: Temper outbursts: These outbursts typically occur in response to frustration and can be verbal or behavioral (the latter in the form of aggression against property, self, or others). They must occur frequently (i.e., on average, three or more times per week) (Criterion 3) over at least 1 year in at least two settings (Criteria 5 and 6). Chronic, persistently irritable or angry mood that is present between the severe temper outbursts. This irritable or angry mood must be characteristic of the child, being present most of the day, nearly every day, and noticeable by others in the child's environment (Criterion 4) Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is common among children presenting to pediatric mental health clinics. Consistent gender difference in prevalence have not been reported in population samples, although clinic samples report a male preponderance. The diagnosis may be more common in younger age groups. Because the symptoms of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder are likely to change as children mature, use of the diagnosis should be restricted to age groups similar to those in which validity has been established (6-18 years). Children with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder are at increased risk to develop unipolar depressive and/or anxiety disorders in adulthood. Children with chronic irritability typically exhibit complicated psychiatric histories. A relatively extensive history of chronic irritability is common, typically manifesting before full criteria for the syndrome are met. Such prediagnostic presentations may have qualified for a diagnosis of:
Oppositional Defiant Disorder
Attention-Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
Major Depressive Disorder Factors associated with disrupted family life, such as psychological abuse or neglect, parental psychiatric disorder, limited parental education, single-parent household, early trauma, death of a parent, parental grief, divorce, and malnutrition (e.g., vitamin deficiency), are associated with the core behaviors of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. A family history may be a risk factor. Those with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder exhibit both commonalities and differences in information-processing deficits. For example, face-emotion labeling deficits, as well as perturbed decision-making and cognitive control, are present in children with bipolar disorder as well as those with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. The same behavior deficit may be associated with different patterns of neural dysfunction. There is also evidence for disorder-specific dysfunction, such as during tasks assessing attention deployment in response to emotional stimuli, which has demonstrated unique signs of dysfunction in children with chronic irritability. Socioeconomic factors affect the presentation of core psychological features of the disorder, including impulsivity as well as emotion, reward, threat, and behavior dysregulation, especially in settings characterized by severe social disruption, such as post-conflict zones or communities affected by long-standing racism and discrimination. It is important to distinguish disruptive mood dysregulation disorder from adaptive responses to adversity that are context-dependent and transitory. While irritability has a strong genetic component in both sexes, patterns differ for boys and girls. For boys, genetic factors appear to account for an increasing amount of the variance of the phenotype of irritability throughout childhood. While genetic factors account for a large proportion of the variance of the irritability phenotype in school-age girls, this decreases into adolescence and young adulthood, with environmental influences playing a greater role. Chronic, severe irritability, such as is seen in disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, is associated with marked disruption in a child's family and peer relationships, as well as in school performance. Because of their extremely low frustration tolerance, such children generally have difficulty succeeding in school; they are often unable to participate in the activities typically enjoyed by healthy children; their family life is severely disrupted by their outbursts and irritability; and they have trouble initiating or sustaining friendships. In both disruptive mood dysregulation disorder and pediatric bipolar disorder, aggression and psychiatric hospitalization are common.
Differentiation of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder from Bipolar Disorder and Oppositional Defiant Disorder requires particularly careful assessment.
The central feature differentiating disruptive mood dysregulation disorder and Bipolar Disorder s in children involved longitudinal course of the core symptoms. In children, as in adults, bipolar I disorder and bipolar II disorder manifest as an episodic illness with discrete episodes of mood perturbation that can be differentiated from the child's typical presentation. The mood perturbation that occurs during a manic episode is distinctly different from the child. During a manic episode, the change in mood must be accompanied by onset, or worsening, of associated cognitive, behavioral, and physical symptoms (e.g., distractibility, increased goal-directed activity), which are also present to a degree that is distinctly different from the child's usual baselines. Thus, in the case of a manic episode, parents (and, depending on developmental level, children) should be able to identify a distinct time period during which the child's mood and behavior were markedly different from usual. The irritability of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is persistent and is present over many months; while it may wax and wane to a certain degree, severe irritability is characteristic of the child with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. The diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder cannot be assigned to a child who has ever experienced a full-duration hypomanic or manic episode (irritable or euphoric) or who has ever had a manic or hypomanic episode lasting more than 1 day. Another central differentiating feature between bipolar disorders and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is the presence of elevated or expansive mood and grandiosity. These symptoms are common features of mania but are not characteristic of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. The key features that warrant the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder in children whose symptoms also meet criteria for oppositional defiant disorder are the presence of severe and frequently recurrent outbursts and a persistent disruption in mood between outbursts. The diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder required severe impairment in at least one setting (i.e., home, school, or among peers) and mild to moderate impairment in a second setting.
In only approximately 15% of individuals with Oppositional Defiant Disorder would criteria for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder be met. Even for children in whom criteria for both disorders are met, only the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder should be made. There is a more prominent mood component among individuals with mood dysregulation disorder, as compared with individuals with oppositional defiant disorder. It should also be noted that disruptive mood dysregulation disorder appears to carry a high risk for behavioral problems as well as mood patterns. Children whose symptoms meet criteria for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder also can receive a comorbid diagnosis of ADHD, major depressive disorder, and/or anxiety disorder. Children whose irritability is present only in the context of a major depressive episode or persistent depressive disorder should receive one of those diagnoses rather than disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. Unlike disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, intermittent explosive disorder does not require the individual's mood to be persistently irritable or angry between outbursts. A diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder involving verbal aggression or physical aggression that does not result in damage to property or physical injury to animals or other individuals occurring at least twice-weekly can be made after only 3 months of symptoms, in contrast to the 12-month requirement for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. These two diagnoses should not be made in the same child. For children with outbursts and intercurrent, persistent irritability, only the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder should be made. Rates of comorbidity in disruptive mood dysregulation disorder are extremely high. It is rare to find individuals whose symptoms meet criteria for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder alone.
The strongest overlap is with Oppositional Defiant Disorder. Not only is the overall rate of comorbidity high in disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, but also the range of comorbid illnesses appears particularly diverse. These children typically present to the clinic with a wide range of disruptive behavior, mood, anxiety, and even autism spectrum symptoms and diagnoses.
If children have symptoms that meet criteria for Oppositional Defiant Disorder or Intermittent Explosive Disorder and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, only the diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder should be assigned. The diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder should not be assigned if the symptoms occur only in an anxiety-provoking context, when the routines of a child with autism spectrum disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder are disturbed, or in the context of a major depressive episode.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Mood Disorders/Depressive Disorders/Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder.md

item.title: Depression Disorder due to Another Medical Condition
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Mood Disorders/Depressive Disorders/Depression Disorder due to Another Medical Condition.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mood Disorders
item.description: Any mood disorder represents a category of mental illnesses in which the underlying problem primarily affects a person‚Äôs persistent emotional state (their mood). Examples: Major Depressive Disorder, Bipolar Disorder, and Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Mood Disorders/Mood Disorders.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Bulimia Nervosa
item.description: Bulimia nervosa is characterized by binge eating (eating large amounts of food in a short time, along with the sense of a loss of control) followed by a type of behavior that compensates for the binge, such as purging (e.g., vomiting, excessive use of laxatives, or diuretics), fasting, and/or excessive exercise. Unlike anorexia nervosa, people with bulimia can fall within the normal range for their weight. But like people with anorexia, they often fear gaining weight, want desperately to lose weight, and are intensely unhappy with their body size and shape.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Eating Disorders/Bulimia Nervosa.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Binge Eating Disorder
item.description: Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent binge eating episodes during which a person feels a loss of control and marked distress over his or her eating. Unlike bulimia nervosa, binge eating episodes are not followed by purging, excessive exercise or fasting. As a result, people with binge eating disorder often are overweight or obese.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Eating Disorders/Binge Eating Disorder.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Anorexia Nervosa
item.description: Anorexia nervosa is characterized by a significant and persistent reduction in food intake leading to extremely low body weight in the context of age, sex, and physical health; a relentless pursuit of thinness; a distortion of body image and intense fear of gaining weight; and extremely disturbed eating behavior. Many people with anorexia see themselves as overweight, even when they are starved or severely malnourished. The lifetime prevalence of anorexia nervosa in adults was 0.6%. Lifetime prevalence of anorexia nervosa was three times higher among females (0.9%) than males (0.3%). A past year prevalence estimate for anorexia nervosa was not generated in the NCS-R sample of respondents.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Eating Disorders/Anorexia Nervosa.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Eating Disorders
item.description: Eating disorders are serious and sometimes fatal illnesses that cause severe disturbances to a person‚Äôs eating behaviors. Obsessions with food, body weight, and shape may also signal an eating disorder. Common eating disorders include binge eating disorder, bulimia nervosa, and, less common but very serious, anorexia nervosa. Based on diagnostic interview data from the National Comorbidity Survey Replication (NCS-R), median age of onset was 21 years-old for binge eating disorder and 18 years-old for both bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa. Based on diagnostic interview data from the NCS-R, the data below indicate the past year prevalence of each type of eating disorder among U.S. adults aged 18 and older. The lifetime prevalence of anorexia nervosa in adults was 0.6%. Lifetime prevalence of anorexia nervosa was three times higher among females (0.9%) than males (0.3%). A past year prevalence estimate for anorexia nervosa was not generated in the NCS-R sample of respondents.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Eating Disorders/Eating Disorders.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
item.description: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) can develop after exposure to a potentially traumatic event that is beyond a typical stressor. Events that may lead to PTSD include, but are not limited to, violent personal assaults, natural or human-caused disasters, accidents, combat, and other forms of violence. Exposure to events like these is common. About one half of all U.S. adults will experience at least one traumatic event in their lives, but most do not develop PTSD. People who experience PTSD may have persistent, frightening thoughts and memories of the event(s), experience sleep problems, feel detached or numb, or may be easily startled. In severe forms, PTSD can significantly impair a person's ability to function at work, at home, and socially.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Anxiety Disorders/Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Panic Disorder
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Anxiety Disorders/Panic Disorder.md

item.title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
item.description: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is often a long-lasting disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions), and behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat over and over. Of adults with OCD in the past year, degree of impairment ranged from mild to severe, as shown in Figure 2. Impairment was determined by scores on the Sheehan Disability Scale.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Anxiety Disorders/Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder.md

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Agoraphobia
item.description: Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder that involves intense fear and anxiety of any place or situation where escape might be difficult. Agoraphobia involves avoidance of situations such as being alone outside of the home; traveling in a car, bus, or airplane; or being in a crowded area.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Anxiety Disorders/Agoraphobia.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Anxiety Disorders
item.description: The wide variety of anxiety disorders differ by the objects or situations that induce them, but share features of excessive anxiety and related behavioral disturbances. Anxiety disorders can interfere with daily activities such as job performance, school work, and relationships. For the data presented on this page, any anxiety disorders included Panic Disorder, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Agoraphobia, Specific Phobia, Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia), Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, and Separation Disorder.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Mental Health Conditions/Anxiety Disorders/Anxiety Disorders.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Observing a Piece of Fruit
item.description: Start with a bowl of apples (or any fruit). Pass the bowl around and have each person take one item. Mindfully observe the piece of fruit for a few minutes. When the bell rings everyone puts the fruit back into the bowl and then see if each person can "recognize" their original fruit. Instructions: First take your piece of fruit and weigh it up in your hands. Get a sense of the texture of the skin, the temperature, the weight, how it feels in the palm of your hand, how it feels as you run your fingertips across its surface. What do you notice here? Spend a few moments doing this. Next, we are going to use our sense of smell to breathe in the scent of the fruit. What do you notice here? Try to stay with just sensing the fruit, perhaps notice if your mind begins to make associations. Your mind will likely wander or begin thinking about things as you move through this exercise, so just notice make a note of these thoughts, and come back to paying full attention using your five senses. Next, take a good look at the fruit. Noticing its visual qualities - color, shape, any irregularities, the stalk, surface texture. Just take it in - looking for details. Keep an eye out for any tendency to make comparisons or judge the fruit! You'd be surprised how often our mind rushes to judgements. You could try next bringing the fruit up to your ear and listening to the sound it makes when you squeeze it or tap it. What sound does a fruit make? (I'll bet you never wondered that before!) Next, take a few moments to feel your fruit. Noticing how it feels. Is it smooth? Is it rough? Bring the practice to a close when you are ready. When you are finished, it's good to reflect on the exercise... what did you notice? Was anything surprising? Where did your mind go? What do you miss when you are on autopilot? How might the skill of mindfulness and observing be helpful to you in your daily life? Under what circumstances might you use this skill?
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Group Therapy/Managing Your Mental Health/Observing a Piece of Fruit.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Therapist Activities
item.description: At the conclusion of this exercise, ask students what they learned from it. The usual comment is that students are not aware that so many share the same experiences. Repression Emotional Alphabet Activity Identify as many emotions as possible for each letter of the alphabet. Role-Play: At the conclusion of this exercise, ask students what they learned from it. The usual comment is that students are not aware that so many share the same experiences. Have clients select feeling words or emotion cards and act out that card. Have clients select feeling words and role play when they felt this way. Collage Cut out pictures that relate to emotions. Find as many emotions as possible. Label the emotion. Feelings Charades Write different emotions on cards, clients draw a card to select an emotion. They then act out the emotion without using any words. The other clients guess the emotion based on the client's facial expressions and other non-verbal clues/cues.

item.title: Group Check-In Sheet
item.description: Problem Worsened Problem Same Problem Improved Problem Much Improved Goal Achieved I will identify triggers to mental health symptoms at least 1 x per week (i.e., anxiety, depression, poor self-image). I will develop and practice using coping skills (e.g., mindfulness, wise mind, practicing acceptance, distraction, sensory self-soothing, progressive muscle relacation, check the facts, opposite action, affirmations, etc.) to reduce mental health symptoms at least 1 x per week. How have you worked on any of your goals and/or mental health since last group? What are two things you have done well since last group? What do you need to work on by next group?

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cross the Line Activity
item.description: This activity is to help identify the similarities and differences we may have. We want to honor and acknowledge those differences but also brings to the surface other differences that we may not have recognized. This process might prove difficult or awkward. This is about getting to know each other and breaking down stereotypes. You can choose if and how you participate. This acticity is simple. Each one of us will read a statement. If the statement is something you have experienced, you cross the line. We will then reset and read the next statement. This exercise has to be done in complete silence. The purpose of this exercise is to help students become more aware of the many types of diversity that exist and to find students who share the same experiences. For this exercise, students form a line across the classroom. Students are asked to step forward and then back into the line based on questions asked by the instructor. Start with questions that are non-threatening to get students comfortable with the exercise. Students can choose to ‚Äúpass‚Äù if they want. Vary the questions to suit your group of students. Listening: Let‚Äôs have silence throughout the exercise ‚Äì no talking, snickering, giggling, etc. Silence will allow all of us to participate fully. Silence will also enable us to experience our personal thoughts and feelings more deeply. Respect: It is imperative that we respect the dignity of each person who is here. Everything that is shared should remain confidential. Nothing that is offered should leave this room. Each statement will require you to make the decision crossing the line or not crossing the line. There are no right or wrong answers. NO PRESSURE. No one here is under any pressure to respond in any particular way to any of the questions. If you have any doubts about sharing some part of yourself, you should feel perfectly comfortable with your decision not to step forward. What kind of feelings did you have as you participated? How did you feel when there were fewer of you on one side of the room? How did the movement of others influence you? What did you learn through this activity that can make our group more welcoming. Walk across the line if your favorite color is blue. Look into the eyes of those you brought with you. Look at those you left behind. Allow yourself to feel whatever you are feeling. Walk back across the line. Questions: You prefer the city. You have visited another country. You have never flown. You know very little about your cultural heritage. You are the oldest in your family. You have lost someone you loved. You are from Ohio. You enjoy sports. You are an only child. You got picked on in school. Your parents divorced. You consider yourself a religious person. You prefer Coke to Pepsi. You prefer vanilla to chocolate. You have been in love You have had surgery. You have lived in another state. You know someone who has been sexually assaulted. You have felt alone, unwelcomed, afraid. You knew someone who has attempted to die by suicide. You have cried at least once this year for someone or something other than yourself. You or someone you know is gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender. You have been a bystander to a racial, sexual, or cultural joke. You have read Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech. You did not cross the line in a previous statement when you should have. You are willing to understand, support, and celebrate diversity. If you have not crossed the line during this activity, cross it now. Here are some additional questions: Walk across the line if you have ever experienced a bad hair day. Walk across the line if you are undecided about your major. Walk across the line if your parents are divorced. Walk across the line if you or someone you care about is in a gang. Walk across the line if you or someone you care about lives in poverty. Walk across the line if you or someone you care about has been homeless. Walk across the line if you have been told or think you are fat. Walk across the line if someone you care about has been abused physically, psychologically, or sexually. Walk across the line if you or someone you care about is dependent on alcohol or drugs. Walk across the line if you know someone who is gay, lesbian, or bisexual. Walk across the line if you know someone who is HIV positive or has AIDS. Walk across the line if you have been put down by someone else and it hurt you. Walk across the line if you put someone down and you knew it hurt them. At the conclusion of this exercise, ask students what they learned from it. The usual comment is that students are not aware that so many share the same experiences.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Group Therapy/Managing Your Mental Health/Group Therapy Facilitation/Cross the Line Activity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Check-Ins & Feedback
item.description: Ho was the last week? Highs? Lows? Accomplishments? Stressors? Triggers: What emotional states have you experienced? What situations did you encounter that were difficult? How did you handle triggers? Address any significant changes in your life including in your living environment, employment, relationships, etc. Is there anything you would like to focus on today in group? Any questions or personal situations you would like to discuss with the group. It helps to talk about the things your group members are doing well first. Start with the positive before providing more challenging feedback. Empathy statements are helpful. Put yourself in the other person's shoes. Self-relating statements are also beneficial. Explain how you have had similar thoughts, feelings, or experiences. Some suggestions for how to start feedback include: "I really thought you did a good job talking about..." "What was it like to share that with the group?" "What do you think about..." "I would have liked to have seen..."
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Group Therapy/Managing Your Mental Health/Group Therapy Facilitation/Check-Ins & Feedback.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Emotions Activities
item.description: What is your current emotional state? Do Frank Weber's emotions assignment. Color in the amount of each feeling inside you in this moment. Explain why you have that level of the emotion Emotional Alphabet Activity Identify as many emotions as possible for each letter of the alphabet. Role-Play In groups of two, they are to create a scenario based on an emotion and role-play it for the group. They cannot actually state the emotion, or describe it in detail, but rather show the situation that elicits that emotion. The other group has to guess the emotion being displayed and explain how they saw that emotion (verbals and non-verbals) Have clients select feeling words or emotion cards and act out that card. Have clients select feeling words and roleplay when they felt this way. Collage Cut out pictures that relate to emotions. Find as many emotions as possible. Label the emotion. Feelings Charades Write different emotions on cards, clients draw a card to select an emotion. She then acts out the emotion without using any words. The other clients guess the emotion based on the client's facial expressions and other non-verbal clues/cues.
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Group Therapy/Managing Your Mental Health/Emotion Regulation/Emotions Activities.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Emotional Awareness Lesson Plan
item.description: Identified the purpose of emotions and defined emotions in actions. The skills introduced today included, 'Check the Facts,' 'Opposite Action,' and 'Problem Solving.' Facilitated today's interactive exercises: Collage of Emotions Emotional Charades Role-Play Homework: Complete either: Emotion Diary Emotion Regulation Practice Sheet

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
Check-Ins Highs, lows, updates, stressors, use of skills? What do you need from the group? Process reactions to last week's start of group, check-in around how they are feeling today, any barriers to getting here? Review Treatment Plan Goals Complete Goals of Skills Training - General Handout 1 What are the client‚Äôs personal goals of behaviors to decrease?  What are the client‚Äôs personal goals of skills to increase?  Administer the Weekly Progress Check-In Sheet (see sheet below)  Review last week‚Äôs skill of ‚ÄúMindfulness‚Äù   Did anyone practice it? Was it helpful? If so, how? If not, what got in the way?  As we move into today‚Äôs group and the introduction of new skills, here is some ‚Äúfood for thought‚Äù from Linehan:   ‚ÄúThis book is dedicated to all the clients of the world who think that no one is thinking of them. I considered telling you that I would practice skills for you, so you don‚Äôt have to practice them. But then I realized that if I did, you would not learn how to be skillful yourself. So, instead, I wish you skillful means, and I wish that you find these skills useful.‚Äù  Facilitate Mindfulness Guessing Item Activity: Start by educating on mindfulness (observing, describing, participating, being non-judgmental, one-mindful, and effective). Explore how these aspects of mindfulness will be integrated into the activity. Put items into a bag. Go around the room, everyone closes their eyes except the describer. The describer describes the item you gave them starting with broad descriptions and moving into more specifics. I usually write on the board types of descriptions in case the person gets stuck such as the shape, purpose, feel, color, weight, size, texture, smell, taste, etc. As the describer begins describing the object, the rest of the group begins guessing what it is, until some gets it right.   Facilitate Wise Mind Activity:  Provide psychoeducation regarding what is emotion mind, rational mind, and wise mind.  Invite clients to draw what it looks like for you to be in rational mind, emotional mind, and wise mind.   Optional Wise Mind Activity: [SKIP]  Chain of commitments to wise mind: cut slips of paper, write or draw descriptions of wise mind, hand the chains in your room.   Facilitate Practicing Acceptance Exercise:  Ask group members to identify one thing in their life right now that they know they need to accept. They can take a moment to identify that thing, write it down, and maybe even describe why they belief they need to accept it. Then they rate their level of acceptance on a scale from 0 to 10 (0 being no acceptance and 10 being full acceptance ‚Äì if they have written it down, they are beyond a 0 which is positive).   View Linehan introducing ‚ÄúPracticing Radical Acceptance‚Äù  https://youtu.be/OTG7YEWkJFI  Provide psychoeducation regarding practicing acceptance.  Introduce worksheets.  Facilitate Practicing Acceptance Exercise: [SKIP]  Defining Myself Circle: Draw a large circle on a piece of paper. Ask clients to write or draw words that describe the ideal them inside the circle. Everything they are willing to accept about themselves. Outside of the circle draw what others have said about them that they do not believe to be true, the things they will not accept because it is not them.   Reminder that there are two broad types of skills ‚Äì practicing acceptance skills (for the things we cannot change) and change skills  ACCEPTANCE SKILLS: Mindfulness, Distress Tolerance  CHANGE SKILLS: Emotion Regulation, Interpersonal Effectiveness  ACCEPTANCE + CHANGE  WRAP UP, REACTIONS, AND TAKE AWAYS  Process reactions to participating in group  What was today like for you?  Was anything surprising or new for you?  What are you taking away?  Videos 
https://youtu.be/OTG7YEWkJFI 
https://youtu.be/rU7Knx3VByA  ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt teach something you don‚Äôt know yourself‚Äù  Skill = changing behavior
item.guid: Clinic Resources/Group Therapy/Managing Your Mental Health/Curriculum/Week 2.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Week 1
item.description:
Assist clients in completing all outstanding paperwork Administer symptom checklist Review informed consent Review treatment agreement Confidentiality What is said in group stays in group, unless you said it. Can talk about your own stuff in group, but no one else and no names. Mandated reporting Any additional suggested rules from the group? Create name tags with pronouns Facilitate introductions Name, employment/school status, current living situation, a funny fact, something they do well, and something they do for fun. Introduce ourselves Facilitate the Cross the Line Activity What kind of feelings did you have as you participated? How did you feel when there were fewer of you on one side of the room? How did the movement of others influence you? What did you learn through this activity that can make our group more welcoming? Explore and Process What is mental health? Why does mental health matter? What brings you to the group? What are you hoping to get out of the group?
Mindfulness - Observing a Piece of Fruit Mindfulness of Taste Explore how and when this skill might be helpgul outside of group. Explore past experiences in therapy, specifically group therapy. Process reactions to participating in the group. What was today like for you? Was anything surprising or new for you? What are you taking away?
DBT Mindfulness Skills | MARSHA LINEHAN - YouTube
Mindfulness of Current Emotion - Marsha on Vimeo NAME was present for the Managing Your Mental Health Group today. An introduction to the Managing Your Mental Health group was provided. Intake paperwork was reviewed including the informed consent, confidentiality, mandated reporting, and the group therapy treatment agreement. Assessed symptoms (frequency, intensity, duration). Clients introduced themselves by stating their name, employment/school status, current living situation, a funny fact, something they do well, and something they do for fun. The psychoeducational topic today was mindfulness. Mindfulness was defined as a state of awareness, attention, and intention. Clients were encouraged to pay attention to the present moment without judgment. Mindfulness skills were reviewed including observing, describing, participating, non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, and effectively. Mindfulness exercises were facilitated to allow clients to practice the skills including ‚ÄúMindfulness of Fruit‚Äù and ‚ÄúMindfulness of Taste." Reinforced appropriate participation and provision of feedback. Normalized the difficulty of practicing mindfulness. Affirmed clients for identifying how the skill of mindfulness could be useful outside of group.   NAME displayed adequate progress throughout today‚Äôs group. They were engaged and participated appropriately. They appeared receptive to today‚Äôs mindfulness skill practice. They demonstrated an understanding of the concept and participated spontaneously without prompting.
